This is actually a pretty hard question to answer so I'll break it down, how I would approach it.
 
Fundamentally the major leg lifts at the gym should be at a minimum a hip hinge (hip dominent movement, the equivalent of an upper body pull) and a knee break (knee dominent movement, essentially the equivalent of a lower body push).
 
However, training just a deadlift and a back squat all the time would likely only amount to a certain level of proficiency without the influence of:
 
Exercise Variation
Intensity Changes
Volume Changes
Rest Changes
Multi-Planar Adaptation
Mechanical Loading Changes
Threshold Considerations
Range of Motion Considerations
Addressing Weaknesses - Continuous Improvement
1 - Exercise Variation
 
I generally switch up exercise variation on a phase by phase basis (a phase typically lasts anywhere from 3-6 weeks, but I've utilized as short as 1 or 2 weeks for what's called a weekly undulating periodization program but that's a little advanced for this answer...).
 
For example:
 
Phase 1:
 
Sumo Deadlift with a Bulgarian Split Squat (instead of a Back Squat)
 
Phase 2:
 
Conventional Deadlift with a Zercher Squat
 
2 - Intensity Changes
 
Typically people build a base, then focus on hypertrophy, then strength, then power, but you don't have to build phases like that, and in fact I typically don't unless someone is building towards some kind of competition.
 
What is important is that the intensity changes during certain phases depending on the programming scheme you want to use.
 
For example:
 
Phase 1 - Emphasis on 8-12 reps
 
Phase 2 - Emphasis on 5-8 reps
 
That's a very basic example but intensity considerations often have a huge impact on performance here.
 
3 - Volume Changes
 
Too much volume (or intensity) all the time and you'll burn yourself out. Psychologist's call these people, 'Over-Motivated Underachievers' because they work hard (a prized cultural skill) but don't necessarily get anywhere because the body just can't handle high amounts of stress for long periods of time.
 
This is why phases are essential, your body needs rest to adapt.
 
Generally speaking most people can't tolerate high volume and high intensity at the same time (intensity is how high the percentage of 1RM any lifts are...1RM or above is the highest intensity), so you must balance the two. 
 
This could be as simple as alternating between intensification phase and an accumulation phase (i.e. one phase is intense, low volume, high load - the other is volume oriented, lower intensity, higher volume, medium to low load).
 
It can be as complex as undulating sequences too, there are many components to neuromuscular training.
 
Down weeks are also crucial here if you have high intensity or high volume training phases, allowing for supercompensation to take place is essential.
 
Work + Rest = Success
 
4 - Rest Changes
 
The less rest you give yourself between sets, between exercises, between training days and between training cycles, the harder it is on your system.
 
The more intense a workout, the more rest you need between sets and possibly workouts/phases.
 
The more volume in a workout, the more rest you need between workouts.
 
Manipulate rest to longer when you need it, and shorter when you want to challenge your nervous system in a new way.
 
Again - in phases.
 
5 - Multi-Planar Adaptation
 
The problem with simplifying leg training to two major lifts is that these lifts often only address one plane of movement, forward and back (Sagital Plane it's called). 
 
Your muscles are 3-D, meaning you had better include some exercises eventually somewhere that require you to move laterally (i.e. Side Lunges, Lateral Sled Pushing, Shuffling, etc...) and rotationally (the transverse plane includes movements like chops, lifts, throwing, etc...).
 
Scientifically speaking, the body is capable of generating more power when engaged through all three planes (think of the amount of watts generated throwing a baseball or a shotput, it's significantly more than even a world-class squat or deadlift). 
 
Don't forget also to train unilaterally (one leg, like single leg squats, step-ups, lunges, etc...) as this forces the body into multiple planes of resistance.
 
You're leaving a lot of muscle untouched by training just two movements, or by using the majority of machines, and you're not refining your nervous system optimally.
 
i.e. Single Leg, Single Arm Deadlifts challenge the body in all three planes. So would rotational rows, and standing position chops and lifts, among many others.
 
So would the majority of throwing activities, hitting activities, kicking (though more of the angular type found in soccer), etc... 
 
I'm not saying you should load patterns similar to your sport (you shouldn't, it's actually been shown to alter movement patterns to a point of decreased performance) but you should get out of the Saggital plane with your training from time to time and challenge your muscles as they are intended to be used, in 3-D).
 
There are a lot of good lifts at the gym that people either don't use correctly, or simply don't know.
 
6 - Mechanical Loading Changes
 
Are you lifting in your barefeet or in shoes, because the difference can matter to how your body responds. Barefoot will tax your feet/toes more than in shoes.
 
There are other considerations though, the overhead squat is significantly harder than a front or back squat because the mechanical advantage in the lift is reduced by the placement of the load above the head.
 
Putting a dumbbell on one side only, taxes your body and your nervous system differently.
 
Putting a dumbbell on the shoulders instead of the hands.
 
A barbell instead of a dumbbell.
 
Changing the angle of pull (wide stance, vs narrow stance) will change the outcome.
 
7 - Threshold Considerations
 
Training the squat and deadlift all the time will train a lot of muscle, but it won't train the nervous system to respond to low threshold situations.
 
Your nervous system is tuned to relax and contract at varying levels of intensity, so if low levels of intensity are out of whack (things like breathing, spinal segmental stabilization, etc...) your ability to fully engage at high nervous system thresholds is diminished.
 
So nervous system training kind of resembles a sliding scale from low to high threshold activities.
 
It seems a little on the 'girly' side (
for most men - while most women avoid the high threshold stuff
) sometimes, but it's the smart way to train.
 
Ensure that your body can tolerate body weight squats just as well as loaded squats. Basic glute bridges, just as well as heavy deadlifts.
 
These low threshold exercises are great for warm-ups.
 
i.e. clamshells, quadruped lifts, plank variations, deadbugs, etc...
 
8 - Range of Motion Considerations
 
A quarter squat isn't the same as a full squat. The glutes and hamstrings are far more engaged in the latter.
 
Mobility training is important, and I generally encourage people to move through 'as full a range of motion as possible' when I'm coaching people. 
 
Work to improve your range of motion appropriately through all the major lifts, it will help a lot in your development at the gym.
 
However, shortening up the range of motion can occasionally lead to break-throughs, and has it's place.
 
i.e. you get stuck at the same spot on your bench press all the time, we can increase your strength at that point but employing a board press where you get stuck.
 
9 - Addressing Weaknesses
 
You could squat and deadlift and hit a lot of muscle, but you'll plateau eventually.
 
At that point you'll want to start using accessory movements to push through them.
 
If hamstrings are the weak link then maybe we want to address them a little more intensely with romanian deadlifts or single leg romanian deadlifts, or glute ham raises?
 
If the glutes are the weak link, maybe we want to do some pull-throughs, or some loaded hip thrusts.
 
If the calves are a weak link, maybe we want to do some calf raises seated or standing, or some explosive jump training (which always lights my calves up...).
 
Ultimately, I'm missing some considerations for sure but the leg does the following movements worth training at some point:
 
Circumduct the Ankle (rotation at the ankle)
Supination and Pronation of the Ankle (Roll the foot inward and outward)
Plantar Flex the Ankle (push foot down)
Dorsi Flex the Ankle (pull foot up)
Extension/Flexion of Foot + Toes
Feet Assist in Stabilizing the Ankle and Knee
Flex and Extend the Knee
Stabilize the Knee
Externally and Internally Rotate the Hip
Flex and Extend the Hip
ADDuct and ABduct the Hip
Stabilize the Hip
Combinations of all the above (the most likely and obvious training choices are ones that put your body through more than one of the movements above...)
Good luck and enjoy yourself!

title: Is a morning gym workout better than an evening gym workout?
article:
Nope. 
 
tldr; 
 
Neither is really better or worse overall if you can't stick with it. 
 
The best time to workout is entirely up to what works for you. Pick a time that you can do the most consistently, then worry about 'optimizing' if at all.
I'm going to address a few fallacies I've skimmed over so far, then I'll get to the meat of my answer in terms of what really matters.
 
1 - Working out doesn't 'jump-start' your metabolism. Exercise certainly 
adds
 
additional energy output
 as it relates to metabolism (See: 
What are the best ways to recover or improve my metabolism?
) but that doesn't mean 'jumpstart
Continue Reading
Nope. 
 
tldr; 
 
Neither is really better or worse overall if you can't stick with it. 
 
The best time to workout is entirely up to what works for you. Pick a time that you can do the most consistently, then worry about 'optimizing' if at all.
I'm going to address a few fallacies I've skimmed over so far, then I'll get to the meat of my answer in terms of what really matters.
 
1 - Working out doesn't 'jump-start' your metabolism. Exercise certainly 
adds
 
additional energy output
 as it relates to metabolism (See: 
What are the best ways to recover or improve my metabolism?
) but that doesn't mean 'jumpstart.' Being awake in the first place burns more energy, eating a meal burns energy, but they don't 'jumpstart' metabolism either. They just contribute to daily energy expenditure.
 
The same amount and type of exercise done at a different part of the day will essentially have the same effect on your metabolism overall.
 
It does generally improve mood and energy though. Especially at moderate intensities (aerobic exercise for instance).
 
2 - Not everybody 'feels' energized 
all day
 from exercising in the morning (
I certainly don't
), the boost it provides to energy/mood is usually only as short as a few hours. It also takes roughly 3 hours for body temperature to increase to highly functioning levels anyway, so you might get an endorphin boost until temperature levels hit peak, that carries you through to the early afternoon (
so a good portion of the day
) but most people will still experience a lull in early afternoon (1-2 PM-ish), despite exercising in the morning. 
 
You might actually do better exercising just before lull that to reduce it's impact. And for other reasons I'll get to below...
 
3 - Exercise does increase memory retention and cognitive function, but these benefits are not limited to a window of 4-10 hours. Exercising in the morning doesn't increase this benefit according to any research I'm familiar with. Furthermore, you wouldn't be wasting those benefits even if there was such a window as most long-term memory retention and cognitive improvement benefits happen during sleep. 
 
Read 
Spark: The Revolutionary New Science of Exercise and the Brain
, but I don't remember it indicating such a window, nor any of the research I read following it up; If anything, closer to exercise would still be better for the several studies done on how subjects perform better on tests done very soon after exercise. The effects on the brain overall however, appear to stick quite well no matter the time.
 
4 - If you work early in the morning, then it might absolutely be a problem to get up 30-60 minutes before that. I used to start my work day at 6 AM, up at five, technically when I should be in my deepest sleep, now I'm supposed to get up 30-60 before that? So 4-4:30...which means getting to bed at 8-8:30 PM to get eight hours of sleep, which is generally just after when circadian rhythm makes most people the most alert. 
 
For anyone other than true larks (small percentage of the population), this is a very daunting task. Sure if you start your work day at 9 AM, getting up at 7 to do a quick workout before work might not be so tough and it might often be better for a lot of folks to get it out of the way before their day gets away from them. Mental fatigue from many decisions throughout the day can make it tough to get to the gym after work for A LOT of people, if it isn't already a routine.
 
However, all of this doesn't make it the best or worst time to train, it totally depends on you the person. Your existing routines, your natural circadian rhythm bias (some are larks, some are night owls, most are in between), your work schedule, your family schedule, etc...etc...
For more details on how to discover something that works for you then I highly recommend you read these (disclaimer: My Blog...):
 
Help! When Should I Train? (Part I) - Skill Based Fitness
 
 
Help! When Should I Train? (Part II) - Skill Based Fitness
 
First, generally speaking consistency matters more than anything else. So if you can make yourself more consistent by getting up in the morning and get it out of the way, then sure that would make working out in the morning better...
for you...
 
This still wouldn't make it better for everyone else.
 
That's first and foremost the most important thing; Training at a time that works for you.
 
It is easier for a lot of people to skip workouts later in the day and so working out in the morning does often work very well for a lot of people, 
but physiologically that doesn't make it ideal. 
And it doesn't have to be
 immediately
 upon waking either, just enough time to get it done before you get into a lot of cognitive loading work that might later hinder your ability to desire to go to the gym in the first place. It's the same reason productivity gurus tell you to get your most cognitive tasks out of the way early in the day. 
 
Actually there may actually be some inherent risks to training within the first 3 hours of waking, particularly if you are say lifting weight or doing explosive work. Less so for endurance/aerobic training.
 
From sleeping all night (horizontal position), the fluid in your spine actually displaces, slightly destabilizing your spine for the first part of the day. This might be associated with injury potential (at least for heavily loaded movements involving the spine). Not only that but nervous system function, muscular blood flow, glucose metabolism and joint mobility at this time of day aren't really that conducive to training.  All of them are limited first in the morning, which is why most world records in sports are not broken first thing in the morning, they are generally broken in early evening.
 
You'd be hard pressed to find many strength or power athletes that successfully do the bulk of their training early in the morning (
some will start at 10-11 AM
). There may be some early morning skates, serving practice or shooting practice, but these are usually low intensity and/or optimized to suit the schedules of student-athletes and break up the training day (
for twice-a-day training purposes
).
 
This generally doesn't apply as heavily to the endurance athletes, who often have early start times to deal with mid-afternoon heat, but they would probably still perform better if it was done in the early evening (
it would just be hotter out still in many climates
). 
 
Again schedules optimized to the person and the objective, not necessarily the physiological optimized times.
 
A physiologically optimized (i.e. derive the most benefit from for performance purposes and anabolism) training window for most people (
depending on their circadian rhythm
) is probably anywhere from about 2:30-3 PM in the afternoon (
just after your circadian dip
) to about 6:30-7 PM at night. 
 
Yes peak circadian rhythm in most people is closer to 8, which is when you might be inclined or think to be ideal. However, training late generally makes it difficult to fall asleep for 2-3 hours post-workout due to hormone fluctuations, so the later in the day you push it the longer you might end staying up. I used to have volleyball practice from 9-11PM in school, and I could never fall asleep before 1AM as a result, which wrecked havoc on my school schedule.
 
Again, here 
I am
 speaking from a fairly pure physiological point of view, if you can't do that, or it impedes you from actually training, you're better off doing what makes you the most consistent. The differences are probably physiologically negligible (I'm throwing out a guess of less than 10-15% difference) long-term, except training first thing in the morning is actually pretty terrible for performance purposes (
which isn't necessarily the same as training...
). It would also probably increase training injury risk slightly for weight training/explosive training. 
 
It would on the other hand make sense if you competed early in the morning, to move your training to early in the morning to acclimatize for your performances.
 
Typically if performance is required or the intensity of training is high, wait at least 3 hours, and maybe even preferably six if you can. If it's just aerobic exercise, endurance, then do it whenever is convenient.
 
There are other influencers too. For instance if you have a high stress, high cognitive load job (lawyer, doctor, entrepreneur, technician, engineer, etc...) then you might be more likely to skip training the later in the day you leave it. If you have a lower cognitive load job (autopilot repetitive tasks, manual labour, factory work, etc...) then you might have the mental reserve to better tolerate training later in the day.
 
Ultimately, the best time to work out during the day depends on you.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
I’m giving the same answer here I would if the question were simply asking about the most “ignorant person” I met, regardless of nationality. This person would have to be my second cousin who just so happens to be American. Over the years she has provided me with ample material to supply a ready answer any time I’m asked about the most insanely inane and extraordinarily moronic things I’ve ever heard in life. I spent three weeks traveling around the Pacific Rim in 2006 and China was one of several counties I visited. While talking with this second cousin of mine shortly after the trip I was ca
Continue Reading
I’m giving the same answer here I would if the question were simply asking about the most “ignorant person” I met, regardless of nationality. This person would have to be my second cousin who just so happens to be American. Over the years she has provided me with ample material to supply a ready answer any time I’m asked about the most insanely inane and extraordinarily moronic things I’ve ever heard in life. I spent three weeks traveling around the Pacific Rim in 2006 and China was one of several counties I visited. While talking with this second cousin of mine shortly after the trip I was casually mentioning something about my time in Beijing that somehow (I don’t remember the exact detail) alluded to the fact I had breakfast at the hotel where I was staying, at which point she had to stop to interrupt me with her astonished (and astonishing) remark. Mind you, I’m not describing the reaction of a child, but the reaction of an adult. An adult who certainly never traveled beyond her own borders, but an adult homo sapien, all the same. She was so astonished to find out that people eat breakfast in China… As in— she was astonished, as in— she found it hard to believe that the concept of ‘breakfast,’ having a meal in the morning hours that is actually part of a routine and actually gets an official title for it as the equivalent of “breakfast.”
 
Let’s stop for a moment to consider this mindset— and while meaning no cruelty or disdain for this mindset, I am okay having a little bit of fun with it.
 
You mean to inform me that breakfast exists in China? As in that super-far-away country with well over a billion people and one of the oldest civilizations in world history dating back to the Shang Dynasty around 1600 BC— they got breakfast over there, for real? No way!!! The same people who created the Great Wall and the Terra Cotta warriors, who gave us the I Ching, Taoism, acupuncture, not to mention all the tea— they were ingenious enough to conceive of having something like lunch or dinner in the morning time, like a whole meal to start the day? Like they really have breakfast, the real thing, not something just kind of similar? Are they just copying us? Is breakfast just another American implant over there like the Disneylands in Shanghai and Hong Kong? Or did these folks really come up with such a thing on their own? You mean to tell me the people who invented paper, silk, gunpowder, printing, the compass, the kite, the umbrella, and all that other stuff were actually sophisticated enough to think that having something like an ordinary meal in the morning made sense? How weird that people all over the world could seriously think of doing the same thing before noon that would involve food— and not just once as a fluke— but EVERY DAY. Wow. How do these things happen? Very interesting coincidence.
 
I can only hope that maybe I was more astonished by her than she was by that. But I guess that wouldn’t be all too redeeming either…
 
Like wow, you mean we don’t just do that over here??? People consume morning meals in other places around this strange world? Do they sleep and go to the bathroom too? What about the birds and the bees on that side of the world? Is it actually the stork for real over there who brings the babies or do those foreign people get to make them babies the same way as us folks over here?
 
I could also mention that this same second cousin has said many other things to me that were spectacular in their own way and have left me stunned speechless in quite different scenarios yet similar outrageously vacuous terms. After divorcing her first husband and telling me about what happened, she explained to me that what really messed up their marriage of less than 2 years was her mother coming home to find my second cousin’s husband having sex with another woman. She made sure to clarify for me that with all the shock involved about this scandalous display of infidelity discovered in flagrante delicto was simply a bridge too far. You see the problem here for her wasn’t the fact that her husband was cheating on her. No, no. It was perfectly fine if he cheated on her anywhere else in the universe indoors outdoors upstairs downstairs in public or private with or without consent with a thousand different women from every country on earth so long as he didn’t do it somewhere her mother would see it, somewhere like her home. So the divorce sounded more like Mom’s friendly suggestion than her own idea. My cousin told me the guy she married was always cheating on her, but that alone wasn’t a sufficient reason to divorce him. Who would be so shallow to even think of such a thing? For such a minor offense, really. Sounds a bit like overreacting. Cheating couldn’t be anything more than like a misdemeanor in the marriage world, right? Now something like forgetting an anniversary might be a felony, but cheating? Divorcing someone over some kind of infidelity would be just like giving the death penalty to someone for j-walking.
 
She said while a lot of people had even gone so far as to suggest something like she should divorce the guy for being a habitual, unhindered, remorseless cheater, she didn’t see it this way from her enlightened perspective. I recall how she capped this off by saying, ever so glibly and almost in a huffy sort of way, without a whiff of reflection or even the faintest iota of critical thinking that could, you know, maybe randomly occur by accident: “Oh no, you don’t leave someone for cheating. You just work through it.”
 
Right. It sounds like a small communication error after all, and can be fixed rather speedily. Maybe just start talking a little bit more between each of his short and maybe often extensive outings (vacations, cruises, Sunset Blvd, maybe a few Turkish style harems including sex sprees with his worldwide sprawl of liaisons).
 
In all seriousness, though, there does seem to be a somewhat intriguing rationale worth considering here. Nothing wrong with my cousin to be able to look at the bigger picture. Maybe if the person caused a genocide, divorce would be justifiable. Compared to that, infidelity seems a bit trivial. I mean, look at this way, as some mother might put it in her sage advice, or better yet, a Solomonic marriage counselor: “Yeah you’re married to a chronic cheater— but at least he isn’t Hitler or Stalin. He wants sex with more people in his life, but does that really make him such a bad guy? Look on the bright side, he’s not wanting to exterminate an entire ethnic group!”
 
This same second cousin also happened to make another noteworthy utterance the day of my grandfather/ her great-grandfather’s funeral. It was especially noteworthy because she said this to me that day and neither of us were actually at the funeral (which was out of state and I was unable to attend for various reasons) but actually just ran into each other by chance in the parking lot of the mall. I thought it was odd enough that the day of my grandfather’s funeral, when I felt sad about not being at the funeral where my parents and many extended family members were, I just happened to see a relative of mine from the same side of the family at the mall. Well, my second cousin had her own way of making this slightly, yet unforgettably odder. Naturally, seeing as how we just randomly ran into one another and it was the day of our grand/great grandfather’s funeral, that was immediately brought up… I think I just said something like, “Crazy about grandpa huh?”
 
She started off with, “Yeah, how do you feel about what’s happened with grandpa?”
 
At which point I said something, which I’m sure would be just about the same kind of answer as anyone would give about how they feel losing one of their grandparents… I could’ve messed with her and said, “Oh I feel great. Dead grandfather. It’s wonderful!” But no, I wasn’t in the humorous mood and said something sincere, like, “Oh yeah, really sad.”
 
But it was her response to this that really took me by surprise, when she said, “I hear he’s getting better.”
 
I was too dumbfounded with disbelief to come up with any notable response. I think I just said matter-of-factly, “His funeral is today.”
 
In retrospect, a better (or funnier and more sardonic) response to say I gave would’ve been something like: “Really? You hear he’s getting better? Interesting. Cuz I was told he died and that the funeral is actually being held today and that my parents are actually up there attending it as we speak… Maybe I should call them and double-check. You never know, it’s possible someone lied about this.”

title: What is the best workout routine to follow?
article:
I train 7 days a week.
 
People tend to assume I’m very motivated.
 
I am—and I can not stress this enough—
not.
 
So you must be really disciplined then?
 
No, I’m not that either.
 
I’m a lazy sack of undisciplined shit.
 
But, I’m also a proactive lazy sack of undisciplined shit.
 
To illustrate, I want to tell you about one thing I’ve never been good at. Because frankly, writing some long ass answer hailing myself and my good habits is just too awkward for my taste.
 
I’ve always been bad at flossing.
DENTAL flossing.
That’s more like it.
 
I’ve tried creating a steady flossing habit for what feels like my whole life.
 
I
Continue Reading
I train 7 days a week.
 
People tend to assume I’m very motivated.
 
I am—and I can not stress this enough—
not.
 
So you must be really disciplined then?
 
No, I’m not that either.
 
I’m a lazy sack of undisciplined shit.
 
But, I’m also a proactive lazy sack of undisciplined shit.
 
To illustrate, I want to tell you about one thing I’ve never been good at. Because frankly, writing some long ass answer hailing myself and my good habits is just too awkward for my taste.
 
I’ve always been bad at flossing.
DENTAL flossing.
That’s more like it.
 
I’ve tried creating a steady flossing habit for what feels like my whole life.
 
I often manage to get started too, but somehow, my routine always falls off a cliff. I’m going at it, gaining steam for a couple weeks, and then”
poof,” 
my momentum stops, dead in its tracks.
 
Just like with you and training, I know flossing is good for me. I’ve seen horrific pictures of rotten, brown teeth and they scare the living shit out of me. I’m definitely motivated to floss.
 
What makes my failures even stupider is that flossing takes little to no time and doesn’t require anything but the smallest amount of effort. I don’t even have to leave the house—I’ve had the same damn flossers in my bathroom cabinet since the Mongols laid waste to all of Eurasia.
 
I have no excuses.
 
But I can’t do it.
 
So what gives?
 
One part of creating good habits is getting the ball rolling.
 
Because healthy routines are like a ball of snow rolling down a hill, steady gaining size and speed. It’s hard to get it moving in the beginning and the longer we do something, the easier it is to keep doing it. But this, while true, is also not helpful. “Just do it” is bad advice, because 
we’re already trying to.
 
This view, of self-discipline=routines, creates a chicken-egg situation: to build healthy routines, we need self-discipline over a long period of time; but self-discipline is in itself a healthy routine, so how the flying fuck do we create that in the first place?
 
Another—often underrated—aspect of habit-creation is making the habit as 
easy to implement as possible.
 
It’s not about powering through using the self-discipline we wish we had, but creating 
an environment
 where a habit is likely to prosper.
 
I’ve been flossing every day for 4 months now.
 
I guess I deserve a medal or at least a diploma of some sort.
 
What’s crazy is how the way I finally made it stick is so stupid and simple I can’t even fathom it.
 
I put the flosser 
with
 
my toothbrush.
 
I was already brushing my teeth. I mastered that shit in kindergarten. Now, every time I do that deeply ingrained habit, I get an instant reminder to up my flossing game while I’m at it.
 
I also bought approximately a lifetime’s worth of dental floss so I always have some available.
 
Because I know, If I have to go the store to buy some, it’s not happening.
When we start doing something new and challenging, our identity and previous habits become this force of nature, pulling us back, to our previous selves.
 
Our status quo.
 
To oppose those forces, we need to create our own force field, one which pulls us toward the habits we wish to create.
 
I see too many people spend their whole existence in an epic fight to go to a dimly lit place and lift weights/and or run on a treadmill.
 
Working out shouldn’t be an epic battle.
 
Stupid as it is, we often stop doing what we achieve to do, not because we don’t want to do the core thing, but because of all the small annoyances we associate it with.
 
If you—like me—ever skipped a work-out because you lacked the proper socks, had a bad hair-day or because it was raining and fuck if you’re going out in the rain, you know this all too well.
 
We should aim to minimise the friction and pain associated with creating a habit and maximise the friction and pain associated with not creating it.
 
We should strive to make training as tempting as possible, while avoiding it should be hard and painful.
 
I floss, not because of my super-saiyan willpower, but because I’ve minimised the friction flossing creates in my life and head, while making the implementation of the habit as smooth and pain-free as possible.
 
Here are some specific examples as to how you can create an environment where the habit of exercise is likely to prosper:
Prepare the things you need beforehand.
 Have your gym bag with clean clothes, water bottle, towel, etc ready. Fill it with everything you need and put it by your door. It will serve as a constant reminder, telling you how close you are to go to the gym.
Set a fixed time.
 Ever postponed anything? Yeah, me too. So why not schedule your training? By giving giving training a specific time and place, much like a deadline, we can making procrastination an as small a factor as possible. Put that shit in your calendar if you have too—it’s what I do for my studies.
Know where you’re going to train and become familiar with the place and logistics.
 Where is the water fountain? 
Is there 
a water fountain? What equipment do they have? When is the best time to go? These logistics, while seemingly minuscule, can add up to a lot of friction and make it harder than it has to be to make this habit stick.
Have a training plan. 
There is a syndrome in the fitness industry popularly termed “fuckarounditis.” Fuckarounditis, while bad for progress, is also inherently unhelpful for making training a habit. Don’t just plan to go to the gym today. Plan to go, do X exercises for X reps/time with X goal in mind. If you’re going to the gym, with no plan and no particular goal you wish to accomplish, procrastinating on it becomes very tempting.
Set some specific short-term goals and measure your progress. 
Have something you wish to accomplish every day you’re there. Maybe it’s lifting 1 rep more than last time, running a bit longer, or something as simple as improving at a certain movement. Mastery waters and stimulates motivation while incompetence kills it. Take advantage of that
Get to know those who work there.
 You don’t have to be friends or anything, but make a bit of small talk. Say hi. Smile. Get to know the lines of their faces. A familiar smile is a lot more appealing than a strangers glance.
Make your workout part of a routine.
 A popular tip I give is to train on the way home from work or on the way to it. The road from your coach to the front door can feel longer and more daunting than a marathon on pouring rain. Going by the gym when you’re already out and about is on the other hand often as close to effortless as it gets.
Go with a friend. 
Social pressure is real. Cancelling an appointment is a lot harder than postponing a workout in your head. As a bonus, camaraderie can also make training more enjoyable. Yes, it should be enjoyable too.
If all else fails, hire a personal trainer and set up sessions several months in advance. 
In the business, we use this as a tactic because it minimises flakiness. While people may want to avoid working out, they also don’t like calling someone to cancel an appointment they’re paying for and know they should go to. You can use this too your advantage too.
Have some fun.
 The best way to keep going to the gym is to actually enjoy yourself while you’re there. Experiment a bit. Find out what part of training is the most fun or at least sucks less. Too many treat the gym as a place of suffering. Counterintuitively, this makes it harder to go than it has to be. When you find something enjoyable about it, you may even find yourself wanting to go. In the end, that’s what makes habits stick. People who wake up at 5am in the morning don’t do so because they’re running on extreme amounts of willpower, but because they, crazy as it is, actually enjoy it.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
This just happened tonight and I feel like venting it out right away. I’m on a date with a girl. We are waiting for getting the food we ordered from a food-truck in Boston Common. We both noticed that two Buddhist monks are looking at from a distance and wondering about the open air Romeo and Juliet that we are about to catch. (Aside: It’s wonderful and goes on all evenings till Aug 1st week; must see! It’s free and called Shakespeare on the Common) No, it’s not about my date; She is European and quite intelligent. Wait for the stupid American— he will make an entrance.
 
(At this point, I would 
Continue Reading
This just happened tonight and I feel like venting it out right away. I’m on a date with a girl. We are waiting for getting the food we ordered from a food-truck in Boston Common. We both noticed that two Buddhist monks are looking at from a distance and wondering about the open air Romeo and Juliet that we are about to catch. (Aside: It’s wonderful and goes on all evenings till Aug 1st week; must see! It’s free and called Shakespeare on the Common) No, it’s not about my date; She is European and quite intelligent. Wait for the stupid American— he will make an entrance.
 
(At this point, I would like to mention that I’m a skinny Indian guy out on a date with a white East European girl who has blue eyes and reddish hair. I mention this background, mainly because I think this American guy felt an itch to find out 
what’s going on… 
We actually got a few stares as we were walking around, especially a few blue eyes straining at me! 
I wonder why…! 
I am actually very pesky at this, I just look at them with my usual smile.)
 
She: Hmm.. I’m surprised. What are religious people doing here?
 
Me: Why? May be they want to see Romeo and Juliet?
 
She: Are they allowed entertainment?
 
Me: Yeah, I think so. They are Buddhist monks, I’m sure they can have a little entertainment.
 
(These two guys were wearing saffron robes, and I can see a chakra imprinted on the side of their bag or something.)
 
She: (Chuckles) May be. But they seem the very temple type!
 
[I’m the type who likes to broaden his horizon. And tries to help with other’s too. At this point, I try to show by example, that Eastern monks can be very different from the Western stereotype. That’s my style! ^_^ ]
 
Me: You know there’s a monk in India who belongs to a Hindu monastic order, but he says he is an atheist monk. And he is a well known mathematician.
 
She: What is an atheist Hindu monk?
 
Me: Among Hindus, you can be an atheist. But, I don’t understand the part of being an atheist monk. May be he follows the discipline, may be he is spiritual but not religious? I don’t know..
 
She: Hmm.. That’s very different. I didn’t know monks can be like that..
 
Random White American Guy pops into our conversation uninvited ( with wife in tow— I am not sure if she is Indian or Latino, but she is brown, not white. Let’s call him Stupid Joe) : Oh they are those scamsters! Don’t fall for those monks!
 
Me: Er… What scam are you talking about?
 
Stupid Joe: Oh those Buddhist monks! They will try to sell you some lucky charms for money! There’s a huge racket of these things!
 
Me: Er… Is it? I didn’t know about that! Thank you!
 
Stupid Joe’s Smart Wife: (Let’s call her Jane from next time!) Why do you say so? Are 
these
 monks scamsters?
 
Joe: I’m sure these are too! They are everywhere!
 
Jane: But, they don’t seem to be selling anything!
 
Joe: Oh they will once you go to them!
 
She (my date interrupts…): Oh.. actually we were talking about an atheist monk who does mathematics.
 
Joe: What is an atheist monk?
 
Me: I don’t understand well either, but that is how he describes himself.
 
Joe: There you go! Another scamster!
 
She: No, he is legit, he is a university professor!
 
Joe: 
Oh I’m sure he is! 
(stupid sarcastic tone ensues…)
 
Me: hahaha… Actually, he has a PhD from Berkeley.
 
Joe: 
PhD from where? Berklee College of Music?
 
Me: hahaha… No, from UC Berkeley. He wrote an award winning PhD thesis!
 
Joe: 
Oh I’m sure, he has many awards!
 
Me: hahaha.. If you are interested, you can look him up. His name is Mahan Mj.
 
Joe gives the most stupid ass look and rotates his head around that certain Americans give, which roughly means “Nah… I don’t buy that!”
 
At this point, I was a few seconds away from my natural reflex to such ignorant people: A small pause with quiet intent look at his eyes; a huge laugh, followed by “Are you a mathematician?” But, his wife knows how he has been making an ass of himself and this is a bit too much! She intervenes: nudges him about getting the food from the food-truck!
 
Jane: Hey, why don’t you take a look for the food? I think this one is ours!
 
Joe wants to continue this stupid conversation but gets verbally arm twisted by Jane, and stumbles to go ahead and take a look at the food truck.
 
As he goes away…
 
Jane (to me and my date): 
Don’t worry, I got you! (laughing with an embarrassed look)
 
We (Jane, my date and me) just look at each other laugh! I hope Joe is thankful to Jane, who saves the situation. He was seconds away from being humiliated. May be Joe is a nice guy, who just suffers from verbal diarrhoea at times. I don’t know. But, he does remind me one of those ignorant uncles in the family who are found in many Indian gatherings of extended families, who speak in very similar ways, and make an ass of themselves in front of everyone. I guess this was another step towards the belief: 
People are not that different after all!
 
NB: 
In case you are wondering, I was talking about Mahan Maharaj who writes as Mahan Mj. Here is his professional homepage: 
Mahan Mj
 
Honorable mentions:
 
Conversation 1:
 
Random old man in a shopping mall interrupts me.
 
He: Hey, Indian guy! Can you help me fix my computer? (with a stupid smirk in his face..)
 
Usually, I would say, very dry manner: yeah, very funny. But this time, I changed it a little.
 
Me: I don’t know how to use a computer. (deadpan poker face)
 
He: What..? Really? (eyes getting bigger)
 
Me: That’s right. I know nothing about computers. Cannot even switch them on. I’m a mathematician.
 
He: Really? (Eyes becoming so big, about to pop out of his face!)
 
Conversation 2:
 
Me: Yay! I finally got the Social Security Number!
 
American acquaintance from Math department: 
Why do you have Social Security Number! You are not a citizen! 
(sudden palpable rage in his voice)
 
Me: Dude! I need this to pay my income tax here! Everyone has it! All grad students, all people who get stipend or salary!
 
Him: Huh.. really?
 
NB: Good lord! This is a future American mathematician! He says he might want to become an investment banker. So, I was wondering, may be one day, he will be a US Secretary of the Treasury and make policies.
 
Conversation 3:
 
American trying to defend Trump’s Muslim Ban: 
But, I-Ran is a state sponsor of terrorism! 
(..rage in her voice)
 
Me: Do you know where the 9/11 terrorists came from?
 
She: I-ran?
 
Me: Nope. Saudi Arabia.
 
She: Huh… really?
 
[No wonder he still thinks Trump has a master plan how to make ‘Murica great again! Funny thing is, his mother is an immigrant. But, yeah you guessed it right, she is a European immigrant with blonde hair and blue eyes from Sweden. Makes 
sense
!]
 
NB: It sounds very stupid how Americans pronounce Iran like “I ran!”. For one last time, folks, it’s okay if you really ran, but it’s not “I ran”.
 
Conversation 4:
 
This is heard from an Indian friend who went on a first date with a White American girl.
 
She: Were you in a relationship before?
 
He: Yeah, I had a girlfriend when I was in Mumbai. But, it didn’t work out.
 
She: I’m so sorry to hear that. Why? What happened?
 
He: She was very much into partying and clubbing. It was fun for a few months at first, but after a point, I felt fatigued. I don’t like to party and go out clubbing every weekend. And she didn’t like travelling or anything else I would prefer to do on weekends. So, we grew apart gradually and this create a rift between us…
 
She: Indian girl? 
Partying? They have clubs there? [eyes bursting out…]
 
Reference:
 
What To Know About Shakespeare On The Common — And Why To Take The Kids

title: What is the best workout routine to follow?
article:
The best five tips I learnt during 15 years of weight lifting - from a female's perspective
 
My fitness journey began with enthusiasm and drive with weight loss in mind, despite not knowing what to do.
 
Like most people, as a beginner, I started in a class setting, watching the instructor and eagerly participating.

Continue Reading
The best five tips I learnt during 15 years of weight lifting - from a female's perspective
 
My fitness journey began with enthusiasm and drive with weight loss in mind, despite not knowing what to do.
 
Like most people, as a beginner, I started in a class setting, watching the instructor and eagerly participating.
 
Group classes were great for about a year or two, and I knew I wanted to increase my intensity and results. As a beginner, I had always wanted to build and maintain muscle mass. My ideal shape was athletic, strong.
 
My ideal shape was athletic & strong. I had aspired to look like this for a long time and lacked the knowledge and skills to move ahead with my plan.
 
My missing puzzle piece was training with weights. I was petrified!
 
Like most females, I had fallen back into my insecure shell. I
 
I would watch all these muscle men, with only a couple of women, 
pounding, grunting and making faces 
(Actually, I was laughing at the facial expressions!).
 It’s still painful knowing in 2021, there are only a couple of women in the weights area. It’s still a space that men dominate.
I admit, I was intimidated a lot and stuck to the usual weight bearing machines in the hope that some muscle would grow — and maybe I’d get some six-pack in the process, But that never happened, and my frustration continued to grow.
Taking matters into my own hands was essential - that's why I invested in a personal trainer. It was great, but I didn't get the results I wanted. I didn't dedicate enough time to weight training or even structure my diet correctly.
 
That all changed when I decided I wanted to body build seriously and start showing my results on stage. That’s the scary bit — having your body scrutinised by judges and the audience. I didn’t care; I knew I could build the body I wanted. It was somewhere growing inside of me, and I just needed a proper coach — and to commit.
Then and there, my weight training journey began, and it hasn’t stopped since.
Learning new things on this journey never stops. There are always pit stops and pivots during the stages of ageing and hormonal shifts. Then when you throw lockdowns in the mix, things can get pretty heated. Here's is the best of the best during my 15-year journey of bodybuilding and nutrition.
 
Use multi joining movements
.
 
(squats, lunges, deadlifts, bench pressing, pull-ups) to use the most muscle groups. These movements develop an athletic, shapely physique, burn more calories, strength and muscle mass. Using this technique every time you train will increase your results and get to your training goals faster. It has never failed me along the bodybuilding journey.
 
Don't shy away from the intense movements.
 
I see a lot of people disregarding squats, deadlifts and chin-ups. I know these are challenging, but throwing yourself into challenging movements will create successful results — and fast.
 
There are instances when your doctor doesn’t recommend a particular exercise — that’s fine.
 
But what I’d like to point out is that not using these muscle groups will produce weakness in your skeletal system, leading to problems in the future.
 
I would follow my doctor’s advice, and if I can do something, I’d start very small. As you increase the weights you lift or the intensity of bands. Your body becomes stronger and will tolerate tension and load.
 
Don’t allow injured muscles to become so weak that they no longer help you lead a normal life. Make use of what you can do to keep strong and active.
 
Nutrition is key to your success.
 
It doesn’t matter if you want to get leaner or build muscle — nutrition is your best friend. Assess your food choices, and adapt according to your needs. Those who want to lose weight will have different requirements than those who build muscle.
 
One big question I get is, "can I do both at the same time?" Well, sure you can, but one will outweigh the other. Too much cardio can lead to loss of muscle mass. Weight training more than four times a week can lead to less effective results & burnout - and worst still, injury. There needs to be a balance of both mediums.
 
How do you discover this balance? No one can tell you what works for your body better than you can. It's a matter of getting into the trenches, trying things out, experimenting and writing down your results.
 
Over time, you will discover the dos and do not’s of your body. Unfortunately, there is no easy answer for this — it takes hard work and a lot of guessing — and it keeps changing as you age.
 
Let yourself off the hook, throw perfectionism out the window, do your best, and your best is the right place to start.
 
Knowing what to do and performing it correctly are two different things.
 
Executing movements with weights is one of the main reasons why I first hired a personal trainer.
I wanted someone to tell me exactly what I should do and how to structure my posture correctly.
I tried to get specific results, and it was easy to get the skills from a person who was already way ahead in the game.
 
I applied their techniques and skills. Over time, I trained with a couple of other experts who brought even more skills for my success.
 
The easiest way to master weight training was because I asked for help. If I had done it myself, it wouldn’t have happened.
 
The journey ahead never ends
.
 
There will be endless points in your life where the journey changes.
We start to age, we change professions, have a family, experience hormonal shifts or develop an illness.
These issues can be very frustrating to anyone that has trained for many years. Things we did ten years ago don't work today.
 
But this is life telling us we need to change, alter and find a different way.
 
That could mean training a lot less, recovering more, watching your nutrition like a hawk, or trying intermittent fasting. The alternatives are endless, but start with one thing at a time and wait. Along my bodybuilding journey, I ate 5 -6 meals a day.
 
Back then, I was about 35. Now at 42, I can't handle that many meals, and I'm just not as hungry as I once was. So we just have to make do with what is presented to us right now.
 
I want to finish this off by saying that when you have a goal In mind, you will then look for the means to attract those results. I always had a set idea of what I wanted.
 
Once you've achieved your goal, moving on to something else will keep the flame of fitness alive.
 
As we grow up, we develop a love for other things. Perhaps for you, it may be pushing your body to its limit.
 
Maybe someone else might decide to take up yoga as well. The remarkable aspect of fitness, no matter what age, you can try an array of things to find out what starts to ignite an emotional trigger within you. For me, that's always been weight training.
 
There is no other form of exercise that ticks all the boxes for my needs, wants and wishes.
 
What will yours be?
 
Please also join me on my various social platforms and do go ahead and download your 
40 Fat Loss Tips & Portions guide.
 I'm also on 
Instagram
 & 
Medium

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
Back in the late 80's I took a road trip to see a famous
 faith healer 
and televangelist (I'll call him Reverend Saul David for this story.)
 
I was learning gospel stylings on the organ for theater, and this preacher-guy had one heck of a musical show to show me the ropes! Think of the 
church scene
 in the movie 
The Blues Brothers
, and you'll have a pretty good idea of the concert I attended that night! 
It rocked!
 
Amen!
 
I am not a believer in all that faith healing stuff. If you are, that's cool. I don't want to offend you, but probably will if you keep reading my answer.
 
Perhaps you should stop read
Continue Reading
Back in the late 80's I took a road trip to see a famous
 faith healer 
and televangelist (I'll call him Reverend Saul David for this story.)
 
I was learning gospel stylings on the organ for theater, and this preacher-guy had one heck of a musical show to show me the ropes! Think of the 
church scene
 in the movie 
The Blues Brothers
, and you'll have a pretty good idea of the concert I attended that night! 
It rocked!
 
Amen!
 
I am not a believer in all that faith healing stuff. If you are, that's cool. I don't want to offend you, but probably will if you keep reading my answer.
 
Perhaps you should stop reading my answer right now if you have ever:
Ordered Holy Prayer Water or similar products from a religious representative during any late-night, paid t.v. advertisement.
Sent your money to religious representatives who raise money for their ministry primarily through their television audience.
Previously been medically-proven paraplegic, had hands laid upon you, and were suddenly healed by the Holy Spirit, and were able to 
rise up
 and walk out of your chair in front of amazed congregants.
If any of these points resemble you, kindly switch over to someone else's answer, because what I am about to say may insult your core belief system. And I don't want to hurt your feelings. I respect that 
you
 believe what you believe. I just don't see eye-to-eye with you.
 
As for the rest of you who are still here, I'll get to describing the venue:
 
The Reverend had rented a large community center/gymnasium out in a rural area, beyond the subdivisions and where the busses stopped running after dark.
 
It was in Chico, California. At that time, Playboy magazine had named it college party city #1 in the USA, so I was a bit worried about how I was going to find my way back into town, in the dark, when I was at
 “ground zero”
 with all the 
freaks
 in town.
 
I entered the building. I was early, with plenty of time to kill, as I'd taken the last bus out on the route, and it was still two hours 'til “show time.”
 
I was met at a reception table
,
 and asked to fill out an information card.
 
It asked my name, address, ailments, worries, how many children I had, financial status, and basically all the information any reasonably “psychic” faith healer would need to know about a person in order to pull off a convincing show.
 
A-HA! Gotcha!
 
I got my seat assignment and sat down.
 
Front row. Next to a nice old couple. She, in a wheelchair. We had a couple hours to shoot the breeze as the room filled up.
 
Nice folks.
 
At one point she needed to use the facilities and asked that I wheel her to the Ladies Room.
 
I obliged.
 
Relieved, I watched her get up and 
walk
 out of her chair
,
 and enter the stall. At one point I worried I might have to go in there with her and help her out, but she was fine on her own.
 
She could walk.
 
The show started right on time.
 
The Reverend Saul David was introduced, as the band geared up and played some 
wonderful
 gospel tunes and he danced around, waving his arms, bobbing his blonde head, smiling (even as his eyebrows were scowling in a creepy way) and everybody clapped their hands and praised Jesus. That was the fun part!
 
The music was 
delicious
. Rich. Inspiring. I'm still a fan of gospel and learned a lot of technique that night. You wouldn't know if you heard me play piano, that I wasn't raised a Southern Baptist. I took to the style like a duck to water. It exudes essence, and soul, and truly touches me. I love the music!
 
But then the music 
stopped
.
 
The fun ended. I suddenly found myself being held hostage for 
hours
. A lot of 
boring
 talking.
 Preaching. Fire and Brimstone.
 
Blah blah blah. 
My eyes glazed over. I wanted to leave, but like I said, I was in the middle of nowhere, way out of town. It was dark, and I really didn't know exactly where I was.
 
The freakiest part of the evening came when the good 'ol Rev started picking people out of the audience.
 
“There is someone here,” he began, “someone who recently lost a son. And God wants you to know, 
Sully
, that 
Tony
 is beside him in Heaven and is just fine.”
 
And Sully would whoop and weep. Relieved that his kid was okay in the Afterlife.
 
“Someone here has been suffering from arthritis. 
Lily
 has owned a bakery for years and can no longer knead her bread!”
 
At which point, my seat neighbor, the one I'd taken to the Lady's room, let out a startled gasp, and put her hand over her lips in astonishment! She was eating that stuff up.
 
The Reverend made his way over to our row and grabbed onto the old woman's head and started speaking gibberish, 
“Loobagoda Brigga Nighga Shwopa-fumanigha poo Veggie lool roog bon FWEEEEEE!”
 
(My eyes went wide. I was suddenly frightened.)
 
“IN THE NAME OF JEEEZUS-AH, YOU WILL BE HEEEEELED, NOWA! Stand up and WALK!” 
He 
screamed
 directly into her face, and I watched, bird's eye view, as 
spittle
 flew from his mouth, into her open eyes and drenched her face.
 
She was weeping as she stood, wobbly at first, then raising her arms started walking up and down the aisles!
 
The congregation erupted. Talking in tongues, arms raised, standing, stomping
,
 as the organ chimed in and accompanied such an amazing “
miracle” 
taking place!
 
The Reverend took her wheelchair
,
 and kicked it, 
actually kicked it, 
away (I was hoping the old lady got it back later.)
 
Oh, the tears did flow!
 
At the end of the evening, the Reverend, tired of making fake predictions by getting information fed to him in his secreted earpiece from the cards we'd filled out before the “show” started, had us all line up and went down the queue, “healing” us one-by-one.
 
He was grabbing heads and 
literally
 pushing people backwards into the arms of his assistants. When he got to me I didn't fall over, I 
resisted, held my ground
 and I laughed in his face.
 
He looked pissed off.
 
Luckily, he didn't point out I was possessed by the devil or anything, or I might have been torn to shreds by the fanatics in that room!
 
Finally, after four hours of exhausting bullshit, it was over.
 
People were gladly handing over a good portion of their paychecks at the reception table as they filed out of the room.
 
Leaving the show, I ended up collecting my jacket from my seat. I met the old couple there, and said farewell.
 
I watched them as they slowly began to walk away, the husband escorting his fragile wife as she painfully took each step and leaned heavily on his arm.
 
“Don't you want your wheelchair?” I asked, as I pointed to it, still sitting in the corner, where the Reverend had kicked it earlier during his sermon.
 
She looked me straight in the eye and said:
 
“Oh no! I've been 
healed by our Lord, Jesus Christ!
 I will never sit in 
that
 thing again!”
 
..And off toddled the most ignorant American I've ever met.

title: Can I do a light workout every day?
article:
Everyday, before going to the gym, I listen to Time by Hans Zimmer on blast and intensely stare at my self in the mirror, while visualising every exercise I’m going to do that day.
 
When the song is done, I scream “Yeah!!!” loudly, startling my roommates and neighbours, as I, now fully pumped up, pick up my training bag, beat my chest like a silverback gorilla, and storm out the door, ready to take the world by storm.
“Dude, did you take the picture yet? Holding my arms up like this is exhausting.”
 
…
 
I hope you know none of that’s true.
 
I do pump myself up before a big lift sometimes.
 
It can indeed b
Continue Reading
Everyday, before going to the gym, I listen to Time by Hans Zimmer on blast and intensely stare at my self in the mirror, while visualising every exercise I’m going to do that day.
 
When the song is done, I scream “Yeah!!!” loudly, startling my roommates and neighbours, as I, now fully pumped up, pick up my training bag, beat my chest like a silverback gorilla, and storm out the door, ready to take the world by storm.
“Dude, did you take the picture yet? Holding my arms up like this is exhausting.”
 
…
 
I hope you know none of that’s true.
 
I do pump myself up before a big lift sometimes.
 
It can indeed be awkward.
 
Slaps are given. Music is played. Grunts are, embarrassing as it is in retrospect, made.
 
But while I use it as a tool, I don’t rely on feelings of motivation, for reasons we’re about to get to.
 
The term motivation is used and abused too much and too vaguely. Before we can talk about it, we need to firmly define what it means.
 
When discussing others, most agree that motivation is 
the desire that drives their actions.
 
Simple, right?
 
But when we’re talking about ourselves—and perhaps most specifically when we speak of notoriously hard to improve aspects of our lives—that’s 
not
 the meaning we give it.
 
We then start mixing it up, with this mythical 
feeling 
that will be able to generate the energy required for us to behave in a particular way.
 
We tend to also treat it as a prerequisite; as if this feeling has to be present before we do a given thing.
 
“I’m not motivated today.”
 
“When am I going to be motivated again?”
 
“I need some motivation before I start.”
 
Notice however, that nowhere in the first definition does it say that one has to 
feel
 motivation. It only speaks of the desire driving action. If I told you Usain Bolt was motivated to train for the Olympics, that only means he has a goal he values in his sights—not that every moment of his experience is filled with feelings of motivation. Point being, that 
these two definitions of motivation are not the same thing.
 
And that is a 
very
 good thing.
Contrary to how we treat them, feelings aren’t instructions we should follow, sent from the deep, all-knowing core inside of us.
 
There is at least no evidence of that.
 
The unsexy, best guess of a truth we currently have is that
 feelings are our brains best interpretations of outward stimuli 
based on our personal biology, history, personality, expectations and culture.
[1]
 
[2]
 
[3]
 
[4]
 
Also, as the high-school version of me would tell you: feelings are fickle beasts.
 
Not constant, but fluctuating.
 
Not rational, but irrational.
 
No one feels pulsating motivation 
all the time,
 just like no one feels constant anger, happiness or joy.
 
Doing something you’re not used to doing, it’s in fact very likely you’ll not 
feel
 much motivation—at least at first. Rarely do we like doing that we’re bad at.
 
So 
“motivation the feeling”
 shouldn’t matter.
 
What should is the 
overarching desire
 that drives our actions, even—and perhaps especially—when we don’t particularly feel like performing those actions.
 
What drives people to train everyday and what we need isn’t 
motivation
, but 
dedication
.
 
Dedication, to a goal we’ve set ourselves.
 
Dedication, to being who we want to be.
 
Dedication, to what 
motivates us
.
 
No one wants to eat vegetables, drag themselves to the gym and go to bed early. These are not sexy, fun or appealing things to do. The only reason why some do them is because they’re dedicated to an overarching goal, desire or way of life they value.
 
But is doing whatever you want to do going to be a constant uphill battle? Are you never going to like it?
 
The good news is that’s highly unlikely.
 
If you’re anything like most people, you’ll enjoy it more and more the more time you spend doing it.
 
As stated, we like doing things we’re good at and we become good at that which we do. It’s a 
positive feedback loop.
One action spurs another, which again spurs the original action.
 
Furthermore, we mostly don’t operate based on momentary desire. Virtually no one contemplates how they feel about brushing their teeth or weighs the pros and cons of cutting their nails.
 
Doing so would be exhausting and extremely inefficient.
 
Most of our decisions are made blindly, out of habit. That which we do everyday is treated just as things to be done. Exercise becomes very much the same way.
 
It’s also important to notice how motivation and dedication are not on opposite sides of the spectrum. One does not take away from the other. In fact, they’re symbiotic, feeding off of each other.
 
The stronger your motivation—being the 
thing
, the 
goal
, the 
desire
 that motivates you—the easier it is to dedicate yourself to it. The more you’re able to dedicate yourself to something, the more motivated you’ll feel, because you’re now accomplishing what motivates you, and few things are more motivating than sensing progress towards a goal we value.
 
Most often, it works like this in practice:
Find something that motivates you.
 As we’ve gone over, this doesn’t mean something you’ll enjoy doing 100% of the time, but simply something that’ll make you happy/successful in the long run.
Dedicate yourself to it.
 You’ll inevitably, for a moment or 100, not want to do it. Do it anyway.
Do it for a long enough time that it becomes ingrained. 
You’ll have to fight less and less to do it. Some days, you’ll still have to though. That’s life.
Too many people accept blindly the idea that they need to feel motivated to do something. That which we decide as true shape our vision of the world.
 
If reaching your goal is something that’s important to you, I strongly recommend leaving that crowd and the idea that feelings of motivation are a prerequisite for action behind.
 
Don’t depend on a fleeting feeling. Depend on what will make you happiest in the long run.
 
Motivation will come and go.
 
It rises, like the ocean, then it sinks again.
 
And you’ll be there. Still going strong. Still working.
 
With it.
 
Without it.
To answer your question directly: No one feels motivated to workout every day. People simply do so because of their habits, environment and identity. If you want to be more consistent in the gym, those are the things you should aim to change, not your feelings of motivation.
Footnotes
[1] 
https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/feeling-our-emotions/
[2] 
Why Your Biology Runs on Feelings - Issue 56: Perspective - Nautilus
[3] 
https://humdev.uchicago.edu/sites/humdev.uchicago.edu/files/uploads/shweder/2008--The%20Cultural%20Psychology%20of%20the%20Emotions%20-%20Ancient%20and%20Renewed.PDF
[4] 
http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.577.4057&rep=rep1&type=pdf

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
On 27 December 2004 I was on a coach heading to Venice from Verona. There had been a few days of very heavy rain, high tides and winds and when we got to the bus station in Padua the driver announced that the coach would have to terminate because of flooding in Venice. There were a fair few English speakers on the coach and the translation of the information went around the passengers. As we were getting off an American gentleman, perhaps in his early sixties, said to me that it must be due to the Tsunami.
2004 Indian Ocean earthquake and tsunami - Wikipedia
Earthquake and subsequent tsunami in the Indian Ocean On 26 December 2004, at 07:58:53 local time ( UTC+7 ), a major earthquake with a magnitude of 9.2–9.3 M w struck with an epicentre off the west coast of Aceh in northern Sumatra , Indonesia. The undersea megathrust earthquake , known by the scientific community as the Sumatra–Andaman earthquake , [ 8 ] [ 9 ] was caused by a rupture along the fault between the Burma plate and the Indian plate , and reached a Mercalli intensity of IX in some areas. A massive tsunami with waves up to 30 m (100 ft) high, known as the Boxing Day Tsunami after the Boxing Day holiday, or as the Asian Tsunami , [ 10 ] devastated communities along the surrounding coasts of the Indian Ocean, killing an estimated 227,898 people in 14 countries, violently in Aceh ( Indonesia ), and severely in Sri Lanka , Tamil Nadu ( India ), and Khao Lak ( Thailand ). The direct results caused major disruptions to living conditions and commerce in coastal provinces of surrounded countries. It is the deadliest natural disaster of the 21st century , [ 11 ] one of the deadliest natural disasters in recorded history , and the worst tsunami disaster in history. [ 12 ] It is also the worst natural disaster in the history of Indonesia, Sri Lanka and Thailand. [ 13 ] It was the most powerful earthquake ever recorded in Asia, the most powerful earthquake in the 21st century, and at least the third most powerful earthquake ever recorded in the world since modern seismography began in 1900. [ 14 ] [ a ] It had the longest fault rupture ever observed, between 1,200 km and 1,300 km (720 mi and 780 mi), and had the longest duration of faulting ever observed, at least ten minutes. [ 18 ] It caused the planet to vibrate as much as 10 mm (0.4 in), [ 19 ] and also remotely triggered earthquakes as far away as Alaska . [ 20 ] Its epicentre was between Simeulue and mainland Sumatra. [ 21 ] The plight of the affected people and countries prompted a worldwide humanitarian response , with donations totalling more than US$14 billion [ 22 ] (equivalent to US$23 billion in 2023 currency). Earthquake USGS Shakemap for the event The 2004 Indian Ocean earthquake was initially documented as having a moment magnitude of 8.8. The United States Geological Survey has its estimate of 9.1. [ 23 ] Hiroo Kanamori of the California Institute of Technology estimates that M w 9.2 is best representative of the earthquake's size. [ 24 ] More recent studies estimate the magnitude to be M w 9.3. [ 25 ] [ 26 ] [ 27 ] [ 28 ] A 2016 study estimated the magnitude to be M w 9.25, [ 29 ] while a 2021 study revised its 2007 estimate of M w 9.1 to a new magnitude of M w 9.2. [ 30 ] The hypocentre of the main earthquake was approximately 160 km (100 mi) off the western coast of northern Sumatra, in the Indian Ocean just north of Simeulue island at a depth of 30 km (19 mi) below mean sea level (initially reported as 10 km or 6.2 mi). The northern section of the Sunda megathrust ruptured ove
