Continue Reading
Discover the Best Workout for You: Customizing Your Fitness Journey
Embarking on a fitness journey can be both exciting and overwhelming with the plethora of workout options available. Whether you're looking to shed some pounds, build muscle, or boost your overall health, finding the right workout is key to sustaining motivation and achieving your goals. Let's dive into the world of fitness and shed light on how to choose the best workout tailor-fitted to your needs and lifestyle.
 
Understanding Your Fitness Goals
 
Before jumping into the latest fitness craze, it's essential to get a clear understanding of what you want to achieve. Here's how to set realistic and personal goals:
Weight Loss:
 If your aim is to lose weight, focus on workouts that enhance 
cardiovascular health
 and burn significant calories, such as HIIT, running, or spinning classes.
Muscle Gain:
 For those looking to gain muscle mass, strength training and resistance exercises like weightlifting or bodyweight exercises will be your go-to.
Endurance Building:
 Sports such as swimming, cycling, or long-distance running can increase your stamina and improve heart and lung function.
Flexibility and Balance:
 Yoga and Pilates provide a perfect blend of stretching and core workouts to enhance these areas.
Once your goals are outlined, consider how each workout aligns with your lifestyle and how they can be incorporated into your daily regime.
 
Considering Workout Preferences and Lifestyle
 
Your workout should not only meet your fitness goals but also jive with your interests and schedule. Consistency will become infinitely easier if you enjoy the process. Ask yourself:
Do you prefer solitary workouts where you can go at your own pace, like jogging or solo weight training sessions?
Are group classes such as Zumba, spinning, or CrossFit more motivating and fun for you?
Does your routine allow long workout periods, or are shorter, more intense sessions like Tabata training better?
Balance is vital—not just on the yoga mat but also in scheduling workouts that fit into your life seamlessly.
 
Workout Types: Pros, Cons, and Who They're Best For
1. HIIT (High-Intensity Interval Training)
 
Pros:
Efficient, burns many calories in a short period
Boosts metabolism for hours after the workout
Cons:
May be challenging for beginners
Higher risk of injury if not done with proper form
Best for:
 Individuals with limited time seeking fast results.
 
2. Cardiovascular Exercises (Running, Cycling)
 
Pros:
Improves heart health and burns calories
Can be done anywhere
Cons:
Can be monotonous
Impact on joints
Best for:
 Beginners to advanced; those who enjoy outdoor activities.
 
3. Strength Training (Gym Workouts, Calisthenics)
 
Pros:
Builds muscle and strength
Increases metabolism
Cons:
Requires equipment or gym access
Progress may be slower
Best for:
 Those looking to tone up or increase strength.
 
4. Yoga and Pilates
 
Pros:
Improves flexibility and core strength
Reduces stress
Cons:
May not burn as many calories
Requires patience and discipline
Best for:
 Individuals seeking a low-impact option focusing on mental and physical well-being.
 
Incorporating Recovery and Nutrition
Remember that the best workout routine is incomplete without proper recovery and nutrition. Always schedule rest days to allow your body to recover, and fuel your workouts with a balanced diet rich in proteins, carbohydrates, fats, and micronutrients. Hydration is also non-negotiable—keep the water flowing!
 
Conclusion
 
The best workout for you is one that you enjoy, that fits your lifestyle, and that moves you towards your fitness objectives. Assess your preferences, experiment with different types, and listen to your body's responses. Dedication to progress rather than perfection will lead to sustainable health benefits and personal satisfaction.
 
Remember to consult with fitness professionals and possibly get a health check-up before starting a new workout regime. Their guidance can help you modify workouts to your level, increasing both effectiveness and safety.
 
As you begin this journey, celebrate every step forward. Whether it's a faster mile, a heavier lift, or simply the discipline to show up to your yoga mat—each accomplishment is a testament to your commitment to a healthier you.
 
Begins with these 
5 key principles you must apply
 in order to STOP the rapid onset of aging that's going on right now, reverse it, and begin "aging backwards" by restoring your body's natural youth hormones.

title: Are there any poor people on Quora, as Internet access is very cheap nowadays?
article:
I am poor. I live in a beautiful part of the USA, the southwest, in the historic state of Colorado and I am poor. Though true, not by the world’s standards for sure, and not by a couple of very important yardsticks.
 
The important yardsticks first: I have a grown son, a 22-year-old man who is by far the biggest “compliment,” or pat-on-the back, that I could ever imagine. He is a totally undeserved blessing that is beyond my comprehension as to why I was gifted with him.
 
Offspring are blessings, so that is one important, non-monetary measurement.
 
Further, I received the “"gift of faith” in Christ, 
Continue Reading
I am poor. I live in a beautiful part of the USA, the southwest, in the historic state of Colorado and I am poor. Though true, not by the world’s standards for sure, and not by a couple of very important yardsticks.
 
The important yardsticks first: I have a grown son, a 22-year-old man who is by far the biggest “compliment,” or pat-on-the back, that I could ever imagine. He is a totally undeserved blessing that is beyond my comprehension as to why I was gifted with him.
 
Offspring are blessings, so that is one important, non-monetary measurement.
 
Further, I received the “"gift of faith” in Christ, as a child, and I am persisting in my very flawed and unremarkable pursuit of as much of what I know He wants me to be, have and do as I know how to and that I have the willingness to cooperate with him to pursue.
 
Another important yardstick.
 
Third, I have reasonably good health and was given strength in the physical part of life, though the strong appetites that often accompany generally good health I have exploited to my disadvantage.
 
Now, by the world’s standards, I have clean-enough water to bathe in; I buy distilled water to drink and cook with; I have 650 square feet with a roof over it all, and doors that have yet to be breached, despite the higher incidence of crime where I live; I have “"stuff,” like an old smart phone, a 32″ tv, an old laptop, some worn out clothes.
 
Pretty rich, as compared to literally 4/5ths or more of the world’s population. But, as compared to what my parents had when they were my age (I’m 59), I am hardly “"eking our” a living and there is little hope for financial security in my fast-approaching “old age.”
 
I have no car (unlike 95% of my city’s population), nothing in the bank, my glasses are 14 years old and taped together on both sides; I also haven't seen a doctor or a dentist for 14 years; and the last time I wore a pair of shoes that were new, decent, department-store shoes was when my son was four years old (18 years ago), when my sister decided to take me shopping and buy me some nice things.
 
I walk and bicycle the two miles to my job, a job which requires me to stand all day and leaves me so tired and sore at the end of the day that I am hardly able to do anything once I get home, or on my days off.
 
Is it poverty to not be able to go to a good doctor? Or is the worse torture having ideas that could solve one’s financial restraints you cannot take action to execute due to limits in one’s energy level means?
 
I experience the second as the worst.
 
Many people in the USA, maybe it’s even fair to say most, live in their own little world and are oblivious as to the conditions that others whom they per chance see at the store, or walking by them on the sidewalk, or sitting next to them at church, are enduring.
 
There are more people in the USA that are poor in the monetary sense than meets the eye.
 
Perhaps most people don't see the scores of thousands that are only a couple weeks from homelessness. And who don’t by any means have “all” their basic needs met because that would crowd out the pleasant self-satisfaction that the richer enjoy on a daily basis, as they get hair cuts and dental work and dinners out that the “poor” cannot afford to count on to lift their spirits or buoy their resolve for tomorrow’s demands.
 
Proverbs 29:2 in the bible says: “When the righteous rule, the people rejoice; but when the wicked are on top, the people mourn.” I think the number of people who are mourning in America is getting larger and has been doing so for about 45 years.
 
If you live in the US, the next time you see a stranger ask yourself ‘How can I tell for sure when the last time was that that person had a good meal?’
 
FOOTNOTE: In the Colorado county where I live (El Paso), and where the headquarters of Focus on the Family, and Compassion International, and International Bible Study, and The Navigators, are located, all world- renown Christian organizations, one-third of all school aged children go to bed hungry every night.
 
Are they as hungry as Mali’s 7.5 million kids under 15 years of age who are often left with no option other than to turn tricks for the ones with money so they can keep “earning” their right to stay at the mosque where the local imams bring one child of every household to serve Allah?
 
Probably not.
 
But can a country who doesn't feed it's own children anymore qualify as a leader of the free world? Also, probably not.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
A writer (I’ll call her Primadonna)who was attending a convention in the UK. She was travelling to Britain for ‘research’ and was invited—no pay, but her room was free, and she could sell her books, meet the celeb guests etc. Now, when I say writer here, let it be known that although her books were professionally published, they were essentially fanfic—based on a tv show and licensed as such. Not exactly deep or original stuff…I’d consider having my room paid for all weekend a pretty good deal tbh.
 
Anyway, someone in our group had been penfriends with her and even met her once or twice, and we 
Continue Reading
A writer (I’ll call her Primadonna)who was attending a convention in the UK. She was travelling to Britain for ‘research’ and was invited—no pay, but her room was free, and she could sell her books, meet the celeb guests etc. Now, when I say writer here, let it be known that although her books were professionally published, they were essentially fanfic—based on a tv show and licensed as such. Not exactly deep or original stuff…I’d consider having my room paid for all weekend a pretty good deal tbh.
 
Anyway, someone in our group had been penfriends with her and even met her once or twice, and we arranged a meal with about 10 people attending. When time for the meal came, Ms Primadonna had not shown up. She sent a message she was still coming. Everyone sat down, but didn’t order as it would be rude if we started before she got there. Time goes by…lots of time. Another message comes—she has a migraine, but she’s still coming. We wait. And wait. Another half hour or more goes by. We are now all starving and not sure what to do. Then ta-da, Primadonna finally swans into the room and plonks herself at the head of the table like a queen. No hello for anyone, a miserable, sour face. (OK, she had a migraine—why not just cancel if she felt that bad? I am a migraineur myself—doesn’t turn me into a jerk.)
 
She grabs the menu, more facial grimaces. “Ugh, I don’t like any of this…and guess what, when I went to the drugstore they don’t have the same painkillers as in America! I’m not taking anything foreign! I can’t believe i can’t get proper drugs!”
 
Silence started to fall over the table. Her tone was petulant, unfriendly and accusatory. Being mostly Brits/Canadians and a little more reserved than she was, no one said, “Why would you think you’d get the same painkillers?’ although you could tell everyone was thinking it.
 
She continued to moan about the menu and didn’t order; the rest of us finally ordered food. Primadonna didn’t seem to like the fact no one was continuously fussing about her headache/lack of drugs and suddenly said, “I have to go’ and disappeared from the restaurant. We tried to make excuses for her because she felt unwell but…
 
She was back at it the next day. I was going to buy her book but ahead of me, I saw a fan go up to her table, buy her stuff then ask for a photograph of her. She flung up a hand to her head in a melodramatic way like some dame in a panto. “Go on but I’ve had a headache…” she whined, all passive aggressive, making her FAN seriously uncomfortable and embarrassed.( There are nicer ways to say ‘no’, and if you are attending an event, you are in the public eye. Not one of the real celebs attending were anything like this.)
 
Later on Primadonna cornered my friend ( the penfriend) while she was walking in the hall with me and another lady. Now came the really cringey stuff. “There…there is DUST in my room,” she said, almost tremulously as if about to cry. Her lower lip was so outthrust in a pout, I thought she might trip on it. “I ran my finger along the ledge and saw it on my fingertip.”
 
(This was an old building, her room was free, and if there was dust in her room, it wasn’t in mine or anyone else’s!)
 
“Couldn’t you ask housekeeping to clean it?” my friend mumbled.
 
Primadonna rolled her eyes to heaven. “This is terrible! Dust! They can’t treat me like this! They can’t do this to me-I’M AN AMERICAN!”
 
There were three of us there besides Primadonna. A stunned silence fell. No one quite knew where to look after this cringe-worthy outburst.
 
Me and one other English girl hastily made our excuses and left the hall, unable to bear it anymore. The girl looked at me once we were out of earshot and started to laugh, “What a horrible, entitled, rude person!”
 
We avoided Primadonna after that but heard her tell people she was a black belt in karate, which seemed pretty implausible given her rather, um, unfit physique and the fact that every ache, pain or inconvenience was a big issue.
 
Later we heard she could not cope with the U.K. and cut her whole ‘research’ trip short and went home to the US early, losing loads of money! I guess she couldn’t handle the fact no one was falling all over her, catering to every whim just because she was American and wrote some fanfics.
 
Later the friend who’d met her in the past said, “I have no idea why she was freaking out about the dust. Her own house is full of brimming cigarette trays and she has about 20 cats!”

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
Some of the most intelligent people I’ve met are American. I think they’re one of the greatest peoples in the world.
 
But I did meet one 
exceptionally
 foolish gentleman who happened to be American. We were in the Canadian Rockies up in British Columbia which is by far the most beautiful place on the planet.
This photograph gives you only an inkling of this staggering landmass. I’ve never seen so many pine trees in all my life, rolling endlessly like waves on the ocean across barren mountains.
 
I was camping near Golden in the summer months, staying at a campsite with a few other travellers. This wa
Continue Reading
Some of the most intelligent people I’ve met are American. I think they’re one of the greatest peoples in the world.
 
But I did meet one 
exceptionally
 foolish gentleman who happened to be American. We were in the Canadian Rockies up in British Columbia which is by far the most beautiful place on the planet.
This photograph gives you only an inkling of this staggering landmass. I’ve never seen so many pine trees in all my life, rolling endlessly like waves on the ocean across barren mountains.
 
I was camping near Golden in the summer months, staying at a campsite with a few other travellers. This was when I used to do hitchhiking up the Trans-Canada Highway.
In this campsite were a variety of different travellers from across the world. Some were Canadian, a few Australians, there was a German, Spaniard and a couple of Americans.
 
We were isolated. Our campsite was deep in the mountains. I saw black bears and all sorts of other mammals. Everyone was naturally curious about black bears, afraid of being mauled to death but also very eager to get a photograph of them.
 
I remember prepping for hours about how I would react in case a bear approached me, looking for its next meal. I knew how to roll on the ground, stand tall and shout, pop off a firecracker and I read up on how to use bear spray if it came to it.
Now enters one of the most idiotic individuals I have ever met.
 
Let’s call him Captain Know-it-All.
Captain Know-it-All had lectured us for the last two nights around the campfire about how he was a ‘citizen of the world’ (whatever that means) in one of the thickest Californian accents I’ve encountered. He also told us about the wilderness as if he were a pioneer explorer.
 
Captain Know-it-All seemed to have an encyclopaedic knowledge of the outdoors, especially wilderness survival. Yet he was very gaunt and seemed to have only left his daily outing to the coffee shop for the first time on this trip. He was very slim, lanky, tall like a giraffe with long hair and a drawn out face.
 
We were all developing headaches as he tried to impress us. His Romanian girlfriend only encouraged him on, inflating his ego to mountainous proportions.
Around his waist at all times was a tool belt containing every piece of kit you can think, including a small hatchet that was impossible to cut anything with and a strange admixture of blunt instruments except for a sharp hunter’s knife which was far too dangerous for this person to carry.
 
He also had fire starters dangling from the belt, a compass in case he strayed ten metres from his car, and all manners of other rubbish he was never going to use. The only thing this absurd tool belt was going to do was weigh him down when a bear’s stomach grumbled. However, out of all these tools, Captain Know-it-All’s most prized possession was a canister of bear-spray.
I was actually told by an expert wilderness survivalist who lived alone in the Canadian mountains to not carry bear spray with me when hiking. I thought this was counterintuitive, but he explained that many of the people who try to use it have absolutely no idea how to safely discharge a canister.
 
Problems include not only being unable to aim at a fast moving bear charging towards you, but missing the target, not opening it fast enough or misjudging wind direction. You can’t just fire glorified pepper spray into strong winds and 
not
 be throughly coated in eye-burning liquids. This expert judged that those with little experience are more likely to hurt themselves with bear spray than have any successful chance of hurting the bear.
 
The best tips for a black bear encounter are not to run away, but to make yourself big by waving both arms and creating loud noises. This will scare off black bears most of the time rather than blinding yourself with bear spray and potentially aggravating a black bear with the spray.
Now back to Captain Know-it-All.
 
This ‘citizen of the world’ (who was very eager to apologise for being American) was packing his belongings for a day of hiking with his Romanian girlfriend. In the boot of their car, they were arranging everything for the hike as if they were trekking to the Grand Canyon and back.
 
Of course, as they both fiddled with the bear spray, they somehow managed to spray each other in the face and eyes whilst knee deep in the boot of their car.
Safe to say, they didn’t go hiking that day.

After all, how to adapt to yourself is a combination of goals and priorities. If you want the quality of The Rock or Matt Bomer's washboard abdominal muscles, or the speed or agility of Usain Bolt or Cam Newton, you have to work. If your goals are not so lofty (you want to feel good, maybe lose a few pounds, or just keep your place), then you still have to figure out how the fitness class will fit your life. Don't worry, through these strategies, no matter what kind of fitness "guy" you are, we can cover everyone.
For the guy who has no free time
 
We see, you are very busy, and sometimes the gym falls at the bottom of the to-do list. Sorry to say that if you are serious about health and wellness, it will not happen. When you seem to have spoken all the hours of the day, you must find ways to increase efficiency. For example, bring lunch so you can spend half of your rest time on exercise and the other half on eating. Or consider becoming an early riser so that you can exercise before life happens, and then suddenly finish the exercise.
 
Short
 
The good news: exercise does not have to take a few hours to take effect. "The minimum effective amount of exercise is 4 minutes, which is the time for a drum exercise," said Josh Holland, a trainer in New York City and founder of Zoomtion Fitness. So, why not start your day with squats or push-ups (20 seconds, 10 seconds rest, 8 reps) while making coffee?
 
Hard to go home
 
This is not to say that long-term exercise will not bring more benefits, although Holland said that you only need 20 to 30 minutes, especially when you are training hard. His favorite is your best partner, including slow repetitive high-intensity strength training, aerobic sprinting and endurance isometric tests.
 
This weight loss routine is the perfect partner exercise
 
A cry for you
 
Strengthen Strength: Choose 5 to 7 multi-joint exercises (such as front squat, overhead press, bench press, low row exercise and pull down exercise), and perform slow repetitive exercises (concentric and eccentric) for about one and a half minutes for each exercise Exercise 5-6 seconds), respectively. Holland said: "The weight should be heavy enough to make you tired."
 
For aerobic exercise: choose aerobic exercise mode (running, biking, rowing, even skipping). Go all out for 12 to 15 seconds. Indeed not, do your best, this is not a half-way time. Recover up to one minute (up to three minutes), and then recover 6 to 10 times. Holland said: "When your distance starts to shrink, then it's time for you to quit."
 
For long-lasting: This fast exercise can be done in your living room using your own body weight. Use wall sitting, planks, handstands or spear rests and lunges rest to create isometric circuits. Move continuously for 1 minute at a time and complete the loop as much as possible until the table fails. Make it more difficult by extending the time.
 
For those who are not motivated
 
For whatever reason, when you stretch your hips toward the gym, you seem to be dragging your feet. It’s not that you are afraid of it, but because it’s much easier to procrastinate or get yourself into work, such as Netflix or aimless web surfing or coworkers’ happy hours, and suddenly, you are not for the week.
 
Set a goal
 
You’ve heard it before, but if you don’t have a clear intention, it’s difficult to measure progress and you don’t even have the motivation to try. Add numbers to it, such as the specific weight loss you want to achieve within a specific time period (remember that 2 pounds a week is considered healthy and sustainable). Or consider the goal of skill or strength: perfect skipping leg training, lift body weight (or 1.5 times or twice the body weight) on the bench or deadlift, pull up 10 or 20 pull-ups, master the muscles, and start Exercise the number of miles within a certain time frame and so on. "Using test and retest models," Holland said. Set a benchmark and then conduct a self-test once a week or every two weeks to assess progress.
 
Let others hold you accountable
 
An exercise partner who is already a gym rat may be your new best friend. Cheer him up by asking for his opinion, suggesting to provide a whistleblower, or keeping up with him, you need someone to whip your ass. Or even promise to pay for the smoothie after exercise to help you get up and drag you there, and don’t let him refuse.

Introduction:
 
We all know that we should be exercising more, but it seems like there's never enough time in the day. Between work, family obligations, and social commitments, where are you supposed to fit in a trip to the gym? The good news is that there are plenty of ways to get your fitness fix without leaving home or spending hours in the gym. We'll give you some tips for fitting fitness into your already busy schedule.
 
1. What are some tips to help you fit fitness into your schedule?
 
1. Schedule your workouts like you would any other appointment.
 
2. Find a time that works for you and stick to it.
 
3. Cut down on unnecessary commitments.
 
4. Make use of technology to help you stay accountable.
 
5. Take advantage of your surroundings.
 
2. What are some tips to help you make time for working out if you're not a morning person?
 
If you're not a morning person, finding time for a workout can be tough. But don't worry, there are plenty of ways to make fitness work for you. Here are some tips to help you make time for working out:
 
-Find a time that works for you. If you can't get to the gym in the morning, try going at night. Or, if you're really pressed for time, try doing a quick workout at home.
 
-Schedule your workouts like you would any other appointment. This will help keep them top of mind and prevent them from getting pushed to the bottom of your to-do list.
 
-Make use of technology. There are lots of great fitness apps and streaming services that make it easy to squeeze in a workout no matter where you are.
 
-Get a workout buddy. Having someone to hold you accountable and push you to work harder can be a huge help when it comes to staying on track.
 
3. What are some tips to help you make time for working out if you're not a night owl?
 
If you're not a night owl, don't try to work out in the evening. You'll be more likely to make excuses and skip your workout if it's scheduled for a time when you're already winding down. Instead, try to work out first thing in the morning or during your lunch break. That way, you'll have already accomplished something and you won't feel guilty about taking some time for yourself later in the day. And if you can't fit in a full workout during those times, try to at least do some quick exercises like squats or lunges. You'll be surprised at how much of a difference even a few minutes can make!
 
4. What are some ways you can fit fitness into your schedule no matter the time of day?
 
When it comes to fitting fitness into your schedule, there are no excuses. Just because you're busy doesn't mean you can't find time for a workout. Here are some ideas to get you started:
 
- Rise and shine: Start your day with a fitness routine. Whether you do yoga, go for a run or lift some weights, getting your sweat on in the morning is a great way to set the tone for the day.
 
- Lunch break: If you can't get away for a full workout, try squeezing in a quick fitness routine during your lunch break. A 20-30 minute walk or jog is a great way to break up the day and get your blood flowing.
 
- Evening routine: Dedicate time at the end of the day for fitness. This could be 30 minutes of cardio or an hour-long strength training session. If you have time constraints in the evening, try mixing and matching different workouts to create a shorter routine.
 
5. What are good ways to stay active even if you can't work out?
 
Even if you can't always make it to the gym or go for a run, there are plenty of other ways to stay active. In fact, simply incorporating more movement into your day can help burn calories and improve your overall fitness level. Here are a few ideas to get you started:
 
1. Park your car at the far end of the lot.
 
2. Take the stairs instead of the elevator or escalator.
 
3. Walk or ride your bike to work or school instead of driving.
 
4. Do some squats or lunges during your commercials breaks.
 
5. Take a brisk walk in your neighborhood after dinner.
 
6. Use a fitness tracker to monitor your daily activity level.
 
Conclusion:
 
We all know how important it is to stay active and fit, but sometimes life gets in the way. With a little bit of creativity and organisation, though, you can find time to work out – no matter how busy you are. These tips will help you make time for fitness, so you can stay healthy and looking great.

title: What happens if you workout every day?
article:
That’s a great question.
 
First of all, 10 kg isn’t light. You can achieve just about anything with the weight of your own body. But, sometimes it’s hard without equipment and dumbbells are a great choice. They are versatile and even portable.
 
So, let’s get into it.
 
In order to shorten this answer and not repeat myself, I won’t write about basic bodyweight training. Here’s an answer where I go in depth about this:
 
Lazar Nikolic's answer to What is the best way to build muscles at home?
 
First of all, if you don’t have a
 pull-up bar
, these dumbbells might come in handy – curl variations (for biceps), 
Continue Reading
That’s a great question.
 
First of all, 10 kg isn’t light. You can achieve just about anything with the weight of your own body. But, sometimes it’s hard without equipment and dumbbells are a great choice. They are versatile and even portable.
 
So, let’s get into it.
 
In order to shorten this answer and not repeat myself, I won’t write about basic bodyweight training. Here’s an answer where I go in depth about this:
 
Lazar Nikolic's answer to What is the best way to build muscles at home?
 
First of all, if you don’t have a
 pull-up bar
, these dumbbells might come in handy – curl variations (for biceps), dumbbell rows (narrow for lats, wider for rear delts) etc. But I highly suggest you try to save up for a pull-up bar, or at least find one in your neighborhood. Or use something else that’s strong enough for you to hold onto. Pull-ups are one of the staples of bodyweight training.
 
This leads us to another point from the previous answer: muscles you can’t easily target without equipment. 
Calves
, for example, are used to the weight of your body, but using 20 kg of dumbbells as a resistance just might create initial overload. Don’t try to exercise your 
middle delts
 with these, though. I’m almost certain you won’t be able to handle so much weight in a side lateral raise.
 
But, the beauty of dumbbells is this – you can make any exercise harder or easier with these. Let’s take this paragraph from the linked answer:
Mix push-ups and dips for the chest, front shoulders and triceps
Mix pull-ups and chin-ups for lats, biceps, rear delts and the upper back
Mix variations of leg raises, planks and crunches for abs and obliques
Do lower back extensions for the lower back (spinal erectors)
Mix hip thrusts and glute bridges for the gluteus
Mix squats and lunges for quads
You can put a dumbbell (or both) in a backpack and create more tension on 
dips
, 
push-ups 
or a 
plank
. You can use one or both in 
squats
 and 
lunges
 easily. You can make both 
hip thrusts
 and 
glute bridges
 harder with dumbbell(s). And you can hold one or both while doing 
crunches 
or even hold one of them between legs in 
pull-ups
 and
 leg raises
 when you get strong enough.
 
But making things harder is in perspective, first you need to create a strong base and develop proper form if you intend on adding weight. That’s where we start looking at things from a different perspective.
 
If 
push-ups
 are too hard, use dumbbells to do a 
dumbbell bench press
. You don’t even need a bench, lay on the floor.
 
Handstand push-ups
 are one of the best shoulder building exercises. But that’s way too hard, even for more experienced individuals. So, how to get there? Well, you can go through push-up progressions, but you can also strengthen these muscles doing 
dumbbell overhead press
. In the beginning, use only one dumbbell and switch to both when you develop adequate strength. Just make sure you are familiar with proper form.
 
In the beginning, you probably won’t be able to 
curl 
10 kg effectively either. So, again – use only one dumbbell. If that’s the case, that is.
 
So, in short – if you pair your two dumbbells with bodyweight training, you can definitely build more than enough muscle.
 
I suggest you head off to 
Athlean-X
 YouTube channel and learn proper form of any exercise you want to do. You can also find great insight on 
Calisthenic Movement
 and
 FitnessFAQs
 YouTube channels.
 
Learn new variations, both easier and harder, if you want to have a good, stable base for future training. Develop your whole body and stretch, so you don’t injure yourself.
 
Don’t chase numbers, do your absolute best on every exercise and you’ll have results. Just make sure that you can safely do anything you set your mind to. Again – 
study proper form in detail before attempting anything
.
 
Good luck!
 
EDIT
: In some other answers, people said that these dumbbells will eventually get too light for you. That certainly is true. But, with good 
bodyweight variations
, you can mitigate this “problem”. You can also change the way you move them in space –
 slow down
, do 
one and a half rep
 style training, do 
21's technique
 and more. Yes, expanding your equipment inventory would be beneficial, but that’s so far ahead of you that you don’t have to worry about that now. Cheers!

title: What happens if you workout every day?
article:
If you are thinking about leading a more active lifestyle, you are not alone
In recent years, an increasing number of Americans have started participating in more sports, fitness and recreation.
 
Whether you are trying to get fit, build muscle or you are just tired of the couch here are some changes you can expect along the way
 
During the first workout , you might feel more alert and energized because ramping up your heart rate means a boast in overall blood flow and oxygen to the brain.
But prepare yourself for the day after , when you will almost certainly get a case of DOMS - short for delayed -
Continue Reading
If you are thinking about leading a more active lifestyle, you are not alone
In recent years, an increasing number of Americans have started participating in more sports, fitness and recreation.
 
Whether you are trying to get fit, build muscle or you are just tired of the couch here are some changes you can expect along the way
 
During the first workout , you might feel more alert and energized because ramping up your heart rate means a boast in overall blood flow and oxygen to the brain.
But prepare yourself for the day after , when you will almost certainly get a case of DOMS - short for delayed - onset muscle soreness.
 
The Soreness will persist for about 72 hours but the good news is you are less likely to get it again as long as you continue to regularly exercise those same muscles.
 
Or, the next fees you will slowly start to ramp up production of Mitochondria via a process called Mitochondrial Biogenesis.
 
Mitochondria are the parts of your cells that ck very carbs, fat and protein into fuel that your muscles use to do their job, like flex and contract.
 
After 6 -8 weeks, studies have shown that people can increase their Mitochondria by up to 50%.
 
With more mitochondria in your cell, you will start to feel more fit and your endurance will increase.
 
So, running 3 miles will no longer feel as difficult as it did during the first week.
 
Once you are 6 months in, all of that hardwork should finally start to show.
 
If your workouts focus on strength training, you will notice your muscles begin to take shape.
 
You are also less likely to fall off the workout wagon at this point .
 
Exercise programs often see a 50% dropout rate within the first 6 months but after that, more people stick with it.
 
Now, if you are more focused on cardio then by 9 months of regular exercise you should see about 25% increase in your VO2 max.
 
VO2 max is often used as a measure of fitness and refers to the rate your body can transport oxygen to your muscles for fuel.
 
Basically, higher VO2 max means you can run faster for longer so, a 25% increase means you can run about 20% further in the same amount of time.
 
After one year of regular exercise, your bones will be denser which reduces your risk of Osteoporosis.
 
Infact , researcher have found that regular resistance training when combined with aerobic exercise can actually reverse the effects of osteoporosis after 12 months.
 
Now, if you maintain your exercise program long term your body might not be the only thing to benefit, your Bank account may also beef up.
 
One study revealed that older people who exercised 5 days a week for at least 30 minutes saved, on average $2,500 a year in medical costs for heart related health problems alone.
 
You will also be at a lower risk of developing Arthritis, Type 2 Diabetes, Dementia and certain types of Cancer like Breast and Colon.
 
In all probability, you are going to live longer than you otherwise would.
 
And that longer life ? It will likely feel more fulfilling because exercise lowers the risk of anxiety and depression BH reducing levels of stress hormones like Cortisol and Arsenal.
 
Of course , all of those benefits depends on the type and intensity of your workout and how long you exercise for each week.
 
A balanced diet is also Paramount to a healthy lifestyle.
 
For the average adult ages 18 to 64 , the US Department of Health and Human Services recommends either a minimum of 2.5 hours per week of moderately intense exercise like brisk walking or biking.
Or, at least 1 hour and 15 minutes each week that combines moderate and high intensity workouts like Running or Swimming sprints.
 
On top of that, make sure and take 2 days each week to strengthen your muscles with some weights or resistance training.
 
This will help your overall speed and endurance .
 
As you begin. Its important to pace yourself and not push too hard too fast or you risk serious injury.
You will discover that the fitter you become, the easier it will be to exert a little more energy the next week, the week after, and so forth.
 
Exercise smart and often. And you will be running marathon in no time.
 
If you want to see few of my great answers on Quora like:
 
How to Lose weight without doing exercise?
What are the best ways to lose weight?

title: Are there any poor people on Quora, as Internet access is very cheap nowadays?
article:
Oh yes. I’ll elaborate since why not, you know?
 
Agreed. Internet is cheap. I rent a $575/month room in a house of five and internet is included. Previous, I rented a $500/month room in a house shared with a married couple and internet was also included. Before that, a $475/month room in a duplex with internet I paid for at the introductory rate of $30/month since I was only there for three months (I would have switched to a local, more economical ISP if I had stayed there longer; I went with /name brand isp/ to do a free self-installation so I wouldn’t have to pay the setup fee which the local 
Continue Reading
Oh yes. I’ll elaborate since why not, you know?
 
Agreed. Internet is cheap. I rent a $575/month room in a house of five and internet is included. Previous, I rented a $500/month room in a house shared with a married couple and internet was also included. Before that, a $475/month room in a duplex with internet I paid for at the introductory rate of $30/month since I was only there for three months (I would have switched to a local, more economical ISP if I had stayed there longer; I went with /name brand isp/ to do a free self-installation so I wouldn’t have to pay the setup fee which the local isp would have charged so I could switch to the local isp for a modest transfer fee once the introductory period from the other isp was over) . Before that, I lived on a sofa in an apartment shared with two alcoholics/occasional crack smokers for $300/month and the internet was included. Before that, I had a job and was living in a $750/month bachelor apartment paying the aforementioned local isp $30/month for internet. Before that, I had no job and internet was included, before that it was included, before that it was included, before that it was included. If one pays rent, there is usually internet. Except for the bachelor, the one case where internet was not included, the duplex, was when the landlord was a literal psychopath.
 
I have used Quora for 4–5 years. For the latter 3 of years I have been poor. I originally started using Quora to acquaint myself with tech culture. I was an arts major and wanted to find my way into the tech sector. I never found my way into the tech sector, but I was well prepared to witness the considerable changes seen in society on account of the almost unprecedented recent advancements in technology. I focused on learning to manage and save money until the information given through Quora became repetitive; my parents were not able to endow me with this perspective. After, I focused on ways to make money. I’ve found recurring viable methods which I believed were suitable for me mentioned. Investing in real estate. ecommerce. Trading stocks and currencies. Then I realized these all take initial resources to begin making money with. There are good reasons I’m poor and these methods are not for me at this time. This is where I’m at now.
 
Many things I’ve realized through Quora have significantly shaped who I am as a person. There is a lot less uncertainty for me in regards to how money can be made, kept and spent. Before Quora, did I think a millionaire had access to whatever luxury? Probably yes. Now I know one million dollars is not a lot of money. Twenty million dollars is a lot of money, in my opinion. I’m given $1050/month through disability assistance, by the way. In any case, a millionaire does not necessarily have the ability to choose between all luxuries. I’ve learned ideas come and go. They don’t have to be trendy, sophisticated and certainly not world-changing to make money. Since I’m now focusing on making a living beginning with the amount of resources I have on hand, my most recent ideas for doing so have been focusing on growing a particular kind of mushroom and getting a newspaper route. I have seen the mushrooms sold in health food stores at a very high cost. I know the market on them is cornered. The mushrooms are esoteric, produced in a small amount of far off facilities and I believe I know how, discovered through local lore no less, to grow them more effectively. The newspaper route, I believe I might just be able to manage most immediately.
 
So- this poor person uses Quora with a focus on learning to make a living. Along with a close friend, this site helps me maintain momentum on the path to finding a career. I use it to learn, sometimes as a way to keep busy, to express myself. For perspective I did not have access to previously, inspiration, mentorship. I want to contribute to society while doing right by my needs, if you will, and clarifying both those ends is an ongoing process for me. Not to imply you think poor people may necessarily have distinct reasons for using Quora, but to state poor people have the same reasons for using Quora as those otherwise do; I am a curious and rational animal with internet access.

title: How to workout
article:
When we decide to exercise , three fundamental questions arise: which is the most appropriate, how many weekly sessions we need and, above all, when we will see some effect. The best option is the circuits in which four or five different types of activities alternate with rest periods between series and series . Coaches say that without killing themselves and choosing the activity table, the body will notice in 66 days.
Plan the session; Exhausting is not a guarantee of good results
 
What is better, to train strength or resistance? We are facing the eternal question when it comes to exercising. W
Continue Reading
When we decide to exercise , three fundamental questions arise: which is the most appropriate, how many weekly sessions we need and, above all, when we will see some effect. The best option is the circuits in which four or five different types of activities alternate with rest periods between series and series . Coaches say that without killing themselves and choosing the activity table, the body will notice in 66 days.
Plan the session; Exhausting is not a guarantee of good results
 
What is better, to train strength or resistance? We are facing the eternal question when it comes to exercising. We arise because we have little time in day to day and we want, logically, to get the most out of our activity. But choosing between both is a wrong view, since it leads us in most cases to the mistake of hitting an aerobic bludgeon, thinking that with it we will burn more fats , or routines with a lot of weight in order to gain more muscle.
 
The reality is that people who manage to train continuously do so on average twice a week and no more than forty minutes each time . With this average, if we want to generate significant changes in our body to improve health and aesthetics, we have to change our perspective. By focusing one day on muscle mass and another on aerobic exercises, the stimulus to which the body is subjected is insignificant, even if we end up exhausted.
The reason is that the organism does not know if it runs in front of a lion to survive - and is making an extra effort for it - or if it trains for a healthy goal. So, if you are sitting for eight hours or so many hours standing up and suddenly an intense and unordered physical activity is imposed, your tendency will be to protect yourself. It will neither burn more fat, nor generate more muscle; on the contrary, it will try to reserve itself and spend as little as possible, in case the effort is prolonged in time. Your reaction is biologically logical.
 
So, what is the ideal dynamic? The answer is very simple: combine the two modalities in the same session or at different times but within the same day. The professionals call it concurrent training. However, after answering the first question, at least two more questions arise. The first: how much time is necessary to use to notice significant changes in the body? And the second: how to combine strength and resistance exercises in each session?
 
The magic figure: nine and a half weeks
 
The University College of London sets at 66 the days necessary to generate or change a habit or to achieve the goal that we set. You rarely get to the ten weeks of training followed. Most of us move by peaks of intensity. There are two periods that are key: the beginning of the year, when many people join a gym or start running; and towards the month of May, coinciding with the fact that the first hot days make us see summer around the corner.
Many coaches propose that we divide our goals into blocks of 66 days. This will not only help us see results, but also motivate us with a goal that has a beginning and an end. Once you have made the decision, you have to plan the exercise with realism. How much time do I train? The American College of Sports Medicine (ACSM) recommends at least 150 minutes of moderate intensity exercise every week spread over five days - a half hour a day - or three sessions of between twenty minutes and one hour of vigorous activity .
 
This is ideal, however, the perfect dose is one that is compatible with the activities of daily and working life in the medium and long term. To achieve the goal, you have to be practical. Therefore, every session we take, even if it is ten minutes, should be used to the maximum and have all the necessary components so that our health improves little by little.
A circuit with which we could start today would be this:
 
1) 200 meters running or walking ;
 
2) Ten squats;
 
3) Eight push-ups.
 
4) Six vertical jumps and return to run or walk 200 meters.
 
We should do it twice, with thirty seconds of rest between each exercise and two minutes of rest between circuit and circuit. The training lasts between twenty-five and thirty minutes.

Plan the session; Exhausting is not a guarantee of good results
 
What is better, to train strength or resistance? We are facing the eternal question when it comes to exercising. We arise because we have little time in day to day and we want, logically, to get the most out of our activity. But choosing between both is a wrong view, since it leads us in most cases to the mistake of hitting an aerobic bludgeon, thinking that with it we will burn more fats , or routines with a lot of weight in order to gain more muscle.
 
The reality is that people who manage to train continuously do so on average twice a week and no more than forty minutes each time . With this average, if we want to generate significant changes in our body to improve health and aesthetics, we have to change our perspective. By focusing one day on muscle mass and another on aerobic exercises, the stimulus to which the body is subjected is insignificant, even if we end up exhausted.
The reason is that the organism does not know if it runs in front of a lion to survive - and is making an extra effort for it - or if it trains for a healthy goal. So, if you are sitting for eight hours or so many hours standing up and suddenly an intense and unordered physical activity is imposed, your tendency will be to protect yourself. It will neither burn more fat, nor generate more muscle; on the contrary, it will try to reserve itself and spend as little as possible, in case the effort is prolonged in time. Your reaction is biologically logical.
 
So, what is the ideal dynamic? The answer is very simple: combine the two modalities in the same session or at different times but within the same day. The professionals call it concurrent training. However, after answering the first question, at least two more questions arise. The first: how much time is necessary to use to notice significant changes in the body? And the second: how to combine strength and resistance exercises in each session?
 
The magic figure: nine and a half weeks
 
The University College of London sets at 66 the days necessary to generate or change a habit or to achieve the goal that we set. You rarely get to the ten weeks of training followed. Most of us move by peaks of intensity. There are two periods that are key: the beginning of the year, when many people join a gym or start running; and towards the month of May, coinciding with the fact that the first hot days make us see summer around the corner.
Many coaches propose that we divide our goals into blocks of 66 days. This will not only help us see results, but also motivate us with a goal that has a beginning and an end. Once you have made the decision, you have to plan the exercise with realism. How much time do I train? The American College of Sports Medicine (ACSM) recommends at least 150 minutes of moderate intensity exercise every week spread over five days - a half hour a day - or three sessions of between twenty minutes and one hour of vigorous activity .
 
This is ideal, however, the perfect dose is one that is compatible with the activities of daily and working life in the medium and long term. To achieve the goal, you have to be practical. Therefore, every session we take, even if it is ten minutes, should be used to the maximum and have all the necessary components so that our health improves little by little.
A circuit with which we could start today would be this:
 
1) 200 meters running or walking ;
 
2) Ten squats;
 
3) Eight push-ups.
 
4) Six vertical jumps and return to run or walk 200 meters.
 
We should do it twice, with thirty seconds of rest between each exercise and two minutes of rest between circuit and circuit. The training lasts between twenty-five and thirty minutes.

title: Is a morning gym workout better than an evening gym workout?
article:
Let’s consider the advantages of both of them.
 
Working out in the A.M.
Consistency
: For some people, working out in the A.M. helps with consistency. This is because early in the morning is usually devoid of sudden commitments. Compare this to afternoon and evening workouts, when responsibilities may arise. Furthermore, a full day’s work can take a toll on our willpower, thus deterring us from going to the gym.
Better sleep
: Since exercise increases heart rate and body temperature, working out too late in the evening (generally after 8 p.m.) may disrupt sleep. On the other hand, one study showed t
Continue Reading
Let’s consider the advantages of both of them.
 
Working out in the A.M.
Consistency
: For some people, working out in the A.M. helps with consistency. This is because early in the morning is usually devoid of sudden commitments. Compare this to afternoon and evening workouts, when responsibilities may arise. Furthermore, a full day’s work can take a toll on our willpower, thus deterring us from going to the gym.
Better sleep
: Since exercise increases heart rate and body temperature, working out too late in the evening (generally after 8 p.m.) may disrupt sleep. On the other hand, one study showed that working out at 7 a.m. (compared to 1 p.m. or 7 p.m.) may help people sleep more soundly at night.
Avoiding crowds: 
Fitness centers see the most traffic between 5 and 8 p.m., making it difficult to get the machine or group fitness class you really want. Mornings see less traffic, making A.M. workouts more efficient. Furthermore, early morning gym-goers tend to get in and get out within a fixed amount of time, leaving no room for socialization and clogging up the gym floor.
Starting the day right:
 When you start a daily routine with exercise, you are more likely to set yourself up for a healthy domino effect throughout the day. Say, for example, you start the day at the gym. This is often followed by a healthy post-workout shake or snack and an increased water intake all morning long. Getting your workout in the morning makes it easier to incorporate a balanced breakfast into your schedule, setting you up for a day of healthy eating.
Working out in the P.M.
Strength:
 If you are not a morning person, then you will definitely have more strength working out in the afternoon or the evening. After all, if you struggle to wake up in the first place, working out in the morning can result in the inability to concentrate (and injury!), which will decrease workout quality. On the opposite side of the coin, an individual who works out later in the day has the opportunity to eat and fuel his body for a tough workout.
Stress relief: 
Many people see exercise as a way to express their pent up stress throughout the day. Having an outlet, such as a kickboxing or personal training, at the end of the workday can provide a healthy way to release daily stresses.
Accountability: 
It’s generally easier to find a workout partner or personal trainer who is willing to meet you for an afternoon or evening workout than one who’s up for a 5 or A.M. weightlifting session.
Availability:
 While it is true that avoiding the crowds is a plus for many early morning gym-goers, the exact same reason can be a negative for other individuals. Gyms offer a larger variety of classes after work than in the morning hours. Plus, a packed post-work class may push you to compete against fellow gym-goers and work harder to get the most from your routine.
What about RESULTS?
 
In terms of results, current studies suggest that 
working out in the morning or in the evening can work just as well
, depending on the individual. 
It all comes down to workout quality and performance.
 
After all, the advantages of working out in the morning vs evening all comes down to personal preference. 
The most objective parameter is your individual performance
. Other than that, no substantial research suggests that one is definitely better than the other.
 
So what should you do if you want to workout in the morning?
 
You should workout in the morning if:
You are a morning person. I.e. you feel energized and fresh enough early in the morning.
You feel fine working out in a fasted state. While you can still consume your pre-workout supplement, generally people who work out in the morning opt to have a proper breakfast after their workout session.
You should workout in the afternoon or evening if:
You are not a morning person.
Your performance is impaired when training with an empty stomach. Indeed, most individuals find they perform better in the evening because they had a chance to get some meals in earlier in the day.
Discovering which one works best for you is easy: try both, and see how your body reacts in comparison. Good luck :D

title: What is a good at home workout routine for intermediate beginners?
article:
Really try to stick to the basics is what I’d say. Here is my list of 5 exercises everyone, not just beginners, should do to help with fundamentals for more complicated lifts.
Push Ups - Push Ups are the bread and butter of any calisthenics/fitness oriented workout. Doing pushups will help your ability to bench press correctly and they are great for strengthening your back 
IF YOU DO THEM CORRECTLY! 
I recommend starting at a 3 x 15 but if you can only do 3 x 10, we all have to start somewhere. If you can already do 3 x 20 or 3 x 25, do that instead. I am doing 3 x 50, trying to get to 4 x 50.
Bod
Continue Reading
Really try to stick to the basics is what I’d say. Here is my list of 5 exercises everyone, not just beginners, should do to help with fundamentals for more complicated lifts.
Push Ups - Push Ups are the bread and butter of any calisthenics/fitness oriented workout. Doing pushups will help your ability to bench press correctly and they are great for strengthening your back 
IF YOU DO THEM CORRECTLY! 
I recommend starting at a 3 x 15 but if you can only do 3 x 10, we all have to start somewhere. If you can already do 3 x 20 or 3 x 25, do that instead. I am doing 3 x 50, trying to get to 4 x 50.
Bodyweight squats - I know, bodyweight for anything isn’t as flashy as “LiFtInG mAd WeIgHtS bRo” but bodyweight squats, when done for high reps, will help strengthen and tone your quads which will then help when you actually perform squats with a higher weight. I personally do 3 x 40 for these but I’d start at 3 x 20 or 3 x 25 for someone just starting.
Calf Raises - These can be done with bodyweight, dumbbells, or the machine at the gym. All 3 work great and unless you’re a neanderthal and don’t stretch beforehand, you shouldn’t get hurt doing these. These help with strengthening your calves (no shit) which will help with running for athletes and overall, aesthetically, I have had my calves commented on just as much as my upper body. I do 3 x 15 for these on the machine, but I load up the weight to 290 lbs. For bodyweight, I do around 3 x 30.
Bench Press - Bench press is probably the most common staple of any chest workout and for good reason. It not only helps with delivering a good pump to the pecs but it also seems to help with filling out the shoulders which for a lot of skinny guys working out is a huge plus. Dumbbells are great to start with as they teach balance and force you to use your pecs and not just your triceps and forearms to lift them. I do either 2 x 8 for this with 225 lbs or 3 x 12 with 165 pounds. I would start with a basic 3 x 10 with whatever weight you can do safely as a beginner.
Deadlifts - Holy shit start light with this. People watch strongmen deadlift 1,000 pounds and they're like “Oh if they can do that then 300 is a breeze for me”. THAT IS THE WRONG APPROACH TO ANY WORKOUT LET ALONE ONE THAT CAN REALLY FUCK YOU UP IF YOU DO IT WRONG! This strengthens your back, core, quads, and triceps among many other muscles when done right. I do this 3 x 5 with 405 pounds. I have been doing these for 5 years though and have built up to that. Start at 135 pounds and do high reps to get your form down. There is no shame in doing these, or frankly any workout, with a coach or trainer to get your form down. Safety is more important than “MaD gAiNz BrO”.
This is not a definitive list and I am not a medical doctor or professional trainer. This is how I was trained for lacrosse and it has worked pretty well for me functionally and aesthetically ever since. Granted there are other workouts like curls that I mostly do to have some “flashy” muscle but otherwise, my workout is based around cardio endurance, strength, and being able to react quickly (which is more of a stretching thing but that’s a different topic for another time).
 
First and foremost, workout to be healthy. Don’t try to be a pro bodybuilder unless you understand what it takes. By that I mean, are you willing to do steroids? Are you willing to eat waaaayyyyyy too much protein than is healthy? Are you willing to give up hours upon hours of time chasing a fleeting feeling that will never satisfy you even if you are the best in the world? If you can answer all of those with yes honestly the fine, you know the risks and that’s that.
 
(BTW not knocking bodybuilders at all. Half of my lifting buddies are bodybuilders and they are some of the coolest people I know. It takes years of hard work, even with steroids, to get to that level. I can’t do bodybuilding because of my health as I already have high Test levels and I really don’t want to fuck with that. Also, my family is predisposed for heart complications and I have no desire to die at the age of 45 as my mom did from a heart attack).
 
Hope this helps,
 
Ben

title: How to workout
article:
Best Exercises
 
If you are not an athlete or even hard exerciser, and you only need to work out to your wellbeing or to fit on your clothing better, then the gym landscape could be overwhelming and intimidating.
 
Just needing to walk by treadmills, stationary bikes, and weight machines may be sufficient to cause you to head back into the sofa.
 
A number of the very best physical tasks for your body do not need the fitness center or request that you get healthy enough to run a marathon. All these"workouts" may work great things for your health. They will keep your weight in check, improve your balanc
Continue Reading
Best Exercises
 
If you are not an athlete or even hard exerciser, and you only need to work out to your wellbeing or to fit on your clothing better, then the gym landscape could be overwhelming and intimidating.
 
Just needing to walk by treadmills, stationary bikes, and weight machines may be sufficient to cause you to head back into the sofa.
 
A number of the very best physical tasks for your body do not need the fitness center or request that you get healthy enough to run a marathon. All these"workouts" may work great things for your health. They will keep your weight in check, improve your balance and range of motion, strengthen your muscles, protect your muscles, stop bladder control issues, and also ward off memory loss.
 
Independent of your age or fitness level, these actions are a Few of the very best exercises that you can do and can Help You to Get in shape and Decrease Your risk for disorder:
 
1. Swimming
You may call swimming the ideal workout.
 
Studies have discovered that swimming may also enhance your mental condition and set you in a much better mood. Water Resistant is another choice.
 
2. Tai chi
A combination of movement and comfort is perfect for the mind and body. In reality, Tai chi is a Chinese martial art that has been known as"meditation in movement." Since the courses are offered at different degrees, tai chi is available - and beneficial - for everybody and every age and fitness levels. "It is especially great for elderly people because equilibrium is a significant part of fitness, and equilibrium is something we lose as we age," Dr. Lee says.
 
Have a course that will assist you to get started and find out the appropriate form. It is possible to locate tai chi apps at the regional YMCA, gym, community center, or senior center.
 
3. Strength training
Lifting light weights will not bulk up your muscles, but it is going to keep them strong. "If you do not use muscles, then they will lose their power over time," Dr. Lee says.
 
Comparable to additional exercise, strength training might also help maintain brain function in later decades.
 
Before beginning a weight training program, make sure you learn the appropriate form. Start mild, with only a couple of lbs. You ought to be able to lift the weights 10 days easily. After a few weeks, raise this by a pound or 2. If you're able to easily lift the weights through the whole selection of movement over 12 days, then move up to marginally heavier weight.
 
4. Walking
Walking is easy yet secure. Additionally, it can help you keep lean, enhance cholesterol levels, fortify bones, and keep blood pressure in check, raise your mood, and decrease your risk for any range of diseases (diabetes and cardiovascular disease, by way of instance ). A variety of studies have revealed that walking and other physical actions can even enhance memory and withstand age-related memory reduction.
 
All you will need is a well-fitting and inviting pair of sneakers. Begin with walking for approximately 10 to15 minutes at one time. As time passes, you may begin to walk further and faster, until you are walking for 30 to 60 minutes most days of this week.
 
5. Kegel exercises
These exercises will not allow you to look better. However, they do something equally as significant -- strengthen the pelvic floor muscles which support the bladder. Strong pelvic floor muscles may go a long way toward preventing puberty. When many women are acquainted with Kegels, these exercises may benefit guys also.
 
Squeeze the muscles you would like to stop yourself from passing gas or urine is the best way to do a Kegel exercise properly. Hold the contraction for a couple of seconds, then release. Be sure that you completely relax your pelvic floor muscles following the decrease. Attempt to perform four to five places every day.
 
Raking the lawn counts as physical activity. So does ballroom dance and playing with your children or grandkids. Provided that you are doing some aerobic exercise for at least 30 minutes each day, and you also comprise two weeks of strength training each week, you may consider yourself a "busy" individual.

After a few weeks, raise this by a pound or 2. If you're able to easily lift the weights through the whole selection of movement over 12 days, then move up to marginally heavier weight.
 
4. Walking
Walking is easy yet secure. Additionally, it can help you keep lean, enhance cholesterol levels, fortify bones, and keep blood pressure in check, raise your mood, and decrease your risk for any range of diseases (diabetes and cardiovascular disease, by way of instance ). A variety of studies have revealed that walking and other physical actions can even enhance memory and withstand age-related memory reduction.
 
All you will need is a well-fitting and inviting pair of sneakers. Begin with walking for approximately 10 to15 minutes at one time. As time passes, you may begin to walk further and faster, until you are walking for 30 to 60 minutes most days of this week.
 
5. Kegel exercises
These exercises will not allow you to look better. However, they do something equally as significant -- strengthen the pelvic floor muscles which support the bladder. Strong pelvic floor muscles may go a long way toward preventing puberty. When many women are acquainted with Kegels, these exercises may benefit guys also.
 
Squeeze the muscles you would like to stop yourself from passing gas or urine is the best way to do a Kegel exercise properly. Hold the contraction for a couple of seconds, then release. Be sure that you completely relax your pelvic floor muscles following the decrease. Attempt to perform four to five places every day.
 
Raking the lawn counts as physical activity. So does ballroom dance and playing with your children or grandkids. Provided that you are doing some aerobic exercise for at least 30 minutes each day, and you also comprise two weeks of strength training each week, you may consider yourself a "busy" individual.

 sandwich ingredient? Well, that depends on what you’re looking for—flavor, health, or just pure yumminess. Continue Reading
Hey there! Sandwiches are one of the best things ever, right? They’re quick, easy, and you can pack them with all kinds of delicious and nutritious ingredients. But what’s the 
best
 sandwich ingredient? Well, that depends on what you’re looking for—flavor, health, or just pure yumminess. Instead of writing about my favorite ingredients, I shared detailed information about sandwiches so you can decide what you want to include in your own creation. Let’s dive into some top picks for building the ultimate sandwich!
1. The Protein Powerhouse
 
Every great sandwich needs a good protein. Protein keeps you full and helps build and repair your muscles. Here are some all-star options:
Grilled Chicken or Turkey:
 Lean and flavorful, these options are perfect for a light, healthy sandwich. Add some mustard or avocado for extra zing!
Eggs:
 Hard-boiled or scrambled, eggs are a classic. They’re rich in protein and vitamins, and they go well with almost anything.
Plant-Based Proteins:
 For veggie lovers, try hummus, tempeh, or even smashed chickpeas. These options are not just healthy but also super satisfying.
2. The Creamy Spread
 
No sandwich is complete without a spread to tie everything together. Choose something that adds flavor without piling on empty calories:
Avocado:
 Creamy, delicious, and full of healthy fats. It’s a great substitute for butter or mayo. Mash it up with a little salt and pepper for a spread you’ll love.
Hummus:
 A fantastic plant-based option that’s rich in protein and fiber. It comes in different flavors, so you can mix things up—roasted red pepper, garlic, or plain.
Greek Yogurt Spread:
 Mix plain Greek yogurt with herbs and spices for a tangy, creamy spread. It’s lower in fat than mayo and tastes amazing.
3. The Crunch Factor
 
You can’t skip the crunch! It’s the texture that makes every bite exciting. Here are some ideas to keep things interesting:
Leafy Greens:
 Romaine lettuce, spinach, or arugula adds freshness and a satisfying crunch. Plus, they’re packed with vitamins and antioxidants.
Thinly Sliced Veggies:
 Cucumber, bell peppers, and carrots are perfect for adding crunch and color. Bonus: they’re super hydrating and low in calories.
Pickles:
 For a tangy twist, add pickles or banana peppers. They give your sandwich a zesty kick!
4. The Cheesy Touch
 
If you’re a cheese lover, this is your time to shine. A little cheese goes a long way to add creaminess and flavor:
Sliced Cheddar or Swiss:
 Classic choices that melt beautifully if you’re making a toasted sandwich.
Feta or Goat Cheese:
 These crumbly cheeses add a tangy, gourmet vibe to your sandwich.
Vegan Cheese:
 There are great plant-based cheese options out there if you’re avoiding dairy.
5. The Secret Ingredient
 
Every sandwich needs that one thing that takes it to the next level. Here are some game-changers:
Pesto:
 Spread a thin layer of pesto for a burst of herby flavor. It’s especially great with chicken or roasted veggies.
Sriracha or Hot Sauce:
 Add a little heat to wake up your taste buds. Just a drizzle will do!
Fruits:
 Yes, fruits! Sliced apples, pears, or even dried cranberries can add a sweet contrast to savory ingredients.
How to Build the Perfect Sandwich
 
Now that you’ve got all these amazing ingredients to choose from, here’s how to put it all together:
Start with a base: whole-grain bread, a wrap, or even a lettuce leaf for a low-carb option.
Add your protein: pick your favorite meat, eggs, or plant-based protein.
Layer on the veggies: the more color, the better!
Spread it out: choose a healthy spread like hummus or avocado.
Finish strong: sprinkle on cheese, nuts, or that secret ingredient to make it truly yours.
The Bottom Line
 
The best sandwich ingredient is the one that makes you excited to eat your meal! Whether you’re in the mood for creamy avocado, crunchy veggies, or flavorful pesto, there are so many ways to create a healthy, delicious sandwich that’s totally your style.
 
So go ahead, get creative, and build a sandwich that’s not just a meal—it’s an experience. Enjoy! 😊

title: Are there any poor people on Quora, as Internet access is very cheap nowadays?
article:
there are lots of poor people on quora.
 
you can tell because they use smart phones instead of computers.
 
they rarely take the extra effort phones appear to require to answer questions without simply streaming a continuous line of text with no structure except punctuation…
 
sure, wealthy folks use smart phones too, but the poor people are still there too.
 
our marriage stole all of our wealth when our ex ran up credit cards we couldn’t pay off…
 
now we’re about as poor as it comes without being back on the streets again.
 
we support our girlfriend of fifteen years because we need help with day-to-day thi
Continue Reading
there are lots of poor people on quora.
 
you can tell because they use smart phones instead of computers.
 
they rarely take the extra effort phones appear to require to answer questions without simply streaming a continuous line of text with no structure except punctuation…
 
sure, wealthy folks use smart phones too, but the poor people are still there too.
 
our marriage stole all of our wealth when our ex ran up credit cards we couldn’t pay off…
 
now we’re about as poor as it comes without being back on the streets again.
 
we support our girlfriend of fifteen years because we need help with day-to-day things and she is a disabled nurse who is now barely able to work in any capacity.
 
she sells her blood when things get really bad like now.
 
we can’t sell our blood, there are too many blood thinners in it.
 
we live in constant fear of that one incident that leaves us homeless because we live from one disability payment to the next with no disposable income to save for a rainy day.
 
quora is where we amuse ourselves as best we can while living in pain every day for the past forty-three years because there are no safe medications to help us with our pain.
 
because we cannot afford both a smart phone and an internet service provider, and because we cannot operate a phone due to its tiny size, our poor eyesight, and our crippled hands, we have only our isp.
 
with our computer it is much easier to type than on a phone and we have built-up our mouse with cardboard to make it fit more comfortably in our hand with a t-wing formation on top that our fingers fit around and below to lift our mouse off the table.
 
our hands would become completely disabled if all we had to work on was a phone.
 
when google, microsoft, yahoo, etc. all went to smart-phone based authentication schemas we had only our girlfriend's phone to use for authentication and that backfired leaving us with no access to any of our original social media accounts.
 
we had to start new accounts and dodge the authentication issue as best we can without a phone.
 
it’s a bit scary.
 
we cannot afford to get the problem fixed, there are far too many hurdles, especially ai help desks.
 
we had an elaborate free private website on weebly that we could scarcely afford to register a personal url for at eighty bucks for five years.
 
when another company bought them out they required a monthly subscription fee of fifteen bucks per month to keep our free account and our paid-for url.
 
so we lost access to our own website on weebly and cannot find it again without our url.
 
we are very poor and therefor marginalized by minor expenses that other people pay without a thought for where the money must come from and what they must do without.
 
we’re doing without much food and with inadequate medication today.
 
we’ll be having ramen again in a little while, just as long as we can stand to wait…
 
because of rent control we can just barely afford to remain where we live.
 
because of rent control our landlord grows more motivated to evict us every year.
 
we are no longer qualified to work in any of the professional capacities we have worked in before.
 
we are far too decrepit to be offered another job, we can scarcely walk.
 
our best skill is now creative writing, but without help we can never finish any of our projects.
 
we hope we will find a writing partner one day, but so far none…
 
quora is a great place for us to find questions that suit our interests and to help us to develop our ideas for our best stories.
 
so far so good, but tomorrow is always in doubt.
 
not even the meals on wheels are reliable, they totally skipped the previous wednesday but only deliver three times a week. wednesday is the only day they provide three meals instead of two.
 
you will note from our punctuation that we are an anti-capitalist.
 
enjoy!
 
-rho…
 
…
 
originally answered…
 
are there any poor people on quora, as Internet access is very cheap nowadays?
