title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
I am from Malta which is an island. I met an American sailor some years ago and he told me that Malta was a city. I told him no it is an island. I can understand many don’t know its existence, I don’t know every land of the world either, but being on an island without knowing it is an island???
 
The rest are online stories from different people.
 
Malta is a very small island compared to other lands, but the word small should not be taken literaly. Once I was telling an American that it takes me an hour by bus to go to school and she replied:” didn’t you tell me that Malta is small?” Sure but that 
Continue Reading
I am from Malta which is an island. I met an American sailor some years ago and he told me that Malta was a city. I told him no it is an island. I can understand many don’t know its existence, I don’t know every land of the world either, but being on an island without knowing it is an island???
 
The rest are online stories from different people.
 
Malta is a very small island compared to other lands, but the word small should not be taken literaly. Once I was telling an American that it takes me an hour by bus to go to school and she replied:” didn’t you tell me that Malta is small?” Sure but that doesn’t mean we don’t take time to go to further places.
 
Another time an American commented on one of my profiles telling me that she heard from a Maltese person that people here all know each other. Thing is, that is a saying we Maltese say, it should not be taken literarly. It is just an expression.
 
Another time I was having a rant about my country, and I received the comment:” I don’t know how you hate Malta, when I was there all I did was partying and go to the beach.” sure because you visited as a tourist you don’t have to live here and pay the bills.
 
Another time I was ranting about the cold, and an American asked me:” isn’t Malta an island?” Hell yeah that doesn’t mean we don’t have seasons. It seems that if Americans know that you live on an island, they think you party all the time and are always in swimsuits; sipping pina colada with flowers in your hair. Yeah right…
 
Another time I wrote a long comment on a post. I wrote that English is not my native language so my English might not be that clear and that I had grammar and spelling issues. Guess what happened? An American left me a rude comment about my grammar and spelling being terrible and called me stupid. *face palm*
 
Another time the opposite happened. An American called me fake because according to him my English was too good for a foreigner. Whaaat????
 
A pet peeve of mine that I have about Americans is when online they write:”this country”, while actually referring to the whole world. Please Americans the internet is used globaly by anyone not just Americans. I hate it when you talk about the world like it is only made up of America. Not part of the question but damn.
 
Then I have these pet peeves which happen by people of all countries. It is not part of the question either but I hate it when it happens. 1. Yes we have our own language. It is Maltese and is an unique language spoken in the Maltese islands. It is not English, Italian, French or Spanish. (Ok English is now accepted as a main language too, but primarly for most of us it is Maltese. )2. Yes we are an archipelago of islands. Malta being the main one. 3. No don’t use google translate to talk to me. That stuff isn’t accurate. 4. Malta is in Europe and part if the European Union. No it’s not in Africa. 5. We have our flag, our government, our independance. No we aren’t part of the British colony anymore, like many Brits seem to think. 6. Italians please not everyone here knows Italian. 7. For the rest of the world, sorry not all of us speak English fluently, it is still considered a foreign language for most of us. 8. Don’t treat me like stupid or ridicule me because I come from a place you didn’t know its existance or trying to fool me because I am a foreigner.

title: What is the best workout routine to follow?
article:
The best workout routine for you is the one you will stick with and still get a good workout.
 
I think the elements of a great workout routine are broken down into-
 
the goal, time, friction, the actual workout itself, and rest. 
 
Here's what I mean and here's what's working for me.
 
Pick one goal. 
As with most things in life, if you pick too many workout goals you'll suck at all of them.
 
For me the goal is cardio. I want a healthier heart, lungs and body.
 
I have some ancillary goals about losing weight, loosen my leg and back muscles and strengthen my back. But my workout right now already helps with a
Continue Reading
The best workout routine for you is the one you will stick with and still get a good workout.
 
I think the elements of a great workout routine are broken down into-
 
the goal, time, friction, the actual workout itself, and rest. 
 
Here's what I mean and here's what's working for me.
 
Pick one goal. 
As with most things in life, if you pick too many workout goals you'll suck at all of them.
 
For me the goal is cardio. I want a healthier heart, lungs and body.
 
I have some ancillary goals about losing weight, loosen my leg and back muscles and strengthen my back. But my workout right now already helps with a lot of those.
 
So, really, I just focus on working up a good sweat. 
 
Time
. I just go in the morning now. No excuses. I don't do ridiculous 6am video conferences or calls anymore (some of the folks I work with are in Singapore, Russia, Bangalore, etc.) 
 
Cut Friction
. Within 10 minutes of waking up I'm in my gym clothes. I keep my key, headphones, water bottle and iPad near the front door so I take them all as I head out to the gym. Same thing if you run or walk to workout.
 
I think the reason so few folks swim or bike for exercise anymore is because of the friction. You have to wear special apparel, shower after and wash out the chlorine (another reason why saltwater pools are much better), and then soak your bathing suit, swim cap, googles in water to get the chlorine out, etc.
 
Unless you work from home, try having two gyms you like - one near work and another near home. In each case, pick the gyms closest to you that you will actually work out in. 
 
I had a home elliptical and a gym 10 feet from my doorstep. I didn't use either much. Now I work out daily because I like my gym and figured out a routine.
 
When I worked in New York, I had two gyms - a free one a work and an Equinox across the street from my home for which I had a work discount. I used both a lot. At one point, the trainer at the work gym said "Terrence, you don't need to come every day." I worked out a lot sometimes. I joined the Reebok gym briefly but it was too far. So even though it was even nicer than Equinox, I worked out more at Equinox.
 
The Workout
. Here's what works for me. I do the 15% max incline on the treadmill in our building's gym. I listen to music, use my iPad and have a water bottle. I do between 20 min to 4 hours of cardio a day, depending. Average is probably 80 minutes. 
 
Why do I do a 15% incline? Because it is less strain on my knees and back to walk uphill than to run at 0-2% incline. And I can do stuff on my iPad while I'm walking.
 
Almost anyone can do this workout. It is super easy. And you can make it hard. Just walk much faster and longer and you'll get a pretty good workout after awhile.
 
I keep track of my heart rate so its between fat burn and a good burn but not dangerous. Then I try to stretch or lift weights. High reps, low weight. I'm trying to avoid injury so easing into weights. Once I build this into a habit, I will switch it up a bit and do stationary bike, stair climbing, rowing, etc. 
 
Rest. 
I take Saturdays off. Mostly because I get up at 5.30am every Saturday to hop on a plane. So I'm already a bit exhausted on most Saturdays. But also partly to stay sane and reward myself. And build a routine I will stick with.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
There we were, my wife, my daughters and and myself, at a limestone cave in southern Oregon. The cave was open for touring - for an entry fee. I paid cash and included an American nickel in my payment. The young lady behind the counter looked closely (obviously not closely enough) and asked "what's this? I'm not accepting this!"
 
I also looked closely and saw that it had "E Pluribus Unum", "United States of America" and "In God We Trust" on it. So in answer to her question, I told her it was an American nickel. She repeated that she wasn't going to accept it and I asked her .. "It says "United S
Continue Reading
There we were, my wife, my daughters and and myself, at a limestone cave in southern Oregon. The cave was open for touring - for an entry fee. I paid cash and included an American nickel in my payment. The young lady behind the counter looked closely (obviously not closely enough) and asked "what's this? I'm not accepting this!"
 
I also looked closely and saw that it had "E Pluribus Unum", "United States of America" and "In God We Trust" on it. So in answer to her question, I told her it was an American nickel. She repeated that she wasn't going to accept it and I asked her .. "It says "United States of America. This IS the United States of America, isn't it?"
 
However, for several reasons, I gave up:
 
- she was an idiot, and usually, there is little to be gained by arguing with idiots,
 
- it was only a nickel and I was able to replace it with another nickel - not worth making a scene over it,
 
- finally and most importantly, it turned out she was also our guide in that very dark cave and perhaps, even if she was an idiot, it wouldn't have been a good idea to unnecessarily antagonize her.
 
Edited; comment added, a week later: I also met another ignoramus.
 
I had an email friend, who I shall call "Granny" from the deep south of the US. I knew she was something of a cranky, ignorant redneck and my children asked me why I would bother to correspond with her? Because she is like a LOT of people out there, and I wanted to try to see and understand the world through lenses which were different than those I usually use (my own).
 
Oh, she was interesting, all right .. if ever some subject came up about politicians, she'd go on a several page rant about them, calling them every name in the book. I'm not sure she knew the meaning of the term "moderation"; at least, she almost never used it. And ignorant? When my Mom was in her mid-80's, she had a series of small strokes and Granny implied it was my fault for not feeding her all sorts of energy foods that you usually see in those scam ads. As it was, my Mom lived to 89; the average lifespan for women in the US is 82.1, so she certainly wasn't taken from us prematurely.
 
This went on for some years .. sometimes I'd tiptoe around her, sometimes, I'd invite a response and would never be disappointed. This carried on until she sent a note and copied several people, whereupon I and one other man on that list had the gall, the temerity, to respond with some of our own comments to the group she identified. Here is the first line of her reply: "
I do not remembe giving either one of you male atheist permission to rape the addresses of my livery
" [sic]. Then she went on to say how she wished she could castrate me, plus a series of other equally vicious comments. And how is it that I still have that quote? Because her response was so incredible, I copied her letter into my diary file, before I deleted all her email and her address. I haven’t heard from her since (18 months and counting), don’t expect to, but wouldn’t respond to her anyway.
 
Granny was a cranky, unhappy old woman who have obviously burned enough people in her life that she complained about not having many friends. It was my understanding that she was estranged even from her daughter; gee, I wonder why?

title: Is a morning gym workout better than an evening gym workout?
article:
You ever see a snowball start at the top of a hill the size of an orange, roll down, and knock over something bigger than a house?
 
I have.
Mama Mia!
 
In all seriousness, research shows there is no better time of day physiologically to workout. Some studies point to more strength in the evening. While others say working out in the morning on an empty stomach boosts fat burning. Either way, there is no scientific consensus about which time of day is better to workout.
 
However, working out in the morning has extreme psychological, financial, and time advantages. 
You may start the size of an orange, bu
Continue Reading
You ever see a snowball start at the top of a hill the size of an orange, roll down, and knock over something bigger than a house?
 
I have.
Mama Mia!
 
In all seriousness, research shows there is no better time of day physiologically to workout. Some studies point to more strength in the evening. While others say working out in the morning on an empty stomach boosts fat burning. Either way, there is no scientific consensus about which time of day is better to workout.
 
However, working out in the morning has extreme psychological, financial, and time advantages. 
You may start the size of an orange, but with these advantages, working out in the morning will have you knocking over Bowser-sized barriers.
You will start your work day knowing you have accomplished more than everyone else at the office. The increased confidence will carry over into your work and promotions will come more easily earning you sizably more income over time.
You will begin showering at the gym saving money on your water bill. You will buy less toilet paper because you’re more…
regular
 at work. Also, by leaving the house earlier you can set your thermostat to kick into energy savings mode earlier, which also saves you money.
You see just how sluggish your coworkers are in the first few hours of every day. You are able to run laps around them in terms of production in the first few hours. In morning meetings you are sharper than everyone else and can impress your boss when he too is likely not thinking as clearly yet.
You have no distractions keeping you from working out in the morning like you normally do in the evening. No emails to answer. No kids to deal with. No projects to finish. No spur of the moment coworker happy hours to keep you from working out.
Your work clothes will fit a little tighter or a little looser in all the right places giving you even more confidence.
You won’t feel as guilty about eating that piece of birthday cake someone brought to the office because you’ve already burned your calories in the morning.
You will have more truly free time after work do do whatever you want. No more feeling guilty for skipping a workout to join friends for dinner.
You will no longer have that nagging, itching pain of tired eyes in the morning. (If you don’t think you have this pain, you are probably so accustomed to it you don’t even know it exists. Try working out in the morning for a week.)
You are more likely to eat healthier throughout the day because you don’t want to waste a workout you’ve already done.
You will actually have more energy and motivation throughout the day due to an increased loci of control.
You will find yourself able to ditch your morning coffee because of the endorphins released from working out. This will save you a ton of money over time.
You will be surrounded by other like minded, success oriented people at the gym in the morning. You will meet some of these people and make more valuable connections. One of these connections might lead to a better job or business opportunity.
Workout in the evening or in the morning. Physically you will not see much of a difference.
 
But if you want to become a giant snowball and knock over Bowser…
 
Workout in the morning!

title: Is running every day better than going to the gym every day?
article:
I've been running every day since May 24, 2021 (today was Day 481). It has been a journey to get here.
When I started running, 
I didn't think it was possible or healthy
 to run every day. Common wisdom in the running community says to take at least one rest day each week.
 
I think that common wisdom is healthy for anyone starting their journey, but 
once you have been running for years, it becomes harder mentally to take a complete rest day
 than to keep moving and doing some sort of active recovery (walking, cycling, etc.).
 
Anyway, the person who caused me to reconsider this after many years of runn
Continue Reading
I've been running every day since May 24, 2021 (today was Day 481). It has been a journey to get here.
When I started running, 
I didn't think it was possible or healthy
 to run every day. Common wisdom in the running community says to take at least one rest day each week.
 
I think that common wisdom is healthy for anyone starting their journey, but 
once you have been running for years, it becomes harder mentally to take a complete rest day
 than to keep moving and doing some sort of active recovery (walking, cycling, etc.).
 
Anyway, the person who caused me to reconsider this after many years of running was 
Hellah Sedibe
, who has been 
running every day for more than 5 years!
 
I saw how happy Hellah is being able to do 
what he loves to do every day and sharing his passion with the world
. I love running too and he showed me it is possible. So, I told myself: "One day, every day"
 
Cautionary Tale from my First Attempt:
 
The first time I tried to streak was back in May 2020. Covid-19 shut down all the gyms, so 
running was my routine.
 I was doing well until Day 59 of the streak.
 
That morning, I remember 
feeling physically and mentally exhausted
 before going out the run. My fatigue usually goes away after the first two miles, so I thought I would be good.
 
I was running a different route through my city and side-stepped onto the gravel. My shoe kept sliding right over the gravel and I felt a pop. My ankle turned into a balloon!
 
I could have avoided this misstep if I listened to my body. I was out for a few weeks after that.
 
And so it goes.
 
Why I tried again:
 
I have a strong motivation to 
make fitness an unbreakable habit
. After a few months of not being consistent with exercise, I was tired of making excuses. I decided to run first thing every morning before work.
 
I asked myself three questions:
Why do I want to do this?
 Running is my favorite thing to do. The rush I get after a run helps me get through my day. The days when I wouldn't run I felt off mentally. I want to share that it is possible and inspire people to find a fitness habit that they love to do every day too.
How do I know I can do this?
 I had already been running for a long time. I have a base level of fitness. Covid-19 let me focus more on running and working remotely gave me more time. All I needed to do was balance harder runs with mostly easy recovery runs each week.
What is my minimum?
 One mile a day. Even if I'm traveling or off the routine, I know I can fit one mile in. Make it easy.
Tips that worked for me:
Build a foundation 
of easy running over months or years before you start a run streak and keep easy days easy!
The first 100 days are the challenge
. Each milestone (30, 60, 90, 100, 200, 300, 365 days) gives a huge mental boost to keep going. After 100, it becomes less physical and more mental.
Follow Hellah Sedibe and thousands of runners
 who have been running every day (check out the 4000+ runners streaking on 
runeveryday
 Some have been doing it for 50+ years).
It feels good to start the day with a run. Good luck and stay healthy! 🙏
 
Edit:
 
I just wrote about 
how to exercise every day
 after hitting Day 500. Check it out :)

title: Is a morning gym workout better than an evening gym workout?
article:
For what outcome?
To get bigger muscles?
To get fat off?
To train for endurance running?
To improve sport performance?
To become more flexible?
I could go on. Here are some general tips
Eating before / after is not as essential as people on here believe. That’s because they are not looking at the science of the bidy
Right now as you read Quora the average person has 2,000 ‘‘calories” of stored sugar energy and 40,000 calories of stored fat energy.
 
So with that in mind you’re not really ever short of energy to work out. In fact training in a “fasted state” (that means with no food eaten for at least 12 
Continue Reading
For what outcome?
To get bigger muscles?
To get fat off?
To train for endurance running?
To improve sport performance?
To become more flexible?
I could go on. Here are some general tips
Eating before / after is not as essential as people on here believe. That’s because they are not looking at the science of the bidy
Right now as you read Quora the average person has 2,000 ‘‘calories” of stored sugar energy and 40,000 calories of stored fat energy.
 
So with that in mind you’re not really ever short of energy to work out. In fact training in a “fasted state” (that means with no food eaten for at least 12 hours or more) is probably the 
most beneficial for weight loss.
 
The body has finite storage capacity and will 
never use fat while you still have stored glucose energy (glycogen for those that love the science)
 
It just would not do that.
 
If you are trying to 
build muscle while staying lean 
then you need to keep a close eye on protein. 
High protein is pointless 
(unless your are selling protein shakes and bars!) The body can not store excess protein. Again it’s the body having finite storage capacity. Anything over roughly 2 chicken legs worth of protein per meal is simply going be turned to glucose or even worse; fat. 
So moderate protein intake is required. THERE IS NO BEST TIME TO EAT ONLY BEST TIME TO NOT EAT! 
Leaving at least an hour before and after is best.
 
Sidebar: everyone has heard of human growth hormone, it’s the bodys ‘repair and rebuild’ hormone. When you wake up HGH is high, and lowers when you start eating. If you buzz to the gym and take some water with a pinch of pink Himalayan salt with you then you can workout with the elevated human growth hormone still circulating. The salted water is the best for rehydration.
 
Hydration is often thought of as loss of water, it’s actually loss of electrolytes that’s the issue. Hence the pink salt.
 
Lastly some think water increases metabolic rate. It does, temporarily. But this is only because the body works to bring the temperature of the cold water up to body temperature. If you really want to be geeky about training 
never drink cold water unless it is to bring your temperature down. It’s a 3% lose of workout energy while it raise the water temperature up.
 
It’s really minimal though.
 
But to answer your question in a more basic way
 
The best time to go is when suits you best. All that above might scientifically help but if you FEEL better at night then you’ll probably get more out of it then dragging yourself there reluctantly in the morning.
 
If you don’t mind either then you need to focus on what your goal is. I’m qualified in nutrition for sports performance and exercise. If you have an actual goal just drop me a comment and I’ll answer specifics
 
Step Away From The Carbs: The science behind weight loss, the recipes to make it happen. Beautiful colour photographs of every breakfast, lunch, dinner, snack and even drinks.

title: Is it bad to do full body workouts every day?
article:
Yes it is okay. We are living in a lazy society, so I understand when people disagree. Sitting on computer 8–10 hours a day is somehow okay, but working out everyday is apparently not, while the former is more taxing on your body. Where does this consensus come from? Simple, economy. Working out more than 3-4 times a week doesn't contribute to the economy. You can't draw more people to go to the gym, buy apparel or supplements if you promote daily exercise. You don't spend more money working out than hanging out elsewhere. So you will not only be told that you can achieve your dream body just 
Continue Reading
Yes it is okay. We are living in a lazy society, so I understand when people disagree. Sitting on computer 8–10 hours a day is somehow okay, but working out everyday is apparently not, while the former is more taxing on your body. Where does this consensus come from? Simple, economy. Working out more than 3-4 times a week doesn't contribute to the economy. You can't draw more people to go to the gym, buy apparel or supplements if you promote daily exercise. You don't spend more money working out than hanging out elsewhere. So you will not only be told that you can achieve your dream body just working 2-3 hours a week, but also that your body cannot handle much more. Besides, gym time is still considered a waste, “why” they will tell you, “waste 6-7 days a week at the gym when you could exercise less and enjoy life more?“ Browsing on social media 3 hours a day is considered more normal. It has nothing to do with sports science, it is ideology.
 
Tell me which one is more taxing on the body: Lifting weights where you spend more than 2/3 of your time resting, or an NBA game? Athletes play up to 4 games a week, plus training, you think you cannot handle doing flys, curls, pulldowns, and basic human movements everyday? In all other sports, lifting weights is the supplement to the main sport, and the average gym goer believes s/he has to have full 3-4 rest days a week to maximize benefits and train hard, how pathetic is that? I know those other guys are athletes, it's their job, etc. But we are talking about the capacities of the human body. You can improve your work load capacity. I'm not saying that everyone can or should be an athlete, but an hour of training a day is nowhere close to an athlete's schedule. Athletes typically have up to 15 sessions a week, each around 2.5 hours. Ask olympic weightlifters and they will tell you. Even some bodybuilders, like Jay Cutler, have been known to train twice a day. One of the most respected academicians in sports science, Mike Israetel, also says you can train more than 7 times a week if you have the time and proper schedule that allows for it. Several months ago, he had three sessions a day himself. “Recovery,” in other words, can be handled pretty well.
 
And now people will pull the “natural” card. It is actually the natural lifters who should train as often as possible to increase protein synthesis. You could get away with training each bodypart once a week if you were on steroids, but that's not the case if you are natural. Keep the sessions short and intense, stimulate your muscles and don't annihilate your joints, so you can train the same muscle group as often as possible. That will give you enough weekly volume to grow.
 
And certain muscle groups can be trained almost everyday. Posture muscles (abs, traps), smaller muscles that won't tax your entire body and do not get heavily involved in big compounds (side/rear delts, calves, biceps) can be trained almost everyday. Bigger muscles can be trained 2-4 times a week. If you schedule smartly, it is perfectly fine.
 
Here
 is a good example by Christian Thibaudeau. It is 6 days a week, but you get the idea.

Everybody turned to look at her since not only did we see footage of the wall being torn down, our teacher passed around a fragment of the wall she collected.
 
Another instance with this classm

It would have to be my classmate in high school. There were several precious instances that I vividly remember.
 
The first one that comes to mind was after a 20 minute lecture by our German teacher of the rise and fall of the Berlin War, my classmate raised her hand to ask how people in Berlin travel from east to west if the wall is blocking the way and if people were forced to circle around the whole city. Everybody turned to look at her since not only did we see footage of the wall being torn down, our teacher passed around a fragment of the wall she collected.
 
Another instance with this classmate was when she found out I was from Mexico. She asked me if I spoke Mexican and if it was hard to adjust to riding in a car instead of a donkey cart. I thought at first she was being extremely rude but apparently she thought all of México was like Hollywood depicts it in Western movies.
 
This is about another person in my high school:
 
I was at my desk reading since I had gotten to class early and was still waiting for the teacher to arrive. A group of boys entered and were conversing loudly amongst themselves. The topic they were discussing was their experiences dealing with the foreign exchange students they were hosting. One in particular was boasting how the English students had never tried Mexican cuisine before so in order to introduce them, they took them to Taco Bell…. At hearing this I started cursing under my breath in Spanish which brought my presence to their attention.
 
“Oh, you're like Mexican right? Do you have any good hard shell taco brands you can recommend? My mom wants to cook them a taco casserole.”
 
I blinked slowly and counted in my head.
 
“Hard taco shells are not considered Mexican, they are Tex Mex and no it is not the same thing. Buy white corn tortillas if you want to expose them to Mexican food”
 
I brought them the next day a jar of my mom’s salsa. They told me it was too spicy for them but that it was good.
 
Update:
 
I forgot one more story possibly because it was so embarrassing I tried to block it.
 
I took a swimming class in high school instead of taking regular PE. I grew up taking swimming lessons year round so changing in the locker room without a towel wrapped around me for modesty never occurred to me to do since we were all girls there. As I was pulling my swimsuit over my chest I felt hands grasp my arms and was twisted to face a classmate. She kept staring at my chest, freaking me out. She starts yelling “OMG your nipples are brown!!! I didn't know there were brown nipples! Why aren't your nipples pink? Did you burn them?”
 
This of course brought forth other white girls who wanted to continue to ogle in amazement in nipples of another color.
 
You would've thought that after that I would have changed with a towel wrapped around me but I only had 15 min to dry myself, change and run to the other side of the building for my next class and keeping the towel around you while you try to shimmy with wet legs into skinny jeans is too much of a hassle. By the third day I wasn't (or rather my areolas) a novelty anymore and was able to change in peace.

title: What are the pros and cons of training full-body every day?
article:
Pros:
 
Dumbbells allow for movement asymmetrically and unilaterally, so you can train one limb at a time, or load one side of the body at a time. You can hit the serape sling patterns of movement with more ease this way too.
This allows them to move more freely as well, which allows the arm (the shoulder joint in particular) to move more naturally through rotation (barbells are fixed and tend to beat up on the shoulders/elbows/wrists more)
They arguably provide more exercise selection than barbells as you can asymmetrically load every lift you could do with a barbell to create a new challenge.
They
Continue Reading
Pros:
 
Dumbbells allow for movement asymmetrically and unilaterally, so you can train one limb at a time, or load one side of the body at a time. You can hit the serape sling patterns of movement with more ease this way too.
This allows them to move more freely as well, which allows the arm (the shoulder joint in particular) to move more naturally through rotation (barbells are fixed and tend to beat up on the shoulders/elbows/wrists more)
They arguably provide more exercise selection than barbells as you can asymmetrically load every lift you could do with a barbell to create a new challenge.
They are easier on the shoulders particularly lifting overhead with a neutral style grip (when compared to the barbell military or overhead press). They allow you to get into neutral grips more easily (which also tend to be nicer on the shoulders).
They allow you to train rotational patterns with greater ease (there are landmine exercises you can do with a barbell that are rotational, and you can off-set the loads of barbell to make them more rotationally demanding though)
Bodyweight on it's own often isn't enough because it's a fixed load, once you've adapted to the load you can only do more repetitions (i.e. you can increase endurance but not really strength at that point). Dumbbells will allow you to train closed and open chain movements too.
Dumbbells often let you train with a more natural arc/position
Cons:
 
Barbells let you lift more (which is more important for lower rep, higher intensity lifting) - especially for the major bilateral lifts (you will generally always be able to bench press, squat and deadlift more with a barbell than dumbbells)
Barbells are less grip intensive. Dumbbells require more grip strength (which isn't necessarily a bad thing - it just creates a limiting factor if you want to train strength/power more completely)
Barbells generally allow for better mechanical loading changes with lower body training. i.e. the difference between a back squat (try putting some DB's on your shoulders to see what I mean), a front squat, an overhead squat, and a zercher squat all lead to good training outcomes when used with some variety.
Barbells allow you to alter grip positions differently by leveraging torque (narrow grip bench vs medium grip or wide grip - can yield different training results you won't be able to get with dumbbells).
Kettlebells provide a better grip challenge than dumbbells and are more suited for exercises like the swing
Kettlebells provide a higher proprioceptive stimulus, particularly for explosive lifts
Bands provide a unique stimulus that is generally hardest where people are their strongest (Dumbbells like Barbells are a more fixed weight relative to the human strength curve)
Sleds allow you to more adequately train concentric only patterns, which can be great for not making you too sore between more dynamic lift days and still getting a training effect.
I could probably go on. At the end of the day I think having access to a variety of stimulus is ideal, however, you can still get a lot done with dumbbells and bodyweight if that's your only existing option.

title: How long will it take to get big if doing full body workouts every day with heavy weights?
article:
Recovery ↑
 
Does the effect of 1 or 2 hours a day really affect muscle growth so much as to need in between rest days per muscle group?
 
No you do not need a day rest in between each muscle group. If you train chest on Monday, you can train legs on Tuesday. You do not need a rest day between those muscle groups.
 
If you workout chest on Monday, it would not be a good idea to work it on Tuesday
 
Some people don’t train chest following a shoulder day as the anterior delt will not be recovered enough.
 
Some people will train shoulders and chest together.
 
Many advocate a lower and upper body split.
Monday - L
Continue Reading
Recovery ↑
 
Does the effect of 1 or 2 hours a day really affect muscle growth so much as to need in between rest days per muscle group?
 
No you do not need a day rest in between each muscle group. If you train chest on Monday, you can train legs on Tuesday. You do not need a rest day between those muscle groups.
 
If you workout chest on Monday, it would not be a good idea to work it on Tuesday
 
Some people don’t train chest following a shoulder day as the anterior delt will not be recovered enough.
 
Some people will train shoulders and chest together.
 
Many advocate a lower and upper body split.
Monday - Lower
Tuesday - Upper
Wednesday - Rest
Thursday - Upper
Friday - Lower
Saturday - Rest
Sunday -Upper
Monday - Lower
Tuesday -Rest
This is largely dependent on the person and where they are in their training.
 
Does muscle grow much less efficiently on workout days during the 23 or so hours that you are not working out?
 
No it would not, your body does not know its workout day until you are actually working out. It will keep recovering until you start your workout.
 
Does muscles only grow on rest days?
 
So a simple explanation
 
Anabolic - Creating new tissue, cells or organs.
 
Catabolic
 - 
Break down of cells in your body.
 
Our body can never be in both states at once.
 
Working out = Catabolic
 
We perform resistance training to cause damage to the muscle fibers.
 
This means we enter a catabolic state as we put stress on our body, our body releases these main hormones
Testosterone
Insulin Like growth factor(IGF)
Growth Hormone(GH)
Cortisol
When we are in a catabolic state, our body is breaking down fat and glycogen to be used as energy.
 
Recovery = Anabolic
 
Now that we have caused damaged to the muscle fibers, we begin the process of repairing the muscle fibers. Once the muscle fibers are repaired they increase in size
 
This is muscle hypertrophy.
 
How does it work?
 
Muscle growth occurs whenever the rate of muscle protein synthesis(MPS) is greater than the rate of muscle protein breakdown. Both, the synthesis and breakdown of proteins are controlled by complimentary cellular mechanisms. Resistance exercise can profoundly stimulate muscle cell hypertrophy and the resultant gain in strength. However, the time course for this hypertrophy is relatively slow, generally taking several weeks or months to be apparent
[1]
 
It is generally agreed that resistance exercise results in increased MPS in the postexercise recovery period . Indeed, an acute bout of resistance exercise can increase the rate of MPS about two- to fivefold after exercise, and this effect can persist for up to 48 h in fed subjects 
[2]
 
So given we can only be in one state at a time, muscle building will only start once you are done working out and you are in your recovery phase.
 
Muscle building does not mean just taking a day off from the gym.
 
You also need to pay special attention to these for hypertrophy
Caloric surplus diet with sufficient protein
Adequate sleep
Manage stress levels
Footnotes
[1] 
How Do Muscles Grow?
[2] 
Journal of Applied Physiology

I have met quite a few americans and some became friends. There are two i can honestly say that i was absolutley so lucky to have met them. However, there have been a few i have disliked. The most recent one was very full of both himself and his country. Now, i have no issue with loving your country, hell, i love Britain. But, the issue with this guy is that he would repeatedly mention the independence war and how britain ‘lost’ against them. Once, i can deal with that, but everytime he spoke he would bring it up. He’d always say that “britain used to be ruling over so many colonies and now look” or “if britain ever had the chance i bet they would try and rule the world but fail. However, if america wanted to rule the world they could.” Like, excuse me, i wanted to ask how your days was or hang out and have a friendly chat but no. Your bringing up past wars and trashing other countries such as germany, asian countries, the whole lot. I remember he would always say nasty things towards the french saying that they “suck so bad” and that “britain must suck more because they lost to france”. I heard the ‘brits are coming’ repeatedly. I just wanted to have fun but clearly this guy was the sort to only value his opinion and shut out/but in everyone elses if they disagree.
 
At one time, we were speaking over the phone and playing games.
 
I have never wanted to punch a prick so much. I was speaking to my younger brother whilst he started playing this loud video over the phone, i had to lower the volume considerably because it was some guy spouting nonsense about america being the greatest etc. After he realised i wasn’t paying attention to the video he started playing it a second time. I ignored him again and he asked “did you hear that?” and i replied “no, it was too loud and i was speaking to my brother so i turned you all the way down.” he got quite agitated at that. If verbally abusing other countries wasn’t enough, he also started being sexist, racist and harshly talking to me about anyone who wasn’t straight such as “f****** lesbians” as he put it. I told him to stop, i didn’t like what he was saying one bit. He told me to calm down and that he was only ‘joking’. Im sorry, but everything that came out of his mouth was not funny at all. At the time i had another american friend from texas, he was a great laugh and would say offensive things but to me they were funny. He’d commonly say ‘filthy brit’ and id quickly reply with ‘filthy american’. There was definately a difference between the two. Even my younger brother, who had never spoke to him (only heard him) was sick of the nasty american.
 
Its one thing to be patriotic but to verbally abuse every other country, race or sexuality is another. I had had enough, so i stopped replying/speaking to him. I just wanted to have some fun and a nice chat, but instead i got an earful of how shit my country is as well as other countries and absolutely terrible things to do with race, gender, sex and women
 
I felt mean ignoring him but he was not the kind of person i wanted to be friends with…

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
Many years ago while in college I befriended a foreign student (FS). I witnessed many dialogues in which she was asked stupid questions and was subjected to ignorant comments by fellow students, in each case an ignorant American (IA). Here are some examples:
 
IA: Where are you from?
 
FS: I am from Uruguay.
 
IA: And where is that?
 
FS: It’s in South America.
 
IA: It can’t be. You are white!
 
Then the foreign student would politely explain that she was a descendant of European immigrants, like the vast majority of the people in her country.
 
IA: You have an accent, where are you from?
 
FS: I am from Uruguay.
 
IA:
Continue Reading
Many years ago while in college I befriended a foreign student (FS). I witnessed many dialogues in which she was asked stupid questions and was subjected to ignorant comments by fellow students, in each case an ignorant American (IA). Here are some examples:
 
IA: Where are you from?
 
FS: I am from Uruguay.
 
IA: And where is that?
 
FS: It’s in South America.
 
IA: It can’t be. You are white!
 
Then the foreign student would politely explain that she was a descendant of European immigrants, like the vast majority of the people in her country.
 
IA: You have an accent, where are you from?
 
FS: I am from Uruguay.
 
IA: And what language do you speak in your country?
 
FS: We speak Spanish.
 
IA: If you speak Spanish you have to be a Mexican!
 
Then the foreign student would politely explain that Spanish is spoken in many different countries.
 
IA: What is your name?
 
FS: My name is Eva.
 
IA: And where are you from?
 
FS: I am from Uruguay.
 
IA: If your name is Eva you have to be Polish, because my best friend’s name is Eva and she is Polish.
 
Then the foreign student would politely explain that Eva is a common name in many European languages.
 
IA: You have an accent, where are you from?
 
FS: I am from Uruguay.
 
IA: I think you have to be from Finland, because my sister-in-law is from Finland and you sound just like her.
 
Then the foreign student smiled politely but did not answer (or maybe I just don’t remember what she answered).
 
On one occasion, while on a trip to California, we were shopping in a small retail store. The saleswoman addressed her in German, to which she replied that she didn’t understand. The saleswoman then asked her where she was from. After hearing the answer “Uruguay,” the saleswoman said, “But you look German, and you speak with a German accent, you have to be German!” (She was not German, her parents were not German, they did not speak German, and they did not have any German ancestry.)
 
She told me of several other encounters with IAs, which I did not witness.
 
She heard several variations of the comments:
 
“If your name is Eva you have to be German,”
 
“Your name is Eva, you have to be from Sweden.”
 
“How come you are white?”
 
“You don’t look Spanish.”
 
She lamented to me that many times when she answered the question, “Where are you from?” her skin darkened and her IQ lowered in the eyes of the American questioner.
 
In one case, on hearing her accent, a woman told her, “You have dark skin, are you from Egypt?”
 
She also heard, “You look Indian, are you from India?” “You have a Russian accent.” “You have an Italian accent.” “Are you Arabic? You look Arabic to me.” “You have an accent, are you from Turkey?” “I recognize your accent, you must be from Albania.”
 
On one occasion, when asked for the millionth time the “where are you from?” question, she answered, “I am from Betazed.” “And where is that?” the questioner then asked, to which she replied, “In Europe, of course!” And the questioner seemed satisfied.
 
As Dave Barry would say, I am not making this up.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
Two different Americans on two separate occasions, one the finance manager at a large furniture store in Charleston, SC as my ex-husband and I financed the purchase of our living room furniture, and the other who worked in a bank, when they asked our living/rental history and we replied we were from Canada, did NOT know Canada is a country north of the United States! The fnance manager replied, “Canada, is that in Colorado?” and the bank employee asked if Canada was in Ohio. HELLO
 
I had to patiently and diplomatically explain to them both that we were from Canada, the big *country* north of the
Continue Reading
Two different Americans on two separate occasions, one the finance manager at a large furniture store in Charleston, SC as my ex-husband and I financed the purchase of our living room furniture, and the other who worked in a bank, when they asked our living/rental history and we replied we were from Canada, did NOT know Canada is a country north of the United States! The fnance manager replied, “Canada, is that in Colorado?” and the bank employee asked if Canada was in Ohio. HELLO
 
I had to patiently and diplomatically explain to them both that we were from Canada, the big *country* north of the US, while picking my jaw up off the ground at their stunning ignorance. Do US public schools not teach even a bare-bones-level of geography? How can any American NOT KNOW the countries immediately north and south of its borders, or even that there’s a country called Canada??
 
One more example of an ignorant American is really reflective of her *parents*, not her, because it was a minor child. My college bordered a busy residential side street that led to a student parking lot in the back and one day one my way to class, driving down the side street an 8–10-week-old puppy ran out from the driveway of a house toward my car. Being an animal-lover I pulled right over, jumped out, grabbed the puppy off the road, and carried her up the driveway where some children were playing. I returned their puppy and asked why they let her run loose into traffic. The oldest child, about 8 or 9 years old, said, “My mama says if that puppy don’t know enough to stay off the road it deserves to get hit.”
 
Inwardly I felt horrified at hearing such an ignorant, heartless thing, especially from a child. But instead of scolding the little girl who, judging from her house and neighborhood, was from a low-income, likely under-educated family, I crouched down and petted her puppy and said, “Do you remember when you were just a wee baby? Remember how when we were really little we didn’t know very much and had to have lots of time to learn stuff?” She nodded. “Well,” I continued, “your puppy is just a baby dog and she doesn’t know anything yet, either. She’s relying on you to teach her to stay off the road so she doesn’t get run over. Just like your mama probably taught you not to run into the road, right?”
 
She nodded again, yes. I told her she had a precious life in her hands, that her puppy also needed to be taught, and protected, like her mama had taught her, and if she took care that her puppy never ran into the road again that puppy would live and be her best friend. She smiled and I said goodbye and headed to class.
 
I think and hope my message got through to that young girl and her siblings, and their ignorance wasn’t their fault—it was clear her mama either didn’t grasp, or care, that puppies need to be trained and confined to their own properties, and they deserve to be properly cared for and protected. That experience gave me a glimpse (one of many, especially in the US South) of generational ignorance that’s passed on between parents and children.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
I live in America, and thus, I have had the pleasure (or displeasure) to go through the public school system for almost all of my schooling. In fact, I am still in it as of now, so the stuff that I see everyday either makes me want to weep for the future of this country, or feel extremely stupid in the face of genius. Mostly the former, so I’ve got a lot of stories about ignorance. But I’ll share the one that I remember the most.
 
There was this boy that I went to most of middle school with. In our eighth grade year, he transferred to another school. Frankly, he was the most spoiled little brat 
Continue Reading
I live in America, and thus, I have had the pleasure (or displeasure) to go through the public school system for almost all of my schooling. In fact, I am still in it as of now, so the stuff that I see everyday either makes me want to weep for the future of this country, or feel extremely stupid in the face of genius. Mostly the former, so I’ve got a lot of stories about ignorance. But I’ll share the one that I remember the most.
 
There was this boy that I went to most of middle school with. In our eighth grade year, he transferred to another school. Frankly, he was the most spoiled little brat I have ever had the displeasure to meet at that point. Everyone in our grade breathed a sigh of relief at the prospect of not having to deal with him anymore. I’m not going to go into detail about what he did in class, but let’s just say my Mythology teacher let loose a scream of frustration because of him and caused all the teachers in the hall to check up on her on one instance.
 
Let’s call him Thomas.
 
Anyways, in my freshman year of high school, we ended up going to the same school, but fortunately, I only had one class with him, and that was French. Now, I take my language classes very seriously. 
Very 
seriously. And so with Thomas disrupting the class with inane comments about 
everything
, (and some of them being extremely sexist and flippant about genders and whatnot) I was ready to pull my hair out. I’m pretty sure the entire class was too, along with our poor teacher. But that’s not the point of this.
 
One day, the teacher pulled up Google maps to show us where the small country of Andorra is. As she was dragging the map to it, Thomas let out a dramatic gasp.
 
By then, the class as a whole had already silently decided that we would all ignore him and his unwanted commentary.
 
However, what came out of Thomas’ mouth just made all of us simultaneously turn our heads to him to stare in disbelief.
 
“That’s where Italy is? I thought it was in China!”
 
The entire class just stared at him with mouths gaping open like fish. Meanwhile, he was sitting in his desk looking genuinely confused about that. After a few seconds of silence and the realization that he actually didn’t know that Italy was indeed, 
not
 in China, the teacher cautiously pointed to the smart board/Promethean thingy and said,
 
“Well, there’s Italy. And here’s Andorra. And make a side note that China does not contain Italy, because otherwise, the Roman Empire would have also been in China, and that just doesn’t make any damn sense.”
 
Seeing as this was Thomas though, he still insisted that Italy was in China. I suppose by that point in the year, the teacher was absolutely done with him, and so invited him up to the board and told him to find Italy in China.
 
I found this deeply amusing and had the hardest time keeping my mouth shut. I saw others struggling to keep their laughter in as well, which really wasn’t a surprise, considering we were all about to see Thomas futilely try and find Italy in China on a map.
 
None of us ever let him live that down.

title: What is a good workout routine at home?
article:
The home workout should target strength and endurance in the muscles that you use daily. This is the most basic requirement.
 
The next is to improve your cardiovascular capacity. The result will be you are working at a lower heart rate than before. Less stress on the heart.
 
Then you should also work on agility and balance. This will regain back the spring in your step as you grow old and move around flat footed. You are also less likely to fall and hurt yourself.
 
The two main muscle groups used daily are the lower body and the upper body pulling action. The third group is the upper body pushing ac
Continue Reading
The home workout should target strength and endurance in the muscles that you use daily. This is the most basic requirement.
 
The next is to improve your cardiovascular capacity. The result will be you are working at a lower heart rate than before. Less stress on the heart.
 
Then you should also work on agility and balance. This will regain back the spring in your step as you grow old and move around flat footed. You are also less likely to fall and hurt yourself.
 
The two main muscle groups used daily are the lower body and the upper body pulling action. The third group is the upper body pushing action. Very seldom used but you can also do the workout if you want to.
 
Forget all the various types of workouts you can do. Just stick to the simplest that you can groove in and do in your sleep.
 
The body weight squat is sufficient for the lower body strength. There is also the need to increase stair climbing ability and endurance. A low stool is a good point to start. Then onto a sturdy chair as you improve. Do this in conjunction with the body squat. It prepares the body when you switch from walking and then climbing stairs.
 
Lower back extensions will cover the upper body pulling action. The most basic is bending forward while trying to touch the toes and then straightening up. It sounds simple but it is NOT. The SPINE must be kept in the neutral position ALL the time. It forces the lower back muscles to do most of the work and thus you will get the proper adaptation. A more advanced and more strength adaptation workout is in the image below.
Pull ups will build arm and related muscles.
 
Push ups are enough for the pushing group of muscles.
 
The agility, balance and cardiovascular part is taken care of by doing rope skipping or rope jumping, whatever the term. For the average person, it is equivalent to running for the same length of time in terms of energy usage if you are looking at weight loss as well.
 
The only problem you will face is that it is NOT easy at first. If you target say 30 minutes, I doubt you can even do the two leg version for 10 minutes. Your legs will start to burn. That is the alert to stop. Just do the one leg after the other version at slow speed. Stop and rest when you are alerted. Then continue until you reach the 30 minutes. As you improve, increase speed and slowly build up until you can do the two leg version continously for your target duration. Rope skipping, especially on two legs involve the toes, the ankles and calves mainly. The thigh muscle do only a bit of work. Hardly any stress on the knees as the angle of bend is small. So no fear of knee injury.
 
Not much more to add except to point out a few things. The rope skipping will most probably bring you up to around 80% of max. This is because you are working at just below the leg burning stage. That level is enough for a fairly high level of cardiovascular adaptation if done for a long enough duration and period. How you schedule your workouts and whether to mix them together in a single session, I leave to you.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
A guy I used to work with had been droning on and on for weeks during the primaries about how there weren’t any viable candidates for president.
 
When I say on and on and on, I’m talking ad infinitum rolling right into ad nauseum on nitrous….and he wouldn’t let up on the gas.
 
I finally became sick of it and one day I said, “Okay, Tommy. Let me stop you right there because, not only is this not the place to discuss it but I’ve heard it before so unless you have something to offer like a solution to your issue, I’d rather not hear it.”
 
This guy in his infinite wisdom went on to ask me in a rather sa

A guy I used to work with had been droning on and on for weeks during the primaries about how there weren’t any viable candidates for president.
 
When I say on and on and on, I’m talking ad infinitum rolling right into ad nauseum on nitrous….and he wouldn’t let up on the gas.
 
I finally became sick of it and one day I said, “Okay, Tommy. Let me stop you right there because, not only is this not the place to discuss it but I’ve heard it before so unless you have something to offer like a solution to your issue, I’d rather not hear it.”
 
This guy in his infinite wisdom went on to ask me in a rather sarcastic tone how I do it.
 
I explained.
 
Then he decided to go into great detail about how wrong I was.
 
“The people they give us are total shit…”
 
Again I shut him down and told him that was the end of it. We had clients coming and my energy was better spent on them.
 
I finally got him to shut up…or so I thought.
 
Tommy spent weeks trying like shit to finish what it was he was saying. I knew where it was going, I’ve heard it before. He wasn’t expressing his opinion anymore. Now he was trying to change my mind. That wasn’t happening.
 
He was fired due largely to his incompetance on the job and sent packing.
 
I was just relieved to never have to hear that huge monologue full of apathy again.
 
Edit: I Need To Add One More Story. I can’t believe I forgot about this one.
 
I was working in let’s just say cable sales and it was soul-crushing. Just as an experiment, there was a discussion going around about banning something so I thought I’d chime in and told everyone, “I have something far more evil than what you guys are talking about and I’m pretty sure that you’ll agree that it needs to be banned big time.”
 
I had their attention.
 
“Dihydrogen Monoxide. This stuff is plain evil. It’s the main component in acid rain, thousands of drowning deaths are a result of dihydrogen monoxide, it can be lethal if you drink the stuff. I’m telling you it’s freakin’ horrible.”
 
That’s all it took. Within minutes they’re looking it up and then slowly, one by one, “Wait…you want us to…what is this, Wade?”
 
As they’re looking it up, they’re puzzled. The people I worked with are looking at me in confusion. The one person who isn’t questioning this is my boss and I had been waiting to show her that her reactionary stance on most things was about to bite her in the ass…here it was.
 
“It’s water,” I said, “But everything I said is true. If a person drowns, they’ve inhaled water, Acid Rain…there’s water as the main component and if you drink it at the rate of a gallon per hour the electrolytes from your body will go bye-bye and you’ll die.” They relaxed but nope, my boss is still ….well she drank the kool-aid, doubting my revelation.
 
She’s pulling up everything she can about the chemical composition on dihydrogen monoxide, clearly convinced that it’s poison. Everyone, including myself is telling her that my initial spiel was bogus.
 
She still tries to convince people to ban water to this day.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
Sorry to go political, but I will…
 
In the most recent election cycle ignorance has never been more clear. The most ignorant people in America are those holding staunch opinions without being able to articulate the other side’s argument realistically. If they can’t articulate the argument realistically and sincerely, it shows that person has never opened their mind enough to consider why others hold an opposing view - that is the hallmark of ignorance.
 
Case in point. The majority of Trump supporters were labeled as “racist, mysogynist, homophobes”. Why else would they support Trump as a candidate
Continue Reading
Sorry to go political, but I will…
 
In the most recent election cycle ignorance has never been more clear. The most ignorant people in America are those holding staunch opinions without being able to articulate the other side’s argument realistically. If they can’t articulate the argument realistically and sincerely, it shows that person has never opened their mind enough to consider why others hold an opposing view - that is the hallmark of ignorance.
 
Case in point. The majority of Trump supporters were labeled as “racist, mysogynist, homophobes”. Why else would they support Trump as a candidate?
 
Racist - Many on the left would posit that Trump supporters want a wall, or tighter border security because “we hate Mexicans or other foriegners”. Not true.
 
1. The majority of those on the right advocating tighter border security are considering the impact of more people requiring more services when we have finite resources to address these problems at current population levels already.
 
2. Many on the Right have watched the impact of unrestricted migration into European countries and believe that careful screening of those seeking entry is simply prudent.
 
Caution and prudence are not racist. Let’s face it, you would not let your daughter spend the night at a stranger’s home until you’ve at least had the chance to speak with the parent. Is that because you are hateful, or is that because you are prudent?
 
Misogynism - Did Trump say horrible things about women? Certainly. Did Hillary defend a child rapist? Certainly. However, based on what we believe to be the best person to address economic issues, issues of national security, job growth, etc - the candidates on the Right were more closely aligned with our views on how to succeed. The vote was not an Anti-Woman referendum.
 
Homophobists - Not seeing a issues like whom one can marry, or what is the appropriate titling of bathrooms, or who must bake a cake for whom, as being a top-priority national concern for America when we are facing stagnate job growth, continued terrorist threats, nuclear capable countries who maintain an Anti-US position does not make us homophobic. It simply says, be reasonable - at the end of the day how important is to a person in Vermont which bathroom I choose to use in Colorado? At the end of the day, how much time do I spend in public bathrooms anyway - so let’s use our time wisely to address bigger issues.
 
In summary - Ignorance is not taking time to see WHY others maintain positions they do. It is typically not out of hate or spite, but rather differing world views. At the end of the day most people on both sides of the aisle want similar things:
An ability to provide for ourselves and our families.
Relative safety in our neighborhoods
Access to food and healthcare.
We simply disagree on the best avenues to enact the greatest good for the greatest number of people. To not understand that and simply say views differ based on Love vs. Hate is completely ignorant.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
The mid-afternoon sun streams through the futuristic reflective glass at a restaurant in Northern Germany. It is about 5 o’clock, so naturally many locals have begun to arrive for a quiet, relaxed, dinner.
 
I’m seated at a table with my cousin, Alfred*, almost five years my senior, discussing politics while quietly sipping a glass of wine. No one dares to raise their voice above a soft murmur, even the wait staff finding it prudent to bend down in order to speak with the many patrons seated around us.
 
Until, of course, the American walks in.
 
Loud and boisterous from the very start, the American de
Continue Reading
The mid-afternoon sun streams through the futuristic reflective glass at a restaurant in Northern Germany. It is about 5 o’clock, so naturally many locals have begun to arrive for a quiet, relaxed, dinner.
 
I’m seated at a table with my cousin, Alfred*, almost five years my senior, discussing politics while quietly sipping a glass of wine. No one dares to raise their voice above a soft murmur, even the wait staff finding it prudent to bend down in order to speak with the many patrons seated around us.
 
Until, of course, the American walks in.
 
Loud and boisterous from the very start, the American demands a table, yelling, “What do I hafta do to get some service in this country?”.
 
An already disgruntled hostess seats him, alone, at a four person table. He immediately orders a glass of whiskey, neat.
 
Almost collectively, the rest of the patrons shrug slightly, returning to their local brews and bratwurst.
 
The waitress brings the American his drink, and sets it in front of him. In almost toddler-like fashion, the American throws his glass to the floor.
 
“Neat! NEAT! I ordered my drink NEAT!” He bellows, as the waitress explains in soft English that his drink was “clean” and not at all dirty. As he continues raving, the waitress chatters in German to her coworkers, obviously upset at this treatment.
 
His raving continues, becoming less and less coherent, before ending with the famous, “Doesn’t anyone speak English in this goddamn country?”
 
Nervously, I raise my hand, attracting his beady gaze. “I’m from Canada, I think there’s just been a translation error…” I begin, before I’m quickly cut off.
 
“I don’t want someone that speaks Canadian, I want someone that speaks ENGLISH!” He screeches, taking a step towards my table.
 
I look him dead in the eyes. I wonder - is he fucking serious? No one can be this stupid. Next to me, Alfred stares intently for a moment, before he LAUGHS.
 
Belly deep, brown eyes open wide in absolute delight, he laughs like he’s doing an impersonation of Santa Claus. His smile is infectious, and before I know it, I’m laughing too. Suddenly, so are the other patrons in the restaurant.
 
“Speaks Canadian!” A man in a tight business suit yells, slapping his thighs to express how absurd he believes the statement to be. Even the uptight woman seated alone with a gin and tonic finds the sentiment to be worth cracking a smile for.
 
“Dumme Amerikaner”, I hear whispered all around me. (
“Stupid Americans”)
 
The man, understanding he is being laughed at (but not much else, apparently), yells “What kind of dipshit doesn’t speak English, anyways?”
 
This does little to help his cause, as nearly everyone in the restaurant speaks English with - at minimum - basic proficiency. The raucous laughter continues - Alfred wipes a stray tear from his eye, his face turning red from laughing so hard.
 
The disgruntled American leaves in a huff, vowing to never go to a country where they speak “Canadian” or German again.
 
*Name changed

title: How to workout
article:
Running on a treadmill is probably my favorite and most fun method when it comes to exercising. It isn't as tiring or grueling on your joints as it is when you're doing runs on varied, uneven, and realistic terrain.
 
I liked going to the gym and rotating between lifting machines like the bicep curl, tricep press, and tricep pushdown when I wanted to blow off steam; but the muscle soreness and stiffness that I got in the inboard side of my elbow (known as the medial epicondyle) was excruciating every time I tried to straighten my arm a day after the workout.
 
As a result, I'd have to go to work the
Continue Reading
Running on a treadmill is probably my favorite and most fun method when it comes to exercising. It isn't as tiring or grueling on your joints as it is when you're doing runs on varied, uneven, and realistic terrain.
 
I liked going to the gym and rotating between lifting machines like the bicep curl, tricep press, and tricep pushdown when I wanted to blow off steam; but the muscle soreness and stiffness that I got in the inboard side of my elbow (known as the medial epicondyle) was excruciating every time I tried to straighten my arm a day after the workout.
 
As a result, I'd have to go to work the next day with my arms squared off in a stiff, rigid, and 45-degree angle. My arms being bent at the elbow and unable to extend without causing agony. People thought I was playing around, “Look at this dick walking around trying to make chicken sandwiches with his robot arms.”
 
So cardio became my go to. Ah, distinctly I remember, it was in the bleak December, and each separate dying ember wrought its ghost upon the floor.
 
(Upvote for the Edgar Allan Poe reference? )
 
I went to exercise at L.A Fitness with a gym rat who practically snorted canisters of preworkout and whey protein. And he had a free guest pass, so I said what the hell. I got the heart, kid! I was always at the disadvantage, but I doggedly followed his workout routine despite feeling I was over training my muscles.
 
The days that we were too worn out or didn't have enough time to go through with a full workout, we treated them as cardio days. Immediately, I fell in love with the treadmill.
 
The way Mr.Protein saw it, it was either go home with your mind carrying your agonized and hypertrophic corpse in a body bag, or do cardio until you dropped.
 
So I grew fond of working to a beat, treading on the elastic band that bounced with a slight resistance as it looped under my feet, and seeing the gorgeous female triathletes who seemed to have unparalleled stamina run alongside me.
 
I'd start off getting started at a slow and steady 3.5 MPH and would gradually increase the speed by .2 every minute. Often, I'd swap my playlist to an upbeat and fast BPM playlist to challange myself to what I deemed a speed round.
 
Raised the incline, raised the speed to 6.0 MPH, and raised the resistance. And every twenty seconds, I'd increase the speed by .20
 
Before all this, I was always confused as to why people enjoyed running track or doing seemingly linear sports ike cross-country. But then I tried it for myself in the comfort of a warm gym. It feels like you're running away from it all. Not in a bad way. It feels a bit like you're the last mazerunner burdened with dashing through the labrynth-complex that is life.
 
There's a controlled rhythm and willpower, and most of the time you'll be too focused on keeping your lungs supplied with oxygen for you to think about much else. It's a fascinating workout all-in-all.
 
Cheers,
 
Daniel.
 
Sources :
 
Golfer's elbow - Symptoms and causes
