title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
Just so you all know most Americans aren’t ignorant, or stupid, although to be fair we could try much more when it comes to foreign affairs, and foreign geography ;). To understand American ignorance we must explain first that the US is a huge country, and each region is incredibly different from one another to the point of almost being another country, and we can’t put them together as a whole. Don’t get offended by my answer btw. Its more humorous but has a large element of truth to it.
 
Basically the US is divided into five regions
 
The Pacific Northwest- 
Hippies, and tech savvy starbucks lover
Continue Reading
Just so you all know most Americans aren’t ignorant, or stupid, although to be fair we could try much more when it comes to foreign affairs, and foreign geography ;). To understand American ignorance we must explain first that the US is a huge country, and each region is incredibly different from one another to the point of almost being another country, and we can’t put them together as a whole. Don’t get offended by my answer btw. Its more humorous but has a large element of truth to it.
 
Basically the US is divided into five regions
 
The Pacific Northwest- 
Hippies, and tech savvy starbucks lovers
 
The South- 
Hicks mostly, where most American stereotypes come from
 
New England- 
Wealthy region, with very good schools, and 99.9% white.
 
Northeastern US- 
Snobby rude people with Italian surnames
 
Midwestern US- 
Friendly people, who are very modest. A lot sound quite Canadian.
 
Now to the actual story about the ignorant American ;)
 
I’m from New Hampshire which is a tiny state in New England. In other words irrelevant. The southern US is very backwards with many conservative zealots who can be quite stupid sounding almost like Donald Trump. The public school system down south is actually a joke, and it makes the whole US look bad. The school systems in New Hampshire are ranked as similar to the ones in Finland which have some of the best school systems in the world. Thus logically your average New Englander who have access to better schools will know more, and be far less ignorant than your average southerner who has access to shittier schools.
 
I’m at a gas station outside a small town called Starkville, Mississippi. Its what you’d picture as a “hick town.”
 
I prefer cash over credit so I usually pay for my gas with cash. When I walk in I say hello. (This conversation is not word for word. It is from memory to the best of my knowledge)
 
The attendant says, “Hi there”
 
As many of you foreigners know Americans are masters at the art of small talk so we begin talking
 
Attendant- “You aren’t from around here aren’t you?”
 
Me- “Yeah, I’m from New England.”
 
Attendant- “Huh, that's kinda odd, I thought you British people had funny accents.”
 
Me- “I’m sorry? I’m from the US.”
 
Attendant- “But then why did you say New England? Aren’t you from England?”
 
At that moment I was half laughing in the inside, but also feeling kinda bad for the lady, because although she was nice, she was incredibly stupid when it came to geography. As it turned out she had never even left Mississippi, and her whole family lived in the same county, so she never really left. Her “comfort zone”, or “radius of knowledge”. To her anything outside of Oktibbeha County, Mississippi is totally foreign. In fact she told me the biggest journey she ever took was to see an old friend in Jackson, Mississippi which is only 201km away(125 mi). When you put that into perspective of the entire United States, and the world that's incredibly small.

title: What is a good workout routine at home?
article:
A good workout routine at home should be creative, detailed, and concise to ensure maximum efficiency and effectiveness.
 
Here's a comprehensive plan that requires minimal equipment while targeting all major muscle groups:
 
1. Warm-up (5-10 minutes):Start with light cardiovascular exercises such as jogging in place, jumping jacks, or high knees to increase heart rate and prepare muscles for activity.
 
2. Upper body strength training (15-20 minutes):
 
a) Push-ups: Perform 3 sets of 12 reps for chest, shoulders, and triceps.
 
b) Dips: Use a sturdy chair or elevated surface to perform 3 sets of 10 reps for
Continue Reading
A good workout routine at home should be creative, detailed, and concise to ensure maximum efficiency and effectiveness.
 
Here's a comprehensive plan that requires minimal equipment while targeting all major muscle groups:
 
1. Warm-up (5-10 minutes):Start with light cardiovascular exercises such as jogging in place, jumping jacks, or high knees to increase heart rate and prepare muscles for activity.
 
2. Upper body strength training (15-20 minutes):
 
a) Push-ups: Perform 3 sets of 12 reps for chest, shoulders, and triceps.
 
b) Dips: Use a sturdy chair or elevated surface to perform 3 sets of 10 reps for triceps and chest.
 
c) Superman Pose: Lie face down on the floor with arms extended forward; lift your chest off the ground along with your legs simultaneously. Do 3 sets of 15 reps to target back muscles.
 
3. Lower body strength training (15-20 minutes):
 
a) Squats: Stand with feet hip-width apart and lower into a sitting position while keeping your weight on heels; do 4 sets of 12 reps for glutes, quads, hamstrings.
 
b) Lunges: Step forward with one foot until both knees are at a right angle then push back up; repeat alternating legs for a total of 3 sets of 12 reps per leg focusing on glutes and quads.c) Calf raises: Stand on an elevated surface like stairs or use dumbbells if available; perform calf raises by raising heels as high as possible then lowering them below the step level. Aim for three sets of fifteen repetitions.
 
4. Core exercises (10-15 minutes):
 
a) Plank: Assume push-up position but rest forearms instead of palms on the ground; hold this position engaging core muscles for three sets lasting thirty seconds each.
 
b) Bicycle crunches: Lie flat on your back with hands behind head, bring one knee towards your chest while simultaneously touching it with the opposite elbow. Repeat for 3 sets of 15 reps per side to engage abs and obliques.
 
c) Russian twists: Sit on the floor with knees bent and feet elevated off the ground; twist your torso from side to side, touching hands to the ground each time. Aim for three sets of twenty repetitions.
 
5. Cardiovascular exercise (20-30 minutes):Choose activities that elevate heart rate such as jumping rope, jogging in place, or performing high-intensity interval training exercises like burpees or mountain climbers. Alternate between high-intensity bursts and short rest periods for an effective cardio workout.
 
6. Cool-down & Stretching (5-10 minutes):
 
Finish your routine by gradually slowing down movements and stretching major muscle groups like hamstrings, quadriceps, calves, shoulders, and chest.Remember to stay hydrated throughout your workout routine by drinking water regularly. Modify exercises based on fitness levels and always listen to your body's signals - if any pain or discomfort arises during a particular exercise, consult a professional before continuing. Stay motivated by setting goals and tracking progress regularly!

title: Is it bad to do full body workouts every day?
article:
Yes. My personal experience may be different than what others have posted as answers. My theory worked with me. Wanting to rebuild after having lost substantial muscle I felt that concentrating on my arms would be helpful with regaining lat and pec development. The stronger the arms the more weight you can handle with rows and bench movements.
 
I theorized that bringing a fresh, high volume blood supply to muscle tissue several times a day would flush out wastes and bring in larger volumes of nutrition. I have equipment at home. I would work my arms when I got up. Get out of bed start with a set
Continue Reading
Yes. My personal experience may be different than what others have posted as answers. My theory worked with me. Wanting to rebuild after having lost substantial muscle I felt that concentrating on my arms would be helpful with regaining lat and pec development. The stronger the arms the more weight you can handle with rows and bench movements.
 
I theorized that bringing a fresh, high volume blood supply to muscle tissue several times a day would flush out wastes and bring in larger volumes of nutrition. I have equipment at home. I would work my arms when I got up. Get out of bed start with a set of curls. My theory was that by doing enough to get a pump in the morning, when I came home from work, later at the gym and a few sets to get a blood flush in my arms just before bed. Keeping the blood in the tissue was the goal. I had spectacular results in less than 3 months. I gained over an inch a month on my arms.
 
I did this in the mid eighties. I ate food that I purchased at the grocery stores and restaurants. I took vitamin supplements. Knox Gelatin and cod liver oil protected my joints.
 
I lifted heavy, three sets trying for four strict reps and then cheating for the next four but resisting and slowing the eccentric part of the movement which should always be done with a full range of motion, working the eccentric part of the rep to shape the muscles.
 
While the pro bodybuilders at that time were eating jars of baby food while working out I found something better. I didn’t know it at that time either but today it is known through science that when a bodybuilder completes his workout the best way to increase the cells absorption of the post workout protein is for the bodybuilder to eat two slices of white bread or a cup of white rice. The simple sugars in the refined grain tempts the cells to open taking in more of the protein maximizing muscle growth.
 
In the afternoon when I returned home from work I would have a snack of peanuts and fresh squeezed cider while doing some arm exercises. The peanuts supplied fat, protein and so many vitamins and minerals as well as arginine. A cup of peanuts has more than 3X the arginine as a most whey servings supplying 40 grams of protein. The natural sugar in the cider opened up the cells sucking in the nutrients while the arginine dilates the cardiovascular system. Before going to bed I would maybe 6 ounces of peanuts and have a glass of apple juice while doing enough arm exercises to get the pump back in.
 
I was really doing a full workout in the morning, a teaser when I got home from work, a full workout at the gym, and enough to flush and pump my arms just before bed. I ate yogurt, steak, eggs, sardines, baked potatoes, salads, cooked vegetables, whole grain breads, almonds, walnuts, I ate humongous amounts of foods but when I started eating the peanuts and drinking the cider I found the gains in strength and size came much more quickly.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
It’s got to be the banker…
 
I’ve lived in the USA twice: grad school plus a year with a normal job, then back home, then the company for which I worked transferred me to the US.
 
Second time, during my incoming session with the HR lady I provided all necessary papers and, when she asked if I had a bank account, I said no and asked which bank they sent payroll from. The office across the street. OK, thank you.
 
So, I went across the street and asked to open a bank account. Lady asks for my ID; I give her my passport and US SS Card. She says “you can’t open a bank account, you need a (US) SSN and you’
Continue Reading
It’s got to be the banker…
 
I’ve lived in the USA twice: grad school plus a year with a normal job, then back home, then the company for which I worked transferred me to the US.
 
Second time, during my incoming session with the HR lady I provided all necessary papers and, when she asked if I had a bank account, I said no and asked which bank they sent payroll from. The office across the street. OK, thank you.
 
So, I went across the street and asked to open a bank account. Lady asks for my ID; I give her my passport and US SS Card. She says “you can’t open a bank account, you need a (US) SSN and you’re not American”. I explain that yes you can open a bank account without being a US citizen and I do have a US SSN, see, this is my US SS Card. “Oh, so you’re American! Then I need your American ID!” No, I’m not American, you don’t need to be American to get an SSN.
 
We went round four or five times until I was finally able to get her to accept a dare: “listen, just type this SSN into your computer and see what it spits up, ok?”
 
She looked at me like she really wished she had glasses so she could glare over them and typed.
 
Lo and behold, the computer spit out… my name, SSN, an old account from that bank (now closed) and an address which happened to match my (expired therefore not valid) Florida driver’s license!
 
She and the branch manager also claimed that it was not possible to transfer money electronically from Spain and that the account didn’t have an IBAN (International Bank Account Number). Even after I pointed to the part of the contract which showed the IBAN they kept saying such a thing did not exist in the USA.
Bonus: this one American, I didn’t strictly-speaking meet.
 
After that US stay I returned home, still working for the same company. And for the first few months there were problems getting my payroll; payments were made but I didn’t get the paperwork because “we can’t get you into the system, I don’t know why, Home Office does it”. Eventually I managed to convince our HR guy to cc me in the latest round of emails with Home Office HR re. “the missing identity information of one Mariluz”, and I replied providing:
 
my full name (that is, the Spanish version),
the version in my US IDs,
my Spanish SSN and NIF (the second one is the general Tax ID),
my US SSN (which doubles as US Tax ID).
 
And the lady from Home Office wrote back “wait, you can have more than one Social Security number?” “yeah, multiple countries have something called some version of Social Security. But your Social Security and our Seguridad Social aren’t the same thing.”
 
Turns out they’d been trying to enter my US SSN both as my Número de la Seguridad Social and as my NIF (Tax ID) into a file identified as being from Spain and the program kept snarling “wrong format” on both fields. The program was smarter and better organized than either of the two humans from HR, American or Spanish.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
For me it isn’t so much a person but it is a kind of mentality. It seems that a lot of universities and people in general are so easily being used ( by media spinning fake news, by other agitators to go an riot,etc) without them realizing why they are “protesting,rioting, beating the snot out of someone with another viewpoint as them”. When you ask them they spout doctrine that have been given to them by media/agitators/etc without actually being skeptic about the whole thing.
 
Why do media push x narrative or opt for narrative Y? What do they have to gain? I will not give a recent example but a
Continue Reading
For me it isn’t so much a person but it is a kind of mentality. It seems that a lot of universities and people in general are so easily being used ( by media spinning fake news, by other agitators to go an riot,etc) without them realizing why they are “protesting,rioting, beating the snot out of someone with another viewpoint as them”. When you ask them they spout doctrine that have been given to them by media/agitators/etc without actually being skeptic about the whole thing.
 
Why do media push x narrative or opt for narrative Y? What do they have to gain? I will not give a recent example but an old one that is easily googled without getting in the swamp of trump/anti trump swamp. During the Northern Ireland problems in the 1970–2000s some journalists and photographers were caught paying Northern Irish kids to throw rocks at police and start trouble. Back then when there were still ethical boards that actually fact checked the news and the reports, you know what they did? They fired those people and gave them a ban ( depending on the severity and the proof).
 
Now let us apply this to modern day. These “fact checkers and control organs” do not exist anymore or if they do, they are holed out utterly to the point of being obsolete. You have to ask yourself: Why is CNN telling something like this or that? What do they have to gain by saying this? What political spectrum do they have (donated to hillaries campaign) and is it visible in their reporting ( this is an ear deafening yes, like most mainstream media outlets).
 
Now armed with these answers ask yourself the following: What does protesting mean for me? Do I benefit from it in any way? If i do protest and it turns violent what will i do? IF i get caught rioting or beating someone up who profits from it? ( the last question is always the media that WANTS riots, it is their bread and butter. IF you riot and “kicking buttskies, the media’s ratings goes up which means more income in advertisements/stock prices will go up etc)
 
So who benefits from rioting? The media and they use you, the people to do it and they do not pay you a dime ( even if they did i don’t think a lot of sane people will accept the money or even riot at all). Thus those average joes and janes are reduced to 21st century slaves that listen to the elite mainstream media overlords clacking of the whip.
 
Of course this isn’t exclusive to the US but the last months it seems that the US is so susceptible to this behavior. Arm yourselves against it by thinking for yourselves, be skeptical about what news says ( be it left, right,etc do your own research if you want to find out the truth). If someone tells you “this is the truth and if you think otherwise you are *insert a curse word or whatever” you know you are dealing with propaganda especially when they do not state facts to back up their claims.
 
Thanks for bearing with me on this rather lengthy piece :)

I'm thinking to myself ”didn't I just told you I don't have any? What are you still trying? As if with such a pity excuse, all of a sudden I will magically get spoons”.
 
So I still have the courtesy to listen to dumb beatch her story, thinking she might actually try to make a point…
 
Well…. No point… just lame azz excuse that should somehow make me magically give her a spoon. Womba bomba starts making a fuss. I know in her culture, when someone says 'no', it actually means 'I'm too lazy azz to git it fur u. So GTFO!'.
 
Anyway, I referred her to a restaurant that might have what she needs, and it only aggravated the situation. She was expecting me, to get her what she wants, even though we are not a restaurant.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
I hired a guy in a small Northern California town to do some work for me. I was not super happy with the quality of his work, but had a short timeline and few options, so decided to make the best of it. I made sure that I was paying him pretty well for his time and energy by market standards, so did not expect much guff.
 
At one point, just a few weeks before the project was due, he asked if I could please stop 
sending
 him project related emails late at night (my normal hours for such things). It was waking him up, he said, and besides he thought it was “unprofessional” for me to hit send while 
Continue Reading
I hired a guy in a small Northern California town to do some work for me. I was not super happy with the quality of his work, but had a short timeline and few options, so decided to make the best of it. I made sure that I was paying him pretty well for his time and energy by market standards, so did not expect much guff.
 
At one point, just a few weeks before the project was due, he asked if I could please stop 
sending
 him project related emails late at night (my normal hours for such things). It was waking him up, he said, and besides he thought it was “unprofessional” for me to hit send while he was sleeping. I should wait until his normal business hours to do so.
 
Note that at no point had I complained about him not responding to my messages late at night. In fact, I’d gone out of my way to establish with him that 48–72 hours was perfectly acceptable response time, otherwise I would call or text him if it was urgent. By definition, anything I emailed him was important and totally non-urgent
 
He literally thought that I should keep track of the hours that he and the other team members kept and only 
write 
emails during that time. He was quite adamant that it was, and I repeat this nincompoop’s words, “unprofessional” for me to do otherwise.
 
I was, in fact, dumbfounded and could not think of what to respond. In that moment, I could not think of anything in recent memory I’d personally heard with my own ears that was quite so ignorant.
 
The medium was designed, after all, so that person A could write and send it any old time that was convenient to them and person B could read and respond in turn when it suited them, in this way being just like paper mail, only faster. The recipient can set up whatever device (pc, tablet, phone) they receive email on anyway they like to suit their own preferences (which the sender could not possibly know). In other words, he could just silence notifications when he went to sleep (although for what I was paying him, he could easily have set up a temporary web-based mail account — for free — specifically for this project and only even logged in to it every few days).
 
Ironically, for 10–12 years of my career in high tech (in San Francisco/Silicon Valley) I specialized in email, in some cases rolling it out on a global scale for large companies. “Unprofessional”, therefore was not merely a ridiculous accusation in this context, but literally untrue.
 
Only later did it occur to me that I should have told him the only time I could sign his check would be late at night but, as a professional courtesy, would decline to do so.
 
If I’m wrong, by the way, someone please tell me in the comments. I’d hate to, like, write birthday and holiday cards or something when the people I’d send them to were taking a nap!
 
I know there are much more important issues to be ignorant on, but this one still stands out in my mind.

title: Are there any poor people on Quora, as Internet access is very cheap nowadays?
article:
I guess yes, by the average materialistic standards.
 
I live in a wood heated hangar, pump water up from the ground, I have my own business, a work truck, my tools.
 
I keep everything cleaned up and tight.
 
Hangar rent and Electra 500€/month
 
food & bottled water 300€/month
 
costs for my business 700€/month ( including diesel, social contributions and vat )
 
income about 1.700€/month after costs
 
no savings ( a few bills in a tin), no property
 
no trust fund, no inheritance ahead
 
but my 2 sons are doing much better than me.
 
The irony of my short story is that, 30years ago my wife and I decided to contribute in 
Continue Reading
I guess yes, by the average materialistic standards.
 
I live in a wood heated hangar, pump water up from the ground, I have my own business, a work truck, my tools.
 
I keep everything cleaned up and tight.
 
Hangar rent and Electra 500€/month
 
food & bottled water 300€/month
 
costs for my business 700€/month ( including diesel, social contributions and vat )
 
income about 1.700€/month after costs
 
no savings ( a few bills in a tin), no property
 
no trust fund, no inheritance ahead
 
but my 2 sons are doing much better than me.
 
The irony of my short story is that, 30years ago my wife and I decided to contribute in our own way to this world, and started a homeless shelter in our local town ( 400.000 pop ) here in Western Europe. We housed up to 24 people sometimes, with food and a bed for them, supported them in paying off debts and generally tried to help them on their feet, the older folk were more permanent.
 
Anyway, it was going great even with 2 small children and a great wife, I even started a farm to cut food costs and give the boys from the shelter something to do and make them feel proud.
 
on top of that we started a pretty nice day center for 1 to 3 year olds, which even became the first kiddie hotel in the country. The mix was great, and everyone pulled together.
 
Untill one day I got a call in the night to urgently come to the shelter, when I got there, everyone was being put into ambulances and 3 stories of the five were gutted and waterdamaged.
 
By a sheer miracle everyone was alive. The longest hospital stay was a week, because of fumes.
 
within a week I was clearing and cleaning, the damage amounted to 250.000 euros, we saw maybe 10.000 Euro from our insurance.
 
we were well insured but conned, and no justice was ever ruled.
 
So it set me back a bit you know.
 
it should have took 2 years to get the shelter into liveable order, I did it almost alone in 1, and the landlady asked us to leave when it was done. So I housed the remaining guys in deluxe containers in our field out back.
 
there was a sort of ““told you so”-vibe even into my outer family, which I forgive/forget, weird writing this, feel a bit tearful remembering it all...
 
Because in that year our baby daughter died in my arms as well, unrelated, she was just too sensitive for this world and died in her sleep, yet right next to me..
 
It was a sad time but my wife and I survived, and eventually thrived, we had to from the get go, just for the kids sake and our kids are great, we all are never out of work, wife and I divorced a few years back still get along great though, but nothing for free, and you know; that’s life, but I still love it.
 
Sorry to to have to do this anonymously, I am too embarrassed about my sober life, as a westerner in Western Europe. Please understand.
 
( wow this sure has stirred up some ghosts.. )

Ask yourself, what it is that you want to achieve. Plan your week such that you have a rest day in your weekly training split.

,
 the rest timing becomes very crucial, because it is in the rest and recovery that you actually grow(along with a good nutrition plan of course). Thus for such a goal 
3–5 days split
 ,with 4th and 6th day as rest is ideal.
 
If you are someone who is

with mix of Strength and Cardiovascular training split would be ideal. Where 5th day can be your rest day.
 
Now, someone like a bodybuilder would usually train a min

 14 times

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
EDIT: Who is Warren Buffet? An adult student sitting next to me in my community college accounting class today did not know. I was and still am a bit shocked. Any interest ever in business or economics or politics or rich people worship would lead to at least knowing who he is. The guy is referenced frequently in the media and by policy makers and is on TV giving interviews and graduation ceremonies speeches. I even saw a joint interview with him and Jay-Z one time. He is not one of those behind the scenes secretive types.
 
ORIGINAL: Everyone has different levels of common knowledge and field sp
Continue Reading
EDIT: Who is Warren Buffet? An adult student sitting next to me in my community college accounting class today did not know. I was and still am a bit shocked. Any interest ever in business or economics or politics or rich people worship would lead to at least knowing who he is. The guy is referenced frequently in the media and by policy makers and is on TV giving interviews and graduation ceremonies speeches. I even saw a joint interview with him and Jay-Z one time. He is not one of those behind the scenes secretive types.
 
ORIGINAL: Everyone has different levels of common knowledge and field specific knowledge. I think my shock factor goes up or down depending on what a certain person does not know that I think they SHOULD know given their age, background, and access to knowledge via their language and modern telecommunication connectivity. Example: I do not expect my 7 year old niece to know basic ingredients for cookies, nor do I expect my 90 year old grandfather to know the different browsers on a computer, nor do I expect some random poor guy in the Central African Republic to name more than one U.S. president or any car company.
 
Last week, I talked to a 60-70 year old white middle class English speaking American from a red state. She stated that she recently learned from a new friend that “there are two kinds of Muslims! I did not know that!” I mentally face palmed but said nothing. Never mind that there a 4 main branches of Sunni Islam, and various versions of Shia (12′ers and 8′ers), and also got Sufis, and offshoots of Shia such a Alawites, and other groups such as Kurds or Central Asians who might mix in certain customs into one of the Sunni branches. I wouldn’t expect any American to be aware of these nuances unless they were from the Middle East pr studying religion or something. I know I don’t have a handle on all of the variants either.
 
What blew me away is the knowledge I expected her to have, considering her age and education and nationality. If you were of college age or above at the time of the USA invasion of Iraq in 2003 and present in the USA or near any English media, how could you NOT be aware of the Sunni vs Shia based breakup during the multi-year USA occupation?! Every day on TV and in the news paper, those two words were mentioned and referred to in any explanation about the ongoing armed conflict, civil war, and reconstruction effort. Every day for multiple years. Any half discussion on Iraq always includes those two words. Were my expectations too high for this woman to know that there were at least “2 kinds of Muslims”? That was an ignorant moment recently.
 
P.S. on second thought, that lady might have been living overseas for a part of the 2000s and she is not the world affairs type and really doesn’t like any details of any conflict (domestic or intl). Chosen ignorance? Probably.

title: What is a good workout routine at home?
article:
1, Push Ups
 
Push-ups work many muscles in your body, including your:
Chest
Arms
Stomach muscles (abdominals)
Hips‌
Legs
Push-ups are a convenient exercise that you can do anywhere. They don’t need equipment or a gym membership. You can also adjust them to meet your own physical ability or to target specific muscles.
 
How To Do it: To do a push-up you are going to get on the floor on all fours, positioning your hands slightly wider than your shoulders. Don't lock out the elbows; keep them slightly bent. Extend your legs back so you are balanced on your hands and toes, your feet hip-width apart. Once in 
Continue Reading
1, Push Ups
 
Push-ups work many muscles in your body, including your:
Chest
Arms
Stomach muscles (abdominals)
Hips‌
Legs
Push-ups are a convenient exercise that you can do anywhere. They don’t need equipment or a gym membership. You can also adjust them to meet your own physical ability or to target specific muscles.
 
How To Do it: To do a push-up you are going to get on the floor on all fours, positioning your hands slightly wider than your shoulders. Don't lock out the elbows; keep them slightly bent. Extend your legs back so you are balanced on your hands and toes, your feet hip-width apart. Once in this position, here is how you will do a push-up.
Contract your abs and tighten your core by pulling your belly button toward your spine.
Inhale as you slowly bend your elbows and lower yourself to the floor, until your elbows are at a 90-degree angle.
Exhale while contracting your chest muscles and pushing back up through your hands, returning to the start position.
2. Glute Bridge
 
A glute bridge is an exercise that can be used to target the gluteal muscles. It is often seen in warm up segments or strength/accessory training segments to increase glute activation, strength, and muscle hypertrophy.
 
How To Do It:
Lie face up on the floor, with your knees bent and feet flat on the ground. Keep your arms at your side with your palms down.
Lift your hips off the ground until your knees, hips and shoulders form a straight line. Squeeze those glutes hard and keep your abs drawn in so you don’t overextend your back during the exercise.
Hold your bridged position for a couple of seconds before easing back down.
3. Toe-touch
 
Strengthen your abdominal muscles with an exercise that combines the toe touch and the crunch and is sometimes referred to as the toe-touch crunch, or the vertical toe touch.The toe touching ab exercise primarily trains your rectus abdominis -- the muscle that makes up your six-pack. Your core, however, includes your side obliques, transverse abdominis, back stabilizers and pelvic floor.
 
How To Do It:
Lie on your back with your palms down by your sides. Bend your knees and bring them toward your torso, then slowly start to straighten your legs. They should ultimately end up perpendicular to the ground.
Lift your arms. While exhaling, slowly roll your shoulders up off the mat, reaching towards your toes. Round your shoulders forward (but keep them down) to create a concave shape with your torso. Your lower back should stay on the ground, but don’t press it into the floor — that’ll flatten the natural curve of your lower back and take you out of the correct position.
Inhale as you lower back down. When you reach the ground, keep the tension in your abs firing. In other words, don’t just relax on the mat. That's one rep.

title: How to workout
article:
> “The Journey of a Thousand Miles Begins With One Step.”
 
― Lao Tzu
 
The Importance of Exercise
 
To maximize my health, my must consume essential nutrients, have plenty of rest, and exercise regularly. Depending on my fitness level, exercise could be as simple as taking a short walk to increase my heart rate and blood flow.
 
I don't need an intense workout such as heavy weightlifting or high-intensity 
Continue Reading
> “The Journey of a Thousand Miles Begins With One Step.”
 
― Lao Tzu
 
The Importance of Exercise
 
To maximize my health, my must consume essential nutrients, have plenty of rest, and exercise regularly. Depending on my fitness level, exercise could be as simple as taking a short walk to increase my heart rate and blood flow.
 
I don't need an intense workout such as heavy weightlifting or high-intensity interval training (HIIT).
How I exercise depends on my health goals. For example, if I want to lose fat and gain muscle, I will focus on heavy compound movements. In addition, my diet is extremely critical.
 
To keep myself motivated, I measure my results. Furthermore, I don't compare myself to others because everyone’s body is different. Every person has his or her unique different genetics, health, and fitness history. The only person I compare to is my former self.
 
I focus on my progress.
 
Persistence and consistency are the two key factors for achieving my goals.
 
Break Through Your Plateau
 
After reaching a certain fitness level, your body will stagnate because it has adapted to those changes. This is great if your goal is to maintain. But if you want to break through the plateau, your body must experience a higher intensity or resistance.
 
This is when progressive overload applies.
 
To get stronger and have more muscle for a particular body part, your body must experience a higher amount of resistance.
 
For example, if you can lift 125 pounds for your barbell military press for 4 to 6 reps and you want more strength and muscles in your shoulders, you must increase the weights during your workouts. Along with proper macronutrients fueling and rest, you will gain more strength and shoulder definition over time.
But the process could take longer if you want to increase muscle and strength while minimizing fat. To do so, you can first bulk to gain fat and muscle. Afterward, you can cut to maintain muscle while losing fat.
 
However, if you're new to weightlifting, you can quickly build muscle while losing fat.
 
Focus on Exercises which Excite You
 
If your goal is to maintain optimal health, then performing enjoyable exercises will be your most desirable and sustainable approach. That's because you're more likely to exercise if you look forward to them. Such options might be a dance class, morning group hike, or a run with your dog.
 
For example, one of my personal favorite hobbies is rock-climbing.
Although it's challenging, I look forward to going to the rock-climbing gym because I find it extremely fun and engaging. It's both physically and mentally difficult because I have many ways of finishing the problem.
 
Working out with a partner can make your exercise session even more enjoyable, not to also mention accountability - you both don't want to let the other person down. In addition to improving your health, you get to spend quality time with them which further deepends your relationship.
 
Producing many health benefits, exercise is an excellent way to release endorphins, ...

“I’m not sure, but 
DEFINITELY
 not Nico.” Nico being my favorite character, I was shocked and a bit surprised to hear this, but I was willing to give her the benefit of the doubt. Perhaps she disagreed with his standoffish behavior, or his questionable decisions early on in the series.
 
“Why?”
 
“He likes Percy.”
 
“So?”
 
“Percy’s a guy.”
 
“I know.”
 
“But that’s just so weird! I mean, boys like girls! Why would he like a guy?”
 
“That’s who he likes. Some people do, you know.”
 
“What? Really?”
 
“Actually, around ten percent of people like the same gender.”
 
“That’s gross. It’s wrong!” I’m bisexual, but I can handle a reasonable amount of homophobia. I generally don’t try to change people’s opinions on one of their core beliefs, and since she wasn’t saying Nico should die or anything, I did the reasonable thing. I tried to start a discussion on it.
 
“Why?”
 
“People are supposed to reproduce.” This was the typical beginning to a decent argument I’ve heard before, so I expected her to start saying that. Instead, she said, “You can’t have babies unless you’re married.” 
Uhhh… What?!
 
“Actually, people who are just dating can have a kid too.” I was also going to explain that gay marriage is now legal.
 
“No they can’t. It’s physically not possible unless you get married.”
 
“You mean when a couple are… 
together
?”
 
“No, getting married, like a wedding.” That is to say, the celebration where women typically wear white.
 
“What?”
 
“You know what, this conversation is pointless. You don’t get it. We should just stop.”
 
She later proceeded to go on a rant about how we didn’t need plastic or any synthetic materials to maintain our present society the way it is. She also related a series of pretty questionable laws of physics (that is to say, completely and obviously false). In addition, she told us that scientists today had the technology to “magically change the atoms in metal into some sort of big atom that makes up a car that can move on its own” without requiring any sort of energy to move it (or wheels, for that matter). I believe she also declared butter did not contain oil. Yes, she did indeed say “magically”.
 
Perhaps her parents simply have not told her these things yet. She had clearly gone through puberty, though, so I don’t know why.
 
I don’t meet a lot of ignorant people, as I generally am surrounded by my rather intelligent, philosophical friends, so maybe she isn’t very ignorant. She’s just the most ignorant one I know.

title: What is a good weekly workout?
article:
Thanks for the A2A!
 
First, I admire your ambition!!  If you only have an hour a day to dedicate to improving your body, exercise is a great start.  Some people 
only
 have that hour a day (Tony Robbins calls it the "Hour of Power"), and working hard is a great way to give back to yourself.
 
Second, if you're interested in weight loss and being healthy, I agree with another answer on here....diet is the first key.  Weight loss/fat loss/overall heatlh is like 75% diet, 25% exercise.  So you'll need to do some research on that first (some great sources are eattoperform or bengreenfieldfitness to start
Continue Reading
Thanks for the A2A!
 
First, I admire your ambition!!  If you only have an hour a day to dedicate to improving your body, exercise is a great start.  Some people 
only
 have that hour a day (Tony Robbins calls it the "Hour of Power"), and working hard is a great way to give back to yourself.
 
Second, if you're interested in weight loss and being healthy, I agree with another answer on here....diet is the first key.  Weight loss/fat loss/overall heatlh is like 75% diet, 25% exercise.  So you'll need to do some research on that first (some great sources are eattoperform or bengreenfieldfitness to start).
 
As for a weekly plan....  Honestly, I'm apprehesive to suggest anything specific simply because I don't know you or your body and how you respond to movement.  The exercises you mentioned - dance, strength, yoga and running - are all very effective in helping with gaining strength and improving cardio health.  I say try one each day and see what you're drawn to.  You can also try high intensity training (also known at HIT or HIIT).  Even try studios like Orangetheory, Pure Barre, even Crossfit.  See what you'll like and what you're willing to continue with. What piques your interest is what you'll be willing to dedicate your time to and work for.
 
I do agree that running for weight loss is a tricky topic.  I suggest you do more research on it.  But doing sprints and tempo runs work really well with increasing VO2 max capacities and help bring you into a fat burning mode instead of sugar burning (this is ben greenfield's aim).  
 
Alternate your workouts.  Don't forget to build in rest.  And working out a solid hour a day HARD isn't necessary.  Get your heart rate up 20-30 minutes a day for strength training and cardio.  Work your body hard during that short time...push yourself.  It'll be more effective than spending an hour in the gym mindlessly lifting weights.  Give yourself some bodywork therapy (pilates, yoga) to balance out the other workouts (those can be an hour - 90 min).   
 
Finally, while I don't feel comfortable giving  you a specific workout, I can tell you what's worked for me in the past:
 
Day 1 - strength training (20-30) with a trainer...hard
 
Day 2 - sprint or tempo work
 
Day 3 - Pilates
 
Day 4 - strength training
 
Day 5 - spring or tempo work 
 
Day 6 - Yoga
 
Day 7 - Rest
 
Since I'm a Pilates instructor, I usually do Pilates mat/props 5-6 days a week.  But those listed on the above schedule are sessions in the studio either guided by another instructor or myself on the machinery.   
 
So...
find studios/workouts/trainers that you'll stick with which also push you
do strength training and hard cardio 20-30 min on those designated days
try hour long classes for dance, yoga, and pilates
don't forget to rest
work your diet to support your new activities
Good luck!!

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
As an American with a pretty good handle on geography (I’ve lived for a time on a few different continents), I will confirm the suspicion of a lot of people re: geography. American education does not spend all that much time on geography. I realized this when I studied history in university ; )
 
That being said, I’ve met the same level of geographical and cultural ignorance in every other country I’ve visited (most especially China, but European countries as well). (BTW, never judge a whole country by the representation of a couple of teenagers. Teenagers tend to be pretty dumb. They’re still wo
Continue Reading
As an American with a pretty good handle on geography (I’ve lived for a time on a few different continents), I will confirm the suspicion of a lot of people re: geography. American education does not spend all that much time on geography. I realized this when I studied history in university ; )
 
That being said, I’ve met the same level of geographical and cultural ignorance in every other country I’ve visited (most especially China, but European countries as well). (BTW, never judge a whole country by the representation of a couple of teenagers. Teenagers tend to be pretty dumb. They’re still working it out.)
 
Americans are at a unique disadvantage in this regard because the whole world is obsessed with our film, music, politics, culture, etc. So everybody knows what’s going on in our country. This creates a false sense of awareness around the world, and ignorance in America. The truth is, an Italian might know all the current events in American politics, but they probably have no idea what’s going on in Senegal, West Africa. Someone in Columbia might have seen the newest film release from Hollywood, but they don’t have a clue who the most popular pop star is in South Korea, etc. etc. etc. And for that matter, I’ve been met with blank stares from people from Switzerland, the UK, Austria, Australia, etc. when I say I’m from Pennsylvania. They don’t know where Pennsylvania is (just south of New York—they know that one); they just know where America is.
 
Knowing where America is without knowing where the individual states are is, geographically speaking, not that different from knowing where Europe is, but not knowing the exact borders of each country. There are a lot of cultures, land, and people in between New York and California. This is also why Europeans tend to enjoy international travel much more (and more cheaply) than Americans. Me traveling to San Francisco, my own country, would be like a German traveling well into Russia. And I’ve heard more than once a European or Asian saying they want to travel to all the major landmarks in the U.S. in a week or two. I just smile and nod.
 
Despite all this, everybody likes to gather together and laugh about how ignorant Americans are. Well, it’s not that simple, and they’re often betraying their own prejudices. All that to say, I don’t expect non-Americans to memorize our state map (that’s not your responsibility) or understand our cultures when all you see are sensationalized headlines in the news and Hollywood blockbusters (and no, I don’t know Kobe Bryant; he’s not my neighbor; yes, I’ve been asked this). But I would love for everybody to judge a bit less. The one thing I’ve learned from traveling the world is that we’re all unbelievably shaped by our immediate surroundings, and none of us has as much justification to judge as we might think.

title: How to workout
article:
Traditional cardio is at best a waste of time, and at worst counter productive. Forget it.. especially for your goals. Ill spare you the long drawn out explaination as to why.
 
To get toned, you need weights and proper nutrition. To lose the fat you have to get your nutrition on point.. theres just no way around it. Its 80% of the game. I recommend a paleo diet consisting of organic meats and vegetables, some fruit and nuts and the occasional root tubor 2 or so days a week. But meat and veggies os the way to balance your hormones and lose the fat.
 
As for training.. if youve never lifted before i 
Continue Reading
Traditional cardio is at best a waste of time, and at worst counter productive. Forget it.. especially for your goals. Ill spare you the long drawn out explaination as to why.
 
To get toned, you need weights and proper nutrition. To lose the fat you have to get your nutrition on point.. theres just no way around it. Its 80% of the game. I recommend a paleo diet consisting of organic meats and vegetables, some fruit and nuts and the occasional root tubor 2 or so days a week. But meat and veggies os the way to balance your hormones and lose the fat.
 
As for training.. if youve never lifted before i URGE you to hire a trainer. You don't have to work out with a trainer for ever but it is important to learn proper form and technique learn what exercises work what muscle groups and Lauren how hard to push yourself how long to wait between exercises order of exercises excetera excetera. Doing research is great but as I'm sure you have noticed for every answer you find you will find someone who says the opposite. Without a professional guiding you often times it's hard to know what advice to take comma granted not all “expert” advice in the health and field industry is really expert LOL. And not all trainers are created equal. You want someone with at least a year experience ask them about their previous clients and their success stories ask them about their methods and protocols and the reason why they use those methods. If they can't give you concrete answers to those questions look for a different trainer.
 
I recommend I recommend weight training 2 days a week and doing two days of interval cardio. I like weights on Monday Thursday cardio Tuesday Friday. Focus on major muscle group multi-joint compound movements. No I promise you you will not get big bulky muscles. You will get strong lean and toned. Working the big muscles using the compound exercises burns the most calories and elicit the greatest hormone response and it's the hormones that really get the job done. Lyft hard-and-fast good in work hard for about 30 minutes and go home there's no reason to lift for more than that the training is determined by effort not volume or duration. So push hard for a short time until you feel and then go do something else. Interval cardio means going as hard as you can for a short period And then resting for a short period and repeating. The routine I like is only 4 minutes you go all out maximum Sprint for 20 seconds then walk for 10 seconds and repeat eight times. That routine is clinically proven four times more effective at both muscle building and fat burning when performed twice a week with 100% maximum effort than 60 Minutes of traditional steady state cardio performed five days a week. Yes you read correctly 8 minutes is superior to 300 minutes as long as you push 100%. Good luck.

title: Is a morning gym workout better than an evening gym workout?
article:
No. Absolutely Not.
 
I work out in the evening after my 9–5 desk job. You can workout in the morning, afternoon, evening or 3am. It doesn’t matter. Morning workout does not fit in my schedule because I like to sleep in the morning plus i have to be at work. My buddy goes to gym at 2am sometime and still looks solid.
 
Here is my 1 year 3 months progress. I work out around 6pm. I take minimum supplements. Food is everything i have.
Left picture is last week on my cut. Right picture is Jan 2016 end of my bulk. Happy with my progress so far. I was always skinny. Last year i was 130lbs and now 153lbs.
 
Wh
Continue Reading
No. Absolutely Not.
 
I work out in the evening after my 9–5 desk job. You can workout in the morning, afternoon, evening or 3am. It doesn’t matter. Morning workout does not fit in my schedule because I like to sleep in the morning plus i have to be at work. My buddy goes to gym at 2am sometime and still looks solid.
 
Here is my 1 year 3 months progress. I work out around 6pm. I take minimum supplements. Food is everything i have.
Left picture is last week on my cut. Right picture is Jan 2016 end of my bulk. Happy with my progress so far. I was always skinny. Last year i was 130lbs and now 153lbs.
 
What matters is what you do for rest of the 22 hours.
 
I sometime workout in the morning and i unable to lift very heavy because of less food. My body is just trained and used to it for evening workout.
 
Your diet should be on point (With cheat meal once or twice a week) if you want good physique. I sleep at least 9 hours. I drink lots of water during the day. I don’t drink, maybe once a month. I don’t eat junk food. I prepare my meals on Sunday.
 
You have to put in some work to build good physique. It’s 100% worth it. I just came back from physical check up. My blood press is low which is great. My Heart is very healthy. The cholesterol level check is on point. Blood Sugar is good. Ear H2o is perfect.
 
Because i workout in the evening, i am very careful what type of food i eat until 4pm. i don’t need energy (Carbs) so i eat small amount of carbs, fat and bunch of protein.
 
My breakfast is very very light and quick. I make smoothies in the morning. Again, i love to sleep in the morning till 8am so i always find an opportunity to get out of the door quickly.
 
8:30am: Smoothies include 1 cup egg whites, 1/2 cup oats, 1 scoop protein powder, 1 tb spoon chia seed, lots of spinach and blueberries.
 
10:30: I make Kodiak pancake with 2 eggs in the morning while drinking smoothie. It’s very quick.
 
1:00pm: 5 oz Chicken and broccoli. Sometimes i throw in yams on a heavy day like back or legs.
 
4:00pm I eat half pita bread or Yams with 5 oz chicken or shrimp. I start introducing carbs now for energy.
 
Workout
 
7:30pm: I go home and make a quick smoothie again. 1 cup oats, 1 scoop protein powder and egg whites.
 
8:00pm: 7 oz steak or salmon with green beans or green peppers.
 
Total Macro: 220P, 192C, 52F
 
I recently started doing 20 minutes cardio after lifting. I lift 6 days a week and Sunday is rest and meal prep day. I do HIIT twice a week to really get shredded.
 
Honestly,
 Working out and getting fit is like trial and error. You have to know your body. What fits for you might not work for me. You will not know until you try.
 
Follow me on Instagram
 nickfitfreak
 if you want to see workout videos and my meals.
 
Happy to help if you have any question. Happy Lifting.

title: How often should I workout for best results?
article:
The best workout is the one you don't skip.
 
Look, you can discuss sets and reps, crossfit and powerlifting, diet and supplements endlessly. And there is some value in it, if only just for entertainment sometimes (especially on the internet). But let's just get one thing straight here - if you are doing 
any
 kind of workout then it's going to have a greater impact than if you weren't. Simple as that.
 
Of course there are caveats. You don't want to get hurt, so they can pretty much all be summed up into one commandment: Thou shalt not be an idiot. Getting under a bar loaded with 495 lbs and squattin
Continue Reading
The best workout is the one you don't skip.
 
Look, you can discuss sets and reps, crossfit and powerlifting, diet and supplements endlessly. And there is some value in it, if only just for entertainment sometimes (especially on the internet). But let's just get one thing straight here - if you are doing 
any
 kind of workout then it's going to have a greater impact than if you weren't. Simple as that.
 
Of course there are caveats. You don't want to get hurt, so they can pretty much all be summed up into one commandment: Thou shalt not be an idiot. Getting under a bar loaded with 495 lbs and squatting it is an experience reserved for a very small percentage of people. There is zero reason to think that you need to do that unless you are 100% sure you can. And the people that do it take safety precautions when they do because they know s@&t can go sideways for the best of us so it makes sense to be prepared. That doesn't mean don't lift heavy. It 
does
 mean that heavy is a relative concept, not an absolute one. If 95 lbs feels super-heavy to you on bench then guess what? It is. The dude on the bench next to you repping 315 is not relevant to your perception.
 
You know all the things people like to give huge importance to? Things like “How long should I rest between sets?”, “How many reps should I do?”, “Are preacher curls better than standing curls?”, “Should I drink a protein shake during my workout or after? How long after?” … are all interesting questions but the truth is the answers have more to do with refinement than gross progress. Get in, lift weights, eat food and don't be an idiot and you will build muscle.
 
Then there's cardio. Want to create a calorie deficit? Do cardio. Want to improve your heart’s performance? Do cardio. Should you do HIIT? Sure. Why not. Should you do long, slow duration? Sounds good. My rule for cardio is this: if you're just putting in the time then you won't get too much out of it. Come up with little challenges for yourself and then beat them. Maybe it's a certain calories/minute average. Maybe it's maintaining a certain speed for a certain time. Maybe it's keeping your heart rate above a certain number. Maybe it's that you want your shirt to be fully drenched when you're done. Whatever it is I promise that setting a goal and then beating it will ensure your cardio has an impact. Getting too detailed about it is great for refinement but once again the gross value is in making it happen.
 
Most of us who train won't be Mr. Olympia, or win an Ironman triathlon. At the elite levels there are little refinements that need to be made, but those vary on an individual basis. For the general population who wants to be fit, healthy and strong (and look good along the way) overthinking is overwhelming. As Nike so perfectly puts it, just do it.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
The most ignorant person I have ever met is 
ME
.
 
When did I realize this?
 
I will tell you that in a second.
 
Before that...
 
I was born in a rural village in South India.
 
I went to colleges in small cities in my state.
 
I have visited my neighboring states during our school excursions.
 
I have never been to North India.
 
But I was a voracious reader.
 
I spent most of my free time in library reading non-fiction books.
 
I subscribed to "
Reader's Digest
" and read every word of it when I was in college.
 
I bought a bunch of General Knowledge books, read about the world and even memorized capitals of all the countries
Continue Reading
The most ignorant person I have ever met is 
ME
.
 
When did I realize this?
 
I will tell you that in a second.
 
Before that...
 
I was born in a rural village in South India.
 
I went to colleges in small cities in my state.
 
I have visited my neighboring states during our school excursions.
 
I have never been to North India.
 
But I was a voracious reader.
 
I spent most of my free time in library reading non-fiction books.
 
I subscribed to "
Reader's Digest
" and read every word of it when I was in college.
 
I bought a bunch of General Knowledge books, read about the world and even memorized capitals of all the countries in the world.
 
I did my Masters in Computer Science.
 
None of these helped me to rid of my ignorance.
 
In March 1998, I came to USA on H1B visa.
 
Pretty soon, I was going to realize that my bookish knowledge is not enough. I need to have worldly knowledge as well which can be achieved by travelling and talking to people from different walks of life.
 
In my second week, I had the following conversation with my colleague during the lunch break.
 
She was in her 50s. I was 24 at that time.
 
ME:
 I saw Tom Cruise movie yesterday.
 
Gwen
: What movie is that?
 
ME
: Mission: Impossible
 
Gwen
: Tom Cruise is an action star like John Wayne in 60s.
 
ME
: Who is John Wayne?
 
Gwen
: He was a very popular action hero in 50s and 60s. We call him "Duke". He was famous for his macho, tough guy movie roles.
 
ME
: Oh..ok. He is like our MGR.
 
Gwen
: (calmly) who is MGR?
 
ME
: (Shocked) 
YOU DON'T KNOW WHO MGR IS?
 
Gwen
: no.
 
I was completely shocked. How could a person not know about 
MGR
?
 
For people who don't know who MGR(M. G. Ramachandran) is, he was a very popular movie star in my state who played mostly macho and tough guy roles in 50s and 60s.
He was very handsome, charismatic, kind-hearted, generous and charitable person. He is known for his charitable nature. People loved him.
 
People in rural parts of my state considered him as God. He entered into politics and became 
Chief Minister 
(Similar to Governor in USA). He was Chief Minister for 10 years from 1977 to 1987 until he died at the age of 70.
 
I didn't realize that I was living in my little cocoon and I believed that everyone knew about MGR as he was popular in my state.
 
I didn't realize that my state and our hero/CM is a speck in the whole world. Remember, this is before globalization, Google, Cell phones(not very common at that time), Youtube, etc.
 
In spite of all my bookish knowledge about the world, I was so ignorant that I sincerely believed that every one in the world knew about my little “world” and I unreasonably expected a person in US who is 8000 miles away from my little state to know about my hero/CM who passed away 11 years back.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
Very, very few. I have met ignorant people of all nations, including my native UK. As to Americans, those from the USA, very few stand out as a ignorant. I’ve met a lot of people from the USA over the years on their turf and on mine. The vast majority were absolutely spot on friendly people.
 
There might be 5 who have pissed me off, but this was down to working culture and shit throwing between themselves.
 
I would like to nominate two for joint first though.
 
We saved your asses in WW2
 
This was a bar in a hotel in the Netherlands. It was the regular stay for a lot of civilian contractors for a US ba
Continue Reading
Very, very few. I have met ignorant people of all nations, including my native UK. As to Americans, those from the USA, very few stand out as a ignorant. I’ve met a lot of people from the USA over the years on their turf and on mine. The vast majority were absolutely spot on friendly people.
 
There might be 5 who have pissed me off, but this was down to working culture and shit throwing between themselves.
 
I would like to nominate two for joint first though.
 
We saved your asses in WW2
 
This was a bar in a hotel in the Netherlands. It was the regular stay for a lot of civilian contractors for a US base close by. All except one, were truly good folks. We could laugh, joke and drink together in the bar and it was a warm ex-pat feel. The new guy decided to drop his limited overseas understanding out to the barmaid. Dotty knows my wife and kids and has given them loads of tips for stuff to do when I couldn’t get away from the office. The guy was a smoking hole after Dotty planted him with a tirade on things like pointing up the road, “you find me one American grave there, you won’t, and I can show you Canadians and British”. His colleagues were truly embarrassed for unleashing this prick on the locals without a briefing. I got a memory of the other folks having a laugh at dickhead’s expense and leaving Dotty a tip and an apology. One guy in the whole crowd was an ignorant American, the rest were simply a great bunch of folks.
 
What do you mean you don’t want my money?
 
This was a whiney east coaster in a cigar shop in Edinburgh. I’m perusing a couple of Cubans and this c#ck pushes ahead of me to the counter as his son wants a cigar and NOW. A middle aged guy in a nice suit was stood by the door. Whiney starts to bitch, moan and make squeaky noises at the counter staff and me. He would not shut up and was making a scene, but no-one really cared. All I wanted was to choose a selection, get it boxed, pay and leave. Whiney has to interrupt me every time I opened my mouth, even thought the rude little turd had shoved his way in. I get bored of bad manners very quickly. Turned to his attendant in the suit, “Bodyguard, minder, that kind of thing?”, Whiney was not engaged, just ranting at the counter folks and suit said with a gentle smile, “just the driver that the hotel provides”. “Excellent, could you tell your cargo that an apology or his teeth are the next things out his mouth?”. Whiney, simply did the third option and fucked off. I’m not saying that he got lot labelled as ignorant was because he was American, but because he was American and made a complete twat out of himself.
 
Summary
 
Out of the many folks I have met from the USA, I can only point to those two pricks above as outliers. There are others, but they would be dickheads anywhere on the planet.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
I was traveling around the US and met him whilst staying at a hostel.
 
I shared my experience with US cops (one time I was jaywalking at 4:30 in the morning and got stopped like a criminal having to get my hands out of my pockets, to put my bag on the car, provide my ID all when spoken to with that typical tone of voice, but it looked and sounded really blown out of proportion(at first I thought the policeman will pull out his gun); the other time I was in Texas and I was queueing to board the bus when the guy in front of me got stopped and searched by a narcotics team. Right after coming up to 
Continue Reading
I was traveling around the US and met him whilst staying at a hostel.
 
I shared my experience with US cops (one time I was jaywalking at 4:30 in the morning and got stopped like a criminal having to get my hands out of my pockets, to put my bag on the car, provide my ID all when spoken to with that typical tone of voice, but it looked and sounded really blown out of proportion(at first I thought the policeman will pull out his gun); the other time I was in Texas and I was queueing to board the bus when the guy in front of me got stopped and searched by a narcotics team. Right after coming up to him they asked me if I was with him and I said -no. They kept on talking to me and ended up asking me if I was on drugs and if I had any narcotics on me because I 'seemed very happy' and repeated that a good few times until it started looking quite serious and until I stopped smiling.)
 
I was telling him how it would never happen in Europe.
 
This guy tells me how it's not true and how he was stopped in Germany randomly and asked for the passport and that he thinks it's because they thought he's a migrant from Africa. Then he says: 'I'm trying to tell them that I'm from from America that I'm an American… '. He kept on repeating this to me. I asked why all this emphasis. He said because there's not a single American who would like to live in Europe. Because America has it all. And they can have anything they want. So there's no point in going anywhere else in the world.
 
Shocking.
 
I said there are plenty of things.
 
Like free education.
 
He said they have free education too but people are too lazy to look for it. That you can get a scholarship for being white, for being black, for being a male, a female and so on and so forth…
 
Then I said: 'how about healthcare?'
 
He said it's the only thing we have against them but if you're employed then it doesn't matter because you will be insured…
 
Then I said: 'what about police brutality?'
 
He said 'I'm from Harlem and I've never been shot, if they get shot it's for doing something '. I asked him if he's seen all of those videos of people getting killed by the police for no reason. He repeated himself as a broken record with no supporting evidence of his statement. (He was also an African American so it was twice as hard to believe his point of view.)
 
It's easy to be ignorant for the things that are far away and don't concern you too much.
 
It is a whole different level of being this ignorant in your own country where you get to talk to people and hear their stories or at least to see the news.
 
That also came from a person who has traveled and been exposed to different cultures and surroundings.
 
I wish I had asked him about homelessness and mental health but I'm pretty sure he would've found an answer to that as well.

Full-Body Workouts (2-3 Times a Week)
 
Pros:
- 
Time Efficient:
 You can achieve significant results with fewer sessions per week.
- 
Increased Frequency:
 Each muscle group is worked multiple times a week, which can enhance muscle growth and strength.

 Easier to schedule and can accommodate busy weeks without losing progress.

Continue Reading
The effectiveness of a full-body workout versus a split routine largely depends on your fitness goals, experience level, and available time. Here’s a breakdown of both approaches:
 
Full-Body Workouts (2-3 Times a Week)
 
Pros:
- 
Time Efficient:
 You can achieve significant results with fewer sessions per week.
- 
Increased Frequency:
 Each muscle group is worked multiple times a week, which can enhance muscle growth and strength.
- 
Flexibility:
 Easier to schedule and can accommodate busy weeks without losing progress.
- 
Caloric Burn:
 Engaging multiple muscle groups can lead to a higher calorie burn per session.
 
Cons:
- 
Intensity Management:
 It can be challenging to perform high-intensity workouts for all muscle groups in one session.
- 
Recovery Needs:
 May require longer recovery time between sessions, especially if workouts are intense.
 
Split Routines (5-6 Days a Week)
 
Pros:
- 
Focused Workouts:
 Allows for higher volume and intensity per muscle group, which can be beneficial for hypertrophy (muscle growth).
- 
Recovery:
 Muscle groups get more recovery time between workouts, potentially reducing fatigue.
- 
Variety:
 More exercise variations and techniques can be incorporated.
 
Cons:
- 
Time Commitment:
 Requires more days in the gym, which may not be feasible for everyone.
- 
Risk of Imbalance:
 If a session is missed, it might lead to uneven training of muscle groups.
 
Getting the Best Results with Least Time Invested
Prioritize Compound Movements:
 Focus on exercises that work multiple muscle groups at once (e.g., squats, deadlifts, bench presses, pull-ups). This maximizes efficiency.
High-Intensity Training:
 Incorporate techniques like supersets, circuit training, or high-intensity interval training (HIIT) to increase the intensity and calorie burn within a shorter time frame.
Progressive Overload:
 Ensure you are gradually increasing the weight or resistance in your workouts to continue making progress.
Consistency:
 Stick to a regular workout schedule, whether it’s full-body or split, to maintain progress.
Nutrition and Recovery:
 Pay attention to your diet and recovery strategies, as they are crucial for maximizing results. Ensure adequate protein intake and consider active recovery strategies.
Listen to Your Body:
 Adjust your training volume and intensity based on how your body responds to avoid burnout or injury.
Conclusion
 
Both full-body workouts and split routines can be effective, but for minimal time investment, full-body workouts (2-3 times a week) are generally more efficient for most people. However, if you prefer or can commit to a split routine and it fits your goals better, it can also yield excellent results. Ultimately, choose the method that you enjoy and can stick with consistently.

article:

At any rate, it was… 1985… or 1987. I don’t remember, but it was the year our high school band went to Florida for our Band Trip, and we marched in Disney World. We were all proud at first, thinking we had been selected… but then someone found out that any marching band can have the privilege provided they apply for the opportunity.
 
The trip was a disaste
Continue Reading
This is contextual. I’ve gone for a good many years without thinking of other people in terms of being the “most ignorant”… mostly because I’ve actually been pointing out to many people how the word ignorant doesn’t define out to mean “stupid”.
 
At any rate, it was… 1985… or 1987. I don’t remember, but it was the year our high school band went to Florida for our Band Trip, and we marched in Disney World. We were all proud at first, thinking we had been selected… but then someone found out that any marching band can have the privilege provided they apply for the opportunity.
 
The trip was a disaster. We, a marching band set up for November football games in New England fall/winter means that our only uniform was a warm wool one. Yeah. We marched in that, in Disney, in April. Two kids passed out from heat stroke, and one from heat exhaustion. Two out of three, although I don’t know how many had heat cramps. So… definitely some ignorance there in regards to the “right uniform for the gig”.
 
But no… this was at some point when we were on our own, and a few of us went into get ice cream on Main Street. My friend Matt… played trumpet… Matt M. Matthews. Yes, his name is… Matthew M. Matthews. I don’t know if he was joking when he told me his middle name was also Matthew, but he did laugh at the time. Anyway, Matt was in front of me, and he asked for two scoops of coffee ice cream on a waffle cone.
 
See, we lived in New England where in grade school in the 70’s, we had three choices of milk in the cafeteria; Plain, Chocolate, or Coffee. At home, there was Elipse syrup right next to the Hershey’s or Quik or Ovaltine. Eclipse was coffee syrup you could pour into milk and make coffee milk, like you add chocolate mix to milk and make chocolate milk. We were also raised with Coffee Ice Cream being a flavor just like any other flavor.
 
Ok. So this was Rhode Island. C’mon… we couldn’t have been THAT far ahead of the rest of the world, could we?
 
But as it turned out, in the mid 80’s in Florida… they had never heard of Coffee Ice Cream.
 
The girl at the counter asks my friend Matt.. “Would you like cream and sugar with that?”
 
Matt was like “On the scoops? If you only have soft serve that’s fine.”
 
She was clearly confused “No, I mean in your coffee. Do you want cream and sugar in your coffee?”
 
Matt picked up on it before I did “You never heard of coffee ice cream?”
 
She was visibly astonished with the idea “That sounds delicious! No, we don’t have no coffee ice cream here.”
 
I was just a little astonished myself to be on Main Street USA in Disney World in the 80’s… to find out they had never heard of coffee ice cream (or coffee milk as we were to also find out). Main Street USA was ignorant of coffee flavoring for ice cream and milk.

Push press has been showed to produce more rate of f
Continue Reading
CLEAN (full squat, not “power clean”)
 
PUSH PRESS (standing, overhead press with explosive leg drive)
 
CHIN UPS (hanging from a dead hang, TOUCH CHEST TO BAR (weighted))
 
ONE
 
The clean works grip, core, hams, glutes, quads, lumbar spine/lower back, lats (yes), spinal erectors, traps, neck and possible a little of biceps (when geting it down) and probably a ton of muscles I don’t even know about. It works those muscles explosively and in a natural, athletic fashion. It builds explosive strength from the floor, squat strength and quick hip flexion.
 
TWO
 
Push press has been showed to produce more rate of force development in the legs than squats or even cleans do. A shorts rom, but enough to give you power to jumpe, sprint etc (which is a short rom too if you break it down). With heavy weights over your head, everything under (back, core, glutes and ofc shoulders girdle) it has to stabilise it, like pillars holding a roof. It devolops massive triceps and delts, even traps and CHEST. Yes. The entire upper body except biceps and. Unlike chest presses, overhead presses develops the delt much much better, and works the meatiest part of the tricep more. You will have a more round chest (less down-heavy like benchers) and wider, rounder delts. Also produces less injury than benching due to more balansed development (and you can actually drop it on the floor, unlike a bench press..). The weight will be heavy AF on the way down since you used legs to get it up. Humans are stronger on exentric reps, and this exercise is actually HEAVIER for that part, which is unique. It may allow you to hold weights close to your max bench OVERHEAD and standing up. Possibly the #1 exercise of all time.
 
THREE
 
Weighted chins will develop the muscles that have already been hit, but not hammered. 2/3 of your torso muscles (or more) will be crushed. Biceps, forearms, lats, rhomboids, rear delts (which compensates for the push press), lower and middle traps, abs and even a bit of upper chest (according to studies). Can be done very heavy.
 
If you get to a 1.5x weight on all these exercises (on chins that means adding 50% of your own bw) for a few reps, you will not have any imbalance. Unlike squat bench and dead, these exercise includes explosive training. They will also give you better delts and traps and a more “masculine”chest. You will be more athletic with those, and more balanced. Squat bench dead has no upper body pulling to work biceps and rear delts, and the bench almost exclusively works the front part. Bad. Another benefit is that squats and deads have higher injury risk, but explosive movements with a moderate weight might build the same size without overloading soft tissue.
 
Please let me know what you think

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
