title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
I’m an American too and this was with teens (around 16–17) but this incident made me want to cry.
 
I was visiting my grandparents up in Minnesota it was our last day when I saw some neighborhood teens hanging out, at the time I was around 14 or 15 and decided to go make some new friends before I left so when I came back I’d actually know people. I went up and introduced myself to them, they seemed like an okay group at first glance. A girl with sandy blonde hair (Girl 1) who was roughly 16 and another girl with the most beautiful curly locks of brown hair I have ever seen, probably the 17 year o
Continue Reading
I’m an American too and this was with teens (around 16–17) but this incident made me want to cry.
 
I was visiting my grandparents up in Minnesota it was our last day when I saw some neighborhood teens hanging out, at the time I was around 14 or 15 and decided to go make some new friends before I left so when I came back I’d actually know people. I went up and introduced myself to them, they seemed like an okay group at first glance. A girl with sandy blonde hair (Girl 1) who was roughly 16 and another girl with the most beautiful curly locks of brown hair I have ever seen, probably the 17 year old. There was a guy with them who was a bit bigger, he wore nerdy glasses, and had a My Chemical Romance Shirt on (not judging I was wearing a band sweatshirt). Our conversation went a little like this,
 
Me: “Hi my name is Lexi. I’m from Ohio.”
 
*Two Girls Exchange Looks*
 
*Guy Pushes up His Glasses*
 
Guy: “O-Ohayo? Isn’t that in like… Japan?”
 
First off, for all you folks who don’t know what caused the confusion “おはよう” is a Japanese word meaning “good morning” it’s the casual form. Even as a nerdy teen myself the only Japanese show I had ever seen was Sailor Moon and it was the crappy dubbed version so I had no idea what he was talking about.
 
Me: “N-No, it’s a stat—”
 
Girl 1 to Guy: “Why would they name an American state after a Japanese word?”
 
Guy: “Maybe an Asian dude discovered it?”
 
Girl 2: “You guys can’t be this dumb.”
 
I remember getting really excited because I was losing all hope.
 
Girl 2: “Ohio is a country in America.”
 
Guy: “It’s possible for countries to be inside countries?”
 
Girl 1: “America is a continent you idiot.”
 
Girl 2 *Looks at me and smiles*: “How do you like America so far?”
 
I couldn’t believe my mind, these teenagers thought Ohio was a freaking country. I opened my mouth to correct them before catching myself and nodding.
 
Me: “It was nice meeting you, see you again some other time.”
 
Girl 2: “You don’t want to stay and hang out with us? We have soda in the refrigerator and chips. We were about to go inside and watch some movies too.”
 
Me: “Ah no t-that’s alright I have to go back to my… 
country
.”
 
They seemed upset and waved to me as I left, they somehow knew my grandmother too and would ask me when I’d be back so I could hang out with them. They were a nice group of kids just… Not the brightest. I didn’t talk to them ever since that day. I told my mom about it and she lost it.
 
Merica’

title: Is a morning gym workout better than an evening gym workout?
article:
In all honesty, It Doesn’t Matter. It is important to exercise and the time you choose to do so has little effect with regard to your results.
(Pic of me working out at mid night)
 
That being said, I have been training in the mornings for years now for various reasons. Here is why I think it helps:
 
Workout in the mornings:
 
If you’re on the fence about starting a morning workout routine, consider the following benefits.
Fewer distractions.
Morning workouts typically mean you’re less prone to distractions. When you first wake up, you haven’t started tackling the day’s 
to-do list
. You’re also less likel
Continue Reading
In all honesty, It Doesn’t Matter. It is important to exercise and the time you choose to do so has little effect with regard to your results.
(Pic of me working out at mid night)
 
That being said, I have been training in the mornings for years now for various reasons. Here is why I think it helps:
 
Workout in the mornings:
 
If you’re on the fence about starting a morning workout routine, consider the following benefits.
Fewer distractions.
Morning workouts typically mean you’re less prone to distractions. When you first wake up, you haven’t started tackling the day’s 
to-do list
. You’re also less likely to get phone calls, text messages, and emails.
 
With fewer distractions, you’re more likely to follow through with your workout.
Beat the heat.
In the summer, working out in the morning will feel more comfortable, as the hottest part of the day is 10 a.m. to 3 p.m. It’s recommended to avoid outdoor exercise during this time.
 
If you prefer outdoor activities, it’s best to work out in the early morning, especially on very hot days.
Increased alertness.
A morning workout may be a better match for your body’s hormonal fluctuations.
 
Cortisol is a hormone that keeps you awake and alert. It’s often called the stress hormone, but it only causes problems when there’s too much or too little of it.
 
Typically, cortisol increases in the early morning hours and drops in the evening. It reaches its peak around 8 a.m. If you have a healthy circadian rhythm, your body might be more primed to exercise at this time.
Better focus.
Physical activity also improves 
focus and concentration
, regardless of when you do it. But if you have trouble focusing during the day, a morning workout might be just the ticket.
 
A 2019 study published in the British Journal of Sports Medicine found that morning exercise improves attention, visual learning, and decision-making.
 
In the study, participants completed a round of 8-hour days of prolonged sitting with and without a 30-minute morning walk on the treadmill. On some days, they also took 3-minute walking breaks every 30 minutes.
 
The days with morning exercise were associated with better cognition throughout the day, especially when paired with regular breaks.
 
If a morning workout does not fit into your schedule, make it a point to move actively in the evening!
 
A well-structured 45-minute fitness routine done four times a day is more than enough to help you seek its benefits.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
I was - and still am - the most ignorant person I have ever met in America.
 
There are thousands, no, millions, forget that, gazillion things I don’t know.
 
I’m not only talking about shallow facts and figures (which we all - SHOULD - know can change often), but about depth of knowledge and awareness about life, that all the book learning can’t teach.
 
This is in large part why I am here on Quora: to learn, change, and hopefully grow. On occasion, I hope to help others to learn if I have basic knowledge to share, but usually I expect the reverse to be true.
 
Certainly I’ve met tons of other people her
Continue Reading
I was - and still am - the most ignorant person I have ever met in America.
 
There are thousands, no, millions, forget that, gazillion things I don’t know.
 
I’m not only talking about shallow facts and figures (which we all - SHOULD - know can change often), but about depth of knowledge and awareness about life, that all the book learning can’t teach.
 
This is in large part why I am here on Quora: to learn, change, and hopefully grow. On occasion, I hope to help others to learn if I have basic knowledge to share, but usually I expect the reverse to be true.
 
Certainly I’ve met tons of other people here in America that lack basic knowledge on our fair nation, but I really don’t care to belittle them here and make them the butt of jokes. Or used as comparisons as how much more sophisticated, just, or worthy the writer was/is. Too many examples of each shared in the answers thus far. If the human examples in all those anecdotes are so ignorant, they may possibly already live and suffer the consequences of their own ignorance and, perhaps fortunately, really don’t care about outside judgments on them. Thus, sometimes, truly sometimes ignorance is bliss.*
 
One never knows what they don’t know, until after they’ve known it.
 
Or more elegantly, a man allegedly said thousands of years ago,
“I know that I don’t know.”
 
Well, he didn’t say it in English (probably either Latin, or Greek), or maybe he never really said it. Some old Greek guy (maybe Athenian, whatever, DUH! What am I, a Greek philosopher?) ; 
I know that I know nothing - Wikipedia
 
Personally, I would love to hear about others having met someone ignorant in some specific fashion and then having the privilege to observe them learn and mature in that particular area. Seeing and being part of positive growth can be a wonderful experience, something that can be as meaningful to the observer and student in life.
 
Ask and learn. Maybe have an epiphany, intellectual, social, cultural, mental, or emotional. One never knows. Literally.
“Ignorance is bliss.” Attribution from the last two lines of "Ode on a Distant Prospect of Eton College"
 
“Where ignorance is bliss, 
‘Tis folly to be wise.”
 
 English poet Thomas Gray (1716-1771)
Original question at the time I answered.
 
Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
 
Like someone who doesn’t know what year the Declaration of Independence happened or how many states are there that make up America?

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
Lack of curiosity is the root of much ignorance. Here’s the story of my encounter with someone who demonstrated that point to me.
 
I was 29 and recently divorced. My ex and I had been regulars at a couple of local restaurants, and I kept going to one of them - a family-owned Thai restaurant. The owners had always treated us nicely, and knowing the situation they went out of their way to make me feel at home there. The restaurant had an open kitchen set off by a counter. I could sit there on my own without feeling self-conscious about it, and talk with the owners.
 
The owners’ oldest son went off t
Continue Reading
Lack of curiosity is the root of much ignorance. Here’s the story of my encounter with someone who demonstrated that point to me.
 
I was 29 and recently divorced. My ex and I had been regulars at a couple of local restaurants, and I kept going to one of them - a family-owned Thai restaurant. The owners had always treated us nicely, and knowing the situation they went out of their way to make me feel at home there. The restaurant had an open kitchen set off by a counter. I could sit there on my own without feeling self-conscious about it, and talk with the owners.
 
The owners’ oldest son went off to college so they had hired a young woman, 19 or 20 years old, to work as a waitress. After a couple of months, the owners started talking about setting us up. I treated it as a joke, but the third or fourth time the owners brought it up the young lady said she would be interested. I got the feeling she was being a good employee and just playing along. and I didn’t feel ready to start dating. The age difference seemed a bit much to me, too, so I made excuses.
 
I couldn’t deny, though, that she was very, very pretty, and in our limited interaction she was very friendly, and the owners were very, very persistent… So I finally asked her out to a movie and then afterward we went to a pub for a drink and dessert. That’s when we actually tried to have a real conversation.
 
It quickly became apparent that not only did we had very little in common, she didn’t know much about the world we live in either - outside of the confines of our small city, and outside of the interests of her circle of teenage friends. Trying to find something that we could talk about was painful!
 
Eventually, I did mention where I worked, and it turned out that her father worked for the same company. He had worked there all her life. Finally, there was an opening to ask a follow-up question! It was a big computer company, and I didn’t recognize her father’s name, so I asked what kind of work he did. She had no idea! I tried to lead her through it: engineering, sales, finance, HR, legal, manufacturing, hardware, software… Nothing rang a bell! She did know that the company made computers, but that was the extent of it. She had never seen her father’s office, never absorbed or asked any questions about what he did. It boggled my mind that someone could live to 19 or 20 years old without having even the slightest clue about what their parent did for work.

title: What is the best workout routine to follow?
article:
In a nutshell: work out early, make it short, and eat for energy!
 
Here’s how:
 
Create a morning routine so you can work out early.
 
A morning routine is a simple life hack that makes you feel super productive at the start of the day, gives you focus, and provides you with a sense of achievement early, so that you already feel you've made progress. A 
morning routine
 gives you time to do what you consider important to your personal development, and gets you closer to achieving your goals.
 
Make it short.
 
What’s the best way to build a habit from scratch? Make it easy to do on a regular basis. The benefi
Continue Reading
In a nutshell: work out early, make it short, and eat for energy!
 
Here’s how:
 
Create a morning routine so you can work out early.
 
A morning routine is a simple life hack that makes you feel super productive at the start of the day, gives you focus, and provides you with a sense of achievement early, so that you already feel you've made progress. A 
morning routine
 gives you time to do what you consider important to your personal development, and gets you closer to achieving your goals.
 
Make it short.
 
What’s the best way to build a habit from scratch? Make it easy to do on a regular basis. The benefits? Instead of making it intimidating, you make a workout routine doable. Instead of aiming too high and telling yourself you must spend two hours at the gym, you opt for taking baby steps and aim for 15-30 minutes. To get started, just pick a shorter activity that requires your body to move, such as:
a 
morning yoga routine
a 
15 minute bootcamp session
a set of hindu pushups
a set of 
sun salutation poses
a set of lunges and squats
a 20-minute power walk
a quick run through the neighborhood
Eat for energy.
 
Always start your day with breakfast. It's your fuel for starting the day and it helps you to feel alert, energized, and motivated. Choose something that is balanced, light, yet filling, such as a combination of protein, healthy fats, fresh fruit. For example:
Overnight oats 
(no cooking needed): mix a few spoonfuls of oats, 1 teaspoon each of chia seeds and flax seeds, some walnuts, almonds, raisins; add a bit of almond milk or water to blend; leave in fridge overnight and top it off in the morning with some fresh fruit.
Parfait
: 
layer Greek yogurt with granola, nuts (walnuts, almonds, cashews) and diced or sliced fresh fruit (papaya, banana, strawberries, oranges, grapefruit, apples, pears, mango).
Oatmeal 
with chia seeds, flax seeds, walnuts, almonds, dates, shredded coconut, raisins or cranberries; blend with a spoon of peanut butter and add fresh fruit on top.
Get more tips on starting positive habits early.
 
There’s a podcast that will seriously get you to rethink the way you look at mornings. It's called 
Achieve Your Goals
 and it's hosted by Hal Elrod, the author of a book called 
The Miracle Morning.
 It is an in depth guide to structuring your mornings so that you can achieve more in less time, and you have time to work consistently on getting closer to your personal goals.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
I can't say who the most ignorant person I’ve ever met might be, because I’ve, frankly, forgotten such interactions, but I can speak of my own moments of ignorance.
 
These somewhat speak to the theme in a lot of these postings, sometimes the posters stating it overtly, that ignorance is not necessarily willful. It's sometimes a matter that one has not experienced or learnt about something as yet.

Continue Reading
I can't say who the most ignorant person I’ve ever met might be, because I’ve, frankly, forgotten such interactions, but I can speak of my own moments of ignorance.
 
These somewhat speak to the theme in a lot of these postings, sometimes the posters stating it overtly, that ignorance is not necessarily willful. It's sometimes a matter that one has not experienced or learnt about something as yet.
I was starting to work on my Master’s in Linguistics and up to then had never met, or even heard of, a Muslim Nigerian, let alone that the majority of northern Nigeria is primarily Muslim or that people with rather Middle-Eastern phenotypic features live there too. I’d met with one for he first time in a Language Acquisition class, and when she’d told me that she was from Nigeria she'd added that people often think about “Black people with that thick accent, right?” I giggled a little.
I’d seen newspaper articles for assignments as a kid, and usually with photographs of people I’d been used to seeing them identify people by name in the photo caption. One day I’m looking at a photograph of a protest in Québec during one of their (seemingly many) demonstrations on independence/secession from Canada. There was one person in particular who interested me (something I now recognize as “you’d found him attractive”) and I really wanted to know his name. It upset me, though, that they didn't mention his name at all. I'd asked my mother why and she didn't have an answer, but eventually I’d figured that they can't ask everyone their name, let alone a line of at least 15 people, and then print all their names under the photograph.
I’m originally from Jamaica, and moved to the United States when I was 6, so initially I didn't sound like I was from the United States. One day when I was at boychoir practice the choirmaster had made a comment at the end of our voice training session (I don't remember the actual conversation for) that I had an accent. I wasn't sure what that meant, since no one has ever said that before, and I wasn't sure if that was a good thing or a bad thing. My friend Justin, when I’d asked him what that meant, just told me it meant I sounded different than he did, and that was okay because he had an accent too (he was from Tennessee). I didn't believe; I didn't sound 
any
 different than he did. He had me laughing the rest of the day saying periodically “See, you have an accent!” whenever I would say something.

title: Are there any poor people on Quora, as Internet access is very cheap nowadays?
article:
Going anonymous for some reason [as this is just happening in my life & my family is on quora and you know in India ghar ki baat ghar mein rahen toh acha hai}
 
I completed my ca final exam on 17th may 2017.
 
Truly, I was’nt prepared for 12 hours a day from 3 months but just 12 hours one day before exam. My papers were good but I cannot say what result would be. I have given few attempts for some reason I am shattered and depressed. From last 2 years I am failure not only in my career but also in family, relations, and dad’s business suffered loss too. Now my parents want me to go for Job. Next day
Continue Reading
Going anonymous for some reason [as this is just happening in my life & my family is on quora and you know in India ghar ki baat ghar mein rahen toh acha hai}
 
I completed my ca final exam on 17th may 2017.
 
Truly, I was’nt prepared for 12 hours a day from 3 months but just 12 hours one day before exam. My papers were good but I cannot say what result would be. I have given few attempts for some reason I am shattered and depressed. From last 2 years I am failure not only in my career but also in family, relations, and dad’s business suffered loss too. Now my parents want me to go for Job. Next day of exam
 
Dad : Beta ab khud ka dekh kuch [Daughter see something for yourself now]
 
Mom : ye CA acha hai, iske pass bahut kaam suna hai [This CA is good, he has much work}
 
Now for my dad : I supported when you made wrong decision & now your business is running good and some credit goes to me too but all credit went to son of your brother. I struggled too.
 
My mom : I already told you back 2 years back I don’t want to go to that CA because of some reason which every CA student knows in our city and till I don’t get to know about vacancy in any firm how can I go to ask for Job? And yes I don’t want to work for Rs. 300 pm.
 
That’s the worst option, please!!!!
 
Now my siblings who taunts me, think me shit. It was me who supported them in everything. I mean everything. Yes literally everything :( and I regret.
 
And my parents don’t say a single word to them
 
Today you see me failure but one day I will be success according to you maybe. But I am successful everyday in everyway. You don’t know what happens to me when you speak shit!!!
 
So what came to my mind is stop eating and eat only one time. I did that and after 3 days I said my parents that I will eat one time and in this way you can save money on 3 time food I have which will surely equal to job money.
 
All I had my wifi, mobile, computer in my room. which are old but my best friends. I love them. I asked them if you want take them too but even if you won’t, you will have to incur expense as everyone in house is using except my mobile.
 
So I want to share I am poor for now. In everyway I guess but I am happy :))))))
 
I ate 3 times in very less portion [2 chapati reduced to 1/4th chapati so that my parents don’t feel anything]….thank you God.
 
I am successful in everything, everyway!!!!! Lolzzz…Not poor but poor…..
 
Happpppppyyyyyyy :))))))))

title: What is a good workout routine at home?
article:
Something that works really well in your situation, is what I dubbed the “prison cell workout”
 
You literally need no equiptment other than a sturdy towell.
 
But what you do need, however, is a ton of cojones or ovaires (This is NOT for the casual “I just want to get in shape” dabbler…this is for people who are serious about making progress).
 
This type of workout looks really easy on paper, but will smoke even very strong people.
 
I still use this once or twice a week to increase my work capactiy and pain threshold.
 
If you can get through this type of routine 3–5 times a week, there’s literally nothin
Continue Reading
Something that works really well in your situation, is what I dubbed the “prison cell workout”
 
You literally need no equiptment other than a sturdy towell.
 
But what you do need, however, is a ton of cojones or ovaires (This is NOT for the casual “I just want to get in shape” dabbler…this is for people who are serious about making progress).
 
This type of workout looks really easy on paper, but will smoke even very strong people.
 
I still use this once or twice a week to increase my work capactiy and pain threshold.
 
If you can get through this type of routine 3–5 times a week, there’s literally nothing that can stop you.
 
This is not only a workout for your physical body, but also for your mental and spiritual muscles.
 
Big words, I know, but try it and you’ll know what I’m talking about.
 
Here goes…
 
Get your smartphone. Or use your watch to stop the time (you’ll try to beat the time you recorded).
 
As soon as you hit “start” and the clock is ticking, you’ll perform 200 push-ups, 250 squats and 100 towell pullups as fast as possible (with excellent form, obviously).
 
Of course you shouldn’t bang out all 200 push-ups, 250 squats and 100 pullups all in one set!
 
Divide the work up, so that you DON’T go to muscular failure on each and every set! That’s really important, or else you’ll burn out.
 
What I do, for example, is that I do sets of 20 on push-up (so 10 sets per “round”), 25–50 reps on squats, 5–10 reps on pullups.
 
Find a set and rep scheme that works for you. Again, you SHOULD NOT go to muscular failure in each and ever set. Keep 2–3 reps in the tank.
 
With that said, the key do these type of workouts, is to rest as little as possible (remember you’re doing this for time).
 
I always hit a set of push-ups, immediately followed by a set of squats and then, without rest, I bang out my pullups. Then I’ll rest for 45–60sec. Only to start the next set.
 
Trust me, your heart rate will jack the heck up on this routine!
 
You don’t have to run any additional cardio with this and you’ll develop a very “functional” type of strength endurance if you stick to it.
 
Oh, and you’ll also build some lean muscle! Especially if you haven’t used these type of “prison cell workouts” in the past.
 
But make no mistake…This is not for the faint of heart.
 
If you need help with this routine, then shoot me a DM or comment down below!
 
All the best and I’m rooting for you,
 
Mattis Rogers

title: Is it good to do weightlifting every day?
article:
I write this as a man who will turn 69 in five weeks – –which means I will enter my 70th year one day later.
 
I worked out in my 30s through my early 50s, three days a week, with good results. I fell off the work out-wagon in my mid-50s – – at roughly the same time I got sober (I was managing to put down almost a fifth of vodka day and still work out –- in hindsight, I have no idea how). I've been sober for 18 years.
 
At any rate, I stopped lifting weights for 12 or 14 years – – and got back into it around 66, after some back surgery, and related aches and pains from an increasingly sedentary life
Continue Reading
I write this as a man who will turn 69 in five weeks – –which means I will enter my 70th year one day later.
 
I worked out in my 30s through my early 50s, three days a week, with good results. I fell off the work out-wagon in my mid-50s – – at roughly the same time I got sober (I was managing to put down almost a fifth of vodka day and still work out –- in hindsight, I have no idea how). I've been sober for 18 years.
 
At any rate, I stopped lifting weights for 12 or 14 years – – and got back into it around 66, after some back surgery, and related aches and pains from an increasingly sedentary lifestyle.
 
I now lift five days a week. it has literally changed my life. I knew I was somewhat overweight, but I have lost over 20 pounds, while putting on at least 8-10 pounds of muscle – – which means I lost close to 30 pounds of fat. It's remarkable how much fat can hide internally (especially in men) in the abdomen!
 
I watched the clock turn back.
 
It's not just that I am stronger and better built – – my skin tone/elasticity is noticeably better, my mood is brighter, my energy level is much greater – – my general sense of well-being and – – "alive-ness" — feels like I have returned to my 40s.
 
There is more and more evidence that intelligent weightlifting – – consistent, and intense enough to be genuinely challenging – – can not only retard the aging process, but to some degree, reverse it.
 
That has certainly been my experience. Of course, my stamina is not what it was 30 years ago, and 45/50 minutes of intense work is my limit, unless I push so hard that I stop looking forward to workouts – – and run the risk of losing focus toward the end – – which is when you inevitably hurt yourself.
 
So I do one body part a day — actually, I divide legs up, and do some legwork on three of those days to make it less brutal – – and I continue to make real progress, look forward to my workouts, and I do not in anyway feel I am over-training.
 
I think every-day is pushing it. But you can definitely do more than three days a week, if you want to — if you do it intelligently, find what works for you (for me, it is weights heavy enough that I am limited to 6–8 reps per set in most cases), and FOCUS INTENTLY ON EVERY REP TO AVOID INJURY.
 
My experience is that five days a week is healthy, fun, and productive. And if you stick with it and push yourself just enough – – the results can be nothing short of magical.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
I met the most ignorant Americans in my life last month. (But maybe not as bad as a coworker I used to have that thought Trump was the president of all countries).
 
I went to a MSC cruise from Genova (most passengers were European) and one day two random American ladies sat next to me during lunch time. I quickly engaged in conversation just for fun, mentioning in excitement I lived in Texas. They said they were from Vegas and Salt Lake City. "There are very few of us here huh?" One said. Continue Reading
I met the most ignorant Americans in my life last month. (But maybe not as bad as a coworker I used to have that thought Trump was the president of all countries).
 
I went to a MSC cruise from Genova (most passengers were European) and one day two random American ladies sat next to me during lunch time. I quickly engaged in conversation just for fun, mentioning in excitement I lived in Texas. They said they were from Vegas and Salt Lake City. "There are very few of us here huh?" One said. They seemed really friendly, curious, and open for conversation, which is what I love about Americans.
 
They asked me where I lived in Texas. I said 4 hours South of San Antonio. "Brownsville?" One asked. I said "yep, around there" that's when things took an interesting turn.
 
"So how is it there with the open border?" One lady asked genuinely concerned. Oh gosh, I knew where this was heading. I looked at her in disbelief. "Uhh.. just like any other city?” I didn't say much as I thought it might be futile explaining I live in a really safe city with high quality of life if they happened to have preconceived opinions about immigrants or border towns.
 
After a little awkward silence I said "I come here with my husband, he's from Netherlands, this is our first time in a European cruise" then my husband arrives almost on cue and sits down with his plate. They take a look at him with their eyes about to pop out and say "I was expecting him to be blonde!" One says shocked. (My husband is more Mediterranean looking -brunette, dark eyes, olive skin, a thick beard). At this point they just start talking to my husband and they mentioned they have visited his country: "Amsterdam and Copenhagen" and I tried not to burst into laughter as my husband explains Copenhagen is in Denmark not Netherlands (and how can you not know this when you visited the freaking country?).
 
Then my brother comes and sits with us (he looks really White) and they look at him confused and ask me, "which one is your husband again?" (I'm guessing in their brain they saw a White man and thought, Oh, he HAS to be the Dutch guy, not this Mediterranean-looking one we were just talking to that says he's from Netherlands! This SURELY has to be a mistake or something!!). 😂😂
 
They were speaking pretty loudly too and I'm sure all the nearby tables were listening and I was just so embarrassed and disappointed and we just left and wished them a safe trip.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
Back in grad school, one Sunday morning, I made my routine 3 month visit to the hair salon. The hair stylist who was cutting my hair was quite a chatty person (most hair stylists here in the US are as it’s a way for them to earn more through tips) and we got a conversation started as soon as I sat down.
 
Midway through our conversation he began asking me about India and a part of our conversation went as follows
 
Hair stylist
: So you are from India aren’t you? I have seen a lot of Indians who visit this salon regularly. They provide for a majority of our salon’s business.
 
Me
: That’s great. Yes, the
Continue Reading
Back in grad school, one Sunday morning, I made my routine 3 month visit to the hair salon. The hair stylist who was cutting my hair was quite a chatty person (most hair stylists here in the US are as it’s a way for them to earn more through tips) and we got a conversation started as soon as I sat down.
 
Midway through our conversation he began asking me about India and a part of our conversation went as follows
 
Hair stylist
: So you are from India aren’t you? I have seen a lot of Indians who visit this salon regularly. They provide for a majority of our salon’s business.
 
Me
: That’s great. Yes, there are a lot of Indians that live in the community just across the street. This salon is conveniently located and everyone likes to avail the student discount you guys offer.
 
Hair stylist
: Yes! So which part of India are you from? Any place that I might have heard of?
 
Me
: Well I’m from Mumbai. I’m pretty sure that you would have heard about the city.
 
Hair stylist
: (
after a brief pause
) Umm, I’m not sure I have (
at which I almost rolled my eyes
). Where is it in India?
 
Me
: (
after having given him the benefit of doubt
) It’s in the western part of India. It’s a pretty famous city as it’s a metropolitan and is the financial hub of India.
 
Hair stylist
: That’s great. I am planning to visit India soon as I have heard great things about the country. I have heard that India is very green and has lots and lots of elephants.
 
Me
: Well, India is definitely green…
 
Hair stylist
: I’ve heard that Indians commute regularly on elephants. Did you also travel on elephants while you were living there?
 
At this point I was ready to jump out of the chair in shock and disbelief. I was shouting out loud in my mind “
WHICH CENTURY ARE YOU LIVING IN?
”.
 
But all I could afford was just a feeble, nervous laugh in an attempt to not make the rest of my haircut awkward.
 
Me
: No, no! We also travel just like you do. In cars, buses, trains and planes.
 
Hair stylist
: (
with a genuinely surprised expression
) Well, I’d be damned. I had no idea!
 
I ended up spending the rest of my haircut explaining how India was not how he had pictured it was.
 
Most ignorant American ever!
 
While walking back home, as I replayed that conversation in my mind, an image of me sitting on a elephant back travelling to school, swaying from side to side formed. I did find that quite amusing though!

Poor…
 
Before all stories of my life..
 
I am new to quora.
 
Currently I am working with Big4 as cyber security consultant. Earning enough to feed my parents.
 
Back to my childhood..
 
I am having 3 siblings. My dad was working in wooden factory. Mom was home tailor. During my primary schooling family income was too low.. So I used to go to school by walk 4kms go and fro.. That time I was only 6 years old.
 
I was having only 2 shirts n 1 half pant school uniforms. My mom brings used school bags from my rich cousin.
 
There was no high school near to my village so now distance increased to 4kms + 4kms.. 8kms go and fro..
 
My big sister was also started working she started mess for factory workers.(who were my father's friends)
 
June 2005, they started giving me 1.50rs for bus tickets .. (75 Paise half tickets, now it's 5rs half tickets inflation rate is too high :( )
 
I was a bright students I got scholarship from my relatives.
 
In 10th I scored 86% and 2nd rank in school.
 
Now I want to join science school but because of financial situation I took admission in commerce field.
 
With in a 6 month I realized that this is not my field, I started learning programming and hacking by my self from college library.
 
I scored 65% in 12th commerce.
 
Then I decided to join computer science but again money problem..
 
I joined BCA distance education. Meanwhile I worked on small shops like ladies wear shop, kids wear shop , computer hardware shops, they were paying me 100rs a day. During summer vacation I joined call center for 2 months.
 
2nd year BCA I have started software development company with my friends was going good.
 
Finally 2012 I have compeleted my BCA with 80% 2nd in university. Wooww
 
Now what. I have done distance courses so no job. Because of lack of projects, shutdown company.
 
But one day I heard about CEH certified ethical hacker certification. I asked my mom and dad to support me last time. They trust me and sold some Jewelry and arrange the 35k rs for my fees.
 
Uhhhuuu I have completed CEH on 14th August 2012 with 95%.
 
And with in 1 week got interviews call and after 3 weeks of joining process I joined India based security products company and… now I am working with Big4
 
Now earning good and planning to buy my own house.
 
Thank you all for reading
 
Update 1: Thank you so much for 500+ views and 20+ upvotes . Love you all

title: What is your favorite sandwich ingredient?
article:
When it comes to creating the perfect sandwich, the choice of ingredients can elevate a simple meal into a culinary delight. While many might argue over the merits of various toppings and spreads, I can confidently assert that avocado reigns supreme as my favorite sandwich ingredient.
 
First and foremost, the texture of avocado is nothing short of magical. Its creamy, buttery consistency adds a luxurious mouthfeel that enhances the overall bite of any sandwich. Whether it’s slathered on as a spread, sliced and layered, or mashed into a flavorful mixture, avocado seamlessly integrates with other 
Continue Reading
When it comes to creating the perfect sandwich, the choice of ingredients can elevate a simple meal into a culinary delight. While many might argue over the merits of various toppings and spreads, I can confidently assert that avocado reigns supreme as my favorite sandwich ingredient.
 
First and foremost, the texture of avocado is nothing short of magical. Its creamy, buttery consistency adds a luxurious mouthfeel that enhances the overall bite of any sandwich. Whether it’s slathered on as a spread, sliced and layered, or mashed into a flavorful mixture, avocado seamlessly integrates with other ingredients while still maintaining its unique identity.
 
Flavor-wise, avocado boasts a mild earthiness that serves as an excellent backdrop for a myriad of flavor profiles. It pairs beautifully with zesty ingredients like tomatoes, onions, and pickles, perfectly balancing their acidity with its rich creaminess. Furthermore, it complements savory proteins such as turkey, chicken, or even bacon, enhancing the overall savory experience without overpowering other flavors. A sprinkle of salt and a dash of lime can take this ingredient to a whole new level, providing a fresh burst of taste that energizes the palate.
 
One of the most appealing aspects of avocado is its versatility. It fits perfectly into various sandwich styles—be it a classic club, a refreshing veggie pack, or even a bold and spicy sriracha chicken creation. Its adaptability knows no bounds, allowing it to be featured in both cold and hot sandwiches with equal success. Additionally, for those who prioritize health, avocados are loaded with beneficial nutrients like healthy fats, fiber, and vitamins, making them not just a delicious choice, but a nutritious one too.
 
While some might debate the issue of ripeness or the daunting task of slicing the perfect avocado, the rewards far outweigh the risks. A perfectly ripe avocado can transform an ordinary sandwich into something truly special.
 
In conclusion, if you’re seeking to elevate your sandwich game, look no further than the humble avocado. With its creamy texture, versatile flavor, and health benefits, it rightfully claims the top spot as my favorite sandwich ingredient. Whether you’re crafting a casual lunch or impressing guests at a gathering, incorporating avocado will undoubtedly impress and satisfy—proving that sometimes, simplicity is key to perfection.

title: What is a good at home workout routine for intermediate beginners?
article:

Start with the basic movements.Don’t go heavy on the weights for first couple of weeks.
 
As for what exercises to do, first know your muscles. You can pick any of the muscles for your first day (most people prefer to take chest and triceps).
 
1)CHEST (One of the 3 major muscles)
 
Instead of doing benchpresses on the very first day, look for a chest-press machine in your gym (usually all gyms have that). Workout on that for a week or 2 and learn the basic movements, how to push the weights in order to target the right muscle and to which extent in order to avoid injury. Second machine would be a pectoral fly machine. Use both these muscles under the supervision of a trainer and learn about the proper movements before using the barbells/dumbbells for dumbbell press (substitution for chest-press machine) and dumbbell fly (for pectoral fly machine)
 
2)BACK (2nd major muscle)
 
Be very cautious while doing back exercises as even a small injury in your lower back can cause physical problems for you for many years. Be cautious about your posture while doing any back exercise which means standing straight (or knees bent in some exercises) and contracting your traps while pushing your chest outwards and keeping your lower back straight by pushing your hips outwards (in exercises in which you are supposed to bend your knees). THIS APPLIES TO EVERY BACK EXERCISE.
 
As on first day, do lat pull down, seated rowing, dumbbell shrugs and bent over rowing.
 
3)LEGS (The 3rd major muscle)
 
Don’t go heavy on squats for the first month if you’re starting gym for the first time in life. Do body-weight squats or simply barbell squats (without lading the weights) to learn to balance and get your leg muscles working. Use leg-press machines and leg extensions to workout your quadriceps and leg curl and seated calf raises to workout your hamstrings and calves respectively for first few weeks.
 
4)Shoulders
 
Instead of doing lifting exercises, do raising ones like dumbbell front raise, lateral raise, bent over lateral raise.
 
5) Arms (Biceps and Triceps)
 
There is not really much to pay attention while working out your arms except for the posture while doing biceps dumbbell/barbell curl ‘coz people tend to use a jerk while lifting which leads to bending the waist backwards which in some cases results very dangerous if the weight is heavy.
 
Hope it helps..Happy gyming..

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
I don’t want to blame one single American person individually, even if it’s tempting to do so when we face so much yanksplaining these days. I guess, it has more to do with some Americano-centrism in the education system rather than individual ignorance.
 
Many years ago, my family hosted an American couple for a few days in Brussels. We had some common friends in California, a Belgian painter and her partner working for the Department of Justice. Both of our guests held senior positions. She was an HR manager for a high-tech company and he was a Senior Attorney. Although they had little command 
Continue Reading
I don’t want to blame one single American person individually, even if it’s tempting to do so when we face so much yanksplaining these days. I guess, it has more to do with some Americano-centrism in the education system rather than individual ignorance.
 
Many years ago, my family hosted an American couple for a few days in Brussels. We had some common friends in California, a Belgian painter and her partner working for the Department of Justice. Both of our guests held senior positions. She was an HR manager for a high-tech company and he was a Senior Attorney. Although they had little command of any foreign language, they were both well-read, and we enjoyed every moment we shared. At one point, however, my father enquired about their projects in Europe.
 
The husband explained that, of course, they were willing to visit the “Beaches” in Normandy, some American war-cemeteries in the region and the war memorial in Caen as well. My father advised them to continue their tour back to Belgium and visit Bastogne, where they’d have the opportunity to visit a museum dedicated to the “Battle of the Bulge”. (as the battle for Bastogne is usually known in the US). He even insisted given that distances are way shorter in Europe they could spend the day over there and come back for dinner in Brussels, stay overnight, and catch their plane the day after!
 
At that point, they were both intrigued. The lady asked about how the actual “short distance was”, and her husband wondered how far Germany was exactly. My father blushed a bit and tried to explain that Bastogne was a Belgian town that American soldiers held against overwhelming Nazi forces until Monty turned up, and the skies cleared in 1944. All that sounded like well-learned school lessons, but he was stunned when he heard the American gentleman remark: Do you really mean that Belgium was occupied by Germany during the Second World War?!
 
My father remained voiceless. And I whispered, “For about four years, that’s right”… It seemed that a new world had opened up before their eyes. They suddenly became so keen to understand and explore, they looked like children discovering their x-mas presents, and we had a great time together. Yet, years after, we still didn’t understand that American schools could not inform American children that the Battle of the Bulge took place in a war-shattered country called Belgium!

article:

I am already heartily sickened by this question, I seem to get it in my “feed” virtually daily. I admit that in the early days, I occasionally rose to the bait, when irritated by similarly, derogative, pejorative questions and posts denigrating Britain and the British.
 
There are ignorant people in every country, including Britain. My next statement re Brexit, will no doubt result in outrage amongst Brexiteers and I shall
Continue Reading
I have only been on Quora for a few months,and prior to that I have never utilised social media. I came to this site, for intelligent debate, humour and to improve my knowledge.
 
I am already heartily sickened by this question, I seem to get it in my “feed” virtually daily. I admit that in the early days, I occasionally rose to the bait, when irritated by similarly, derogative, pejorative questions and posts denigrating Britain and the British.
 
There are ignorant people in every country, including Britain. My next statement re Brexit, will no doubt result in outrage amongst Brexiteers and I shall be subjected to vitriolic , venomous abuse. However, in my opinion, many who voted to leave, must have been ignorant of the benefits of being in the EU, and the ramifications of leaving and did nothing to inform themselves prior to making such an important decision. A far more important decision than electing a President, they only last 4 years. Brexit is probably forever. A prime example of a large percentage of British voters displaying ignorance.
 
I have never been to the US and have no desire to, I have no American connections or friends, I have no vested interest. However there is already too much anger and enmity in todays world. I do not know in whose interests it is to sow discord between us, Quora ,to drive traffic, trolls who feed on anger or even more sinister, other nations who have a vested interest in creating disunity between NATO countries. Unless we are really lucky, I think we are on the verge of WWIII, I hope and pray I am mistaken, but we need to stand shoulder to shoulder, now more than ever.
 
Finally, I have been moved by the plight of those, right thinking Americans, who are horrified and embarrassed by the election of Trump. I know I am” old school”, arguably just old, and the values I adhere to are probably not held by many anymore, but as Brits we always fought for the “underdog” and were taught one should not “ kick a man when they are down”. This is not to imply any feelings of superiority over the US, but simply to reflect that many of the American Quorans need to be shown some empathy and understanding.
 
No doubt I will now also be subjected to abuse by Trump supporters as well as Brexiteers. If I were smart, I would disable comments, but I’m not going to, well not yet!
 
I am readying myself for the onslaught of hate.

Donald J. Trump
. No where in the world could there possibly be another person more ignorant who has
 no excuse 
to be so ignorant as Donald J. Trump. He has had every advantage known to mankind—education, wealth, privilege, travel, access to libraries and museums and all kinds of educational and self-enrichment media. He has had history’s masters of diplomacy, oratory, and statesmanship (often in person!) to study, after which to model and mold his own way, his own unique path. Instead, after 70 years of all that wealth and privilege, 
THIS CRAP
:
…is the best we get from him.
 
This might be amusing if it were his parting words after announcing his resignation on December 31, 2017, but my God we haven’t even yet started with this fool:
 
“What Trump is, everyone has known and has been able to see for decades, let alone the last few months. The revelations of the past week of his vile and crude boasting about sexual conquest—indeed, sexual assault—might have been shocking, but they should have surprised no one.
 
“Indeed, there is hardly any public person in America today who has more exemplified the ‘earthly nature’ (‘flesh’ in the King James and the literal Greek) that Paul urges the Colossians to shed: ‘sexual immorality, impurity, lust, evil desires, and greed, which is idolatry’ (3:5). This is an incredibly apt summary of Trump’s life to date. Idolatry, greed, and sexual immorality are intertwined in individual lives and whole societies. Sexuality is designed to be properly ordered within marriage, a relationship marked by covenant faithfulness and profound self-giving and sacrifice. To indulge in sexual immorality is to make oneself and one’s desires an idol. That Trump has been, his whole adult life, an idolater of this sort, and a singularly unrepentant one, should have been clear to everyone.
 
“And therefore it is completely consistent that Trump is an idolater in many other ways. He has given no evidence of humility or dependence on others, let alone on God his Maker and Judge. He wantonly celebrates strongmen and takes every opportunity to humiliate and demean the vulnerable. He shows no curiosity or capacity to learn. He is, in short, the very embodiment of what the Bible calls a fool.” 
Speak Truth to Trump

article:

Her mom makes sure she and her younger sister (also thin and lanky) get plenty of good food to eat. Not just good-tasting

For reference, literally everyone in this little anecdote are in America and have (presumably) lived here for at least a little while
 
I have a friend in middle school. She is not the ignorant person. Neither is her mom, who also comes into play here.
 
What my friend 
is 
is athletic as heck.
 
She's thin and lanky, she walks or bikes the couple miles to school and back each day (which she chooses depends on weather), and she's won more than a few awards for the school's track team.
 
Her mom makes sure she and her younger sister (also thin and lanky) get plenty of good food to eat. Not just good-tasting food, but good-for-you food.
 
My friend recently discovered she has high cholesterol despite all this.
 
Her mom called the doctor's office to schedule an appointment for her, and answered the secretary when asked what the appointment was about.
 
The secretary is the one who's about to get roasted like my brother's blackened smores marshmallows.
 
The secretary has Friendmom stop right there, and basically says, "I can tell you how to fix this right now."
 
"Great!" Says Friendmom. "How?"
 
"Make your daughter eat less fast food, play fewer videogames, and get more exercise."
 
Let me make this clear:
 
My friend is very athletic, way more athletic than I've ever been. She eats healthy, another thing I'm sadly lacking in sometimes. She's like a really really strong twig, while I'm closer to a mushy rock. Yet my cholesterol is fine, and hers is not. And this secretary is refusing to schedule an appointment for her and is instead telling Friendmom what she would have to do if Friend was dangerously fat.
 
Needless to say, while I can't remember who Friendmom said hung up first, I'm pretty sure Friendmom laid into the secretary pretty hard.
 
How that person got a job in any part of the medical field, I don't think I'll ever know.
 
(Yes, I know high cholesterol can go with being overweight, and often does, and that the mother might be trying to play the victim here, (internet stories, my guy) but a thing I do a bunch with the sister is pick her up and spin her around with my weak noodle arms. I could easily do that with this friend if I wanted to, I just do it more with her sister becaus it was easier when she was a baby and I was a Big Girl™ :D (meanwhile friend and i have been closer in age and size basically our whole lives))

title: Is it bad to do full body workouts every day?
article:
The most effective workout routine for building muscle mass follows a simple formula.
 
Compound Workouts + Calorie Surplus + Recovery = Muscle Mass.
 Each part of this equation will need equal attention if your aim is to pack on muscle in the most efficient way possible. There are many ways to the top of the mountain but this method has worked for me over the past 15 years strength training whilst working full-time at a desk job.
 
Compound Workouts
 
I choose the bang-for-your buck compounds like squats, deadlifts, bench press and bent over rows. Spreading this out intelligently throughout the week will allow my muscles to recovery, adapt and ultimately grow. As I’m in the office 3 days a week (with access to a gym) my current routine is as follows:
 
Day 1:
 
Barbell Bench Press 12/10/8/8
 
DB Flys 12/12/12
 
Barbell Rows 12/10/8/8
 
Lat Pull Down 12/12/12
 
Barbell Military Press 12/10/8/8
 
Barbell Upright Rows 12/12/12
 
Day 2:
 
Barbell Squat 12/10/8/8
 
Barbell Lunge 12/12/12
 
Deadlift 12/10/8/6
 
Smith Machine Calf Raise 15/15/15
 
Day 3:
 
Incline Dumbell Chest Press 12/12/12
 
Close Grip Pull Downs 12/12/12
 
Seat Arnold Press 12/12/12
 
Cable Curls/Tricep Pull Downs Superset 12/12/12/12
 
Lying Leg Raises x20
 
Angels & Devils 1 min
 
Things to keep in mind when executing the workout:
Always control the weight (do not let the weight control you)
Think about what muscles are contracting and focus your power there
Always have a tight core with each movement - this creates a stable base for each exercise and reduces risk of injury
Rest 60–90 seconds between each set
Calorie Surplus
 
You will need to consume more calories than you are burning to build muscle (the opposite is true if you want to shed some weight).
 
There is a bit of work upfront as you’ll need to find your baseline and track how much food you are eating. A good starting point are the numerous BMR calculators available (I use the MyFitnessPal one) and then adjust based on the amount of activity you undertake during the day (I use my smart watch to give me guides).
 
When I first started I was surprised at how much more I actually needed to eat to exceed the calories I was burning. Adding a protein shake between meals has helped get these numbers up.
 
Recovery
 
The final ingredient and arguably the most important.
 
If you don’t let your muscles (and body) recover then it will not be able to adapt to the stimulus your workout has provided. Muscles grow when you rest so recover harder than you train. Prioritise your sleep and make sure you listen to your body’s needs.
 
When your body is recovered your workouts can be executed with a greater intensity and that will ultimately be the most effective if you want to build muscle.
 
SO
…the most effective workout routine to build muscle incorporates:
Compound Lifts executed 3 days a week
Calorie Surplus - fueling your body more than it burns
Recover - give time for your muscles to grow
I hope that helps. Enjoy the journey!

title: What is a good workout routine at home?
article:
I good home exercise routine can actually help you to gain good body composition and stay fit.
Cardio : Cardio is very important part, Its something you should do in order to warm up your body. Cardio exercises are important for heart and lungs , which you can’t skip. 20 high Jumps , Running , jogging is preferred.
Stretches : I strongly recommend having emphasis on maximum body stretches, it’ll increase your functionality in upcoming exercises.
Push Ups : Keep your hands at same distance as broad as your shoulder width for starters , at least 20 push ups recommended but don't be disappointed if 
Continue Reading
I good home exercise routine can actually help you to gain good body composition and stay fit.
Cardio : Cardio is very important part, Its something you should do in order to warm up your body. Cardio exercises are important for heart and lungs , which you can’t skip. 20 high Jumps , Running , jogging is preferred.
Stretches : I strongly recommend having emphasis on maximum body stretches, it’ll increase your functionality in upcoming exercises.
Push Ups : Keep your hands at same distance as broad as your shoulder width for starters , at least 20 push ups recommended but don't be disappointed if you can’t . It isn't because you are weak it is because you are not in practice.Also Push Ups with less distance between your hands = Good for triceps and shoulders , Push Ups with more gap between your hands = Good for chest . Including 2–3 types of Push Ups recommended.
Pull Ups : Have a bar and do as much pull ups exercise as you can , and if you can’t just try again and again . You will increase repetations eventually with time .
Weight exercises : If you have weights, biceps curls and shoulder press exercises are adviced . Weight training is important part of workout routine but it optional in the start and you can include it in your routine in future.
Important Tips :
Don’t include too much exercises in the start. More than one exercise for single body part won't make that muscle making process shorter but will exhaust your energy and time.
Start from your efficiency with less exercises in beginning and increase repetitions and exercises with time.
Don't think about the result , Trust the process!!!. Enjoy workout routine and only include exercise that you like. (For beginners) . (We don't want our body to get tired early of the routine.)
You don't need protein powder or any extra supplement apart from the daily food you get. Just eat much you want but there should be 4–5 hours at least gap between workout time and food time. Eat any junk food much you want but remember once in a month, don't eat on regular basis . It makes you lazy .
Most important thing is “Rest”. Do take 8 hours sleep at least . Do Workout 4 days a week . Remember your don't get muscle in workout time but it builds muscle when you sleeping.
Start today, be consistent. Good wishes to you .
 
Do up vote the answer if it helped.
 
Pic Source : Google images.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
Not a person, but a whole region.
 
After moving to Bumfuck, KY I have met many, many people who I would call ignorant. I really think they've only seen brown people on tv.
 
Talking to some girl at the gym:
 
Me: Yea I just moved here from Maryland.
 
Her: Oh, is that over there by Afghanistan?
 
Me: ……no
 
The demographics of the county I work in is 96% white and the rest are mostly black. I'm from Pakistan and I obviously look like it as well. I get looks from people all the time because I stick out very easily.
 
I'm not Muslim (I love me some ribs, mmm), I was born in the US and I only know how to speak Engli
Continue Reading
Not a person, but a whole region.
 
After moving to Bumfuck, KY I have met many, many people who I would call ignorant. I really think they've only seen brown people on tv.
 
Talking to some girl at the gym:
 
Me: Yea I just moved here from Maryland.
 
Her: Oh, is that over there by Afghanistan?
 
Me: ……no
 
The demographics of the county I work in is 96% white and the rest are mostly black. I'm from Pakistan and I obviously look like it as well. I get looks from people all the time because I stick out very easily.
 
I'm not Muslim (I love me some ribs, mmm), I was born in the US and I only know how to speak English (typical American). First day on the job and I’m going around to check out the plant and meet some people.
 
Me: Hey nice to meet you, my name is Mustafa.
 
Him: Oh, are you from Iraq?
 
Me: ……no
 
There was also a time where a pulled pork sandwich saved me from landing on the employee enforced terrorist watch list.
We were having a party at the plant for no LTI’s ( Lost Time Incidents) for like the last year. They catered BBQ and there was a whole spread of pulled pork, cole slaw, corn, potato salad, etc.
 
Free food? Shit, first thing I did was throw my lunch away. That BBQ was so fucking good. I ate 3 plates and sampled everything. We didn't have BBQ like this back in Maryland (or should I say Iraq, lol). It was a good thing I ate everything too.
 
I was later told that apparently some people were watching me to see if I ate the pork or not. Based on that data and knowing me for 5 months, they would conclude whether I was a potential terrorist threat or not...
 
I sincerely pity the people who have this way of thinking.
 
Edit: I think I was re-living the frustration of these events as I was writing this answer. I did not intend for this answer to be so negative. Although I bashed some of the people around here for some of their actions, there are many more people who are absurdly polite and generous. You can pretty much strike up a conversation with anyone around here too. Like I said, I pity some of the people around here because I believe the history and demographics of this area inhibit tolerance.
 
Edit 2: Anonymous because I still work for this company. I googled my name and this answer was right next to it. I don't want HR to make a big deal out of this, so keep it on the down low.

4 refreshing and delicious sandwiches!
 
Nutritionally balanced, healthy, delicious and filling!
 
One bite is rich in layers, full of ingredients, so satisfying
 
Put your favorite ingredients and you can have breakfast in a few minutes~
 
-
 
🔺Ham and egg sandwich
 
[Ingredients] Toast, ham slices, eggs, tomatoes, lettuce, cheese slices
 
[Method] Fry a poached egg, fry the ham slices with the remaining oil, put lettuce, tomatoes, poached eggs, ham slices, cheese slices on the toast in turn, cover with another piece of toast, and wrap it with plastic wrap
 
-
 
🔺Taro and pork floss sandwich
 
[Ingredients] Toast, taro , purple potato flour, milk, seaweed meat floss
 
[Method] Steam the taro, add appropriate amount of purple potato flour, milk, sugar substitute, and beat into taro paste. Spread thick taro paste on both slices of toast, spread seaweed meat floss on one slice and press it, cover with another slice of toast, and wrap it with plastic wrap
 
-
 
🔺Mango and crab stick sandwich
 
[Ingredients] Toast, mango, crab stick, tomato, lettuce, salad dressing
 
[Method] Tear crab stick into strips, slice mango, put lettuce, mango slices, crab stick, salad dressing on toast in order , tomato slices, cover with another piece of toast, and wrap it with plastic wrap
 
-
 
🔺Cheese and corn sandwich
 
[Ingredients] Toast, corn, ham, meat floss, cheese slices
 
[Method] Squeeze the cooked corn kernels and ham cubes with salad dressing and mix well. Spread meat floss, cheese slices, and corn and ham salad on the toast in turn, cover with another piece of toast and wrap it with plastic wrap
 
-
 
🔺Mango yogurt sandwich
 
[Ingredients] Toast, mango, solid yogurt
 
[Method] Pour the yogurt into gauze and suspend it in the air, refrigerate Filter out the whey overnight, take out the solid yogurt and stir it until smooth, spread a thick layer of yogurt on both slices of toast, put half a mango pulp on it, cover it with another slice of toast, and wrap it with plastic wrap
 
-
 
🔺Kimchi beef sandwich
 
[Ingredients] Toast, beef, kimchi, eggs, cheese slices, seaweed shreds
 
[Method] Fry a poached egg, fry the beef slices with seasoning, put the poached egg, seaweed shreds, cheese slices, beef slices, kimchi on the toast in order, cover it with another slice of toast and wrap it with plastic wrap

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
A US Coastguard Official…..
 
Circa 2003. In the aftermath of 9/11, Homeland Security Department was expanding exponentially. I was a young 2nd Mate on a cargo ship carrying liquefied gas. It wasn't the best time to be a 20 something, brown skin south Asian male in the US, but that is a story for another time.
 
US Coastguard had expanded their security role significantly to inspect all incoming ships. Naturally, lot of rather inexperienced people were recruited, or pushed through the ranks.
 
In Houston, we were ‘hosting’ a team of USCG personnel, who insisted upon checking the whole vessel armed with
Continue Reading
A US Coastguard Official…..
 
Circa 2003. In the aftermath of 9/11, Homeland Security Department was expanding exponentially. I was a young 2nd Mate on a cargo ship carrying liquefied gas. It wasn't the best time to be a 20 something, brown skin south Asian male in the US, but that is a story for another time.
 
US Coastguard had expanded their security role significantly to inspect all incoming ships. Naturally, lot of rather inexperienced people were recruited, or pushed through the ranks.
 
In Houston, we were ‘hosting’ a team of USCG personnel, who insisted upon checking the whole vessel armed with scary looking weapons, ammo good to go.
 
The Captain's feeble attempts at explaining that it wasn't a good idea to consider firing a round while you were aboard a ship loaded with 30 thousand tons of highly explosive propane was met with general derision from the ‘protectors of American way of life'!!
 
Anyway, I got tasked with accompanying the team inspecting the deck area. The 3 ‘coasties' were most interested in ascertaining if I was an Arab. That out of the way, they thawed a bit (I am not Arab, incidentally). The least hostile one then decided to ask me the question I shall never forget.
 
“So Mr. Mate, tell me which is the farthest place you have ever been to?”. My jaw dropped! Was he kidding?! No, not at all. An answer was expected of me.
 
“From where?” I ask. Now the coastie is already a bit confused. “Er, you are Indian, right? So which is the farthest place from India you have been to?”
 
“Here. This place. Houston”, I tell him.
 
I shall never forget his face. Utter confusion written on it. “How can this be the farthest place from ANYWHERE? I mean this is Houston, right?! This IS the centre of the world!”
 
I had multiple experiences of similar kind. I was asked by one security personnel if I was Russian. And I am as Indian looking as is possible! He was friendly. But his ‘reason for asking' was that there was apparently an active Russian gang around that area indulging in stealing car stereos!! He was just ‘making sure'!
 
I am trying not to generalize. Maybe it had to do with the fact that I was a sailor on high risk ships. We met the same kind of security personnel every time we sailed into US. Calling US ports in those days would always leave a metallic taste in every sailor's mouth.

We were on social assistance (welfare) on and off in my upbringing, and she worked at some points (we lived in a town far from any jobs in her field so it was hard for a long time) and at another point she had student loans and was taking online courses towards an accounting degree. (Which she did not complete, as it was still very expensive and student loans are very stressful to have and difficult to keep applying for and getting approved for.)
 
I left when I was 17 in 2012 and have since been homeless three separate times for a minimum span of one month and a maximum span of around 7 months or so at a time. I am currently on social assistance. I had previously tried to go to university when I was 17 and found myself in hospital for mental illness related issues and had to drop out. I make paintings right now but they don’t generally sell, mainly because I am too ill to manage getting a portfolio together, applying to galleries, and I cannot afford the costs associated with applying.
 
I often do not eat, and I cannot generally afford luxuries. My rent is $375/month CAD, which is only so low because I share a room with my partner. Utilities are $80/month (internet as part of this), and I have leftover around $100 for basic needs for the month. I try to grocery shop and grow food and bake my own bread whenever I can in order to save on food, and keep an eye on sales on canned food and things like vinegar for cleaning and toilet paper. I share a home with three other adults, ages 19–28. We’ve also had homeless friends stay here sometimes when they’ve needed it. (When you live homeless as a young person around here, I think it’s typical to stay at different friends’ places in rotation so as to avoid putting too much pressure on anyone in particular, especially because of the weirdness of social protocol and figuring out whether you count as a guest or a temporary roommate.)
 
I would love to share pictures of my home but it’s really messy and also I would need to ask my roommates if that’s alright, since the mess belongs to a bit of all of us. I want to thank all the other poor people for sharing pictures and stories of how they live. It makes me feel proud of what little I come from and less lonely to see all of you talking about it.

I don't know why this question specifies Americans- perhaps the author has something against Americans? But nevertheless, as an American, I will answer.
 
My 12 year old son's father, by far! We split & he had full custody for a short time, before it graduated into joint custody. During this time, my son was enrolled into kindergarten. His father was telling me, quite proudly, about the process of enrolling him into kindergarten, ‘since I had never done so’. He was simply boasting at the fact that he had full custody (at that point in time), & telling me about how they require medical insurance information for enrollment.
 
I said “That's just a section on the form to fill in, in case there is a playground accident or something & he has to be taken to the hospital- so they have the info to present the hospital, or if there is a specific hospital that he needs to be taken to”. He adamantly rebutted what I said, since ‘I have never enrolled anybody in kindergarten, so I obviously wouldn't know what is necessary’. He truly thought/thinks that medical insurance was a necessary requirement to be enrolled in kindergarten! I tried to explain, saying “It is a federal requirement for children to attend school from 5-16 (+ or - in different states). With that being the case, how could the government possibly hold a 5yr old accountable for his parents’ having/not having medical insurance? That's insane! “.
 
He continued to insist that indeed it is necessary for every 5 year old to have medical insurance to be enrolled in kindergarten. I then said “What about illegal aliens?”. As we live in California, there are many illegal aliens enrolled in school, enrolled in University (many times with scholarship), working jobs, living in apartments, etc. He answered “Illegal aliens don't send their kids to school”. Crazy!! We live in the midst of a lot of them, from places near & far alike (Mexico, China, India, Guatemala, Cambodia, Vietnam, Korea, Eritrea, etc.).
 
No matter what I did, I could not convince him that 5yr olds can't be held accountable for making sure that their parents have provided medical insurance for them, so that they can go to a state-mandated institution.
 
The scary part? This man is vice president of Engineering in the tech company he works for. And this is not a mom & pop, fly-by-night company.

Thank you again for the A2A! :)
 
I don’t want to give a too long-winded answer, but I’ll go over the 2 
fundamental 
principles to a good workout routine.
 
A workout should follow these 2 rules and be tailored to an individual’s personal goals and limitations(an injury, for example).
 
That being said, I’ll share 
mine
 at the bottom!
Compounds - 
every workout of mine starts with an applicable compound movement. Back day? Deadlifts. Leg day? Squats. Chest day? Bench press.
 
Too often I see guys skip these fundamental exercises altogether. Maybe they’re afraid of being hurt, or believe they can substitute them with other, less effective exercises. 
Learn these exercises - they aren’t easy, but they’re worth it!
 
I also see them starting workouts with an isolation movement. This wastes your energy for the harder, more productive compound. The structure of a workout should take care of the more difficult and compound movements 
first.
Progressive Overload - 
this is probably the most important concept. You need to be 
getting better!
 Don’t do the same weight every day; try to do one more rep or go up in weight. Once your body gets accustomed, it’s time to shock it with something more intense so you keep getting better.
 
With all this being said, here’s my workout.
 
Keep in mind that my goals are to be exceptionally 
strong
 
with 
a decent amount of size. Depending on your level of experience, this might be too much 
or 
too little for you!
 
Day 1 - Back
 
Deadlifts - 6x5
 
Barbell Rows - 5x5–7
 
T-Bar Rows - 4x5
 
Weighted Wide Grip Pull-Ups - 4x5
 
Narrow Grip Pull-Downs - 4x8–12
 
Bicep Curls - 3x10–12
 
Day 2 - Chest
 
Bench Press - 6x5
 
Incline Bench Press - 4x5–8
 
Bent-Arm Incline Dumbbell Fly - 4x8–10
 
Cable Fly - 4x10–12
 
Weighted Chest Dips - 4x6–8
 
Narrow-Grip Bench Press - 4x5
 
Cable Push-Down - 3x8–12
 
Day 3 - Legs
 
Barbell Back Squats - 6x5
 
Sumo Deadlift - 4x5
 
Walking Lunges - 3x8–12
 
Leg Press - 4x8–10
 
Glute-Ham Raises - 4x12–15
 
Leg Extension - 4x10–12
 
Leg Curls - 3x10–12
 
Calf Raises - 3x15–20
 
Day 4 - Shoulders
 
Overhead Press - 6x5
 
Rear Delt Cable Fly - 4x10–12
 
Arnold Press - 4x8–10
 
Bent-Arm Side Raises - 4x10–12
 
Straight-Arm Side Raises - 3x10–12
 
Machine Overhead Press - 3x8–12
 
Day 5 - Rest!
 
Day 6 - Repeat Cycle

As Sheri already mentioned, it always helps to share your goals, which could be anything from losing weight to toning-up or building muscle mass.
 
How would the exercises be different, depending on my goals?
 
1/ 
Weight-Loss
 
If you are actively looking to reduce your bodyweight, then you want to be doing a greater percentage of cardio, in addition to some high-rep resistance (bodyweight) exercises.

Toning-Up
