My income alone is insufficient to keep us above the poverty line, and it is tough to survive at this level. Yet we are lucky because there is light at the end of the tunnel and we will eventually have a retirement income from his former place of employment.
 
I suspect we are not the only Quorans below the poverty line. My generation is supposedly the first in which people were unlikely to reach the level of p
Continue Reading
Yes, this is the first year my husband is retired, but we have had to wait 1.5 years before he can start withdrawing his retirement benefits unless we were willing to take a steep penalty. My income alone is insufficient to keep us above the poverty line, and it is tough to survive at this level. Yet we are lucky because there is light at the end of the tunnel and we will eventually have a retirement income from his former place of employment.
 
I suspect we are not the only Quorans below the poverty line. My generation is supposedly the first in which people were unlikely to reach the level of prosperity their parents had achieved, and my students were even more unlucky - I taught in 2007 and the economy crashed that year, leaving most of my college seniors with no prospects of landing a job in their profession so that they could make payments on their student loans, which would start coming due just after graduation. Most left the state and moved around seeking any job they could find, leaving our state impoverished for young people to keep things going.
 
This is the effect of many decades of “trickle down economics”. The name and theory sound good, but in essence it requires pumping all the wealth up the to wealthiest people in the world, who do their best to hoard everything they get, with reasonable success. A bit does trickle back down to the middle classes and even less to the poor, but nothing compared to what the economic and tax policies have taken from us. And the latest tax restructuring policy is “trickle down” on steroids; it will be about 15 times worse for the economy than the current tax policy. I’m glad I never had kids, I will not have to watch them struggle worse than I had to in this wreck of a nation we are leaving to the next generations. There is no longer any shame to being poor, it is apparently the policy of the government to keep us that way so that we can’t rise up and set things right again.

Me: …fuck it, I’m done

Like some of the other posters, I buy the .99 produce bags so we have produce, I shop the discounted meat racks, we don't buy any clothing at full prices, we walk whenever we can, when we need something extra like new shoes, school fees etc. we work to earn the money and figure it down to the pennies.
 
I still stand in the produce section and drool over the berries and most fr
Continue Reading
When I read the comments on here, I think, “"How can I even think of myself as poor?”
 
I live below the poverty line in the USA. I have had much harder times in life than now, but I am still considered to be poor in the USA. Like some of the other posters, I buy the .99 produce bags so we have produce, I shop the discounted meat racks, we don't buy any clothing at full prices, we walk whenever we can, when we need something extra like new shoes, school fees etc. we work to earn the money and figure it down to the pennies.
 
I still stand in the produce section and drool over the berries and most fruit, wishing we had money to buy it. There is half the food in the grocery store that I never buy because we don't have the money. Do we ever go hungry? No. We are well fed, but it takes more time to prepare it homemade.
 
My husband is disabled with a mental health condition, which means he is able to work part time. However, whenever he can, he picks up extra work. I run my own business as a property manager. My teen sons work odd jobs, until they are able to work part time after school and in the summer. We work hard for everything we have. I had health insurance for the first time in the last two years and have only used it once. I am figuring I will not have it after the new policies go through. I am more concerned about my children.
 
Sometimes it is amazing how you can have so much, but at the same time, so little. Every small decision becomes a life decision. I am hoping that hard work will pay off. But then the old car breaks down, the roof leaks, or if I get sick, I know we could be sunk completely.
 
We have Internet, but we don't use much heat, we don't have air conditioning, we look for free activities, we use the library, we volunteer and we survive. We use free apples from neighbors or friends, we trade work for eggs, and we get creative.
 
Quora allows me to be creative and live outside my financial status.

[Edit, July 21: I had thought that Switzerland had no standing army, but it seems I am mistaken. I appreciate William Smith’s correction on this p
Continue Reading
>someone who doesn’t know what year the Declaration of Independence was signed or how many states make up the United States of America
 
Obama said, at a campaign rally in 2008, that he had visited 57 states and had only one left to go.
George W. Bush, in a discussion with aides, where the issue of the Swedish military came up, insisted that Sweden had no standing army (he appears to have confused it with Switzerland). [Edit, July 21: I had thought that Switzerland had no standing army, but it seems I am mistaken. I appreciate William Smith’s correction on this point.]
 
Donald Trump, recently arrived in Israel from Saudi Arabia, explained to his Israeli hosts that he had “just gotten back from the Middle East.”
 
CNN news anchor Poppy Harlow, commenting recently on Trump’s visit to France, mistook our national anthem for the French national anthem.
 
Libertarian candidate Gary Johnson didn’t know what Aleppo was.
As to the date of the Declaration of Independence, I would be surprised if most Americans could name the year and would not be surprised if a great many of them said “1492” or something like that.
 
I think it would be very interesting if someone posted a question on Quora asking respondents to give, without doing any research, just the years, not the exact dates, of the following events:
The surrender of the British at Yorktown, ending the American Revolution
The assassination of Abraham Lincoln
The attack on Pearl Harbor
The assassination of President Kennedy
As to events nearer in history, I would be very surprised if most Americans could tell who was President when they were born.
 
Surveys show that most Americans cannot name a single Supreme Court Justice or identify one from a photo, find Iraq on a map, or name our three branches of government. It occurs to me that if American citizens were required, as a condition of voting, to pass the same test that immigrants must pass in order to become citizens, there would be a lot fewer voters.

So we arrived we needed to get to our hotel and thought the subway would have been inconvenient and so we caught a cab. Now firstly, we have crazy taxi’s in South Africa, but this guy was something else entirely. Racing through red l

Well this isn’t per say related to American’s ignorant about America but rather, American’s being ignorant about the world.
 
When I was in New York back in 2013, it was my first time visiting and so I was taking everything all in and loving it. So I had decided to meet one of my mates when he was there as well as he knew New York better than me as he had gone before.
 
So we arrived we needed to get to our hotel and thought the subway would have been inconvenient and so we caught a cab. Now firstly, we have crazy taxi’s in South Africa, but this guy was something else entirely. Racing through red lights, swerving to miss pedestrians, the works and while doing this he decides to create conversation with us. Now me being the naive South African, I am more than willing to chat with this guy, who seems to be of Arab descent. He then proceeds to ask the usual, based on our accents and luggage, Is it our first time in New York? Where are we from? and how long we’re staying. Now in response to the question, ‘Where are you guys from? you’ve got a strange accent’ our response was obviously ‘South Africa, do you know it?’, his prompt response was “Yeah, yeah, my wife … she’s from South Africa”, now naturally this excited me, so I’m like, “Oh, really?”, for him to then say, “Yeah man, you know Egypt right?”
 
Now at this moment my mate face-palms himself and I just keep quiet and the conversation doesn’t really go anywhere from there. Now for all you who don’t already know, Egypt and South Africa are worlds apart, let’s put that in context. South Africa is nearly 6500 kms away from Egypt, or visually:
Now for further context on this a trip from London to New York is just over 5500 kms. That really puts the size of Africa in context and the level of ignorance of some Americans.
 
Look in their defense there is so much to do, see and happening in America that I can sometimes not blame them, but regardless, this did happen.

Over the summer we went up the west coast to the sunshine coast in Brititsh Columbia Canada. Mostly for fishing and crabbing, all the fun seafood stuff.
 
Day 1
 
We arrived at about 5 and promptly started fishing. I had just pulled up a red rock crab from a net and measured it. A somewhat elderly couple showed up started to blab on about how good they were at crabbing and told me my 
120
 mm rock crab was too small.(red rock crab need a minimum of 
115
 mm to be legal for capture.) After I told them as much t hey started to accuse me of not respecting their rules. (which are also my rules as I'm a British Columbian too.) They threatened to call fisheries but stopped when I alerted them that the nearest fisheries office was almost 
100
 
kilometres
 away.
 
Day 2
 
We were grilling some food on a 
propane
 grill when an bare chested old man showed up and told us that we aren't allowed 
charcoal
 grilles as It was fire season. What?!?

And that we had too many fish (we had like 5 mediums sized flounder.) Then he just assumed we were indigenous peoples because he thought my mom looked slightly like a native American. (she doesnt.) He started to call fisheries. Well actually he didn't, turns out he was just on his home screen the whole time.
 
All in all not a great trip, hope you people enjoyed reading about my travel disasters.
 
Tl ;dr 
An old couple couldn't measure with a ruler.
 
Some dude couldn't tell we were using propane instead of charcoal.
 
This creeper started assuming we were indigenous and took random pictures of us without consent.

title: What is a good workout routine at home?
article:
You can always do some great bodyweight exercises, such as squats, burpees, push-ups, mountain climbers, a plank, hollow-body rocks, etc. I would invest in some gear though, such as: a pull-up bar, a sandbag, a kettlebell, a jump rope, maybe a TRX, perfect push-up, etc.
 
I would also do a lot of eccentric exercises to make some of your exercises more difficult. For example, if you were doing an eccentric style pull-up, you would pull yourself up to the bar a normal pace, but then on the way down (during the eccentric portion of the lift), you’d slow down, maybe taking 3–5 seconds to descend all 
Continue Reading
You can always do some great bodyweight exercises, such as squats, burpees, push-ups, mountain climbers, a plank, hollow-body rocks, etc. I would invest in some gear though, such as: a pull-up bar, a sandbag, a kettlebell, a jump rope, maybe a TRX, perfect push-up, etc.
 
I would also do a lot of eccentric exercises to make some of your exercises more difficult. For example, if you were doing an eccentric style pull-up, you would pull yourself up to the bar a normal pace, but then on the way down (during the eccentric portion of the lift), you’d slow down, maybe taking 3–5 seconds to descend all the way to the bottom.
 
A great book is Ross Enamait “Never Gymless,” has a ton of different workouts and ideas and routines to get you started. Super affordable and a great resource that I use until today.
 
If you’re trying to bulk up and put on muscle fast, invest in Creatine Monohydrate, and then probably Whey Protein (I prefer concentrate as it has more immunological benefits, but if your sensitive to milk, try Isolate). If you’re trying to put on size, you need to be eating 1g to 1.5 g of protein/per lb of bodyweight (example: 100lb male needs to ingest 100g-150g of protein/daily). I’d try eating 30gr of protein immediately within 30 minutes of waking up (see Tim Ferriss’s 4 hour Body book for more info regarding that.
 
Also just challenge yourself in new ways. Try gymnastic moves like handstands, try perfecting a perfect 15 second handstand hold. Or construct your own parrallete bars out of PVC pipes, and practice doing an L-sit hold. These isometric types of exercises are great for the home gym lifter, and will tax you in a ways you’re not used to. Something that is severely overlooked in weightlifting is grip strength. A great thing to do so simple, but would be just hanging for a pull-up bar as long as you could. Improved grip strength will improve all your other lifts such as pull-ups, dips, etc.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
I’ve spent hours in horror reading these replies. It’s like rubbernecking at a car crash; you want to look away but can’t.
 
Making this anonymous so as not to embarrass the in-law who was about to have her first baby. She asked my wife what labor was like. She was obviously a little anxious about things, so my wife tried to assure her she’d get through it. Then they got to the part about the actual delivery, when the in-law asks:
 
“So how does that work? Do you have to be totally naked, or can you, like, wear a swimsuit or something?”
 
My wife also reminded me recently of the interview she sat in on
Continue Reading
I’ve spent hours in horror reading these replies. It’s like rubbernecking at a car crash; you want to look away but can’t.
 
Making this anonymous so as not to embarrass the in-law who was about to have her first baby. She asked my wife what labor was like. She was obviously a little anxious about things, so my wife tried to assure her she’d get through it. Then they got to the part about the actual delivery, when the in-law asks:
 
“So how does that work? Do you have to be totally naked, or can you, like, wear a swimsuit or something?”
 
My wife also reminded me recently of the interview she sat in on with her old boss. They were looking for someone to work the reception desk, and the applicant was an Englishwoman who’d moved to the USA. Apparently the interview was going well until my wife’s boss said, “You seem really nice, and you’re qualified enough, but we’d really prefer a native English speaker to answer our phones. Now, I realize English isn’t your first language, so would you be comfortable handling the phones?” My wife said the applicant flashed her a WTF look, while my wife facepalmed as subtly as she could.
 
Then there was another in-law who didn’t realize the sun is the closest star to Earth.
 
And a former co-worker of my wife who loved sweating when she worked out. Why? Because sweat is melted fat. So if you’re sweating, you’re losing weight.
 
Or another of her co-workers (she has all the fun stories) who insisted on correcting my wife when she brought a quesadilla back to the office for lunch.
 
Co-worker: “That smells good. What is that?”
 
Wife: “Just a quesadilla I got down the street.”
 
Co-worker: “A what?”
 
Wife: “A quesadilla.”
 
Co-worker: “Ohhh. You mean a KWAY-sa-DIL-la.”
 
Wife: “No, I’m pretty sure I mean a quesadilla.”
 
Co-worker: “No, you’re pronouncing it wrong. I took Spanish.”
 
Wife, who actually did take four years of Spanish in high school: “Oh, my bad.”

title: How often should I workout for best results?
article:
I guess it would really depend on what kind of results you were wanting to see. Results can be massive or miniscule. You'll see which one based on the effort you put into training for those results. There is no magic formula. Many programs out there each will suffice for results. Consistency is key!!!
 
Progression also. Yet secondary.
 
A waitress carries a beer tray for twenty years… check out those results. The load hasn't changed but her arm did. From consistency. But that's the thing. She could have built a bigger bicep in half the time by doubling the amount of beer mugs she carried over time.

There is no magic formula. Many programs out there each will suffice for results. Consistency is key!!!
 
Progression also. Yet secondary.
 
A waitress carries a beer tray for twenty years… check out those results. The load hasn't changed but her arm did. From consistency. But that's the thing. She could have built a bigger bicep in half the time by doubling the amount of beer mugs she carried over time. That's progression.
 
Find a program that you can stick to FIRST! 3 DAY 5 DAY ONE DAY… THEN ADD THE LOAD! GO SLOW! Choose only one exercise. A compound one. start ridiculously light. Learn proper form. Add 2 percent every week.. Then along the way, add another compound movement. Same thing. Really light. Learn the movement. Teach your body how-to coordinate all the necessary bones muscles and nerves till your an expert! Slowly add more weight. Add another exercise. Continue until all major body groups are now being utilized. Now? Stop! Take a week off. You deserved it.
 
Boredom will set in. Change up the exercises. Switch from free weightvto machines, machines to dumbells, and back to barbells… keep going… slowly add more volume. More sets. If you become lethargic and tired. Take a week off.
 
And in 5 years, you will see results! Real results. People you haven't seen in a while will drop their jaws in awe results! Ex girlfriends calling you back results…. But most importantly, YOUR RESULTS! YOU DIDNT BUY THOSE, THEY WERNT GIVEN TO YOU. YOU EARNED EVERY INCH.
 
Are you happy with it?
 
Yes? It only takes a third of what you were doing in volume to maintain what you have. Maintain it! Don't lose it!
 
No? Back at it! Another 5 years. Keep it fresh. Change it up. Fucj the numbers. Numbers are for egos.

title: Is it bad to do full body workouts every day?
article:
How do you get the best results possible with the least time invested?
 
Full-body workouts.
If you are a beginner do them twice per week, and if you are intermediate or advance then you can do them three times per week.
 
I would also add in that another great option for advanced trainers is a 4-day upper lower split. But that is for people with especially good recovery abilities.
 
It amazes me how much the bodybuilding industry has confused the shit out of people. Telling them to workout 6 times per week, eat 2 grams of protein per pound of bodyweight, and other useless nonsense. Sure that works for the guys taking steroids, but all it does for a natural trainer is lead them nowhere. Yeah, you might experience results in a few months, but after that you’ll stagnate.
 
Full-body workouts on the other hand, are the perfect routines for natural trainers. They offer enough volume, but not too much to where you can’t recover from. In addition, you’re joints and central nervous system get more of a break and time to recover because you’re not training as often.
 
All you need in a full-body workout is a major push, a major pull, and a major legs exercise. The intermediate and advance could also benefit from some assistance exercises for the arms and calves. But other than that, this is all you will ever need to grow. I currently am 6′1 and weigh 203 lbs, at 11 percent body fat. And I have been on a maintenance routine only lifting weights twice per week and sprinting on a third day. I haven’t gained any mass (hence the maintenance routine) but I still have continued to gain strength. One of my example workouts was this:
 
Weighted Dips: Work up to max set of 5 reps
 
Weighted Chin-ups: Work up to max set of 5 reps
 
Squats: Work up to max set of 5 reps
 
Calf raises and forearms: 2–3 sets of 10–15 reps
 
Will you get to be 250 at 5 % body fat and become some absolute beast?? Hell no, not even close. But no natural trainer will ever get that close. If you are around 6 feet tall, the most you can ever expect to weight at 10 percent body fat is probably 215 to 220. And those numbers are for someone with very great genetics.
 
I love how people think they need to follow the split routines 6 days per week because everyone else is doing it.
 
Well, how many people do you see that are big and strong? Not many. How many people do you see at the gym following those splits who are actually big and NOT taking steroids? Probably zero.
 
I talk about this in great detail in my book which you can find here: 
Basic But Brutal

article:

In all 3 pictures this lady is the same weight. But her composition is very different.
 
Here is a picture that illustrates why:

Continue Reading
Weight is only one metric you should be following.
 
Your weight can remain constant, but your body composition can change. Look at this example:
In all 3 pictures this lady is the same weight. But her composition is very different.
 
Here is a picture that illustrates why:
Get rid of enough fat, and gain enough muscle and you can change shape dramatically without the equally dramatic change displayed on the scales.
 
Take measurements of key areas fortnightly; Arms, thighs, chest and waist. Take pictures at the same time from the front and side, back too if you can. Use the pictures and measurements to gauge your progress.
 
Here’s my first 8 weeks, at times my weight was static and it could have demoralised me without seeing it myself:
Finally, eating ‘healthy’ isn’t a guarantee. It’s possible to still be in calorie surplus on a healthy diet. Also, are you really sure what you are eating is really “healthy”?
 
Too often people believe they are eating healthily stating they eat salad daily so that should be enough. But:
Do they use dressing? How much? Which one?
Do they have Mayonnaise?
Are they adding cheese to the salad?
How much Carrot did they eat?
Do they have several tomatoes too?
Are they adding eggs including yokes? How many?
Do they add “bacon bits” or “crunchy onion”?
Even a salad can quickly end up with too much sodium, fat or sugar.
 
At the very least if you still aren’t seeing progress, keep an honest food diary for a few days. Don’t alter your eating because you are now writing it down, be honest. After a few days calculate your calories and macros.
 
Plain and simple, if you are in a calorie deficit, you will lose weight. There is no other possible outcome.
 
Here’s an example of how quick changes can happen when your diet is carefully controlled:
 
Stuart Cross's answer to What are some example meal plans for a male full body transformation when combined with exercise?

Hi there!
 
It is 
more
 
than okay
 to exercise twice a day.
 
Exercise is an incredible practice which do wonders in your body. It stimulates every cells and muscles. It not only benefits your body but also your mind, attitude and mood. Human body needs revitalisation every 12 hours, but due to loads of commitments and responsibilities people fail to do it twice a day.
I would like to say something to those who have issues in doing excercise in the evening.
 
Every lock has a key and every issue has a solution! 
:-)
 
If you can't go with evening session (if you work till night), concentrate on every morning, give your 100%. Excercise at your best. Have a complete, healthy breakfast. In the evening, you can revitalize your body with breathing exercise, neck exercise and also chair exercise (you can Google about this). All the three are very effective and can be practiced even at the working place.
 
If you are not the one who work till night but feel tired to do it in the evening, no worries, you can deal with it. You too give your 100% in the morning and in the evening…. set the music systems on. Increase the volume. Throw the day's stress in the air. Let music intrude your soul. Feel it. Get on the floor. DANCE. Dance like a crazy little kid. This is an excellent exercise for your body- both physically and mentally. (Try, you'll love it)
 
Which category you belong? The former or latter? Whatever it is, no problem. Say hello to healthy lifestyle and a better body.
 
There are some unfortunate beings (like me) who doesn't get chance to workout in gym, but that's not at all an issue. You can do miraculous workouts at home like squats, lunges, skipping, cycling, yoga, etc. Remember one thing, your food intake should be at the best, if you workout twice a day. Drink plenty of water. Sleep very well.
 
There
 
shall not be any excuses for excercise.
 
Cheers to healthy life! :-)

title: How to workout
article:
What makes a workout a good workout?
 
When you completed the last rep, or the last lap, or the last submission or whichever sport you train for, how did you feel?
 
Did you feel like a million bucks?
 
Like you have a weight lifted off your shoulders?
 
Does it feel like you tested yourself?
 
Yes?
 
Good.
 
No?
 
Good.
 
Listen…
 
It doesn't matter how you feel, good or bad, motivated or lazy, strong or weak. What matters is that you 
got shit done.
 
You did the workout.
 
Given that you are on a proven program that will elicit changes in body composition and strength. What makes a workout good or even great is doing it.
 
There 
Continue Reading
What makes a workout a good workout?
 
When you completed the last rep, or the last lap, or the last submission or whichever sport you train for, how did you feel?
 
Did you feel like a million bucks?
 
Like you have a weight lifted off your shoulders?
 
Does it feel like you tested yourself?
 
Yes?
 
Good.
 
No?
 
Good.
 
Listen…
 
It doesn't matter how you feel, good or bad, motivated or lazy, strong or weak. What matters is that you 
got shit done.
 
You did the workout.
 
Given that you are on a proven program that will elicit changes in body composition and strength. What makes a workout good or even great is doing it.
 
There are days you 
feel 
like a million bucks. You are excited to step forth and challenge yourself that day.
 
Those are the easy days.
 
Then, there are days you 
feel 
weak. Your sick of the day to day grind. You want to stay in bed.
 
Those days…
 
Those days are the ones that count. Those days are your TEST DAYS.
 
No matter the day, if you can get yourself to the gym and finish your workout, it was a great workout. Even if you just go through the motions.
 
Do it, go through the motions.
 
Those feelings after a workout are great and in many ways that is why we workout. The chemical release feels good, pushing oursleves feels good. Im not trying to downplay those factors.
 
You see the 
feelings
 will come and go. You can't trust them to get you to the gym. You can't trust them to keep you on track.
 
You need to keep yourself on track.
 
That little whisper in your head -
 
“Not today, I could use the rest”
 
“But I have so many other things to do, I can skip today”
 
Shut them down.
 
Feeling lazy? Too bad, it doesn't get a vote.
 
Feeling tired? Too bad, it doesn't get a vote.
 
Feeling depressed? Too bad, it doesn't get a vote.
 
You have the only vote.
 
And that vote shall and always will be towards 
getting shit done.

title: How workout exercises?
article:
Muscles grow when you push them beyond their limits, either by metabolic stress (many reps and high lactic acid levels), or by mechanical stress (lifting heavy weights that tear up muscle cell tissue). So if you want big and strong muscles that can withstand the test of time and whatever life throws at you, I recommend you do both. Follow a varied routine that challenges your body in both ways, one week of each, constantly alternating. Doing the same workout every week is both boring and not productive. There is no magical number of sets. When going for mechanical stress it is possible to achi
Continue Reading
Muscles grow when you push them beyond their limits, either by metabolic stress (many reps and high lactic acid levels), or by mechanical stress (lifting heavy weights that tear up muscle cell tissue). So if you want big and strong muscles that can withstand the test of time and whatever life throws at you, I recommend you do both. Follow a varied routine that challenges your body in both ways, one week of each, constantly alternating. Doing the same workout every week is both boring and not productive. There is no magical number of sets. When going for mechanical stress it is possible to achieve the desired effect after only 1 set, just make sure warming up properly. When the muscle tissue is torn and damaged, it will start a regenerating process that rebuilds and reinforces the damaged area. Normally it is ok to perform 2 and even 3 sets of this kind of tissue-breaking training, and 2 exercises will be plenty, making sure to hit the muscle from different angles and causing growth in a large area. 
 
For the metabolical stress effect you will need more reps and less weights, but again- there is no magical number of exercises. Do as many as you want to, and I recommend you superset them or giantset them, in order to hit the same muscle from many different angles, all in one highrep round of exercises. I like to do 3 exercises on each musclegroup, for 3 rounds of trisets, when doing this kind of training. It can come up to a total of 45 reps on one round, doing 15 reps on 3 exercises with no rest in between, on the same muscle. it will give you the most insane feeling of pump, and surely cause a very good environment for growth. The levels of natural growth hormones is highly affected by this, and this is the reason why people call the high-rep range hypertrophy training. It usually takes 3 exercises to train a muscle from all the relevant angles/lengths, so that answers your question I guess.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
I apologize for giving 2 scatological answers, but both are gems from friends of mine in college and I can’t really pick a winner. I went to a pretty good school, so general ignorance wasn’t a common trait, but each of these guys apparently had a terrifying gap in their ‘common knowledge’. (I should also say that both conversations were entirely unrelated, and neither of my friends knew each other). Using aliases for both. And I truly hate to have to affirm this, but apart from altering their names, every detail of these stories is true.
 
#1 - “Jeff” had his first ever serious girlfriend in his 
Continue Reading
I apologize for giving 2 scatological answers, but both are gems from friends of mine in college and I can’t really pick a winner. I went to a pretty good school, so general ignorance wasn’t a common trait, but each of these guys apparently had a terrifying gap in their ‘common knowledge’. (I should also say that both conversations were entirely unrelated, and neither of my friends knew each other). Using aliases for both. And I truly hate to have to affirm this, but apart from altering their names, every detail of these stories is true.
 
#1 - “Jeff” had his first ever serious girlfriend in his freshman year of college, and one day mentioned that he wasn’t sure what to do because he thought his girlfriend might have a really serious medical condition, but she didn’t seem to think it was at all serious and seemed embarrassed that he kept bringing it up. With a touch of prodding, I got him to share with me (it has been >15 years now and I’m using aliases, so I feel ok breaking the ‘confidence’) what was wrong.
 
As it turns out, she pooped. Like a guy. Because “Jeff” had been under the impression that women didn’t ever poop (though thankfully, he knew that they pee). When I asked what he thought happened with their waste that couldn’t be passed as urine, he said he just assumed there was some other way their bodies dealt with that.
 
#2 - “Kevin” and I were chatting about random things and it came up that I’m allergic to dogs. He told me that it was probably for the best, since dogs were disgusting animals. I assumed he took issue with the slobber, or maybe general hygiene, or even that some (I gather) eat their own vomit, poop, etc. Nope. He felt, very viscerally, that it was a perfect metaphor for the nature of a dog that it is born covered in feces. Because dogs are born through the anus. Because dogs don’t have vaginas, and get impregnated also through the anus.
 
His family owned dogs.

title: What happens if you workout every day?
article:
A2A. In my opinion, the best way to train for beginners and intermediates is 3–4 days a week, full-body. I train that way 95% of the time myself and I have been training for 14 years.
 
Note that this is the current trend in the newest and most cutting edge powerlifting training programs out there, Norwegian and RTS for example.
 
Advanced lifters who train 5–7 days a week, sometimes twice a day, may need to split their training up a little. They still squat, press and pull 3–7 days a week.
 
What is the problem with split training routines?
 
Let’s look at the concept. Basically the idea is that you trai
Continue Reading
A2A. In my opinion, the best way to train for beginners and intermediates is 3–4 days a week, full-body. I train that way 95% of the time myself and I have been training for 14 years.
 
Note that this is the current trend in the newest and most cutting edge powerlifting training programs out there, Norwegian and RTS for example.
 
Advanced lifters who train 5–7 days a week, sometimes twice a day, may need to split their training up a little. They still squat, press and pull 3–7 days a week.
 
What is the problem with split training routines?
 
Let’s look at the concept. Basically the idea is that you train a body part, say legs. once a week, completely into the ground, you “destroy”, “demolish”, “annihilate” your legs, then rest for a week.
 
Now, both research and experience has shown that first, most drug-free trainees cannot recover properly from such an extreme training session and that milder sessions spread out over the week work better and second, that the muscle building period after training in drug-free people is only 1–2 days and that they are then ready to train again.
 
In other words, you get much better results, at any stage of advancement, from squatting 3 sets Monday, 3 sets Wednesday and 3 sets Friday, than from squatting 9 sets Monday and resting for a week.
 
Not only that, but you avoid the crippling soreness that you get from once-a-week training and feel fresher and stronger all the time.
 
Yes, advanced trainees sometimes train for 5–10 sessions a week and then incorporate some sort of split, but they still work each basic movement several times during the week.
 
Whole-body does not imply that each session needs to be exactly the same. I keep them similar for total beginners. Repetition and practice in the base lifts is crucial. But for intermediates and above it is feasible and useful to vary the sessions, both the set/rep scheme and the exercise.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
A few years back I was volunteering at a Christian camp for kids aged 6–12. I'm not particularly Christian but my friend's family was part of the organising team, I loved kids and thought it would be fun.
 
For some reason every year, there would be young American “missionaries” who would fly to the heart of Provence in the suburbs of a rich French city in order to help out at that camp.
 
One of them stood out. He was a goof ball, always had a smile on his face and always awkwardly trying to help out. At one point we had to go and get some firewood or something of the sort so we both headed further
Continue Reading
A few years back I was volunteering at a Christian camp for kids aged 6–12. I'm not particularly Christian but my friend's family was part of the organising team, I loved kids and thought it would be fun.
 
For some reason every year, there would be young American “missionaries” who would fly to the heart of Provence in the suburbs of a rich French city in order to help out at that camp.
 
One of them stood out. He was a goof ball, always had a smile on his face and always awkwardly trying to help out. At one point we had to go and get some firewood or something of the sort so we both headed further from the group. In the 20 minutes we were together he baffled me.
 
First, as we got close to the road, we saw a couple of Asian tourists who asked me for directions. I helped them out and they went their way.
 
All of a sudden my friend randomly shouted out:
 
“-CHING CHANG CHONG”. THEN HE BOWED.
 
ME: Um. What was that??
 
Him: Oh I just spoke to them in Korean.
 
Me: Wut. Do you speak Korean?? And how do you know they speak Korean?? They could be Japanese or Chinese or from any other Asian country.
 
Him: Not really. And they looked a bit Korean don't you think? I just wanted them to feel at home.”
 
As I said, I was baffled.
 
Second, as we walk back to the home he tells me a little about his life.
 
“Him: Yeah I come from Atlanta. Did you know that we have powdered lemonade in Atlanta? Do you have powdered lemonade in France??
 
Me: Um- [WAT IS POWDERED LEMONADE?? LEMONADE IS LEMON WATER AND SUGAR WHY DO YOU NEED TO MAKE A POWDER OUT OF IT]
 
Him: Cause we have that in the US. That's because we're a developed country. How developed is France? Because the US is like super developed. Not like Africa.”
 
He really was a kind kid but that level of ignorance stayed with me. If only because it was funny.
 
He went on to a puppeteering college. To become a puppeteer.

title: Is running every day better than going to the gym every day?
article:
Picture this
. It’s July. I was randomly scrolling online when I found out that a 10km run was happening in December. I had thought for a while that running was a cool thing to do but hadn’t ever really tried, so I got my parents to sign me up.
 
Only problem is, 
I hate running
. Like seriously despise it. It’s boring, painful, and completely pointless. I thought that by signing up I’ll be forced to go and practice, but I was completely wrong.
 
Slowly, day by day, the run came closer and closer, and yet, other than a couple of runs here and there I still couldn’t get myself out to run. Finally, t
he d
Continue Reading
Picture this
. It’s July. I was randomly scrolling online when I found out that a 10km run was happening in December. I had thought for a while that running was a cool thing to do but hadn’t ever really tried, so I got my parents to sign me up.
 
Only problem is, 
I hate running
. Like seriously despise it. It’s boring, painful, and completely pointless. I thought that by signing up I’ll be forced to go and practice, but I was completely wrong.
 
Slowly, day by day, the run came closer and closer, and yet, other than a couple of runs here and there I still couldn’t get myself out to run. Finally, t
he day of the run arrived, and I still had never run 10km in my life before.
 
So there I was, at the start line, for an activity I don’t like and was completely unprepared for.
 
The run was tiring, but not too bad. I stopped only twice. At the beginning of the run, I was disgruntled and annoyed that I had ever signed myself up. By a quarter of the way through, I had accepted my fate. And by halfway, I was enjoying it. I ended up finishing the first 10km run in my life in less than one hour.
 
After the run was over, I realised that 
running isn’t so bad after all. It’s the mental barrier that gives the biggest block.
 
Since that day, I’ve been running 4–5 times a week.
 
You can easily search up the scientific benefits of running, but here’s what I can tell you from personal experience:
 
When I run, I get the best ideas
 
It’s a great, almost meditative escape from today’s constant notifications and distractions
 
After running, I feel great, awake, and energised, not to mention focused
 
It’s an activity that you begin to enjoy that you can feel proud of, unlike things like gaming/watching TV
 
So if you’re wondering whether to take the plunge and start running, I’d give a resounding YES, because it’s one of the best activities I’ve started in a long time.

article:

I was having lunch at a small restaurant in Dallas in ’05 and was being served by a waitress who was probably in her mid to late 30s. When I handed her my credit card she saw my name and said:
 
“Huh, that’s an interesting name, what kind of Mexican are you?”

kind 
of Mexican?”
 
I’m kind of
Continue Reading
I’m going to give an example of ignorance, not closed mindedness, and it’s an experience that stuck with me because it really taught me to be more understanding.
 
I was having lunch at a small restaurant in Dallas in ’05 and was being served by a waitress who was probably in her mid to late 30s. When I handed her my credit card she saw my name and said:
 
“Huh, that’s an interesting name, what kind of Mexican are you?”
 
I was a bit confused and said “I’m not sure what you’re asking.”
 
She responded “You know… are you a Guatemalan Mexican, Salvadorean Mexican, you know, what 
kind 
of Mexican?”
 
I’m kind of snarky so my gut was to immediately shoot back a snide comment, but a few things occurred to me.
This woman was extremely friendly and trying to engage with a customer.
I’m ambiguously beige and while of Indian parentage I often get confused for mediterranean, latino, persian, etc.
Most Americans have never left the country (60%+ don’t have a passport)
With the Mexican border about 500 miles away, a knee jerk assumption that a foreigner who looked like me was from Latin america isn’t the worst guess in the world
She was making an effort to understand national differences in Latin America.
So yes, she was ignorant about nationalities and geography, but she was trying and ignorance and closed mindedness aren’t the same thing.
 
Instead of being a dick I decided to engage her in conversation (the diner was pretty slow). I explained where my family was from and we got to talking about travel and ended up having about a 20 minute conversation.
 
Moving through life in a series of well traveled highly educated bubbles it was a really good reminder for me that the experience of a lot of people in this country is wildly different from mine but a lack of exposure doesn’t always mean a negative response and it’s worth giving people a little slack.

There were two.I met one whilst on a bus going to Madison WI, for my cousin's wedding. She was my seat mate, and we'd been having rather a nice conversation. She turned around and told me that “for a Canadian, you speak really good American.” You could have bowled me over with a feather. This woman used to live in Port Huron, across the Ste Claire River from Sarnia, Ontario. True, during the time she lived there, if you turned to CBC tv on Sunday mornings, you'd have heard ,”Ici Radio Canada”, but that wouldn't have been the only Canadian network broadcasting in the area. People from Sarnia have long gone to Port Huron for shopping, as well. You'd think that she'd have known that Canadians, like Americans, overwhelmingly speak English.
 
The other incident occurred in Nashville, TN. I was on holiday with my parents and one of my sisters. We had just seated ourselves AAT a Shoney's restaurant, and the waitress came round to fill our coffee cups. She was a little puzzled that three of us wanted hot tea. We'd learnt the difference between just ordering tea and ordering hot. She inquired where we were from.
 
“Toronto, we said.
 
“What state's that in?”
 
“It isn't in any state. It's in the province of Ontario.”
 
“And what state's that in?”
 
My dad was obviously getting a little tired of this. “It's not in any state. Toronto's in Ontario, and Ontario's in Canada.”
 
“Canada, huh? What state's that in?”
 
“It isn't a state,” Dad repeated. It's that big country on top of the US on the map.”
 
“That's a country? I thought it was just empty space. I never knew there was anything there.”
 
Dad was taught to be polite. He didn't say anything more to the girl (she was maybe 17), but as she walked away, he muttered something disparaging about the state of American education.
 
Other than that exchange, though, our road trip to the American South was wonderful.

title: Is a morning gym workout better than an evening gym workout?
article:
Muscle may be different and unrelated to strength in some cases.
 
Strength as an expression of neuromuscular system ability will almost always be best expressed later in the day. Almost all world records for strength/power sports are broken in the late afternoon to early evening (4–8 PM).
 
It takes about 3 hours after waking for full nervous system functioning to kick in. Think of it like a 3-hour computer system reboot.
 
Not to mention your spinal fluids are not in an advantageous position for loading after being horizontal for the morning. So some kind of spinal flossing for morning workouts is al
Continue Reading
Muscle may be different and unrelated to strength in some cases.
 
Strength as an expression of neuromuscular system ability will almost always be best expressed later in the day. Almost all world records for strength/power sports are broken in the late afternoon to early evening (4–8 PM).
 
It takes about 3 hours after waking for full nervous system functioning to kick in. Think of it like a 3-hour computer system reboot.
 
Not to mention your spinal fluids are not in an advantageous position for loading after being horizontal for the morning. So some kind of spinal flossing for morning workouts is always a good idea.
 
All that being said, the time you can actually train will always work better than the time you can’t.
 
Just because late afternoon/early evening is the ideal time to express strength as a quality, doesn’t mean a thing if you can’t and don’t train at that time because the time is bad for you.
 
Training in the morning gets it out of the way for most people before other aspects of their lives take over and prevent regular training from occurring. Consistency will trump time of day no matter what and many people find morning better for that reason.
 
They may never get as ‘strong’ but rarely is maximum strength really all that important anyway. The average lifter isn’t working towards a world record in anything. For muscle gains, I’m not convinced it matters. You need even more consistency for muscle hypertrophy. I still think you will train better later in the day but that isn’t convenient for a lot of people. So even if you’re 10% stronger at that time, in the grand scheme of things it won’t mean a thing for 95% of the population.
 
Train at the time that is most convenient for you because elite athletes don’t ask questions like this on Quora. They are already training in the late morning and early afternoons twice a day.

Continue Reading
1. **General Guidelines:**
 The frequency of exercise depends on your fitness goals, overall health, and the type of exercise you engage in.
 
2. **Aerobic Exercise:** 
For cardiovascular health, aim for at least 150 minutes of moderate-intensity aerobic exercise or 75 minutes of vigorous-intensity exercise per week. This can be spread throughout the week.
 
3. **Strength Training:** 
Include strength training exercises for major muscle groups at least two days a week. Allow at least 48 hours between sessions targeting the same muscle group.
4. **Flexibility and Balance:** 
Incorporate flexibility and balance exercises 2-3 times per week, especially as you age. This can include activities like yoga or tai chi.
 
5. **Consistency is Key:**
 Regularity is more important than intensity. Consistent, moderate exercise often provides better long-term health benefits than sporadic intense workouts.
 
6. **Individual Variations:** 
Adjust frequency based on your fitness level, health conditions, and personal preferences. Some may benefit from daily workouts, while others may find every other day more suitable.
 
7. **Rest Days:** 
Allow for rest days to prevent overtraining and reduce the risk of injury. Your body needs time to recover and adapt to the stress of exercise.
 
8. **Listen to Your Body:** 
Pay attention to how your body responds to exercise. If you feel fatigued or notice persistent soreness, consider adjusting your routine or taking additional rest.
 
9. **Consultation with Professionals:**
 If you have specific health concerns or are starting a new exercise regimen, consult with a healthcare professional or fitness expert to tailor a plan that suits your needs.
 
Remember, the key is finding a sustainable routine that aligns with your goals and accommodates your lifestyle while promoting overall health and well-being.

Continue Reading
There isn't that one best workout for everyone. Of course there are standard routines available but it really depends on a number of factors to come up with what works best for you. If your primary interest is enhancing muscle strength and size, here are a few factors you need to consider before committing to any rotuine:
Your primary goal: Are you purely interested in gaining more muscle strength, or simply to put on some more muscle? Are you looking to squezze in some Aerobics for your cardiovascular endurance?
Time: How much time are you willing to put in per week?
Focus areas: Are there anything specific areas of particular interest? Are you looking to get a more defined upper body/lower body? or just want a good six pack to take your physique to the next level?
Now having looked at that, let's go through a quick wrap-up of some of the most effective routines for strength and hypertrophy conditioning:
 
Full-body workout routine
 
This aims at hitting all the major muscle groups in one session. It's widely considered as one of the best approaches for beginners looking to up their general body strength before taking up some more specific approaches. Each workout day is typically followed by a rest day to allow for muscle recovery.
 
Split Routines
 
This approach emphasizes a particular body region or a group of muscles per workout day. Good examples include the Upper/Lower Body and Push/Pull/Legs (PPL) Split Routines. The former typically alternates between upper and lower body Workouts in the first 2 days followed by a rest/recovery day. The latter alternates Push and pull workouts in the first 2 days followed by a leg day.
 
Check out this comprehensive read for more details on workout routines and how you can go about choosing what should work best for you:
https://healthnuggetdotcom.wordpress.com/2021/07/07/workout-routines/

Many years ago I was in Toronto, Ontario, Canada for a couple of service calls over a period of a few days.
 
The first night, after dinner, I hit the hotel bar for one nightcap (I've never been a big drinker).
 
I sat at the bar with an obvious US citizen to seats to the right of me and to the right of him, around the corner of the bar were two more obviously US men.
 
The guy near me was obviously into his cups and decided he'd had enough so asked for his bill.
 
The bartender totaled it up and gave it to him, he looked at it pulled out a US $20 bill and placed it on the bar.
 
(note:at that time the US$ C$ exchange rate was very close to 1 to 1)
 
Canadians are/were quite used to taking US currency and from daily exchange rate quotes give you your correct change in Canadian paper and coins.
 
Anyway, the bartender rang up the sale and placed the man's change (in Canadian currency) on the bar.
 
Now, unlike US currency but like most other countries, Canadian paper currency denominations are each a different color. Also, at that time, there were C$2 bills in circulation.
 
Among the bills and coins in front of my inebriated countryman was a C$2 bill. He picked it up, brought up close to his nose, squinted at it while swaying on his stool. Did I mention he was obviously drunk?
 
Now, by this time I and the other two Americans were watching this transpire with some interest.
 
He loudly slurred to the bartender, "What's this?"
 
To which the bartender replied, "It's a two-dollar bill."
 
Then he asked, "What's it worth in REAL money?"
 
Triple face palm! And the four of us stared at him as if he'd had just grown a second head.
 
The bartender's mouth opened and shut several times like a fresh caught trout before he was able to answer.
 
I looked over at the other two Americans and we just shook our heads in embarrassment.

I am a 32 year old single woman. My husband and I split up almost a year ago. He took his debt and our kids. I took my debt. I live in a tiny house (it's less than 200 square feet.) my rent is 550 a month. I pay my ex 50$ a month to stay on his phone plan so I have a phone and internet. He pays the car insurance. I had a small chunk of cash when I moved out, but it ran out quickly. (Stay with me, this is all back story. It makes sense in the end)
 
I was out of the work force for eight years raising our kids. So once I was on my own, I couldn't find a job. No one was hiring, or they wanted someone with more experience and a better work history. By the time I found a job, (a part time, minimum wage job,) I was three months behind on everything but my rent. To pay my rent I was selling my plasma. The ex was making my car payments so I would still have a car.
 
I am poor. I am below the poverty level. I make 400$ a month at my job. I have 20k in debt I can not pay. I have rent to pay, its 550. Gas and electric are 150 a month. I pay the ex 50 for my phone. Now I have to come up with a car payment, which is 400 a month, but the ex will still pay for the car insurance. I go to a food bank for my food, plus take home messed up pizza orders from work, so the only food I buy is the cat food for my feline companions. And I buy the cheapest I can, so it's only 5$ a month I spend on their food. I pick up extra shifts when I can, which is why my checks are 200$ and not 100$ like my coworkers. I rob peter to pay Paul. And I can't sell my plasma anymore, because I have a false positive for hepatitis a. So I lost out on my income from that. I am still looking for a second job, or a better job.but until then, I am working my ass off to make ends meet, and the ends are so frayed that sometimes I'm afraid they will never meet again. I am poor.

article:

This was not a period of mass US travel to Cuba - far from it, Rose, Jenny and I had flown from Ecuador, and we were eating in a non touristic restaurant in Havana usually frequented only by Habañeros.

I answer this on the understanding that there are many of my own countrymen who are just as bad… but still…
 
Me, a friend I will call Rose (from Cleveland Heights, Ohio) and another friend, Jenny from Norway, were eating in a restaurant in Havana in 2003. This was not a period of mass US travel to Cuba - far from it, Rose, Jenny and I had flown from Ecuador, and we were eating in a non touristic restaurant in Havana usually frequented only by Habañeros.
 
There was a drunk/stoned guy from San Diego at the next table, who had travelled via Canada to come to a close friends’ wedding being held in the main restaurant. The fact that he had managed to negotiate the many difficulties of making the journey would typically preclude the dumbassery to follow.
 
He heard us speaking in English so came and inserted himself in the conversation. After pronouncing Rose ‘super hot’ (but with ‘stick up her butt’ because she didn't want him to come sit with us) he spoke to me briefly - ‘hey Engliiish! Do you know the Queen? (Answer - of course not numbnuts, please leave us alone, you can see we just want to hang out together) he started on Jenny.
 
Stoner - Hey, you have a fun accent - where are you from?
 
Jenny - Norway.
 
S - Oh, is that a country? Where is that?
 
J - Scandinavia in Northern Europe. We are the long, narrow country next to Sweden. Like where ABBA are from? We have 5m countrymen.
 
S - Never heard of it! So where is it?
 
At this point, Jenny tries to explain she is from Trømso in the north, and if you pivoted Norway on its southern point, it would reach as far as Rome. I thought this was a pretty cool analogy and a good way of explaining the size of Norway.
 
S - Where’s Rome? Is that in Russia?
 
He could have been stoned or he could have been a moron, but I’ve never met an American before or since that imbecilic.

title: What happens if you workout every day?
article:
You’ll probably make steady, measurable progress in strength and size - so long as you work hard each session and try to keep increasing the weights you use over time.
 
While there are lots of articles and chapters in books about “muscle confusion” I don’t think that argument has been well thought through. Some variation in exercises does help to hit the muscle group from different angles, perhaps work different muscles within the group with different emphasis and so on, but that just means you do a few different versions of each movement over time.
 
Personally, I find the basics still work. Squat
Continue Reading
You’ll probably make steady, measurable progress in strength and size - so long as you work hard each session and try to keep increasing the weights you use over time.
 
While there are lots of articles and chapters in books about “muscle confusion” I don’t think that argument has been well thought through. Some variation in exercises does help to hit the muscle group from different angles, perhaps work different muscles within the group with different emphasis and so on, but that just means you do a few different versions of each movement over time.
 
Personally, I find the basics still work. Squats, presses, deadlifts, rows. My routine is built around that. I do variations like front squats, step-ups, hack squats, sumo and stiff-legged deadlifts, one-arm pulldowns instead of pull-ups sometimes, kettlebell rows or T-bar rows… but the core of the workout remains the same. Of course, I’m at an age and lifestyle where continuous progress is not even the goal - I’m happy to stay at the same weight / shape / strength levels while being able to eat normally and have a few drinks over the course of the week.
 
Apart from anything else, those 4 moves are so fundamental to training that you really need to groove them - and then keep practicing them. So for the first few years of training, always do them. After that, if you want a few different workouts over the course of the week that’s fine, but still squat, row and press at least once a week (deadlifts once a week is fine from the beginning - many people don’t recover fast enough to be able to do more).
 
So, find the best moves, keep them at the core of your routine, put in a few variations from time to time and do it for the next few decades… unless you’re entering this year’s Mr. Olympia or World’s Strongest Man in which case you shouldn’t be on this forum for advice.

I can’t really compete with some of the other answers, but it seemed so absurd. 
Warning:
 there will be foul language.
 
I’m a bartender. One day two women walked in, each looking about 20–25. Only one comes up to the bar, but she tried to order drinks for both of them. Obviously not happening. I can’t afford that fine, plus, I’d lose my job and my drivers license. South Carolina laws are fun like that.
 
So the lady angrily chases down her friend so they can both be carded. We’re already off to a bad start.
 
She orders a strawberry daiquiri. I ask what rum she would like in it, and started listing off what we had. She said she just wanted a strawberry daiquiri.
 
I gave her the benefit of the doubt. I thought to myself “maybe she wanted a non-alcoholic daiquiri! That would explain why she didn’t think she needed to show me I.D. 
and
 why she won’t answer about rum! I can do that.” So I ask.
 
Nope. She wants the alcoholic version. So, I gently explain that alcoholic strawberry daiquiris are traditionally made with rum. And I ask her again which rum she prefers.
 
If she didn’t know, I could explain the flavors of what we had, or just give her a recommendation. I’m actually a pretty good bartender, and I understand that not everyone knows their liquors.
 
But no. She turns to her friend and screams “I don’t know what the fuck this bitch is saying to me! I just want a god damn strawberry daiquiri!”
 
Hindsight is 20/20. I’ve since thought of some great things I could have said to her, but at the time I was stunned into silence. After a moment I called over my manager to deal with these lovely ladies.
 
Needless to say, I didn’t get tipped.
 
Random bonus bar story:
 
This past Christmas day, a gentleman in his late 60s comes up to the bar. I ask him what I could get for him. His reply? “A prettier bartender.”

title: What is the best workout routine to follow?
article:
Troy - I try to move every day in some work-out way. I’ve followed this plan for a lot of years. There are apps now that help with that. I’ve been a long-distance runner, now mostly do shorter distances and sprints to protect my knees (!) but I do have the equivalent of a home gym in my house. I haven’t spent a lot of money. It’s 5, 8 and 10 pound weights, a Bosu, an old Spin bike, a boxer’s jumprope, a TRX system and a small trampoline. If you put my name into Quora I suspect you will see the many questions I have answered regarding work-out routines. If you’re just starting out, I’d book an 
Continue Reading
Troy - I try to move every day in some work-out way. I’ve followed this plan for a lot of years. There are apps now that help with that. I’ve been a long-distance runner, now mostly do shorter distances and sprints to protect my knees (!) but I do have the equivalent of a home gym in my house. I haven’t spent a lot of money. It’s 5, 8 and 10 pound weights, a Bosu, an old Spin bike, a boxer’s jumprope, a TRX system and a small trampoline. If you put my name into Quora I suspect you will see the many questions I have answered regarding work-out routines. If you’re just starting out, I’d book an hour with a Personal Trainer. It will be well worth the time and money. Talk about what you'd like to accomplish, what your goals are and ask if you could talk just a bit about nutrition and diet because that contributes greatly to getting to or staying at goal weight. Places I've worked out at include Tracy Anderson’s Studio in LA, Barry’s Bootcamp in LA, Pure Barre in Los Gatos, here in Northern California where I live. I’ve studied ballet so I do some of those basic exercises. I love to dance so I’ve done Zumba. I subscribe for free to XPT life with Gabby Reece and Laird Hamilton. They give weekly inspiration to get and keep you fit. She’s an Olympian and he’s a big wave surfer, so they are at the top of their game always, but I like to learn from the best! I hope I’ve covered some of what you are asking. I still like the basics - do something cardio first, then sit-ups, planks front and side, lunges, burpees, squats, push-ups. I try to conquer the pull-up which remains hard for me. I ended up putting up a bar in my cellar, and sometimes I just hang from it, then I try hoisting myself up and down for as many times as I can which is usually only a few. I gotta keep working on that. Best of luck and thanks for stopping by…

Wake up, there are whole COUNTRIES of Holocaust deniers out there, hundreds of millions of people. Attitude to gay people? Same thing. Someone never heard of Azerbaijan? Well, how old is the country, after all? How many of your Baku neighbours would know where Nauru or Brunei are? They may be smaller, they may not participate in international bodies, but at least they are on the map for much longer.
 
Most of our lives we live among people we select. We select our friends. We select our colleagues by selecting our jobs. Most of us here are working intellectual jobs, which adds to the quality of the company around us. But when you get into a situation when you interact with RANDOM people a lot - that's a true eye opener.
 
How many of you, car drivers, would argue the fact that the traffic order anywhere, no matter how it compares to other places, is maintained by a mere ~25% of all drivers, while all the rest just thoughtlessly and mindlessly abuse it, relying on someone else's thinking, care and reflexes? To me this reflects the distribution of knowledge (and the sense of responsibility) in pretty much every aspect of life.
 
Look at the quality of questions on Quora. How much of those are googleable in less than one minute? Of those, how many will have a complete answer among the first five results? Here we go…

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
A few years ago I took my family to the Tower of London, which is a large castle on the North Bank of the river Thames. As we were queuing to go into an area of castle known as the “Bloody Tower” due to the murder of two child princes in the 15th century, I became aware of an American family in front who were complaining loudly.
 
Apparently, they were “disgusted” at the lack of provision for disabled guests to explore the medieval fortress. Now, not all disabilities are visible, but this family didn't appear to have any ailments - except perhaps restricted thinking. The Tower of London was start
Continue Reading
A few years ago I took my family to the Tower of London, which is a large castle on the North Bank of the river Thames. As we were queuing to go into an area of castle known as the “Bloody Tower” due to the murder of two child princes in the 15th century, I became aware of an American family in front who were complaining loudly.
 
Apparently, they were “disgusted” at the lack of provision for disabled guests to explore the medieval fortress. Now, not all disabilities are visible, but this family didn't appear to have any ailments - except perhaps restricted thinking. The Tower of London was started in the year 1066 on the base of an even more ancient Roman Fort. Being a Royal Fortress it was designed to be - well - a Fortress! If you go to the walls and tap them, they won't wobble because they are made of 20 foot thick stone and not fiberglass. This IS NOT DISNEY LAND!
 
I am actually very much in favour of accessibility for all, but I draw the line at vandalising a world heritage sight to do so. Perhaps they wanted the ancient cobblestones covered in tarmac, or holes smashed through the battlements for ramps and elevators?
 
I had similar experience when visiting the USA (which I love as a country) in the mid 1990's. Me and my friend were queuing for a ride at one of the Magic Mountain theme parks when some rather portly middle aged women picked up on our accents and began talking loudly amongst themselves.
 
Lady One: “I've never seen the need to visit anywhere outside of the USA - oh except once when I went to Hawaii.”
 
Lady Two: “Hawaii is in the US hon’.”
 
Lady One: “Are you sure?”
 
Lady Two: “You paid for things in US dollars didn't you?”
 
Lady One: “Yes, but everywhere accepts US dollars.”
 
Lady Two: “That is true but Hawaii is in the US hon’.”
 
Lady One: “Are you sure?”
 
And so it went on…🙄

I grew up in western Pennsylvania. It's a very backwards, rural and racist place. Black people were the n-word, if you had black friends you were an n-lover, all Hispanic people were “Mexican” and are here for our jobs, etc.
 
I had a customer where I worked one night tell me he could “never go to Florida.” When I asked why, he responded, in total seriousness, “There's too many wetbacks there.” I heard customers at McDonald’s talking about the incident when Nidal Hasan shot 13 people at Fort Hood, and one of them said, (again, 
in all seriousness
)
 “
I
 
don't know why the Army hired somebody named Hasan anyway!” (She pronounced it “Hussein.”) They either had no idea, or more likely,
 they didn't care
, that the guy was an American, born and raised.
 
But the area’s racism doesn’t go unnoticed - Congressman John Murtha, (D, now deceased) once called his own constituents racist. When they freaked out and forced him to apologize, he called them rednecks in his apology. It was such a big deal, Saturday Night Live even used the incident in a sketch.
 
Here are the quotes:
Thanks to Alex Deas in the comments for this! And here's the SNL sketch:
 
Watch Biden and Murtha Rally Predict Problems For Obama from Saturday Night Live on NBC.com
 
“Anybody here ever seen a movie called Deliverance?”
 
Priceless.
 
*This answer excludes the multiple people I have now met who think you can drive to Hawaii, the multiple people I have tried to explain the difference between widescreen and pan and scan to who didn't grasp it even when showed the images side by side, and an ex who believed that trees in nature were planted by people.

title: How to workout
article:
As of this moment in time, I prefer running first and yoga second. I hated running in middle and high school (anything before, I probably enjoyed, but don't remember much), mostly because it was forced upon me by the school administration in the form of pacers and the infamous 1 mile runs. 
 
Once college hit and I began to realize that my health is actually on my shoulders, I ventured into the world of yoga, mainly because it doesn't involve any kind of traditional cardio (i.e. running). I never tried bikram, but hard-core classes like power yoga or advanced vinyasa flow made you sweat and toned
Continue Reading
As of this moment in time, I prefer running first and yoga second. I hated running in middle and high school (anything before, I probably enjoyed, but don't remember much), mostly because it was forced upon me by the school administration in the form of pacers and the infamous 1 mile runs. 
 
Once college hit and I began to realize that my health is actually on my shoulders, I ventured into the world of yoga, mainly because it doesn't involve any kind of traditional cardio (i.e. running). I never tried bikram, but hard-core classes like power yoga or advanced vinyasa flow made you sweat and toned and super freakishly flexible. I began jogging when I realized that my heart rate wasn't going as fast as when I first started, and weirdly enough it didn't feel like a work-out without breathing hard. 
 
The first time I ran more than 2 miles was mind-boggling. And then I ran a 5k (on my own, not in a race and rather slowly), I literally thought I was dreaming and pinched myself. Compared to other avid runners, I'm quite slow, I average probably 10min/mile to 12min/mile depending on the day, but each time I hit another distance (like 5 miles, etc) or time goals (like 5k in 30min, etc), it hooked me. Of course I have days where I absolutely loath putting my running shoes, so I substitute yoga. 
 
One thing that I have noticed with running more often for longer times and distances is that you can get extremely tight quadriceps, hamstrings, glutes, gastrocnemius, essentially all your leg muscles and your abs. So I'm not as stretchy and yoga is actually a bit more painful (I appreciate wooden people's yoga feats more now), which in turn led me to more running. So lots of stretching and sprinkling of yoga along with some healthy goals and good running shoes resulted in this weird love for running. :)

A Spaniard here.
 
I remember, when I was a little child that my father had a friend who owned a kind of bar of Irish pub thematic, he had a daughter that lived and worked in the USA and she married to an American. One day my father asked his friend how was the life in the USA, given that his friend used to go there sometimes to see his daughter and her family there. The friend of my father spoke to him to an anecdotic situation that his daughter lived there when a friend of her asked that If in Spain there were negroes and If Spaniards had problems and conflicts with them as they had in the USA, The daughter of my father's friend left out speechless and later she answered to her that in Spain there were no negroes and of course they didn’t have problems and conflicts with them ( this happened in the mid 2000’s and back then the multiculturalism in Spain wasn't considerably higher as it’s nowadays).
 
When the friend of my father told him the anecdote of his daughter, my father was stayed mind-blowing because of the higher level of cultural ignorance and racism among Americans.
 
Also my father met many Americans when he lived for many years in his youth in the Balearic Islands and he told me that they used to be very arrogant and proud.
 
Also there are many cultural ignorance among Americans with regards to Spain and Spaniards, I’m fed up of hearing how Americans constantly refers to Spanish language as “Mexican” and that Mexicans colonised Spain, that they associate things like “Tacos” Mexican hats and other things associated to Mexican culture as it was part of the Spanish culture.
 
In an Episode of the TV series “ How I met your mother” they placed Barcelona in Extremadura ( an Autonomous Community in the south west of Spain) and wrote badly the city of Valencia as “Valenciania”.

title: Is running every day better than going to the gym every day?
article:
Running used to be my go-to exercise 3 years ago. Running and cardio was the only part of my fitness routine and I quickly lost weight but my body still didn’t feel “tight”. Yes it kept me skinny but I wanted more out of my workouts and cardio wasn’t doing that for me. I wanted definition; not just a small waist. For contrast, this was me in 2017.
In 2018, I decided to change my fitness routine completely. I began doing squats, deadlifts, ab crunches and lunges with weights. I started low, maybe 15lbs (Iol don’t judge me) and gradually got up to 40lbs, then 45lbs and so on. I’ve been working ou
Continue Reading
Running used to be my go-to exercise 3 years ago. Running and cardio was the only part of my fitness routine and I quickly lost weight but my body still didn’t feel “tight”. Yes it kept me skinny but I wanted more out of my workouts and cardio wasn’t doing that for me. I wanted definition; not just a small waist. For contrast, this was me in 2017.
In 2018, I decided to change my fitness routine completely. I began doing squats, deadlifts, ab crunches and lunges with weights. I started low, maybe 15lbs (Iol don’t judge me) and gradually got up to 40lbs, then 45lbs and so on. I’ve been working out mainly from home the last 5 months and I’ve been in really good shape. I am not as disciplined as other fitness freaks but I still try to work out at least 3 times a week, 45 minutes each session. Some months when I’m really disciplined, I can really trace my abs and definition. Right now, I’ve lost some definition and muscle mass because full-time summer classes and work is stressing me out. I haven’t been as dedicated.
 
What worked for me was basically adding resistance and weights to my training and workouts. It did wonders in building my body strength, and strengthened major muscles of my body like my glutes. Weight training also increased my body weight by about 5lbs. That is an extremely good thing because I have actually gained muscle (which weighs more) and lost some fat. For reference, I use a body caliper I bought from amazon to measure this.
 
Women have a weird resistance to weight training, I promise you won’t look manly or hulk-out if you pick up that 20lb weight. You will have to work your ass off to get to that low body fat percentage and ripped. I personally don’t have the discipline for that.
 
This is me in 2020, satisfied but still a long way to go from the perfect physique.
