title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
Back in 1989 the day after the Berlin Wall fell, it was the big topic of conversation the next morning at work, of course. There was a woman in her late 20’s who was a coworker and her response to all of this was, “I didn’t know there was a wall around Berlin.” We all laughed, thinking she was joking. She wasn’t.
 
In talking with her and trying to explain what had happened and why, it soon became apparent that she was woefully ignorant of so much. She had no idea why Berlin and Germany were divided at that time, nor what had led to it. She had no idea what the Cold War was. She knew there had be
Continue Reading
Back in 1989 the day after the Berlin Wall fell, it was the big topic of conversation the next morning at work, of course. There was a woman in her late 20’s who was a coworker and her response to all of this was, “I didn’t know there was a wall around Berlin.” We all laughed, thinking she was joking. She wasn’t.
 
In talking with her and trying to explain what had happened and why, it soon became apparent that she was woefully ignorant of so much. She had no idea why Berlin and Germany were divided at that time, nor what had led to it. She had no idea what the Cold War was. She knew there had been a WWII, but not when and thought it had been the US, England and Germany vs. Russia. She was shocked to learn we’d dropped two atomic bombs on Japan (who she didn’t even know was involved in the war). She couldn’t see how any of this was relevant to the world or international politics at the time. To her, it was just long ago, far away, and completely unimportant. This is the type of voter who says, “I’m voting for candidate A because they’re cool and promise to fix all the world’s problems”… and her vote counts as much as that of someone who’s actually informed.
 
A funny followup: A month later I was recounting this story to a neighbor and expecting a reaction from him along the lines of “Oh wow! You’ve gotta be kidding!” Instead, he appeared to get a bit miffed and insulted by it. He then asked me who this woman was. When I told him, he said, “That’s not funny! She’s my cousin.” It appears that reading and thinking were not top priorities in that family!

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:

I met him in the old city centre of Ljubljana, the capital city of Slovenia, in an Internet Cafe (this was in 2004). He started complimenting how far Slovenia has come since his last been here, claiming it was all wood and straw houses in the eighties, with mud roads, no electricity etcetera.
 
I listened to him, trying to extract where he in Slovenia he actually was when he last visited, but couldn’t find out from his explanation. In any case there was nothing matching his description even in the far off
Continue Reading
Not exactly in America, but the person I met was from the US, while he was visiting Slovenia.
 
I met him in the old city centre of Ljubljana, the capital city of Slovenia, in an Internet Cafe (this was in 2004). He started complimenting how far Slovenia has come since his last been here, claiming it was all wood and straw houses in the eighties, with mud roads, no electricity etcetera.
 
I listened to him, trying to extract where he in Slovenia he actually was when he last visited, but couldn’t find out from his explanation. In any case there was nothing matching his description even in the far off year of the eighties. It sounded more like a fairy tale, and extremely condescending.
 
When I couldn’t figure out what he was talking about, I asked him directly: “Where in Slovenia were you, actually?”
 
“Zagreb,” he answered. The capital of Croatia, a neighboring country. Which is also an old city without any straw wigwams, mud streets, etcetera.
 
I told him kindly he might have been somewhere else, and we finished this conversation. He then looked at me very intensely and started looking through his pockets, after which he presented me with a dollar. “Have you ever seen this? This is ONE AMERICAN DOLLAR!”
 
I lost the will to entertain him and showed him a one euro coin. I was travelling recently and had some left in my pocket. Slovenia was at that point not in the monetary union and had a local currency.
 
“Have you ever seen this,” showing him the small 1 EUR coin. “This is 1.29 American Dollars.”
 
He didn’t want to talk to me anymore and left.

When I told them that I was from Israel, and could visit Jerusalem whenever I wanted to, and could speak read and write Hebrew. In 1974 I was travelling by myself in the US. I’d just graduated high school and treated my self to a long vacation in the US before coming back to begin my three year military service.
 
While on a train from LA to San Francisco, I got into a conversation with what seemed to be a reasonably normal family. When I told them that I was from Israel, and could visit Jerusalem whenever I wanted to, and could speak read and write Hebrew. Then they asked me something about Jesus, and could I speak the same language he did. I told them yes, but like most Israelis, I’m Jewish. This floored them, apparently these guys had never met a Jew before. One of the kids, a 10 or 12 year old, kept looking at me and whispered something to her mother. The mother than asks me would I mind if her daughter could feel my horns. It was clear there was no malice involved, just boundless ignorance. I explained to her that no, we do not have horns, so there is nothing to feel.
 
As a former South African, I’ve also had the pleasure of been asked by Americans how come I’m not Black if I’m from Africa, and was it dangerous there because of all the lions everywhere.
 
Even my American wife, who is reasonably intelligent, and well educated (degrees from two good colleges a notch below the Ivy League), and grew up in a upper middle class family who lived in a fairly affluent neighborhood of a large and sophisticated city (NY) can sometimes surprise me with flashes of ignorance. Several times I’ve had to correct her about American history. Clearly American education is in a bad way.

It was not uncommon to see CNN personalities, rappers or aspiring actresses passing through the first floor lobby.
 
One day I walked up to the first floor elevator at the same time as one of the CNN anchors. Already standing there were two women in their early 20’s, actress types, most likely heading to the casting office on the 5th floor. They had already pushed the button for the elevator.
 
When the door ope

About 20 years ago I was working in the high-rise CNN building in Hollywood. There were numerous other businesses in the building including an ad agency, a record label and a casting office. It was not uncommon to see CNN personalities, rappers or aspiring actresses passing through the first floor lobby.
 
One day I walked up to the first floor elevator at the same time as one of the CNN anchors. Already standing there were two women in their early 20’s, actress types, most likely heading to the casting office on the 5th floor. They had already pushed the button for the elevator.
 
When the door opened, they both looked up at the number illuminated above the door, which read “1”. They looked at each other and didn’t make any effort to enter the elevator. Before we could walk around them, the door closed again.
 
They pressed the button again and the door reopened. They looked up at the number “1” - and again did nothing. The door closed and they once again pressed the button.
 
The door reopened and one of them finally said “Let’s just forget it and take the stairs.” As they turned, one of them looked at us and said “Who ever heard of an elevator that only goes to the first floor?”
 
When the elevator door reopened, the CNN anchor and I finally went in. There was dead silence for several floors while each of us undoubtedly tried to make sense of what they had just said. Finally, the CNN anchor said, “One of them I could maybe understand but NEITHER ONE of them knows how an elevator works? I wonder how often they lock themselves in their car.”

I was taking a train to Dallas with my daughter years ago because she was ill and needed to be seen by a specific doctor who was doing child trials on a new drug not yet available in Canada. By the time we got to Arkansas we, and most others on the train were very bored, and my daughter was sleeping as was normal for a sick child. To amuse some children who had gotten on the train in Arkansas, I showed then my Canadian coins and promised them each one if they could name the animals Two of them recognized the beaver and arctic hare, although she called it that white bunny where Santa lives (she was about 6!) and took the coins back to show their mother who asked me where they were from and who was the lady on the front. When I told her that I was Canadian and that that was the queen,she exclaimed very loudy “Oh my goodness! Them people over in Canadia have a gay cross dresser guy on all their coins! How awful for them!” Then she looked me right in the face and yells. “Do y’all know what christianity is or are you one of those crazy cult people?” when I explained who the queen was and told her why were on that train, she again shouted loudly. “Do y’all not have doctors in Canadia?”
 
All I can say is that I’m really glad hat she did not home school her kids .
 
That same trip I also had someone ask where I was from in Canada . When I said Ottawa,they stated “oh,that suburb of Montreal,” the got all upset when I said “yeah, like Washington is a suburb of New York”

Time your food. You need to balance your food intake according to your workout time. You also need to have a proper balance in timing between workout--food---sleep. In case you consume something after you comeback(which you should--protein intake).
Do not compensate for your missed workout, by going at a different time. It will disorient your system. Keep going in the evening . If you want a switch if timing, make a complete switch. Else your workout becomes obsolete and will gave adverse effects on your health.

SUIT
 you.  If the evening workout is causing you trouble. Try something else but do not let it affect your body in a way other than what you expect out of it.
Eat Clean, Train Dirty:)

Oh man, there are so many. Here are three of the best I can think of off the top of my head:
 
When I was in high school, my friend's sister thought that Alaska was an island in the Pacific close to Hawaii because of how they're normally placed on maps.
I just remember asking her if she had ever thought it strange that an island would have such a perfectly straight side. She said she had always wondered about that. This girl was 18 and was born and raised in the US.
 
When I was a junior in college I was in a class called 'abnormal psychology' which was primarily a class on mental illnesses. This was a required class for a psychology degree, so it was full of third year psych majors. At the beginning of the semester, the professor made it quite clear that the use of the word “crazy” was not allowed in discussion of mental illness in this class. Towards the end of the semester, we're discussing schizophrenia and the professor asked the class for symptoms. This girl raises her hand and answers “
I don't know, when people just act crazy.
” He asked her to elaborate. She couldn't. I still can't get over the fact that 
she raised her hand 
to give that answer.
 
Last one. In 2008, all news outlets were covering the breaking news of Russia invading Georgia. I am sad to say that I heard from several people that they 
thought Russia was invading the state of Georgia in the US.
 No, not the US as a whole. Just Georgia. The Russian government just really wanted access to peaches I guess.
 
And we wonder why the rest of the world thinks we're idiots.

It’s so hard to find just one example. So I’ll give a few shortened examples:
The week after I graduated university, I was finishing up my last few days at my old job and planning my move to Beijing. On the last day, the entire crew who was working made sure to wish me well on my future journey in Japan.
One of my dear friends insists there are 5 continents: N. and S. America, Africa, Asia, and Europe. According to him, Australia is part of Asia and Antarctica isn’t a continent.
An acquaintance is always sending those little chain letter things, and at one point he sent one about how this year (2017) was “money bags” because February had 4 times each of the 7 days. No matter how much I explained that February usually has 28 days (with the exception of leap year), so it usually has that, he didn’t understand and kept asserting that it was a lucky year that would not happen again for 83 years.
When I was helping arrange a pizza party as part of my dorm’s association in university, we were ordering when they asked if we’d like the pizza cut as slices or in squares. One of the board members insisted on squares because it would be more pieces, so we could feed more people. When the rest of us tried to explain that it was the same amoutn of pizza, it would just be cut differently, she didn’t understand.
I knew a family that lived next door to my father that all refused oral hygiene because they believed that it opened them up for cavities and infection. They legit believed that the plaque would build up and protect their teeth.
Anti-vaxxers.

title: Is it bad to do full body workouts every day?
article:
Doing full-body workouts every day can have both benefits and drawbacks, depending on several factors such as your fitness level, workout intensity, and recovery practices. Here’s a breakdown:
 
Benefits:
Efficiency
: Full-body workouts allow you to target all major muscle groups in a single session, which can be time-efficient.
Increased Frequency
: Training each muscle group more frequently can lead to better muscle growth and strength gains, especially for beginners.
Caloric Burn
: More frequent workouts can help with weight management and improving cardiovascular fitness.
Drawbacks:
Recovery
: Muscles
Continue Reading
Doing full-body workouts every day can have both benefits and drawbacks, depending on several factors such as your fitness level, workout intensity, and recovery practices. Here’s a breakdown:
 
Benefits:
Efficiency
: Full-body workouts allow you to target all major muscle groups in a single session, which can be time-efficient.
Increased Frequency
: Training each muscle group more frequently can lead to better muscle growth and strength gains, especially for beginners.
Caloric Burn
: More frequent workouts can help with weight management and improving cardiovascular fitness.
Drawbacks:
Recovery
: Muscles need time to recover after workouts. Daily full-body training can lead to fatigue and overtraining, especially if the workouts are intense.
Injury Risk
: Without adequate recovery, the risk of injury increases due to wear and tear on muscles and joints.
Plateaus
: Constantly doing full-body workouts without variation may lead to plateaus in strength and muscle gains.
Recommendations:
Listen to Your Body
: If you feel fatigued or sore, consider taking rest days or alternating with lighter workouts.
Vary Intensity
: You might do high-intensity workouts a few times a week and lighter sessions or active recovery on other days.
Incorporate Rest Days
: Aim for at least one or two rest days per week to allow for muscle recovery.
Ultimately, the best approach depends on your individual goals, fitness level, and how your body responds to training. If you’re unsure, consulting a fitness professional can provide personalized guidance.

That depends on your fitness goals.
 
But here is an ideal workout routine that I follow and has proven to be pretty much effective.
 
I like to target each muscle separately and so I follow a one-day-one-muscle routine (I've been going to the gym for almost a year now)
 
So here is a sneak peek into my routine :
 
Monday : Chest
 
Tuesday : Shoulders + HIIT
 
workout
 
Wednesday: Back
 
Thursday : Legs
 
Friday : Biceps +Triceps
 
It may look weird that I've placed my biceps and triceps workout after my legs workout as people usually perform their biceps and triceps workout after their back workout. The reason behind this is that you perform heavyweight exercises like deadlifts,squats,etc during back and leg workout which spikes your testestorone level sky high. This you can use as an advantage for your forearms workout as testestorone plays an essential role in muscle building.
 
Also, if you look at our anatomy,biceps and triceps are located such that exercises targeting these muscles performed together can give best results as research shows.
 
And finally,
 
Saturday : HIIT + BODY EXERCISES FOCUSING TARGETING ALL THE MUSCLES SEPERATELY.
 
By doing this you give the extra conditioning to the muscles.
 
And then the most important day out of all
 
SUNDAY , the rest day! Rest days are equally important as the other days. Your body requires rest to recover and build
 
That's all! Tell me if you like it or would like to recommend some improvements into the program.
 
Thank you for reading! Cheers!
 
AM.

1. Cardiovascular or cardio Exercises:
 
- Try activities like running, cycling, swimming, or brisk walking.
 
- Aim for at least 150 minutes of moderate-intensity cardio or 75 minutes of vigorous-intensity cardio per week.
 
- Cardio workouts get your heart pumping and improve your endurance.
 
2. Strength Training:
 
- Do weightlifting, try resistance bands, or bodyweight exercises like push-ups and squats.
 
- Focus on different muscle groups on different days to avoid overworking one area.
 
Like back on Monday arms on Tuesday….
 
- Strength training builds muscle, increases metabolism, and you will see strength increasing.
 
3. Flexibility and Mobility:
 
- Include stretching exercises like yoga or Pilates.
 
- Stretch before and after your workouts to improve flexibility and it is said that it will reduce the risk of injury.
 
4. Rest and Recovery:
 
- Don't forget rest days! Your body needs time to recover and repair.
 
- Aim for 7-9 hours of quality sleep each night to get your muscles recovered.
 
5. Nutrition:
 
- Eat a balanced diet with plenty of fruits, vegetables, lean proteins, and whole grains.
 
- Stay hydrated with water.
 
- Nutrition is a big part of getting fit and staying healthy. Many people think working out is main reason for muscle growth but the most important part is your diet. So give equal importance for diet as much as workout.
 
Remember, the key is consistency and finding activities you enjoy, because that makes it easier to stick with your routine.
 
Pls consider upvoting :)

1. Bridge
Often this exercise is seen as 'an exercise for women', but with the bridge you build brute strength and endurance in your buttocks, hips and lower back. By building strength in these muscle groups you strengthen your core. You will become stronger with exercises such as squats, dead-lifts and leg presses. In other words, you can not skip this exercise.
 
You can build this exercise by starting with a lot of repetitions and light weight and making it heavier with a barbell that you position on your hips.
 
2. Dumbbell Side Bend
This exercise focuses on the obliques (obliques). Many strength athletes are afraid that by performing this exercise the waist will widen, and they do not want that. This exercise strengthens the strength of your spine, in addition to the oblique muscles, which will give you more strength in exercises where you have to push over your head.
 
Add one of these (or more) to your workouts and you will notice that your strength in other exercises, such as squatting, will increase enormously.
 
3. Dumbbell Farmer Walk
By moving a heavy weight from one point to the other where you have to keep your balance, your core is addressed. This exercise is ideal for strengthening your core while the chance of injuries is nil.
 
If you want to make this exercise more challenging (and even more effective), you must perform this exercise with 1 dumbbell. The execution is the same, but by using weight on one side you have to constantly stabilize your body.
 
Want to know the #1 secret to better body shape

At first, I decline. But someone else gave me away. So he finds my account and starts scrolling.

I guess that didn't sit r

I cannot say that there is one specific person who is more ignorant than everyone else, but here’s one for you.
 
I am sitting in class, working on my homework. A fellow student of mine (a white male) asks me for my twitter username.
 
At first, I decline. But someone else gave me away. So he finds my account and starts scrolling.
 
During the night of the election, and the night after, I had tweeted a few things about the outcome. I side with Hillary, and I was just a little upset at the results. In one tweet, there was mention of white supremacy and male dominance in society.
 
I guess that didn't sit right with him, so he turns to me and asks why I tweeted it. I said,
 
“that's just how I feel”.
 
He starts arguing with me about politics (which shouldn't really happen in a high-school setting), and telling me about how white supremacy isn't a real thing. I just ignore him.
 
Then he turns to his friend and says:
 
“you know what I do to these kinda people? I block them.”
 
So he blocks me in front of my face to make me feel bad. This didn't really affect me at all in any way, and I never wanted his attention in any way, but it was their attitudes that really irked me. I know that they have all the right to block me, but way they did so really threw me off.
 
This was by no means the rudest encounter, but it showed me a general trend in American people. It is that people like to give eachother a hard time when it comes to opinions. Many people find it hard to ignore when someone has a different view than them.

title: Is running every day better than going to the gym every day?
article:
I am not a professional runner. I run 7 days a week and occasionally 2 times a day. My knees are not shot. My body is not wreaked (nor is it wreked). My motivation is not diminished, it is strengthened.
 
Basically blanket statements are just not helpful. As a coach, I would ask you a number of questions about your fitness goals and motivations. Then you can decide if your personal fitness level, motivation, and physical ability would benefit from running daily.
 
IF….and that’s a big IF….Running daily is a good fit for you, here are some potential benefits:
The mental toughness of enduring the grind
Continue Reading
I am not a professional runner. I run 7 days a week and occasionally 2 times a day. My knees are not shot. My body is not wreaked (nor is it wreked). My motivation is not diminished, it is strengthened.
 
Basically blanket statements are just not helpful. As a coach, I would ask you a number of questions about your fitness goals and motivations. Then you can decide if your personal fitness level, motivation, and physical ability would benefit from running daily.
 
IF….and that’s a big IF….Running daily is a good fit for you, here are some potential benefits:
The mental toughness of enduring the grind. Even embracing the grind. That will make you a tough racer, and probably a stronger person in other aspects of your life.
Running daily gives your body a regular, predictable stimulation. The constant calorie burning, consistent flow of hormones and other bodily functions will add a consistency to your physical well being and mental well being.
Better racing performance. I don’t know any really competitive runners who train less than 7 days a week. There are occasional exceptions to the rule but generally, top high school,collegiate, professional, masters or just really competitive distance runners train every day. The total volume of miles is a key factor in performance improvement so if your volume of miles goes up and you sustain it for a long period of time, your cardio performance will improve.
And also, I’m tired of the body shaming BS about a runner’s physique. Mo Farah is a world class athlete and looks great.

Well… I'm from Africa and I once worked for an airline so I've had quite a few experiences, from the now commonplace “Who's the president of Africa?”, to “Oh wow! I have a South African friend called Ziki, do you know him?”
 
Sigh! Africa is not a country so no president, and, no, we don't all know each other!
 
Funny thing is, it was always Americans who seemed entirely clueless about the ‘mystery’ that is Africa. Mostly it was hilarious, but every once in a while you ran into a truly offensive ignoramus.
 
So, this one time I'm in Thailand, in between flights and with a couple of days lay-over. We're out sampling the night when we run into this merry group of Americans who seem really friendly because they stopped to say hi.
 
“Where are you guys from?” One of them asked.
 
“Africa.”
 
“No f**king way! Africa?! How'd you get here?”
 
“Same way you did…”
 
“Hey, is your father like the supreme chief of your village or like a dictator ruler or something? You must be African royalty to afford to travel out here.”
 
And the crazy bit is, they didn't even realize they were being offensive! Africa is not some back-water, stuck-in-the-dark-ages , war-torn, dictator ridden, desease infested place where one has to be native “royalty” to travel, get a good education, or learn a foreign language. Therein lies the danger of a single narrative (from the Western media) and a lazy audience of said narrative, who lack the motivation and curiosity to research and find out for themselves more about what they see in the media.

However, there’s this willful ignorance in them that they do not give a dam about what’s going on outside of their town, let alone other countries. Heck! most of them have never even been outside of Michigan their entire lives.
 
While I was there, I walked around, shook many hands and talked to many people. And the question that i got asked a few times was: “
So do you have 4th of July in your country where you came from?”. 
At first I didn’t think much of it and politely answered “no” (as in we do not celebrate America’s independence day in my country).
 
Later it felt a little odd when a middle aged bearded man with a bulging tummy asked me the same question. “
So do you have 4th of July in your country where you came from?”.
 Only this time I decided to play dumb and asked him back: “
no, but what’s 4th of July all about anyway?”. 
To which he answered: “
Ohhhh! You don’t know? it’s when we all come hang out, drink some beer and watch some fireworks!”. 
It then struck me that he had no idea what the 4th of July was all about, and no! he wasn’t trying to pull my leg either.

My brother and I, were working for different MNCs and used to stay in same flat. Though we did not stay with my family during weekdays yet we used to travel home every p

Poor…!!
 
The word poor, can be referred in many ways. So here is my view..
 
I am an Indian, came to USA for masters, completed and doing an IT job for an year now. I could buy a car and can start planning for a best life here but I am still poor..
 
Don't you believe? Read below then!
 
It's been two and an half year since I miss my family. I was rich when I was in India with my family. I was rich when I was doing a small pay scale job. My brother and I, were working for different MNCs and used to stay in same flat. Though we did not stay with my family during weekdays yet we used to travel home every possible weekend to spend time with my parents.
 
Imagine how beautiful it is to travel four hours to go home with an elder brother, halting bike at every food station to have food and to exchange the ride.
 
My parents do not expect money from us but presence with them. I didn't spend a single day here in USA that makes me feel rich. My parents are farmers, and most of my happiest moments are the moments that I spent time with my family.
 
I am from a completely rural village, I have a joint family with my parents, an elder brother, two sisters and their husbands, four nephews, and a niece. My life before coming to USA was like a daily festival since we don't use technology (smart tv/mobile, computer, and no internet) in our daily life. Our happiness was in being together, working together and living together which I am missing now.
 
So I am poor without their presence and those wonderful moments.

Continue Reading
Well, this didn’t happen to me, but to a close friend of mine. So this one did strike me as hilarious
 
So my pal happens to visit the United States on an exchange program from Qatar. One weekend, he heads to Miami to party and get drunk with a couple of friends he met at his University. He smokes a couple of joints in his hotel room and heads to one of the most famous night clubs in town.
 
Halfway through the night, he realises he can’t find his passport. He’s Lebanese by descent, and being an Arab, he was petrified by the thought of being caught by the authorities without any documents and the fact that he was high on drugs and alcohol. So he takes a cab and hurries back to his hotel room to search for his passport.
 
As luck has it, his cab gets stopped by cops on the way since he didn’t wear his seat belt, being on the front passenger seat. The cop walks around to him, asks him to roll down his window and asks for indentification. He fumbles through his wallet and pulls out his Qatar civil ID card.
 
Since most of you may not be aware, Qatar is referred to as the “
State of Qatar
” on all official documents. The cop looks at him with a puzzled expression and then questions him, “The State of Qatar?? Is that up north??” My friend(trying to explicitly control his laughter), replies with a sheepish grin, “Yes sir, that’s a new state up north!!!!”. The cop smiles at him, taps him on the back, and lets him be on his way.
 
I don’t think I have come across anything more ignorant or this damn hilarious!!!!

Lift and Carry !!
DeadLift:
With deadlifting, you don't need fancy techniques like drop sets, super sets, or rest/pauses. Stick with simple training and reps of 1-10.
Deadlifting is the base upon which all real back strength is built. There's not a more 
true-to-life
 exercise. You bend over and pick up something heavy. That's it.
The deadlift's simplicity is also the reason it's so effective. It stresses every major muscle group in your posterior chain, but none more so than your back. It works your back from the base of your erectors to the top of your traps and ev
Continue Reading
Two essential movements of life..
 
Lift and Carry !!
DeadLift:
With deadlifting, you don't need fancy techniques like drop sets, super sets, or rest/pauses. Stick with simple training and reps of 1-10.
Deadlifting is the base upon which all real back strength is built. There's not a more 
true-to-life
 exercise. You bend over and pick up something heavy. That's it.
The deadlift's simplicity is also the reason it's so effective. It stresses every major muscle group in your posterior chain, but none more so than your back. It works your back from the base of your erectors to the top of your traps and everything in between.
Squat:
Just as we should eat the foods our bodies were designed to eat, we should move our bodies the way they were meant to move and impose the stressors they were meant to bear. That means squatting, and squatting often. Our hips flex, knees bend, and ankles dorsiflex so that we can rest comfortably in a squat position..
Squat is a complicated movement that forces the body’s parts to work and grow stronger together as a 
single unit
Farmer’s walk:
The Farmer's Walk activates nearly every muscle group. The core braces and stabilizes the entire body. Grip strength in the hands, wrists and forearms is a necessity. The upper back works to keep the shoulders and chest from sagging. The legs obviously propel the walk, and the cardiovascular system is engaged throughout the entirety of the movement. As a result, your entire body is put to work burning fat and creating lean muscle stores.

Continue Reading
I used to live in central Texas. Racial lines are still very distinct there—you can HAVE African-American and Latinx friends, you just can’t eat with them or worship with them. For this to be the unwritten rule shows the ignorance of most of that area’s population, but one white Southern Baptist lady really showed her ignorance to a friend of mine. She went to see “Amistad” with my friend, a black grandma. During the scene where they are captured and taken aboard the ship to make the forced migration to America, the Southern Baptist lady asked my friend “Why is he so upset?”
 
My friend, considerably more patient than I would have been if asked the same question, had to explain to her that these men had just lost their freedom. I would have added in that the Southern Baptist Convention is the nation’s largest Protestant denomination (even though half of them never show up for church) and it split with mainline Baptists in the 1800s because they wanted missionaries to be able to own slaves. They openly say this in their seminaries when men interested in becoming pastors (it’s never a woman) study the history of the denomination—which I can respect them for admitting. But these are the people who want to determine how teachers address slavery. If you can watch “Amistad” and still argue black people were better off under slavery and not understand why they fought back and why America erupted into a civil war over the issue, then you are the most ignorant American I have ever met, and a horrible human being.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
New York City, May 1998.
 
I am queuing at the buffet of a hotel in Times Square. Things seem to be slow, and the gentleman in his sixties who is standing just beside me starts a conversation. In a very polite way, with soft and charming voice, he is complaining about the service. He soon understands that I am a foreigner and feels the urge to apologize for the situation, where the staff of the hotel has clearly underestimated the flow of the clients.
 
"In America, we like when things are properly set up in advance and made on purpose for a specific event. Consider that we have an idiomatic express
Continue Reading
New York City, May 1998.
 
I am queuing at the buffet of a hotel in Times Square. Things seem to be slow, and the gentleman in his sixties who is standing just beside me starts a conversation. In a very polite way, with soft and charming voice, he is complaining about the service. He soon understands that I am a foreigner and feels the urge to apologize for the situation, where the staff of the hotel has clearly underestimated the flow of the clients.
 
"In America, we like when things are properly set up in advance and made on purpose for a specific event. Consider that we have an idiomatic expression in English for saying that."
 
"Really? And what is it?"
 
"We say 'ad hoc'."
 
I think for a moment whether to bite my tongue or not, but I can't resist.
 
"Well...that's Latin, I am afraid."
 
"This is unlikely! Never heard a Latino use that expression.”
 
At this point, yes, I decided to bite my tongue.
 
Edit:
 
In this story I’m referring to that kind of benign ignorance that makes you chuckle and that you find everywhere in the world. I’m sure that in another part of the globe there’s someone who’s laughing aloud for something that I said or did in the past (or I will say or do in the future).
 
Then there is the ignorance that scares me. Unfortunately, you can find this in all the places too.
 
I think they are so different kinds of ignorance, they would deserve to be defined with different words.
 
The gentleman in this story was a very nice person. I wish I could have spent more time with him.

I usually eat one big meal a day or 2 medium meals. I love a bargain and frankly won't buy anything unless it's half price, reduced or buy-one-get-one-free. ALDI is near mine and under £20 can last my family a fortnight (2week).
 
I pay the wifi and that's it. I also help out with the gas and electric.
 
I got my forklift licence through welfare, I have worked in factories. 12 hours, weekends, nights, you name it.
 
I'm currently working as a labourer in NE London, I get a ride there Monday 3am and return home Friday 2pm. I get free accommodation and some free food. The money is good but I must wait as it is fortnightly pay.
 
I know the value of money. I know what I want to do with my life. I'm just a simple guy, I don't stop for anything because I don't want to be like this forever.
 
You have to be an opportunist in this life.
 
Keep winning

title: Which 3 exercises would give me the most complete workout?
article:
TLDR: 1. Squat 2. Deadlift 3. Bench 4. Overhead Press 5. Weighted Pull-ups
: Squat: I prefer “Olympic” or High bar back squat, geared more towards actual adaptation reather than demonstration- the parallel squat. Low bar or “parallel squat” is meant more for geared lifters (because of the gear). High bar is more practical and trains full range of motion. And yes, you do let your knees track over your toes a bit. Nothing excessive and it's not bad for the knees. It's part of the proper movement. In a Low Bar squat, you're stance is set up differently. That's when it's bad for your knees to go ov
Continue Reading
TLDR: 1. Squat 2. Deadlift 3. Bench 4. Overhead Press 5. Weighted Pull-ups
: Squat: I prefer “Olympic” or High bar back squat, geared more towards actual adaptation reather than demonstration- the parallel squat. Low bar or “parallel squat” is meant more for geared lifters (because of the gear). High bar is more practical and trains full range of motion. And yes, you do let your knees track over your toes a bit. Nothing excessive and it's not bad for the knees. It's part of the proper movement. In a Low Bar squat, you're stance is set up differently. That's when it's bad for your knees to go over toes. Either one will build strong legs, just one for a full range of motion.
Deadlift: 3 different stances to choose from here. Conventional-ands outside feet. Feet stay fairly close together. Sumo- Feet out wide, grip in-between legs. Semi sumo or Squat stance- Mix between the 2 previous stances. Grip between legs, but feetfairly close together, about the distance (maybe a little wider) of a squat stance. About shoulder witdth.
Bench: needs no explanation.
Overhead Press-aka Military Press-aka Shoulder Press: Hits shoulders more (except rear delts). Bench doesn't transfer enough to this lift to merit excluding OHP. At some point in your life you'll have to lift something heavy overhead. You don't want to find out then that your bench doesn't quite do the job in this position.
Weighted Pull-up: If you can Deadlift a Buick but can't pull yourself over a wall, something is majorly wrong. Treat it as a main lift.

Year: 2016, 
Month: October
 
It was past 9 pm and I was returning from my job. I was exhausted from my 5 hour shift and was almost asleep in the backseat of the cab. As I was resting my eyes, I felt the dreadful arrow of small talk approaching me. Polite person that I am, I gave in and pretended to be interested. So, this driver (who is american) starts talking how he is majoring in psychology and discussing my field of interest. When he heard I was from India, he seemed be to excited and then he uttered something that most indians hear in a foreign country. “I always wanted to visit India and see Taj Mahal.” As a respected citizen of India, I started telling him more about India and how we have other tourist spots as well. Then he went ahead and said something that made me go “Whaaaa?! Really?!” and jerked me off my sleepy state. He said, “India is also known for Burj Khalifa right? That building looks extravagant. Have you ever been there? Where does your parents live? In Dubai? Which part of India is Dubai in? North?…. $%&^$##$^$&%^”. I rolled my eyes so hard, was about to go blind. I let him rant because I was in no mood to give him a geography lecture. He kept muttering something for the rest of the drive and I gave him a periodic “Ahaan! I see” “O Really” “That’s great”!!
 
My point being you cannot afford to be educated enough to have an advanced degree and suck so hard in geography. To me you are this huge ignorant person, who just doesn’t care to peep outside the borders of his own country.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
First off, I'll get my apologies in early and point out that we have this guy, so we can't point fingers:
I did some work in America for a bit, and absolutely loved it. I met a wide range of fascinating people, but highlights definitely included:
A lady who believed the world was 4000 years old. I would have argued but as she was armed at the time I decided not to press the point.
Being military I was approached by a man who gave me a once over while I was in uniform. He cheerily stuck out his hand and loudly proclaimed “G’day!”. I wished him a “Good afternoon” in retu
Continue Reading
First off, I'll get my apologies in early and point out that we have this guy, so we can't point fingers:
I did some work in America for a bit, and absolutely loved it. I met a wide range of fascinating people, but highlights definitely included:
A lady who believed the world was 4000 years old. I would have argued but as she was armed at the time I decided not to press the point.
Being military I was approached by a man who gave me a once over while I was in uniform. He cheerily stuck out his hand and loudly proclaimed “G’day!”. I wished him a “Good afternoon” in return. He asked how I was enjoying the US and then pointed out I was a long way from Australia. “Sorry, I'm not Australian. I'm British”. This caused mass confusion as he insisted the Union Jack on my arm was actually the Australian flag, while I was fairly adamant that it wasn't.
Dining in a restaurant a few weeks after the Royal wedding, the waitress came up towards the end of the meal and asked if I was Prince William. After a few jokes I told her I wasn't. She laughed, and told us how much she had enjoyed watching the wedding in Paris. I felt I had to step in and point out that the British Royal wedding had actually, oddly enough, taken place in London. “Is London in Paris?” Reacting to my expression, she attempted a regain, “or is Paris in London?”
There was also one person who asked if my Gurkha soldiers were slaves.
In all seriousness though, I found the majority of Americans to be extremely friendly and genuine with an extremely refreshing ‘can do’ attitude.

Monday: Cardio. Today I took it easy and did 19 minutes on the bike.
 
Tuesday: 5x5 squat, 3xheavy (3–5) bench, 3x10 pull ups, 2 sets on slant board, 2x10–12 cable row
 
Wednesday: Rest.
 
Thursday: 4x4 deadlift, 3x8 bench, 2 sets on slantboard, 2–3x12 dumbell curls, 2x10 overhead press
 
Friday: Cardio. Generally bike, but could be running.
 
Saturday: Rest or light cardio, as in maybe a 1.5 mile run if I feel like it.
 
Sunday: Work up to a heavy single on squat, then 2x3 backdown sets, Romanian deadlift as I feel like it, which could be none up to a 2x12, 3x12 bench, 3xAMRAP pull ups, 2x10–12 cable rows, 2x10 overhead press.
 
Weights are enough to be challenging but not 
too 
hard. I’ll also dial back the number of sets if I’m not feeling it. Sometimes life happens and I miss days, and I have to take it easy if I miss more than one in a row. I’m not in my 20s (or 30s) anymore.
 
Reasons: Squat, bench, and deadlift are to get good at squat, bench, and deadlift. I’m looking to get up to a three plate squat, 250 bench, and double body weight deadlift. Also general strength helps in daily life. Pull ups, RDLs, and overhead press are accessory movements to assist with bench and deadlift. Cable rows are to keep my bad shoulder from acting up. Curls are because, to quote Megan Gallagher, “Biceps make me feel pretty.” Ab work is because I get tested on sit-ups. Cardio is because I get tested on cardio and to keep my heart and lungs working right despite the other bad stuff I do to them.

Sunday: Shoulders/Arms.
 
For me, I genuinely enjoy training and my workouts are medium intensity for about an hour to an hour and a half each day. I take in roughly 3,000 calories per day and get 8 hours of sleep. The split that I use gives my muscles enough time to recover between workouts. When I start to feel a little bit of generalized fatigue and weakness (signs of over training) I just take a day off without changi
Continue Reading
I have been training seven days a week for the last three years.
 
My split is this:
 
Monday: Legs
 
Tuesday: Chest/Back
 
Wednesday: Shoulders/arms
 
Thursday: Legs
 
Friday: Chest
 
Saturday: Back
 
Sunday: Shoulders/Arms.
 
For me, I genuinely enjoy training and my workouts are medium intensity for about an hour to an hour and a half each day. I take in roughly 3,000 calories per day and get 8 hours of sleep. The split that I use gives my muscles enough time to recover between workouts. When I start to feel a little bit of generalized fatigue and weakness (signs of over training) I just take a day off without changing anything in my diet.
 
The VAST majority of the time that you hear people talk about over training, they aren’t really describing over training, they’re just describing being weak willed. Genuine over training IS a thing but it’s hard to get there unless you work out like a fiend and don’t eat/sleep enough.
 
That said, not everybody has the same goals or even the desire to be in the gym as much as me. This is totally understandable. So if you WANT to go to the gym seven days a week, go for it…get a split that makes sense and make sure you eat/sleep enough.
 
I also highly recommend a joint supplement if you’re going to train this much. I train with something called Texas Method where I alternate heavy weight days with hypertrophy (8–12 reps) days. A joint supplement is helpful to ward off some of the inflammation that comes naturally with weight lifting

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
The one who made my jaw drop is an old co-worker who asked nonchalantly, very loudly, to everyone in an open office: “Is there any difference between Vienna and Venice? Is one a country and the other a city?”
 
A long silence before anyone answered.
 
Her ignorance was even more confounding in the context of the many privileges in her childhood. Her father is a doctor at a prestigious teaching medical school. She grew up in one of the most affluent suburbs of America, attending the best public schools possible — you know, it’s one of those places where Chinese is taught in public schools. She went t
Continue Reading
The one who made my jaw drop is an old co-worker who asked nonchalantly, very loudly, to everyone in an open office: “Is there any difference between Vienna and Venice? Is one a country and the other a city?”
 
A long silence before anyone answered.
 
Her ignorance was even more confounding in the context of the many privileges in her childhood. Her father is a doctor at a prestigious teaching medical school. She grew up in one of the most affluent suburbs of America, attending the best public schools possible — you know, it’s one of those places where Chinese is taught in public schools. She went to college without a single debt.
 
And here’s the clincher — she had traveled extensively through Europe after college. She loved to recount how she had traveled for a few months, going from one city to another. It seems that at no point did she look at a map of Europe and consider the possibility of visiting Venice or Vienna, two of the most famous European cities.
 
Lastly, I would like to say how much I hated working with this co-worker and her proud ignorance. I worked in sales that frequently happened over the phone. Often, when I was on the phone with a client, she would eavesdrop (open office and she seemed to have the most amazing hearing — I suppose to make up for her other deficits), and she would shout out what she thought the answer should be. Of course, it never occurred to her that she was only hearing one side of the conversation and, therefore, her shouted answers were always wrong!

title: What is a good at home workout routine for intermediate beginners?
article:
There are 4 ways of shedding weight at home while maintaining an overall good health.
 
Freehand exercise:
 
You can practice freehand exercises or aerobics at home easily and you do not need to visit a gym for this. Just buy clothes and shoes that are suitable for aerobics, buy an aerobics DVD that comes with music and start exercising at home.
Yoga:
 
Yoga is an ancient holistic exercise system for the entire body as well as mind invented by ancient sages in India. Forget all the crash-dieting courses or impressive machines in gym; yoga is the real thing. While it will not help you shed weight directl
Continue Reading
There are 4 ways of shedding weight at home while maintaining an overall good health.
 
Freehand exercise:
 
You can practice freehand exercises or aerobics at home easily and you do not need to visit a gym for this. Just buy clothes and shoes that are suitable for aerobics, buy an aerobics DVD that comes with music and start exercising at home.
Yoga:
 
Yoga is an ancient holistic exercise system for the entire body as well as mind invented by ancient sages in India. Forget all the crash-dieting courses or impressive machines in gym; yoga is the real thing. While it will not help you shed weight directly, but will tone up your body and build your stamina to a remarkable extent.
Also, it makes your joints flexible and is able to keep various physical disorders (such as Arthritis) at bay. Research on yoga, buy a few books and DVDs and get started from tomorrow. The only thing you will require is an exercise mat.
 
Pilates:
 
Pilates is an exercise system that is influenced by yoga and is extremely beneficial for the muscles. It yields almost similar results as the yoga as Pilates also require you to hold a pose and control breathing like yoga. You can practise Pilates on an exercise mat or can buy a few Pilates devices.
Exercise machines:
 
You can purchase a machine such as a treadmill, rowing machine, or elliptical trainer for exercising at home while watching your favorite program on TV. This will provide you good cardiovascular exercises and will also enable you to lose weight fast.

There is a dearth of information available online to understand workouts/exercise and their outcomes, so go ahead and read them. Try to filter out what is just bro-science and what is factual instructions/explanations. Go to some reputed or popular websites like 
Bodybuilding.com - Huge Online Supplement Store & Fitness Community!
 yes its not just for meat heads. 
YouTube
 is another very resourceful option.
 
The next step, observe everyone working out, when I say everyone i mean someone who impresses you with their skills from what you learnt above. Try to breakdown each move into steps and understand how the body is moving as a whole.
 
Its now time to stop leaning and start practicing, start with what seems to be manageable volume/intensity never stress yourself in your early stage. Start to feel every muscle that you think/read should be working. Once you have started to feel the actual muscle/muscle group being impacted by your movement you are good to start engaging them.
 
Each of these steps keep repeating, because there are so many ways to workout/train & exercise that you will never stop learning. The most import thing to remember is “listen to your body” it know what not to do. Anything that is making you very uncomfortable even in the slightest of ways, stop it and consult some one you know understands it.
 
Enjoy your workouts and achieve what you have in mind for your body.

I thought I had commented on this but apparently it didn't post.
 
"Who was the most ignorant person you have ever met in America?" I prefer the term “Undereducated". Being undereducated isn't always a personal choice, but I can see examples of blissful egocentric ‘ignorance’ as detailed in some of the answers to this.
 
One trip my wife Susan and I made to Florida, we had a humorous run in with an innocent and untouched young lady whose education didn’t cover some things, but we are not sure what was exactly missed.
 
Somewhere between 2004–2007 (update: I found our map yesterday dated under Governor Ernie Fletcher) it was 2007:
 
Ernie Fletcher - Wikipedia [ https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ernie_Fletcher ]
 
My wife and I were traveling to Florida from Indiana. We stopped at a little roadside gas station on highway I65 going through Kentucky without any sign of a nearby town.
 
When we went in to buy a drink and a snack after filling up the tank, my wife - who was born and raised in England (and has a bit of accent left, even after being naturalized US citizen) had been living here in Indiana for more than 20 years. Her accent apparently caught the attention of the pretty young Kentucky lass, maybe about 16 or 17 years of age, who was managing the cash register.
 
“"Where y’all from” she asked with a beautiful smile. I replied we were from Indiana. She giggled slightly and said. “"No, I mean ‘originally’, (then looking at my wife to address her) she said: “because I heard your accent while the two of you were talking.”
 
Susan said “"well I've lived in Indiana since 1968, but I was born and raised in England.”
 
Immediately the young Kentucky flower opened her eyes wide ...

However, it's important to remember that the affordability of internet access can still vary widely depending on the country, region, and individual circumstances. Additionally, even with affordable internet access, economic disparities persist, and poverty can affect people's access to various resources, including the a
Continue Reading
Internet access has become more affordable and accessible in many parts of the world, including in regions with lower income levels. However, it's important to remember that the affordability of internet access can still vary widely depending on the country, region, and individual circumstances. While the cost of internet access has decreased in many places, there are still individuals who may face economic barriers to using the internet.
 
Additionally, even with affordable internet access, economic disparities persist, and poverty can affect people's access to various resources, including the ability to own or maintain devices like computers and smartphones, which are essential for accessing the internet. In some cases, people may have limited access to the internet due to economic constraints.
 
Therefore, it's entirely possible to find individuals from diverse economic backgrounds on platforms like Quora. People's participation on the internet is not solely determined by the cost of access; other factors like education, language proficiency, and awareness of online platforms also play a role in shaping internet usage patterns.
 
Quora, like other online platforms, aims to be a space where people from various backgrounds and experiences can ask questions, share knowledge, and engage in discussions, fostering a sense of inclusivity and diversity. It's important to recognize and respect the diversity of users and their unique circumstances when participating in online communities.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
“Who was the most ignorant person you have ever met in America?”
 
When I was an undergrad, I worked as a tutor for Mass Rehab 
Massachusetts Rehabilitation Commission
 
One of my students was a man in his late 20s, confined to a wheelchair. His fund of common knowledge was astoundingly impoverished.
 
He didn’t know what ocean we Bostonians live on, or the states that border Massachusetts. He didn’t know that there were other countries to the north or south of the United States. He could not distinguish between cities, states, and nations. He could not tell time or use the calendar. He didn’t know what
Continue Reading
“Who was the most ignorant person you have ever met in America?”
 
When I was an undergrad, I worked as a tutor for Mass Rehab 
Massachusetts Rehabilitation Commission
 
One of my students was a man in his late 20s, confined to a wheelchair. His fund of common knowledge was astoundingly impoverished.
 
He didn’t know what ocean we Bostonians live on, or the states that border Massachusetts. He didn’t know that there were other countries to the north or south of the United States. He could not distinguish between cities, states, and nations. He could not tell time or use the calendar. He didn’t know what a sign saying “10% off” meant. He did not know the relationship between the earth and the sun or the moon. He didn’t know what causes day or night. He didn’t know that rain comes from clouds. (He thought that killing a spider caused rain.) He didn’t know what the moon was. He couldn’t name the president or the mayor. (He did know that the Boston police were different from the Cambridge police, but he didn’t know why.) He could not add or subtract fluently. He could not multiply at all. He did not know that the world was a globe.
 
He had been a gangbanger as a young teen, so he effectively stopped paying attention in school around the age of 12. He stopped attending school around the age of 14. He was paralyzed by a bullet in a gang-related shooting at the age of 19. Whatever he had learned in school had evaporated during the 16 years since he stopped paying attention.

article:

Suddenly a loud but whiny voice pipes up with those weird Californian cadences… ‘Gee I didn’t know they had black guys in Britain!’

Another nasal valley girl, whispering… ‘D’ya see his friend? He looks Puerto Rican.’
 
Well I’m Jewish actually, but I do tan well even in the gloomy E
Continue Reading
One time me and my mate Steve went for a pint in a pub near Victoria station where people get off the train from Gatwick Airport, lots of newly arrived tourists getting their bearings and their first taste of proper beer.
 
Suddenly a loud but whiny voice pipes up with those weird Californian cadences… ‘Gee I didn’t know they had black guys in Britain!’
 
Me and Steve stop, and Steve examines the backs of his hands theatrically. Yup, he’s still Nigerian.
 
Another nasal valley girl, whispering… ‘D’ya see his friend? He looks Puerto Rican.’
 
Well I’m Jewish actually, but I do tan well even in the gloomy English summer…
 
We get a couple of pints in at the bar and sit down with the confused ladies.
 
Steve, putting on his best comedy Lagos wideboy accent, grins and says ‘Aha, I see you have noticed I am a man of colour! I am an Igbo! My tribe live by hunting elephant and repairing TVs. I do the TV repair bit…’
 
Well they didn’t get the sarcasm and the conversation kind of went downhill from there, with squeaked monosyllables from them and increasing quantities of good old British bullshit from us (in stupid accents) until they went to the loo and never came back.
 
A bit mean I know, but come on they had just flown to London, one of the most diverse cities on the planet, without a frickin’ clue what they were letting themselves in for. We did tell them to look us up in Brixton, I don’t know if they ventured there or how gobsmacked they would have been if they did.

Yes, there are poor people on Quora.
 
You use the word ' 
Very Cheap' 
interet to describe the availablity of it. Cheap is a relative term as it is best defined based in your income.
 
I am one of the poor people on Quora. I do not have access to the internet because it's cheap for me but rather because I forego certain things just to be able to have access to the internet. While most of my colleagues spend money on alcohol, I make sure I use it in data bundles. What's the reason for this? The reason is that I learnt at an early age from my poor yet wise grandparents,vwho raised me from age two when I lost parent, that knowledge is power.
 
I have have used the internet for the very good of me. I was fortunate to be able to live in Canada for one year as a volunteer . I have visited the USA. I could today be naturally poor but rich in knowledge and all thanks to the power of the internet that I would wish it was free for all especially in developing countries. If and when I have the funds, my desire is to take internet to rural Zambia where I come from so kids there may widen their knowledge base.
 
Through Quora, I learn every day. And I put the knowledge to good use by applying it in things that matter the most. So don't assume that all people that have access to the internet do so because it's cheap. There are those of us spend a good part of our wage on internet just so we can share with you our experiences on things that you would otherwise take for granted.

article:
The optimal time during the day for weight training may vary from person to person. The body needs to workout at a time when the mind and body are bound to perform at its best. 
 
If your tendency is to fall asleep in the early hours of the night and wake up fully refreshed in the morning then morning might be a good choice. 
 
On the other hand if your tendency Is to fall asleep later in the night, and get physically / mentally recharged slower in the morning, then working out in the evening would be the better alternative.

Continue Reading
The optimal time during the day for weight training may vary from person to person. The body needs to workout at a time when the mind and body are bound to perform at its best. 
 
If your tendency is to fall asleep in the early hours of the night and wake up fully refreshed in the morning then morning might be a good choice. 
 
On the other hand if your tendency Is to fall asleep later in the night, and get physically / mentally recharged slower in the morning, then working out in the evening would be the better alternative. 
 
Other points to consider:
Morning 
Testosterone levels are higher in the morning. Body temperature is lower.
Evening 
Coordination, stamina, body temperature, flexibility & Strength are at its peak in the evening
 
Personal Observations:
1. I've observed that whenever I worked out in the morning I grew leaner. Probably due to higher testosterone levels in the morning, in addition to the absence of food in the body which induced processing of fat for fuel. 
 
2. On the other hand whenever I worked out in the evenings I clearly felt stronger and could lift heavier, consequently I grew bulkier. 
 
3. Chances of getting unhindered access to exercise equipment in the mornings are higher. Most gyms are not overly crowded in the early hours of the morning as opposed being super crowded in the evenings. 
 
4. If you choose to finish your workout in the morning, there is an absence of stress anticipating your evening workout. 
 
Hope that helped.

title: Which 3 exercises would give me the most complete workout?
article:
Body weight only:
Pull ups. There are several variations; wide grip, narrow grip, vaulters (one overhand grip the other underhand). Remember good form! The number of reps isn’t as important as keeping great form. Also avoid ‘kipping’ The legs to help propel you up. Keep legs hanging straight. Finally try to do these e-centrically, as in explode up, then Descend for a slow three count to full arm extension. Lather rinse repeat.
Pushups. Also several variations. If you really want your forearms to explode try fingertip pushups with elevated feet. Hands beneath shoulders, palms off the floor and do
Continue Reading
Body weight only:
Pull ups. There are several variations; wide grip, narrow grip, vaulters (one overhand grip the other underhand). Remember good form! The number of reps isn’t as important as keeping great form. Also avoid ‘kipping’ The legs to help propel you up. Keep legs hanging straight. Finally try to do these e-centrically, as in explode up, then Descend for a slow three count to full arm extension. Lather rinse repeat.
Pushups. Also several variations. If you really want your forearms to explode try fingertip pushups with elevated feet. Hands beneath shoulders, palms off the floor and don’t let them touch. Balance weight across all fingers and thumb. Try for eccentric approach as well.
Handstand presses. Place hands on floor slightly wider than shoulders, about 6” away from the wall, facing the wall. Lock elbows. Kick one leg up so it touches the wall and you’re now upside down. Get the other leg up, though it can stay bent for balance. You should now be feeling it in your entire upper body. Lower your body by gradually bending elbows out, the push up and lock elbows. Lather rinse repeat. Be careful with this one!
I approach this grouping in one 60 minute session when traveling without gym facilities available, and it’s a ball buster. I use fingertip pull-ups on door jambs in hotel room, then fingertip pushups with feet on bed then handstand presses. Mix them up for a hypertrophic approach, crank up some German tekno deth metal and off you go!
 
Best of luck!

title: Can I do a light workout every day?
article:
It really all depends on your personal goals that you set for yourself. If your goal is to increase the muscle tone of your legs and general fitness, then training your legs everyday with lights would be doable.
 
However, if your goal is more ambitious- to increase leg size and definition- then daily leg workouts performed at a heavy weight would not be a good thing to do.
 
Whenever you're serious about your gains, especially when it comes to gaining size and strength, you must always take the progressive overload principle into account. It is an adaptation of Hans Selye’s General Adaptation Syndr
Continue Reading
It really all depends on your personal goals that you set for yourself. If your goal is to increase the muscle tone of your legs and general fitness, then training your legs everyday with lights would be doable.
 
However, if your goal is more ambitious- to increase leg size and definition- then daily leg workouts performed at a heavy weight would not be a good thing to do.
 
Whenever you're serious about your gains, especially when it comes to gaining size and strength, you must always take the progressive overload principle into account. It is an adaptation of Hans Selye’s General Adaptation Syndrome.
 
When you train with heavier weights, your muscles will incur more damage and consequently need more time to recover. And it’s only after the muscle recovers, does it begin to adapt and grow in size and strength.
 
If you perform heavy leg workouts every day, you deny the muscles a chance to recover. And when you deny recovery, you also deny the legs the potential to grow bigger. This is called overtraining.
 
The generally recommended rest period is 24 to 48 hours per muscle between workouts. I know when I used to be a powerlifter, and was squatting between 600 and 700 lbs drug-free, because of the heavy weights involved, There would be weeks when I needed a full week to recover.
 
For the average beginner, working your legs every day with heavy weights will likely result in overtraining. And this would be counterproductive to making strength and muscle gains.

I enquired whether he had just moved to Oregon and he said yes, but I

Once, I was driving from Vancouver, Canada to Reno, Nevada, in the USA. I stopped at a self serve gas station in a small town in Oregon state, to top up my tank. A young man about thirty something came up to me and I handed him Eighty Canadian dollars, The sale was Sixty four dollars. The man looked at me and said, “sorry, we don’t take foreign currencies”. He then looked at my car and asked me where Vancouver was, after seeing the licence plate. I offered my bank’s debit card, but that of course, was also a foreign product. I enquired whether he had just moved to Oregon and he said yes, but I grew up in Washington State.
 
Washington State is the one next to Vancouver, and it’s between Vancouver and Oregon. Yet, he never heard of a place called Vancouver. Any way, it was too early to get cash at the nearby bank, and could not get access to an ATM machine, so I asked him to take back his gas by syphoning it. Suddenly, another customer came in and he tried to explain that Canada is ALMOST like part of the USA , but the man was not convinced. The new customer asked whether I was on my way to Vancouver, and I replied “No, I was heading to Reno. “ He gave the gas attendant Sixty four dollars, then turned to me with a big smile and said, “see you 3.00pm at the Circus-circus Casino, partner. At 3.00 PM, I met Jim in the Casino, and handed him Sixty four dollars (in US currency) After (31) thirty one years Jim and I still meet up when I visit or pass through Oregon State.

I stayed a week in a Hyatt near Boston for work. The last couple of days there was a wedding there, so the hotel was full with family of the bride and groom, including an assortment of old ladies.
 
Since the breakfast buffett was slammed because the hotel was full, we all shared tables, so I got the chance to sit down with Bette, a lovely old lady from Oklahoma.
 
During that breakfast, the following things were said:
 
“So, where are you from? (Argentina) Is that in Mexico?”
 
I explain that no, that it’s a whole lot more south, below Brazil
 
“Oh, it’s all jungle over there, right?”
 
Well, no, it looks a lot like the midwest, to be honest. If I dropped you in La Pampa and told you you were in Kansas you may believe it.
 
“So, how did you get here???”
 
By plane.
 
“They have flights down there?” “What are you here for?”
 
Work, I work for a software company.
 
“Oh, so you lived in other countries and learned there, right?”
 
Because apparently the idea that we could have universities in lower mexico was too stunning, I tried to gently introduce the idea that I was born in a city founded in 1573, before the lost colony of Roanoke, and yes, we do have universities. And hospitals. And other things. And planes.
 
After about half an hour of this (and honestly, she was a 
lovely
 old lady, it was an awesome breakfast) she said goodbye with “You look almost white! Not like a mexican at all!”
 
I learned a lot about life in Tulsa in the 50s too, BTW.

I have met many people in the US who didn’t know things I consider basic knowledge. I also met a good few who didn’t understand why should they even be bothered with those things. And I also met a few who were genuinly curious and willing to learn. The one person who annoyed me beyond belief with his ignorance was a college student junior. All he wanted in life was to go to Irak and “kill those idiots over there”… He was the type who knew nothing about anything, but he was damn sure about it all.
 
Of course I had my fair share of “do you have TVs where you live”, “is Europe on the West Coast”, “what do you eat in your country”, and so on.
 
I also had a friend who likes skiing and has travelled to Switzerland a few times to ski, though he could not find it on a world map.
 
I worked at an amusement park, and at our housing we put up a great world map and everyone put a pin on their place of origin, so it was quite a colorful map… many american friends were awestruck how diverse Europe is despite being so “little” and how people didn’t live in huts and caves in Eastern Europe despite it mainly being post-communist countries.
 
The greatest finding of mine was that despite the fact that most people in the US are terrified of communism and they get instantly get a seizure when they hear the words “good” and “communist” in the same sentence actually very few of them could tell what it means, let alone be able to describe a political and economical system within it.

Despite his devastated health, condition still he is striving to feed us. Last year I got the job and recently resigned to it, just to be with him closely. He is highly self-respected person. He is not allowing me to take the responsibilities. So I joined as a School teacher in my locale. And preparing for GATE exam which was postponed as my father advised me to go for job, at that time he didn’t told me the reason.After resigning job I came to knew that last year he is almost on death bed, they hided this from me. To support my brothers education he told me to join the job just in case anything happens to him.
 
My father’s only entertainment, watching cricket; for which he has to go to relatives/ friends home.
 
My mother likes to watch movies and old songs; but adjusted with radio, gifted by neighbours (may be gifted is better word.)
 
Brother and me has to do the same.
 
It takes almost two yrs just to buy a small T.V. which is a common thing in most of the people.
 
I mentioned only one thing here. But many are there but they never gave me thought of I AM POOR, but recently when I struggled to find a place to give the freedom to my tears.
 
I don’t know whether my answer make any sense, so many things running in my mind. Almost spent 2 hrs but not able to put in words.

Yes. By many standards, I am poor. I am presently unemployed, despite two degrees, several certificates, and various diplomas, and whatever else regarding classes, courses, seminars, books, studies, research, and experience that I may have had, Pontiac Michigan is not an easy market for me. I was a paralegal, but this area is pretty flooded with paralegals. There are jobs here and there, but I can’t do fast food very well, therefore Dunkin Donuts lasted 4 days. So, I am paying rent on savings and sitting in my attic room, waiting for my ship to come in. So, when I hear people complain about “megachurches” making “millions” of dollars and how all people who’ve worked for a church are insanely rich, it pisses me off grandly. I worked for two churches and often gave bags of my own food to people, cutting myself short, and the church was sustained by a pastor who had a job in the electrical field, not by donations. Neither exist anymore, by the way. Because many people think that churches are welfare agencies and if they don’t get everything they demand, we are horrible hypocrites. Sometimes we just don’t have it, and are POOR, like the rest of you. Maybe we were oddballs in the church world, not demanding money nor promising that God will rain gold bars upon you if you give money to us. So I am back to looking for dishwashing and prep cook jobs. Something about demanding money “for God” that really turned my stomach. I don’t know; obviously it wasn’t my calling.

I am. Believe it or not, I am very poor and I am homeless. Luckily there is plenty of free WiFi here, otherwise I wouldn't feel so rich in knowledge and information.
 
When you are down, below poverty level, in the pits , in the actual streets, its difficult to pull yourself back up without help of some sort. Without a family structure or support network to throw you a safety line . You're pulled under, struggling to come up. Everyday, everything is a struggle. You lose people along the way, too. Its not their fault, society is taught to turn the other way. Although ,there are those people with great compassion for the suffering of humanity, and those people I view as a miracle .
 
The way I see it, I found myself here and I can just go back the way I came here if all else fails. I was just recently hired by UPS for seasonal help. It’s hard trying to get a shower before work so I take one the night before . I am lucky to find there is a hot water spout in the middle of the cemetery. The down side, it’s in the middle of the fucking cemetery. But , once its closed, the only people who are going to see me are dead and I will smell nice when I go to work.
 
I hold with me now only my work clothes and 1 set of sleep clothes and gave away all my other clothes to a girl who said all hers were stolen. I try not to share too much personal information so I don’t slip and let it out that I dont have a place to live right now(I am banking on being able to get one before anyone knows the difference.) I made a choice that no matter what, there isn't going to be any reason good enough why I can't work like people with a home do. (Oh, if they only knew)
 
The plain...

The case was: She was sitting with her bag next to her (on the chair besides her). A lady, around the same age as the American also arrived and did not find any place to sit. she politely asked the American Lady if she could keep her bag on the floor and vacate the chair if she does not have a companion along.
 
The impertinent American vary casually shrugged and told the Indian lady that she did not have a companion but wouldn’t keep her bag on the f
Continue Reading
I met an American lady on an Indian Airport, Delhi Airport to be precise. Just like everyone else, she was waiting for her flight of a hill station.
 
The case was: She was sitting with her bag next to her (on the chair besides her). A lady, around the same age as the American also arrived and did not find any place to sit. she politely asked the American Lady if she could keep her bag on the floor and vacate the chair if she does not have a companion along.
 
The impertinent American vary casually shrugged and told the Indian lady that she did not have a companion but wouldn’t keep her bag on the floor because it would get dirty.
 
The exasperated Indian lady, just stood their stunned and confused for a while. After a long period of waiting, the flight got delayed. The conversation was repeated as the Indian request again and the American denied.
 
By the time, the people sitting around seemed to be ready to intervene. Two of them even stood up and offered their own seats. But the Indian lady denied and turned to the American with a simple and perfect response,
 
“If you do not wish to dirty your bag, then you can take the floor and the bag can take your seat. But kindly, vacate the available seat since no one is using it.”
 
Everybody around us staring smiling, including a handful of foreigner sitting behind us.
 
I don’t believe all Americans are like that but people, irrespective of their nationality can be very rude (to put it politely) sometimes.

She told me that she was a devout “Christian”. One Saturday evening when I was doing laundry, she was
