As an exchange student in West Texas not too terribly long ago, I had the opportunity to meet many ignorant people. I’d have to say the most ignorant (and fascinating) one I met was a female college student who worked a part-time student job in the office of the dorm I was living in at the time. I would stop briefly to chat with her on occasion when stopping by the office to get change for the laundry or vending machines, or when I checked out a vacuum cleaner, picked up a package, and so on. She told me that she was a devout “Christian”. One Saturday evening when I was doing laundry, she was working her shift, and I stopped by to get change and shoot the breeze a bit. I don’t remember how it happened, but we somehow ended up discussing the issue of racial segregation. She had mentioned her opposition to interracial relationships between blacks and whites, and was explaining why she was opposed to such relationships (and that she wasn’t racist). Here comes the most profound ignorance I have ever experienced in America: what she told me was that god and jesus never intended for the races to mix because blacks and whites go to separate heavens when they die. So naturally, it only made perfect sense for them to be separated here on earth as well. That’s my “most ignorant person in America” story, and it is very true- this actually happened, and I believe now that there are many more Americans just like this woman who are just as ignorant, if not more ignorant.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?

One of the most common ones was “What’s your donkey’s name?” At first I thought they were kidding. I would usually reply with a fake laugh and tell them my donkey was their namesake. They were always baffled by the fact my donkey had an American name like Brian or Britney, rather than Pedro or Conchita. (I don’t own a donkey, but I’d love to.) My answer was never funny to them, which resulted in me re
Continue Reading
Back when I was a kid, I used to spend three weeks every summer in a Camp near Orlando, Florida. I’m Mexican, so the other American kids used to pose the strangest questions about life in Mexico. One of the most common ones was “What’s your donkey’s name?” At first I thought they were kidding. I would usually reply with a fake laugh and tell them my donkey was their namesake. They were always baffled by the fact my donkey had an American name like Brian or Britney, rather than Pedro or Conchita. (I don’t own a donkey, but I’d love to.) My answer was never funny to them, which resulted in me realizing they weren’t joking. I’m aware they were just kids, maybe ten or eleven years old, but ever since that happened, I began to think of Americans as very intelligent and civilized, but quite ignorant when it came to information regarding other countries, or sometimes even their own. For example, I once took a Business Cultures class in Berlin where all the students were Americans, except for me, and none of them knew what the highest mountain in the United States’ was, except for me, a Mexican. I acknowledge this reply could be interpreted as a generalization, which I think it is, because most of the smartest, decent and dedicated people I know are from the U.S., but I do think ignorance is one of the main reasons why a clown is currently working in the Oval Office. Also, we’re not much better off. A clown governs Mexico too, and ignorance is a main cause as well.

Make sure you get at least 7 hours of sleep everyday.
Never miss your breakfast.

Jogging

You can also install some applications that will help you to keep yourself keep on track.
 
Hope this helps.

So I had just recently moved to America and was at my first day of middle school. My homeroom teacher had asked two girls to help me find my locker.
 
On our way, they asked a bunch of questions.
 
1.) Do you speak Indian? (Facepalm….later that month dozens of people asked me the same thing)
 
2.) Why do you know English (omg person, you can't just ask someone why they know English)
 
Next we walked back to the class and had to say the American pledge when the morning announcements started. I told them that I didn't know the words. Response?
 
3.) Well the words are on the screen but OMG why don't you know the pledge ? Wow your country is really weird to not know the AMERICAN pledge.
 
Facepalm.
 
Later that day in class, I saw
 
1.) China being labelled Russia (and vice versa)
 
2.) Math teacher asking me if I know any math (since I come from a country no one has heard of)
 
3.) Tons of people asking 1 and 2 from above
 
4.) Heard Milky Way was a planet
 
5.) More weird map labelling
 
American people aren't all ignorant, just that all who are seemed to be accumulated at my middle school…
 
Edit: I'm in high school now. I was on the way back home from school in my bus when I heard this conversation:
 
Girl: You're brown so you're Jewish right?
 
Boy: No I'm not, I'm Indian.
 
Girl: How do you say 'young' in Jewish?
 
Boy: I don't know cause I don't speak Jewish. I'm Indian I told you.
 
These are juniors/seniors in high school.
 
Facepalm.

title: Is a morning gym workout better than an evening gym workout?
article:
My understanding is that a morning workout would be better. Here's why:
 
1) 
It gets you energised for the whole day
 - Getting the blood pumping in the morning is a great way to drive away the laziness and inertia from the night and get your day kick-started.
 
2) 
It primes your body to make the best use of the food eaten during the day
 - By getting your metabolism up in the morning, you prime your digestive system to make use of the fuel that it gets during the day, i.e. the food that you eat. 
 
3) 
It ensures that your metabolism stays up the whole day
 - You will likely end up burning more calories, 
Continue Reading
My understanding is that a morning workout would be better. Here's why:
 
1) 
It gets you energised for the whole day
 - Getting the blood pumping in the morning is a great way to drive away the laziness and inertia from the night and get your day kick-started.
 
2) 
It primes your body to make the best use of the food eaten during the day
 - By getting your metabolism up in the morning, you prime your digestive system to make use of the fuel that it gets during the day, i.e. the food that you eat. 
 
3) 
It ensures that your metabolism stays up the whole day
 - You will likely end up burning more calories, and hence fat, because a morning workout, followed by a day of  regular activity, keeps your metabolism going the entire day. 
 
When you exercise in the evening, the long hours of sleep that follow bring your metabolism back to the pre-exercise level by the time you wake up. 
 
Also, the ideal cycle is to fuel the body right after exercise - this ensures that the fuel is spent in getting the muscle glycogen back up and in repairing the damage to the muscle fibres. If you exercise late in the night and don't follow that with food, then that highly beneficial period is likely to be wasted.
 
That being said, if you can't consistently exercise in the morning, then evening exercise is a good way to go. It would be far more beneficial to consistently exercise in the evening than to do just 1-2 days in the morning and then let go of it.

Wow so many answers!
 
Well i will pitch in a bit. I am from \U0001f1f3\U0001f1ec Nigeria but I'm a resident in America.
 
For the past 9 years I have schooled, worked and partied with a lot of Americans. Till today people still ask me questions such as what mode of transportation I used to get here, how my English/diction is so good (we were a former British colony and even if we weren't I would learn the language before deciding to go and study in a foreign country) .
 
People have been genuinely surprised when I showed them a picture of what my childhood home looked like because it's wasn't constructed with mud and straws and it was bigger than the average house here.
 
People are shocked at how educated I am and have a hard time believing I am a member of my chosen profession.
 
When I was new here, these things irritated me when they occurred but now I just use it as an opportunity to educate people.
 
What I still don't understand today is the lack of curiosity of the outside world from many Americans. If I tell you I'm from Nigeria, I expect you to ask me a lot of questions about the life and culture over there. Instead what I get is the opposite.
 
I believe that regardless of your feelings towards a certain country you should always want to learn about foreign lands.
 
Americans are great but I wish more Americans were more knowledgeable about the world around us and not ask me if I ever killed an antelope for lunch as a kid haha.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
My answer is a little different than a lot of the answers on here. I want to tell you about a time in which I was made aware of how ignorant I was:
 
I spent 4 1/2 years in Sri Lanka, living just outside a very small town and working with people in a poor fishing village. My friend actually lived in the village but I lived a couple of miles away from it. We are both Americans. Because she lived in the village, she spent a lot of time with the families there and especially, the children. She got to know them very well and learned a lot about their lives. The village I lived in was better off finan
Continue Reading
My answer is a little different than a lot of the answers on here. I want to tell you about a time in which I was made aware of how ignorant I was:
 
I spent 4 1/2 years in Sri Lanka, living just outside a very small town and working with people in a poor fishing village. My friend actually lived in the village but I lived a couple of miles away from it. We are both Americans. Because she lived in the village, she spent a lot of time with the families there and especially, the children. She got to know them very well and learned a lot about their lives. The village I lived in was better off financially than the one she lived in.
 
We decided to put on a drama with the kids. One day, we were rehearsing, and having trouble as usual because the children were not very disciplined and some really tried to get the best of us. We were rehearsing outside on the top of a small hill. They were not following us quickly when we called to them, and were jumping around and trying to tiptoe through the grass and rocks. I looked down and realized that they were all barefoot.
 
The facepalm moment: I asked my friend, “Why aren’t they wearing their shoes?” She said, “Most of them don't have any.”
 
A pair of flip-flop sandals could be bought for about 100 Rupees, or about 93 cents (American.) At that moment I came face to face with how ignorant I was about real poverty, the fact that these kids’ families couldn't even afford a $1 pair of shoes for their kids.

Change “American” for any other nationality and you will get some crazy stories. There are some really good ones posted here, ranging from innocent lack of knowledge to boorish behaviour.
 
I suggest there is no end to the stories that can be told about people being “ignorant”. Regardless of how you use the word ignorant, (uneducated , rude or stupid) 
some,
 not all
 
Americans, you encounter travelling in the US and abroad may or may not be ignorant.
 
I must say it is unfair to “ignorant” people all over the world to award Americans the “championship title” without considering how “ignorant” people in general can be, all over the world. You don't have to leave your hometown, to easily encounter both kindness and rudeness in public these days.
 
There is some truth to the idea that Americans can live their whole lives with no need to have any knowledge of the world outside the US but I dint think it is a uniquely American experience.
 
Travel and education are slowly creeping away from possible or affordable for the middle class or working class in most countries today. Jobs, wages and inflation will continue to exacerbate the issue of “ignorance” of the world beyond one's hometown, everywhere.
 
That is not an excuse to not find a library, read, go to school, research on the internet, learn a language or to be rude towards others different from you. An improved primary and lower school education with broader world scope would help.

Things for sure are changing, but the ones who can afford a smartphone, read/type in English, are definitely not poor (or among the poorest)
 
Poor is a relative term. But from my perspective, poor those form whom life means surviving just another day. They are around us, but they are invisible to our eyes because they’re such a commonplace.
 
The following will also take you less than 20 seconds to understand what “poor” really means, and why you can’t imagine them using Quora:
 
She has a million questions in her eyes she wants to ask you. Do you have any answers?
Finding answers in the heap of garbage.
If they were on Quora, the only question they could ask is: “
What did we do to deserve such a life?”
The thirst for knowledge comes only after the thirst for water is quenched.
A basket full of answers?
PS: 
I started writing this answer because I wanted to write a viral answer that’d get a lot of upvotes. But, while I was typing it out, I decided to go anonymous because I don’t want to use someone’s misfortune for a trivial thing like upvotes! Poverty depresses me. I don’t know what I can do to change this, but I think about it every single day. Hopefully, I’ll get a chance to help a few lives one day!
 
Just don’t close your eyes to these people, who because of no fault of their own, are way less privileged than you are. If you close your eyes, the politicians will never care about them either…so, do your bit, whatever you can!

The teacher was going over the basics of our country and offhandedly me

I’m going to go along with your theme of not knowing something about the USA, though I certainly have met people that were more ignorant than the one I will mention here.
 
It was 9th or 10th grade, I don’t remember which and honestly it shouldn’t make much of a difference to this story. We were in our geography class for people who suck at geography, as I do. Seriously, I am really dumb when it comes to geography, so the fact that this person was worse than me should be enough for this answer, but there is more to this story.
 
The teacher was going over the basics of our country and offhandedly mentioned that the line at the top of the USA was the 49th parallel. I then chimed in with “well that’s easy enough to remember since there’s 49 states below it”.
 
The girl behind me then says…. “wait… There are 51 states?”
 
The teacher looks over at her in disbelief. “I’m not even going to dignify that with an answer”
 
She looks at me so confused and, while I don’t remember the exact wording, she basically states that she thought there were 50, but Alaska and Hawaii are both at the top of the map, and 49 plus 2 is 51.
 
I retort back “Of course there are 51, didn’t you know Puerto Rico became a state just this year?”
 
She BELIEVES this. She is so confused, and the teacher looks utterly amused and then explains to this poor confused soul for about 5 minutes that Hawaii isn’t actually right next to Alaska, and no, Puerto Rico isn’t a state.

I've never been to the USA, but I did have a very cringeworthy encounter with an American couple in Paris.
 
This was in 2014. Two of my friends and I had decided to meet up in Paris for a reunion. Things were going great and we had loads to catch up on. We were three little Asian women gallivanting around Paris in the dead of winter, and it was glorious.
 
We decided to go to dinner one evening and stumbled upon a quaint bistro in one of Paris’ cobbled streets. It was cold, so we hurriedly went in.
 
The bistro was filled with people, but it was for the most part quiet, except for a VERY loud middle-aged couple who were sat by the window.
 
They were very open and gregarious. You could tell they weren't locals, because they were conversing in very loud English while trying to engage the scowling waiter in friendly conversation even though it was clear he couldn't understand much, if anything. Every so often you would hear their enthusiasm reverberating across the room.
 
“Oh, just look at this! We don't get this back in the States, do we, Julie?”
 
“Absolutely, The food is just wonderful. This was the best food we've had all week. I can't wait to recommend this place to all my friends! How long have you been working here?” the woman exclaimed, directing the last question at the increasingly bemused waiter.
 
Eventually, we were given the table directly adjacent to this American couple. After a short while, we noticed the couple smiling at our direction. We must have immediately caught their attention because we were the only ones in the entire bistro speaking English.
 
Then the American lady turned towards my friend and remar...

article:

After he walked away, I said, incredulously to a fellow sergeant, “ Can you believe that shit?” Damned if one of the Soldiers didn’t try to defend him: “ Well, maybe he didn’t knooow, not everybody knooows EVERYTHING…” After bestowing a little corrective behavior on Miss Corporal Defender of the Ignorant , I then had to explain to this group of Soldiers that a) Indeed the State of Rhode Island and Providence Plantations is a state, AND was also one of the original thirteen colonies

I once overheard an Army lieutenant tell a group of Soldiers that “Rhode Island is not a state, it’s an island”. After he walked away, I said, incredulously to a fellow sergeant, “ Can you believe that shit?” Damned if one of the Soldiers didn’t try to defend him: “ Well, maybe he didn’t knooow, not everybody knooows EVERYTHING…” After bestowing a little corrective behavior on Miss Corporal Defender of the Ignorant , I then had to explain to this group of Soldiers that a) Indeed the State of Rhode Island and Providence Plantations is a state, AND was also one of the original thirteen colonies plus b) The lieutenant, as an Army Officer, is required to have a college degree. Therefore, at a minimum, he should know the damn states he is sworn to defend!
 
I don’t know who I would consider more ignorant, the lieutenant or the corporal.
 
Something I was ignorant of until later: Rhode Island was the first colony to break allegiance with England.
 
On a lighter note: As I was looking at maple syrup in the downtown Portland, OR Whole Foods one fine rainy day (and lamenting the price!), a model-gorgeous woman came and stood next to me. After a couple of minutes, she turned and asked me “How do you know if maple syrup is organic?” I could NOT help myself, I turned to her and sweetly said “Oh, it comes from free- range trees!” She smiled and thanked me. There were two guys peeping at her from the end of the aisle, and they just about died laughing…

BTW the word ignorant simply means lack of knowledge.
 
I worked with a woman who was taught only by using only specific text books, movies and so on that were written or made by her narrow-minded, very strict church.
 
Her belief system included nothing that is taught in the regular school system and did not teach math past the addition and subtraction level as all other math was a lie. Any and all information otherwise taught in the regular texts books was written by the devil. They even have their own version of the bible which I found frightening. So much blood and death. Anything good was replaced by something bad.
 
When their daughter was 17, she had the SAT and other state required tests to take. She had not learned most of the necessary knowledge to pass any of them.
 
Plus this was her first exposure to the outsider and “normal” people. She knew nothing that the others knew as her education was so strictly regulated. When tested by the school system, her knowledge of standard information was that of a very young child. Although in her school she was considered an A+ student.
 
She was unable to be admitted to college and but somehow managed to befriend a neighbor outside of her faith who helped her get her GED.
 
She ran away from home and lived a “normal” and continued her education. She has just received her license as a physicians assistant.
 
Thank you Andreas Schwab for the edits, guess I'll have to proofread better.

This lady loved her technology. She’d buy every new Macbook and iPad that came out, had about five different cameras including a DSLR and several Go-Pros with attachments. She also bought her one year old son three hundred, yes, 
three hundred 
present for his first Christmas! She’d also been given a car for her birthday, drove a scooter here in Australia

The most ignorant American I've met lived on the same floor of the dorm as I did when I was doing my undergraduate degree. She was a Texan who’d been living in Missouri and her parents were computer programmers who bred tropical fish as a hobby.
 
This lady loved her technology. She’d buy every new Macbook and iPad that came out, had about five different cameras including a DSLR and several Go-Pros with attachments. She also bought her one year old son three hundred, yes, 
three hundred 
present for his first Christmas! She’d also been given a car for her birthday, drove a scooter here in Australia, and had several other cars in her garage back home.
 
She came to me one day complaining how unfair life was because she couldn't get a scholarship even though she was poor because her parents made too much money.
 
Now, my family sponsors several children in poverished areas around the world and I've had the huge privilege to be able to visit two of them who lived in slums in Thailand. I've seen abject poverty with my own eyes and have been close to it myself, having at times had only a few dollars to my name.
 
Her complaint, therefore, absolutely floored me. I told her so, straight to her face and her only argument was that she has the right to have nice things and she has the right to spoil her son if she wants.
 
I still boggle over that incident even seven years later. It's the sheerest, completest ignorance I've ever encountered.

She looked at him with utter confusio

Oh, this person was the ultimate in ignorance: Around 1986, my writing partner (Also named Steve) had a roommate, “Joan”. She was a nice person, but completely ignorant about how the world worked.
 
First Joan story: Steve had mentioned to her that he was going to take some soda cans to the recycling center (this was before the city picked up recycling curbside), and asked her if she had any. She brought in several overflowing bags of cans from her car and left them in the kitchen. Later that night, she came home to find Steve crushing the cans with his feet. She looked at him with utter confusion and said, “Why’d I give ’em to you if you were gonna ruin ‘em!?”
 
Second Joan story: The Prince’s Trust is a charity established by Prince Charles. In 1986, the trust held the “Prince’s Trust All-Star Rock Concert” in Wembley Arena, to celebrate its 10-year anniversary. Joan was watching this concert on TV, and after watching nearly the whole show, says: “I don’t get it — when is Prince gonna perform?!”
 
Third Joan story: Joan decided to take a clay sculpting class at a community college. One night she arrives home from her class, carrying what appears to be a large, unsculpted hunk of clay, and inquires, “I don’t know if my teacher really likes my work!” Steve: “What was your assignment?” Joan: “We were supposed to do a self-portrait in clay.” Steve: “What did your teacher say?” Joan: “I’m not sure — do you know where Easter Island is?”

Yes i was. But not anymore because I have a good phone now and can afford data pack for JIO. It was before bought this phone. At the time I was using a Nokia 501 model with a damaged screen.The phone was given by my sister because I had a very basic Nokia model.
I hardly recharged rupees 10 for a month. At the time I was using Aircel, and Aircel has an offer worth RS.27 where it gives 125 MB valid for 28 days. I used to manage to recharge the data pack and used the data only for Quora (and sometimes WhatsApp).
 
I used to load all the answers and disabled the data pack so that it wont use unnecessary data. I read all the answers and reloaded it again and switched off the data. But the data doesn't last for more than 20 days. So whenever I got a chance (like friends hotspot or public wifi), I loaded the data and read the answers, but that can't happen all the time.
 
So I got an idea and sent a feedback mail to Quora.
 
The content of the mail was:
 
“Dear Quora admins,
 
I dont have internet connection all time so please make quora as an offline application like twitter so that people like us will get benefit and can use this app.”
 
And I hope one day we can use this app in offline mode and people like me a can use that.
 
But I forgot about it after using jio. So the same thought goes for the quora admins who can afford data pack 24/7.
 
Please quora make this app as offline for the people who can not afford data pack.
 
#peace

Let me tell you my story......My father is a farmer. Till my 10th standard I was not mature enough to understand my parents' hardwork. After that I stayed in hostel in Hyderabad for my Intermediate. And by god's grace I got free seat in one of the top 10 engineering Colleges in Hyderabad. Then I moved to another hostel at Uppal in Hyderabad. I chose that hostel so that my father would pay the less amount of rent(Rs.3000/- per month, which is the minimum amount of rent in that area). I teach home tuitions for two hours in the evening after returning from the college to support my father somewhat financially. Now, due to corona I am not doing that and I came to my hometown. These days, I came to know how hard my father works daily to lead our family. He always tries his best to provide us with all we want. I am happy to say that I am blessed with lovable parents and supportive sibling. I feel rich to have them.
 
I am going to enter into the final year of my bachelors very soon. I wish I could get placed in one of the reputed companies and overcome our poverty and make my parents happy.
And ofcourse I could use this platform since I could get internet for cheap. Thanks to Ambani

article:
Anyone is ignorant about what they don’t know.
 
Yet many Americans are ignorant about what they DO know:
 
Their fellow Americans.
This is ignorance on a level and a scale rarely encountered in Modernity.
 
It implies a lack of imagination to grasp that their way is not the only way; they fail to appreciate nor understand difference.
 
Are they blinded by ideology? Probably. Are they blinded by ideology because they fear that they are at risk of losing the linchpins of their identity (their totem poles). Again, probably.
 
For example, losing their totem poles to Science, Globalisation, Modernity and the dea
Continue Reading
Anyone is ignorant about what they don’t know.
 
Yet many Americans are ignorant about what they DO know:
 
Their fellow Americans.
This is ignorance on a level and a scale rarely encountered in Modernity.
 
It implies a lack of imagination to grasp that their way is not the only way; they fail to appreciate nor understand difference.
 
Are they blinded by ideology? Probably. Are they blinded by ideology because they fear that they are at risk of losing the linchpins of their identity (their totem poles). Again, probably.
 
For example, losing their totem poles to Science, Globalisation, Modernity and the death of Tradition.
Many Americans equate liberalism with communism; such Americans believe America will be great again when Modernity is replaced with Tradition - 
their
 Tradition. Or they conflate their myths with incontestable history.
 
You could call that ignorant, or just uneducated. But that’s not the point:
 
Instead, it shows that Americans really are drowning in a mind numbing fear of losing their identity.
 
So much for just shy of half of all Americans.
So what about the other half?
 
This fear of losing identity is what the other half of Americans totally ignore about 
their
 fellow Americans.
 
So, in America, everyone is totally ignorant of everyone else.
 
And that is simply astonishing.
So, the most ignorant American I ever met?
 
Easy:
 
The whole bloody lot of them.
 
Think! Grasp! Understand!

1. They have a strong passport and a strong currency which does aide them in traveling around the world more easily than many others. You find American travelers everywhere, increasing the chance of encounters with their ignorance.
 
2. Their native language is English, widely recognized. They don’t have the advantage of switching into another language. If they sa
Continue Reading
While it has been quite entertaining to read these answers, I don’t think Americans on an average are really any less or more ignorant than the average person anywhere else in the world. I think there are some reasons why it may seem so:
 
1. They have a strong passport and a strong currency which does aide them in traveling around the world more easily than many others. You find American travelers everywhere, increasing the chance of encounters with their ignorance.
 
2. Their native language is English, widely recognized. They don’t have the advantage of switching into another language. If they say something stupid, most people will know it.
 
3. For the better or worse, US is a hot migrant destination. Making people from other parts of the world better places to spot their ignorance than the other way around.
 
4. Last but not the least I’d say that some of the ignorance does come from a certain arrogance that comes from believing in notions like “the greatest country in the world”.
 
And as though the impression wasn’t enough, they have chosen one of them to grace the White House to make it official.
 
P.S.: Btw, having recently moved here, I too have an ignorant American story.
 
So this happened in the early 2016. I had been here a couple of weeks. A white woman, a complete stranger, said to me, “Really, you’ve been here only five weeks? It doesn’t show!”
 
Her stereotyped Indian cemented my stereotyped American. :-)

title: How often should I workout for best results?
article:
Daily.
 
Current research says that about an hour each day is ideal. 4 to 5 days should be cardiovascular workouts. Depending on your health and fitness level this means running, jogging, walking, cycling, swimming, etc. Minimally two days (up to every other day) should include strength workouts. That includes weight lifting, body weight workouts, stretch bands, etc.
 
Four critical aspects to fitness are: cardio vascular health, strength (including maintaining muscle mass and bone density), flexibility, and balance. For this reason, I include yoga as well, usually 2 (minimally, usually more like 3)

Daily.
 
Current research says that about an hour each day is ideal. 4 to 5 days should be cardiovascular workouts. Depending on your health and fitness level this means running, jogging, walking, cycling, swimming, etc. Minimally two days (up to every other day) should include strength workouts. That includes weight lifting, body weight workouts, stretch bands, etc.
 
Four critical aspects to fitness are: cardio vascular health, strength (including maintaining muscle mass and bone density), flexibility, and balance. For this reason, I include yoga as well, usually 2 (minimally, usually more like 3) to 4 times per week.
 
For me, at 70, mostly retired (meaning some flexibility regarding time), this means:
A daily run 5 to 6 days per week. 3–5 short runs of minimally 3 miles, often 4 miles. One long run, by which I mean double digits (10 miles or more). One medium run of about 6–8 miles. I *try* to be consistent but do not always make it. For the past 15 years, I have averaged about 1500 miles per year.
Teaching or taking 3–5 yoga classes per week. I do not keep this up while traveling. I average about 125 yoga classes per year.
Strength workouts. I have been doing strength work, either body weight workouts or (more recently) lifting in the gym about 2 or 3 times per week.
Probably putting it all together I average 10 workouts of some sort each week. But mostly it is about having fun and feeling good. This stuff is my jam.

I live in the Central Valley of California about one hundred miles or so from the central coast.

Continue Reading
Well my most ignorant American encounter was actually in the United States.
 
I live in the Central Valley of California about one hundred miles or so from the central coast.
 
One week end my wife and I drove over to the small town of Cambria for the day. While in Cambria we decided to drive on Highway 1, the Pacific Coast Highway a little further North where there is an almost year round Elephant Seal colony on a beach near San Simeon and Hearst Castle.
 
Now this was in early September. The beaches at that time where still filled with Bull Elephant Seals, measuring about twenty feet around 6.1 metres in length and weighing in tons. Though they look like Jabba the Hut or giant slugs those critters can move at a pace that most humans get brathless running.
 
So we arrive at the parking lot over looking the beach, called a rookery when the seals are present.
 
The viewing area is on a cliff, only about one hundred feet (30 m.) high. This cliff is also topped with a wooden and chain link fence, so you can view through, but there are warning signs every few feet which include warnings about climbing down onto the beach below.
 
As my wife and I watched, a young family came along the fence, young man, young woman and a toddler as well as a baby in the womans arms.
 
There was a muttering between them, and the young man with camera climbed up and over the fence. On reaching the ground on the other side, the young woman passed the baby over to him along with a camera.
 
He then climbed down onto the beach with the baby to find one of the huge Bull Elephant Seal so he could pose the baby for a “photo opportuni...

Continue Reading
I recently went to a play, a major theme of which was racial inequality.
 
After the show, there was a talkback with the cast.
 
The facilitator of the talkback asked the audience if they had any questions or comments about the show.
 
An older woman raised her hand.
 
“When I was growing up, we called ’em ‘negroes’. We used to have one who cleaned our house. I tried to teach her French, but she didn’t want to learn. That was their problem. They didn’t want to learn anything.”
 
The facilitator paused, and one of the cast members raised his hand.
 
“When my grandmother was growing up, she was a black maid for a white family. She spent her entire life being told she wasn’t worth enough to teach and that learning was a waste of her time. She was told that what she said didn’t matter. Why would she want to learn? She didn’t think anyone should waste their time teaching her.
 
“I’m not saying that means your experience is invalid, but there are different perspectives. We should talk about all of them. Thank you for your comment.”
 
The woman in that audience may have been near the top of the list of the most ignorant people. But because the facilitator and the cast didn’t shoot her down or berate her, she had a chance to learn.
 
After the talkback, she told the facilitator:
 
“Thank you for doing this show. It was great.”
 
Hopefully that woman left that theatre a little more aware than she came in.

title: What is the best workout for me?
article:
That's kinda like asking what's the best car to own. Depends. If you want something really fast and sporty, a corvette. If you want to haul material and tow a boat, a pick up truck. If you want a reliable car that'll always get you to work on time, a Honda accord.
 
Most people don't know specifically what they want, fitness wise, they just want to be “better.” Slimmer, stronger, more energetic and less pained. They want the Honda Accord body.
 
Which means a routine that has cardio, strength and mobility. Emphasis should be on cardio, since it's longer to build and quicker to lose. Try for three 30
Continue Reading
That's kinda like asking what's the best car to own. Depends. If you want something really fast and sporty, a corvette. If you want to haul material and tow a boat, a pick up truck. If you want a reliable car that'll always get you to work on time, a Honda accord.
 
Most people don't know specifically what they want, fitness wise, they just want to be “better.” Slimmer, stronger, more energetic and less pained. They want the Honda Accord body.
 
Which means a routine that has cardio, strength and mobility. Emphasis should be on cardio, since it's longer to build and quicker to lose. Try for three 30 minute cardio sessions a week. Running, biking, swimming, whatever gets your heart rate up. If you can't go 30 minutes, slow down until you can.
 
Supplement this with strength and mobility exercises, either after the cardio or a different day. If you have access to weights, then stick with the major lifts: bench press, squat, deadlift, overhead press, lat pull down. If you don't, then use bodyweight exercises: push ups, pull ups, squats, planks and glute bridges. Finish up with stretches for mobility. Yoga is good for this too.
 
Once you know more about fitness and your body, you might decide you want the pick up truck body (weightlifters) the sprinter body (sports car) the long distance body (hybrid) or the obstacle course body (jeep). All are worthy goals, but if you're not sure, then start with the Accord.

title: What is the best workout routine to follow?
article:
Hi,
 
to build muscles is better to lift on every muscle group at least two time a week. Research reveals that when you train a body part, protein synthesis remains elevated generally no longer than 48 hours. In most cases it is elevated approximately 36 hours, after which time it returns back to a baseline level. So, if you use a body part split, you are repairing and rebuilding for up to 2 days, and giving that muscle 5 days off each week. Though this will build muscle, it won't lead to optimal muscle growth rates.
 
Instead of bombing a muscle group each day with endless volume, you are better of
Continue Reading
Hi,
 
to build muscles is better to lift on every muscle group at least two time a week. Research reveals that when you train a body part, protein synthesis remains elevated generally no longer than 48 hours. In most cases it is elevated approximately 36 hours, after which time it returns back to a baseline level. So, if you use a body part split, you are repairing and rebuilding for up to 2 days, and giving that muscle 5 days off each week. Though this will build muscle, it won't lead to optimal muscle growth rates.
 
Instead of bombing a muscle group each day with endless volume, you are better off targeting muscle groups several times per week with a smaller amount of volume per day. By training a muscle group 2-3x per week with a more moderate volume, you will experience a greater degree of weekly protein synthesis per muscle group, and as a result, more optimal gains.
 
If you want to build muscle as rapidly as possible, consider switching to a full body workout. By targeting each muscle group 3 times per week, you will keep protein synthesis levels higher, on the average, which will lead to more optimal gains.
 
For intermediate lifters who have already built a quality amount of strength, training on an upper/lower or push/pull/legs split might be a better option. Heavy weight can take it's toll on joints and connective tissue, so a few extra days of rest per week might be beneficial
 
Greets,
 
Joel

Not in America, but I had an American exchange student visiting me in Germany when we were in high school. It was his first time abroad. Let's call him Jack. 
There is a lot of fruit-growing in my home region, mainly apples, pears and grapes. 
There are also frequent summer storms, with occasional hail. The hail would destroy the fruit. So, whenever such a storm approaches, the farmers shoot chemicals into the air to melt the hail. 
When we went for a walk with Jack, precisely such a storm was approaching. And of course chemicals were shot into the storm, using little rockets. Those rockets, well, sound like rockets too. 
This was the year 2003, one day after the USA had invaded Iraq. Jack's father was in the National Guard. He was much closer to actual weapons than I was. 
Upon hearing the rockets, he started being uncomfortable and asked what that was. 
In a flash of wit, I proceeded to tell him that that was artillery. And then that the border skirmishes with Switzerland seemed to have broken out again, as happened every now and then. That WWII never ended in this region, that the border is not clearly defined, and that not many people heard about this overseas. That Germany and Switzerland are in a low-intensity war since decades. But that our boys would keep us safe. 
He went completely pale, but after one minute I couldn't keep it up any more, and burst out laughing. It was funny how easily he believed me.

I have to say I was shocked to say the least. And at that moment, I just wanted to beat the crap out of this kid. He was a tall, fat dude. Don't think that he was joking. Trust me, I can take a joke and make jokes about brown people including terrorist jokes. But he wasn't kidding. He said it with a totally straight face and I could tell he was trying to offend me.
 
I could have gotten in a fight with him but I chose not to. I thought about it and came to the conclusion that I was there representing my own country. If I did that, it wouldn't be a very good impression. But you know the reason I love America? A lot of students from my class spoke up and told the guy to shut up. Even the ones I wasn't friends with.
 
Later on, The guy got suspended for telling the teacher to fuck off and later got into a fight leading to his expulsion. I really hoped he'd turn out differently but well..
 
Ethan, if you ever realize your mistake and end up at this post, please know that I forgive you :)

article:

I do have a question for you though: do you even like running? or like yoga? and I won't ask about dancing, because everyone likes dancing, except liars. If you don't like running or yoga, then don't do them. For these same reason, if you don't like weight lifting then don't do it!
 
But, assuming you do enjoy and take pleasure in all of the above activities, it might be bes
Continue Reading
If you're trying to lose weight: diet is always the first priority. So get that on track and everything else will come into place.
 
as for exercise, I assume you are a beginner, so you have a lot of lee-way. Anything will work. 
 
I do have a question for you though: do you even like running? or like yoga? and I won't ask about dancing, because everyone likes dancing, except liars. If you don't like running or yoga, then don't do them. For these same reason, if you don't like weight lifting then don't do it!
 
But, assuming you do enjoy and take pleasure in all of the above activities, it might be best to just rotate them:
 
Day 1: Weights
 
Day 2: Run
 
Day3: Dance
 
Day 4: Yoga
 
Day 5: weights, etc. 
 
Take days off as needed. 
 
Tips: On weight days, lift heavy. Don't do high reps. When you lift heavy weights, you are forced to use good technique and pay attention. For this reason, heavier weights are safer. With light weights, people just mindlessly do reps and eventually develop elbow tendinitis or some other easily preventable condition. 
 
On run days, 
for best results
, don't just jog for 40 minutes straight. Do sprints, intervals, or do a stop-and-go-run where you go for a sprint, slow to a walk, and repeat over and over. Acceleration requires the most energy AND it will illicit a hormone response favorable to fat loss (weight loss is not all about calories!)
 
Hope that helps,
 
Nate

Find the weight that you can do 8 to 12 reps for 3 sets. Do as many chin ups as you can.

The most important thing is the mechanics on al
Continue Reading
The short answer is yes. However, it also depends on 2 things; Movement choice and intensity. There are 6 important movements; the Squat (bar on back), Deadlift, Press (standing, overhead barbell), Bench Press, Bent Barbell Row, and chin up (Hands facing towards you).
Find the weight that you can do 8 to 12 reps for 3 sets. Do as many chin ups as you can.
Increase weight by 5 lbs. on all exercises when you can do 13 on last set, except The Press, increase it by 2.5 lbs. Gains will be slow with only one day a week.
Rest 90 yo 120 seconds between sets.
The most important thing is the mechanics on all exercises. Pay a trusted trainer to help you master the mechanics. Also, if your older, invest in a belt.
Diet: Heavy on the protein the day of and after your training. Don’t skip the good fats. More carbs the day before and on training day. Figure out your daily calorie needs and stick to it.
Gains will be slow, but you will be very surprised at how your body responds. Stick with THESE basic movements. All other movements IN THE WORLD are merely variations of the first five movements. They are the only ones you really need. The chin is a variation of the barbell row. But it isolates the biceps, not a hugely important muscle, but today’s social standards seem to demand that they be trained in some form of isolation.
 
Remember, mechanics are the key. Perform them right to stay healthy and become strong.

My dad is an Uber driver, but my mum, who is jobless, always complains about how he doesn’t earn enough money, or doesn’t go to work often, but I can’t be angry with him as he is our only money source, so at least he does work.
 
I struggle to live in this home as of the black mould that is everywhere in this damn house. I find it so disgusting but we simply don’t have enough money to fix it. That’s why I’m so embarrassed to have friends over. Another thing, which is not related to being poor but I just want to rant, is that I’m not allowed to go out with my friends, so I’m always stuck in the house. And then my mum complains that I’m always on my phone but there isn’t anything for me to do! Most of the time I’m just stuck at home crying secretly looking at all my friends having fun on there outings. This is also why I self-harm. But anyways back on to the topic.
 
My two sisters and I share a room, but our room is the size of a box, meaning that everything is squished together and it is hard for all of us to study (my oldest sister is in uni but still lives at home, and my other sister is in year 13).
 
I just hate living here and honestly would like to die but I’m told scared :)

I worked at a service station in Anchorage Alaska. My boss was a very nice man and would help a guy if he felt he needed it. Well we pumped gas. We do some other small things like fix tires or perhaps change oil.
 
New employee. You could tell he wasn’t real sharp by talking to him. But it was the evening rush as people was getting off work. He would bring the money from a customer and he would stand in front of the cash register in a frozen state. I would politely wait… ‘How much was it dude?’ He would tell me so I would get the money and punch it in. This was before computers. This register is like a calculator. I would show him. I would type in 5 0 0 gas cash. I would tell him ‘five dollars gas cash, ok?’ and he would nod his head. But next transaction he would be standing there in front of the cash register froze. ‘How much?’ And ‘OK 7 dollars gas cash’ and this went on and on and finally he got kind of upset and told me ‘don’t go over my head man’ which left me froze in front of the register picking my jaw off the floor. I spent the entire night doing my job and half of his. I think he was there a week until the boss scooted him away.
 
Later that first night he told me he would drink the air freshener Lysol. 
Lysol
 is made out of 
ethanol
 alcohol so he was a severe alcoholic. Yeah he was pretty much brain dead. Untrainable and nearly impossible to work with. Beyond ignorance. Poor guy.

Hi, I am a certified personal trainer and here are my two cents on this :-
 
Honestly there are a ton of programs online which will suit your purpose, just Google “
bodyweight exercises for home workouts
” or something along those lines and you'll be good
.
 
However what I've noticed is that the general population tends to miss out on the essential parts of a well structured workout routine for example :-
 
1.) Mobility Drills and Stretching to achieve and increase R. O. K for movements and to minimize the risk of injuries
 
2.)Correct execution of the form which when done improperly, can either cause unnecessary aches and pains or injure you
 
(Ex: - back rounding in squats, heels rising up, Having a anterior/posterior tilt in your hips due to tight surrounding muscles)
 
Hence I would recommend virtual online training which fits your budget from reputable sources... It's not 100% compulsory, but think of it this way -
 
if you are willing to give 1–2 hours a day to your body, wouldn't you want it to function optimally and give it the proper care it needs rather than teaching it improper movement patterns and risking 100% avoidable harm?
 
For those interested in some high quality virtual training at a budget friendly price (9.99£) check out 
FIT live 
and sign using my link to get access to the daily live workouts I perform (teaching everything from scratch) :-
 
Fit.live/arya

It’s incredibly expensive for me.
 
For last twenty years I have been surfing web, reading and most importantly and religiously… watching movies, TV shows and other programs. I cannot imagine of living without Internet. That would be a torture, that would kill me inside.
 
Yes, sometimes It feels like I’m being selfish, spending so much for just my own contentment but I do manage by squeezing other expenses like skipping meals at work, walking on foot to work instead of taking cabs, never buying new clothes, shoes for myself etc. In short, I sort it out enthusiastically.
 
At work, I have made friends with folks running a pharmacy nearby and were kind enough to share their wifi password with me, It’s all good!
 
Troubling thing is… that I have started considering to get the Netflix subscription, as I’m tired of watching movies on those malware and ads ridden websites.
 
But first….
 
Gotta figure the next squeeze point. \o/

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
I’m American and have lived in more than 30 different places in 8 US states before moving to China, so I’ve met and worked with far more people than the average person, and thus have met far more ignorant people than most. Now, it’s true that everyone is ignorant (i.e. lacking knowledge) about some things, but when it comes to public education in the US we all learn certain basic math, US history and geography, basic science, etc. I have indeed met one person that didn’t know what year the Declaration of Independence was signed, and another who argued with me that there are NOT 50 states in th
Continue Reading
I’m American and have lived in more than 30 different places in 8 US states before moving to China, so I’ve met and worked with far more people than the average person, and thus have met far more ignorant people than most. Now, it’s true that everyone is ignorant (i.e. lacking knowledge) about some things, but when it comes to public education in the US we all learn certain basic math, US history and geography, basic science, etc. I have indeed met one person that didn’t know what year the Declaration of Independence was signed, and another who argued with me that there are NOT 50 states in the US, because Alaska and Hawaii didn’t count. But I met one person some years ago, while working in a fast-growing franchise specializing in gourmet subs and sandwiches that shall remain nameless, who is without a doubt THE most ignorant person I ever met in my 57 years on this Earth.
 
Now, this young man (22 at the time) was a high school graduate, but while taking a phone order, he had to use a calculator to add the cost of two sandwiches, $5.50 and $4.50.
 
On one occasion he mentioned he was a vegetarian, and while discussing various plant sources of protein he stated that he gets most of his protein from fish and chicken. Somewhat confused, I said “Didn’t you say you’re a vegetarian?” He replied “Yes, but fish and chicken aren’t meat, just beef and pork.”
 
I repeat, he was a high school graduate.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
The most ignorant person I’ve ever met is, strangely, also one of the most intelligent and well-educated people I’ve ever met. He was one of my college fraternity brothers. We both joined in the spring of freshman year, and as juniors he and I were the fraternity’s president and VP, respectively. Now when I tell you this guy is intelligent, I’m not kidding around. He got excellent grades while double majoring with a heavy course load every semester. He scored over 170 on the LSAT and went on to graduate from Columbia law. Yet despite his impressive intellect and education, he is obscenely igno
Continue Reading
The most ignorant person I’ve ever met is, strangely, also one of the most intelligent and well-educated people I’ve ever met. He was one of my college fraternity brothers. We both joined in the spring of freshman year, and as juniors he and I were the fraternity’s president and VP, respectively. Now when I tell you this guy is intelligent, I’m not kidding around. He got excellent grades while double majoring with a heavy course load every semester. He scored over 170 on the LSAT and went on to graduate from Columbia law. Yet despite his impressive intellect and education, he is obscenely ignorant, and unfortunately, I think his supremely high intelligence made him that way. He’s one of only a select few people I’ve ever personally known that I would concede to being more intelligent than myself, and I think he’s the kind of person who’s so smart and so accustomed to being correct that he has lost any ability to maintain an open mind and overcome confirmation bias. He automatically dismisses any opinion he disagrees with as bullshit. Politically he’s a right-wing extremist who’s oblivious to his own extremism and genuinely believes all American liberal ideas to be idiotic nonsense. He lacks any ability to see outside his extremely-narrow worldview. It’s a shame that someone with such an excellent mind can be so hopelessly self-absorbed that they don’t see any errors in their own thinking.

title: What is a good workout routine at home?
article:
A great home workout you can do is called PLP. I would suggest doing this every other day instead of everyday.
 
P - Pushup - As you progress you can start experimenting with different types; Feet up on a bench, diamond, clap, etc.
 
L - Lunges - As you progress you can start adding weight. If you have dumbbells you can hold them in your hands. If you don't have dumbbells just pick-up heavy stuff with handles (4L milk jug filled with water, rocks or sand)
 
P - Pull-ups - You can get a pull-up bar that goes across a door frame for relatively cheap at Walmart. The bar will usually have different handles
Continue Reading
A great home workout you can do is called PLP. I would suggest doing this every other day instead of everyday.
 
P - Pushup - As you progress you can start experimenting with different types; Feet up on a bench, diamond, clap, etc.
 
L - Lunges - As you progress you can start adding weight. If you have dumbbells you can hold them in your hands. If you don't have dumbbells just pick-up heavy stuff with handles (4L milk jug filled with water, rocks or sand)
 
P - Pull-ups - You can get a pull-up bar that goes across a door frame for relatively cheap at Walmart. The bar will usually have different handles so you are able to switch between chin-ups, pull-ups and neutral grip pull-ups.
 
Example Rep scheme: Try adding 1 additional rep every time you do this workout.
 
Pull-up - 10 reps
Reverse lunge with no additional weight - 10 reps with each leg
Push-up - 10 reps
 
If you can only do 3 pull-ups at a time break it up. Do 2 pull-ups and rest for 30–60 seconds and repeat until you get to the desired number.
 
Once you start getting into the 30 rep per exercise area change up the exercises and start back at 10.
 
These three exercises are a good place to get started when doing a workout at home. They work most of the primary muscle groups and will give you a good base strength.
 
Here is an article that goes more in-depth :)
 
https://www.t-nation.com/training/plp-the-60-day-challenge

title: What is the best workout routine to follow?
article:
There is no one "best" workout routine that is right for everyone, as the best workout routine will depend on a variety of factors such as your fitness goals, your current level of fitness, any injuries or medical conditions you may have, and your personal preferences.
 
To find the best workout routine for you, it may be helpful to consider the following:
Set specific fitness goals: Determine what you hope to achieve through your workout routine, such as losing weight, building muscle, or improving your cardiovascular fitness. This will help you to focus your efforts and choose exercises that are
Continue Reading
There is no one "best" workout routine that is right for everyone, as the best workout routine will depend on a variety of factors such as your fitness goals, your current level of fitness, any injuries or medical conditions you may have, and your personal preferences.
 
To find the best workout routine for you, it may be helpful to consider the following:
Set specific fitness goals: Determine what you hope to achieve through your workout routine, such as losing weight, building muscle, or improving your cardiovascular fitness. This will help you to focus your efforts and choose exercises that are most appropriate for your goals.
Consult with a fitness professional: A personal trainer or exercise physiologist can help you to develop a workout routine that is tailored to your specific needs and goals.
Take into account your current fitness level: Choose exercises that are appropriate for your current fitness level, and be sure to start slowly and gradually increase the intensity and difficulty of your workouts as you become more fit.
Mix up your routine: To avoid boredom and plateaus, try to vary your workouts and incorporate a variety of different exercises and activities. This can help to keep you motivated and challenge your body in new ways.
Ultimately, the best workout routine is one that is safe, effective, and enjoyable for you, and that helps you to achieve your fitness goals.

article:
Just before my fifteenth birthday, while on holiday, I became ill. My mother took me to the ER at a hospital in Joliet, Illinois. When dealing with payment, the clerk asked my mother about insurance. My mother produced a card that said that my father was a British diplomat at the UK Mission to the UN in New York and that the UK government would indemnify any member of the family for any medical expenses incurred in the US. The clerk looked at the card and said, “I've not heard of this insurance company before!” She then proceeded to phone someone and it was one of those occasions when one coul

Just before my fifteenth birthday, while on holiday, I became ill. My mother took me to the ER at a hospital in Joliet, Illinois. When dealing with payment, the clerk asked my mother about insurance. My mother produced a card that said that my father was a British diplomat at the UK Mission to the UN in New York and that the UK government would indemnify any member of the family for any medical expenses incurred in the US. The clerk looked at the card and said, “I've not heard of this insurance company before!” She then proceeded to phone someone and it was one of those occasions when one could hear what was being said by the person at the other end.
 
The conversation went something like this:
 
Clerk: 
I have this card and it says the patient is indemnified against medical costs by the United Kingdom. I've not heard of this insurance company. Can you help me with it?
 
Woman at other end of the line: 
You know what Canada is? It’s another country. So is the UK. The UK is the country from which the Original Thirteen Colonies won independence.
 
Clerk: 
Oh, thank you!
 
Despite being in a lot of pain (I had pleurisy), I listened to this conversation in total disbelief. I simply couldn't believe that anyone couldn't understand and accept what was written on that card, particularly someone whose job it was to read insurance documents and understand what was and wasn’t covered.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:

I used to work in the drawing office of a large steel mill which was doing some major upgrades, and the contractors were from an American company. My main job was taking care of the tens of thousands of drawings and making prints of them when necessary. There were some serious problems with the new installations and so the American CEO turned up to try to get it all sorted out.
 
One morning my boss came into my office with the CEO and asked me to print some of the drawings, which I did. When I came back, the CEO

The person I am talking about was an American though he was in Australia at the time.
 
I used to work in the drawing office of a large steel mill which was doing some major upgrades, and the contractors were from an American company. My main job was taking care of the tens of thousands of drawings and making prints of them when necessary. There were some serious problems with the new installations and so the American CEO turned up to try to get it all sorted out.
 
One morning my boss came into my office with the CEO and asked me to print some of the drawings, which I did. When I came back, the CEO was parked in MY chair at MY desk. I stood there waiting for them to leave so I could continue with my work. There was literally nothing I could do until the CEO moved out of my workspace.
 
The CEO looked at me and then at my boss and said “Why isn’t she working? Isn’t there something she should be doing?” (So far this guy had not said a word to me, not even a distant “Good morning”). My boss said there wasn’t actually anything I could do just at that moment. CEO gives me another dirty look and says, “Get rid of her then!”
 
Now for all I know this guy might have been able recite the whole declaration of independence, name every state and state capital, and known the whole of the constitution by heart. But one thing he was definitely ignorant about was plain good manners.

Yes, because “poor” is a relative term. Unless you define it. And it has been defined by the good folks sitting in big buildings with free parking for their cars.
 
If you earn less than $60 bucks a month, you’re below the poverty line. If you earn more than $60 per month, you are ABOVE the poverty line.
 
People who earn less than $60 a month, they are not on Quora.
 
So no, “poor” as per definition, are not on Quora.
 
Less than 3.5 Billion are connected to the Internet in one form or the other. That leaves almost as much who are NOT connected to the Internet. So generally speaking, it is will be unwise to assume that poor people are using the Internet, using Quora etc.
 
Being poor is and will remain a relative concept… a person who is showing us a wardrobe and a TV and a phone is NOT poorer than a few people I know who earn less than $80 bucks a month (here in Pakistan), and then have four kids to feed. And when you would ask that person if things are tough, he may first praise God for giving him so much, and then relate an incident or two of people poorer than him, people who are on “automatic fasting” because they dont have access to food.
 
So even if there are poorer people on Quora, they are still on Quora and were blessed enough to speak and understand English and have access to the Internet. Most people don’t. And possibly won’t for years to come.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
In 2006, my wife Jenn and I were on a Mediterranean cruise. One of our ports of call was Athens. On the bus ride from the ship to the Acropolis, we overheard the following conversation between two Americans (as best as I can recollect). The woman was from Texas, had a strong Southern drawl, was in her forties and had bleached blonde, big hair. The man was non-descript.
 
Texas Woman – Did you stay in Rome before boarding the ship?
 
Man – Yes, we did. We spent a couple of days there to see the sights. It was fantastic.
 
Texas – Did you see the Colosseum?
 
Man – Yes, it was unbelievable, just incredible.
Continue Reading
In 2006, my wife Jenn and I were on a Mediterranean cruise. One of our ports of call was Athens. On the bus ride from the ship to the Acropolis, we overheard the following conversation between two Americans (as best as I can recollect). The woman was from Texas, had a strong Southern drawl, was in her forties and had bleached blonde, big hair. The man was non-descript.
 
Texas Woman – Did you stay in Rome before boarding the ship?
 
Man – Yes, we did. We spent a couple of days there to see the sights. It was fantastic.
 
Texas – Did you see the Colosseum?
 
Man – Yes, it was unbelievable, just incredible. Did you go there?
 
Texas – Oh, no! I couldn’t go there! All I could think about were all of the Christians who died there. It’s a terrible place. All those poor martyrs for Jesus. I just wouldn’t feel comfortable going to such a place.
 
Incredulous, my wife and I just looked at each other. First of all, she's incorrect as almost every scholar of Ancient Rome or of Early Christianity has concluded that Christian martyrs were put to death at the Circus Maximus or other venues, not at the Colosseum. Even Christian authorities didn’t cite the Colosseum as a place of martyrdom until something like the 16th Century. Be that as it may, it astounded us that someone would pass up the chance to visit such an extraordinary place like the Colosseum for such a reason.

I have two…
 
The first one was a guy I used to work with, in his twenties, who had graduated high school and received an associates degree.
 
Guy: “I would walk with you to the other building, but I forgot my coat, and I don’t want to catch a cold”
 
Me: (after a few seconds of blank stare) “you do know that going outside when it’s cold is not how you catch a cold, right?”
 
Guy: “what?! then why would my mom have told me that?!”
 
About an hour later guy returned to my office and said, “you know, I’ve been doing some research on the internet, and you’re right. It says that colds are caused by viruses.” I just sat there nodding yes while pondering who had tied his shoes that morning.
 
The second one is actually a guy I grew up with, now he does have a reputation for not being the brightest star in the sky, but I would still expect him to grasp a concept such as this, especially with his dad being a pilot. I showed up to his house as he was about to sell his car, and the conversation went as such:
 
Him: “I just finished swapping the wheels out, I put the factory ones back on there”
 
Me: “oh, cool”
 
Him: “they were really heavy though, I didn’t take the air out of the tires before I took them off”
 
Me: (realizing where he was going with this) “would it have made them lighter if you did?”
 
Him: “well yeah, they each had 32 pounds of air in them!"

title: How long will it take to get big if doing full body workouts every day with heavy weights?

Sure, you can even put on muscle.
 
For years I overtrained, 2 sessions a day a one time. I then cut back on gym time and transferred my obsession to cycling. The best I ever got was after working in Slovakia for a few months, where I only trained at weekends. I returned to Thailand and subsequently won my 1st race back.
 
Well that turned out to be my only 1st place - although I still got the occasional podium after resuming overtraining.
 
I stopped racing and started back in the gym about 5 years ago. Every other day, I gradually improved but never got near to where I was before.
 
Almost 3 years ago I had a change of circumstances and now train at most 5 times a fortnight- and often only have time twice a week.
 
I can't squat shit anymore, or bench press nearly as much either but on curls I'm only about 10kg off my best- and my best was 25 years ago!
 
Dorian Yates famously said : “ If training 10 hours a day and eating dog shit was the way to be a winner, I'd have done it. As it is you need first to shock your muscles and then let them rebuild, this takes longer than 24 hours”. He won 6 back to back Mr Olympia titles.
 
So my 2 cents is : pretty fast, to get your heart rate up and moderately heavy is the way to go. I'm now 64 and maintaining as much muscle mass is no longer just for asthenics, it's Essential for a a mobile and healthy old age.

title: Can I do a mixed workout every day in the gym?
article:
A mixed workout is the best way of training for me, and it might as well be the same case for you. As someone who has been working for long hours during the day, it is not possible for me to hit the gym every day of the week (although I want to). I can afford to go for 4 days at max, no matter how much I love working out, I understand that prioritizing gym before my work is not a good option for me, personally. A mixed workout is the best way of training for me, and it might as well be the same case for you. As someone who has been working for long hours during the day, it is not possible for me to hit the gym every day of the week (although I want to). I can afford to go for 4 days at max, no matter how much I love working out, I understand that prioritizing gym before my work is not a good option for me, personally. This is why I try to cover my entire body during those 4 days.
At first, I struggled to find a workout split that would help me do all workouts in 4 days, but then I saw the push pull legs workout. I started following that, and the results were amazing. I even researched the whole mixed workout thing, and I understood that doing a mixed workout every day is better than the typical bro split, at least for me. You can easily target different muscles of your body and can focus more on compound lifts. These lifts help you burn more calories, build more muscle, and improve your strengths. Compound lifts also help you raise your testosterone levels, which is another advantage.
 
Not only does it saves time, but it also helps you target each muscle group in a short period of time. I have been following the mixed workout split for almost 3 years now, and I do not feel like going back to the same old bro split, as my body feels way better working out like this.

title: Which 3 exercises would give me the most complete workout?
article:
Most good exercises target multiple parts of the body. Instead of 3 per body part, I'll give you 6 per area plus 4 for the core (I mean... you want those Jesus abs don't you?)
 
Upper body: bench press, row, chin up/wide grip pull up or the relevant cable machine exercises if you can't get chinups/pullups right now, shoulder press/push press,
Lower body: squat, deadlift, lunge/step up, supine hip extension/split squat
Core: plank (60 s), side plank (45 s), plank with pull down (4x20), side plank with row (4x20)
 
Do a 4 workout split of these exercises (upper A, lower A, upper B, lower B). Always be
Continue Reading
Most good exercises target multiple parts of the body. Instead of 3 per body part, I'll give you 6 per area plus 4 for the core (I mean... you want those Jesus abs don't you?)
 
Upper body: bench press, row, chin up/wide grip pull up or the relevant cable machine exercises if you can't get chinups/pullups right now, shoulder press/push press,
Lower body: squat, deadlift, lunge/step up, supine hip extension/split squat
Core: plank (60 s), side plank (45 s), plank with pull down (4x20), side plank with row (4x20)
 
Do a 4 workout split of these exercises (upper A, lower A, upper B, lower B). Always be doing the first two exercises. Switch between the ones with the slash every other workout. Do one of the core exercises every work out. Since you're going for mass, do 5 sets of 5 reps except for the core exercises.
 
A few pro-tips:
1. Don't focus too much on your arms. Most compound exercises should cover your arms. You don't need to dedicate an entire section to just arms.
2. Avoid machines. As a rule of thumb, the only machines you want to use are the ones where you're pulling a cable.
3. Make sure you take the first two workouts easy so you can get your form down. Having bad form will break you.
4. Muscles are built in the kitchen, not the gym. If you're serious about putting on mass, you need to eat 4000-5000 calories a day, depending on your body type.

In the 1970s I was working in a large office in a major U.S. city. A file clerk approached me one morning. Our conversation went something like this:
 
She: Walt, can you help me?
 
Me: With what?
 
She: My glasses. I just got glasses for the first time but they are too strong.
 
Me: I don't know how I could help.
 
She: My mother and I tried to wash them with bleach, but that didn't help.
 
Me: Huh? Why would you wash them with bleach?
 
She: 
We were trying to wash some of the medicine out of them.
 
I don't know if she was the most ignorant person I've ever met but I always think of that conversation as the most ignorant I've ever had
 
Note 1: I've lived in the U.S. for most of my 70 years, but I've met ignorant people elsewhere. When living in London for a couple of years I was “impressed” by a young man who, after talking about how much he loved Ford cars, asked me if they had Fords in the United States!
 
Note 2: I recently read a biography of a man who, in his early 20’s, was at a formal dinner party and realized that he did not know how to butter his own bread because his mother had always done it for him! I was astounded by this level of ignorance but, to his credit, he was able to figure it out by watching how his dinner partners did it. The man was Paul Erdos, arguably the most influential mathematician of the 20th century.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
Over the course of my travels I've met a handful of American and other Western folk alike and all of them seem to have common misconceptions that blissfully scream stupidity. Here are a few snippets from the numerous conversations I've had with them. (In the Q&A format)
 
Q. Your from India? I heard you guys have cows walking around everywhere?
 
A. Cows do walk on the street now and then but in most big cities this is a rare sight.
Q. Your from India, you speak 'Indian' right?
 
A. ‘Facepalm moment’, oh man. A person from India is known as Indian. Similar to how an American is from America. In India we
Continue Reading
Over the course of my travels I've met a handful of American and other Western folk alike and all of them seem to have common misconceptions that blissfully scream stupidity. Here are a few snippets from the numerous conversations I've had with them. (In the Q&A format)
 
Q. Your from India? I heard you guys have cows walking around everywhere?
 
A. Cows do walk on the street now and then but in most big cities this is a rare sight.
Q. Your from India, you speak 'Indian' right?
 
A. ‘Facepalm moment’, oh man. A person from India is known as Indian. Similar to how an American is from America. In India we have a host of languages that we speak and I speak Kannada in particular.
Q. Do you guys have snake charmers and fortune tellers everywhere?
 
A. Sure, we're one big folk lore of a country! It's just a notion move on.
Q. Why do you guys use water and not toilet paper? Isn't it disgusting?
 
A. I think we believe in cleaning up our mess completely and not keep things hanging until further action is taken.
Q. You're from Indian, can you speak English?
 
A. Yes Einstein, does it look like I'm talking to you in Swahili.
It's awfully amusing to see the notions that many westerners have about India. I sometimes don't know if most these notions are due to ignorance or stupidity. I convince myself that it is ignorance but every now and then I'm proven wrong.

title: How to workout
article:
I start my day by doing some animal flow. Animal Flow is ground-based movement, made fun, challenging and effective.
 
It is a structured series of animal-style movements that can be linked together to form flows (similar to yoga). It's good for building mobility, strength and developing motor control (something many programs are missing).
 
What is Animal Flow?
 
Created by Mike Fitch, Animal Flow is a trademarked bodyweight program that’s centred largely around ground-based work. It features animal-style movements that encourage core stability and strength, joint strength, and body awareness — all wi
Continue Reading
I start my day by doing some animal flow. Animal Flow is ground-based movement, made fun, challenging and effective.
 
It is a structured series of animal-style movements that can be linked together to form flows (similar to yoga). It's good for building mobility, strength and developing motor control (something many programs are missing).
 
What is Animal Flow?
 
Created by Mike Fitch, Animal Flow is a trademarked bodyweight program that’s centred largely around ground-based work. It features animal-style movements that encourage core stability and strength, joint strength, and body awareness — all without any fitness equipment.
 
If yoga and Capoeira(a system of physical discipline and movement originating among Brazilian slaves, treated as a martial art and dance form) were to have a baby, it would look like animal flow. The idea behind animal flow is it develops mobility as well as power. This system is also designed to improve strength, power, flexibility, mobility, and coordination for all levels of fitness enthusiasts.
 
So, should you try it?
 
Sure, it’s a little bit intimidating at first, but it’s a cool and unique way of moving your body and it’s a really good workout.
 
For those still wary to try “just have fun and let go of any inhibitions you might have.”
 
It feels silly at the beginning, but everyone’s there for the same purpose.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
Ignorant is not an American only problem, when I lived in Greece, I met ignorant people from all over the world that came there on vacation. The Greeks though, are pretty well informed about most things.
 
Ignorant is not the same as stupid, stupid is also not an American only problem.
 
I did know a young US Navy Sailor, female, who sat down next to me at the base club. She asked me if I had heard the news, I said” that you were pregnant”, she said “yes”. My response was “yes I had heard that”, she responded “I don’t know how it happened” I responded “well, were you having sex” she said “yes, of co
