I am new to training for muscle gain but from all I have read there is no “best weekly workout routine.” You have to keep changing your routine about every 6 weeks to keep getting the benefit of increase in muscle. I started with a 5-week introduction to muscle building, This was and hour a day 3-days a week. I progressed onto another five week routine that was 4-days a week. After I complete this, I can do upper/lower, push/pull workouts. There are so many ready-made workouts, out there, I will probably do an upper/lower one after that. I have already picked out workouts after that for the next 36 weeks (3x12 week workouts of 4,5 and 6 times a week)
 
as 
RAPHAEL HOLMAN
 touches upon, diet is very important for any chance of muscle gain. You need the right balance of protein/carbs/low fat and try to stay away from sugar and empty calories like alcohol. You need to eat little and often, I always have packets of dried apricots/prunes/dates nearby and a packet of almonds. These help to reach your (at least) 5-a day fruit/veg and help me reach my daily protein target.
 
Supplements wise, I use Whey protein and Creatine. Along with multivitamins and omega tablets I take Zinc and Magnesium, I also kelp supplement along with prescribed medication for Hypothyroidism.

First, she was just staring at me. I let her be. My thoughts, she rarely sees an Asian except in nail saloon - a joke I often heard). Then she started calling her friends. And in between her conversations, I could hear her telling them ‘Oh my God, she has a p

2012. Was on a business trip to the States. Had a delayed flight in Michigan. Decided to do something productive, open up my laptop to finish some work. In between I was checking my Blackberry as well (yes, Blackberry was considered an ‘In thing’ during those years ) . Then came a young lady who sat next to me. She was probably in her 20. First, she was just staring at me. I let her be. My thoughts, she rarely sees an Asian except in nail saloon - a joke I often heard). Then she started calling her friends. And in between her conversations, I could hear her telling them ‘Oh my God, she has a phone . And a laptop . Oh my God’. At that point, I couldn't help but smile to myself. That was probably one of the most ignorant encounter I had so far. Yes, where I came from we don't live on trees despite some assumptions. We are normal human being just like you are. With the same quality of life you have, probably better of less but we are all equal. Btw, the aforementioned conversation came from a girl who has never traveled outside her home state & was about to head to Florida for the first time to see her dad. How do I know? Because she asked me afterward about my phone and in return an interesting conversation transpires. And now I am based here. God bless America.

title: What is the best workout routine to follow?
article:
The best workout routine depends on your individual goals, current fitness level, and personal preferences. Here are some general guidelines for an effective workout routine:
Aim for 3-5 days of exercise per week, with a mix of cardiovascular activity, strength training, and flexibility work.
For cardiovascular exercise, options include brisk walking, jogging, swimming, cycling, or using an elliptical machine. Aim for 150-300 minutes per week of moderate-intensity cardio.
Strength training 2-3 times per week, focusing on major muscle groups like the legs, back, chest, shoulders, and arms. You can
Continue Reading
The best workout routine depends on your individual goals, current fitness level, and personal preferences. Here are some general guidelines for an effective workout routine:
Aim for 3-5 days of exercise per week, with a mix of cardiovascular activity, strength training, and flexibility work.
For cardiovascular exercise, options include brisk walking, jogging, swimming, cycling, or using an elliptical machine. Aim for 150-300 minutes per week of moderate-intensity cardio.
Strength training 2-3 times per week, focusing on major muscle groups like the legs, back, chest, shoulders, and arms. You can use free weights, resistance bands, or bodyweight exercises.
Include 10-15 minutes of dynamic stretching and mobility work before workouts, and static stretching afterwards.
Progressive overload is key - gradually increase the intensity, duration, or weight over time to continually challenge your body.
Allow for rest and recovery days between sessions for the same muscle groups.
Consider your individual needs, such as any injuries or limitations, and adjust the routine accordingly.
The most important thing is finding a sustainable routine you enjoy that helps you work towards your fitness goals. Experiment to discover what works best for your body and lifestyle.

Right now I can’t afford the internet (it’s not amazingly cheap), luckily my neighbour is happy to let me use his internet otherwise I wouldn't be on Quora answering this question. Poor is relative. I am poor by my country’s standards and what I was used to. I am disabled and rely on benefits (after having worked all of my adult life as well as raising a family), I cannot afford luxuries, I often have to choose between paying a bill or buying decent food. Right now I can’t afford the internet (it’s not amazingly cheap), luckily my neighbour is happy to let me use his internet otherwise I wouldn't be on Quora answering this question. I never buy new clothes, they’re either given to me by family and friends or they come from charity shops. My diet is mostly cheap food, I bulk up on rice, lentils and pasta, while not unhealthy there isn’t much variety and its’ very boring. I don’t have a social life, partly due t my disability and partly due to not being able to afford one. I live in a tiny house which is in the middle of a slum area because I can’t afford anything else.
But…..if I compare my situation to some of the people who have answered then I am quite wealthy, or to many other people around the world. I do know that I will always have something to eat, I have the ability to heat my house and eat hot food. I have clothes, a bed and shoes, so while for a 1st world country I am poor compare that to many other countries and I am rich.

title: What is the best workout for me?
article:
Squat: First of all, you will never not want to be able to get up off the ground. When loaded and done properly, the squat will have positive effects on your quads, glutes, hams, abs, low back, lats, and upper back, as well as increasing stability and proper movement patterns in the knees, ankles and hips. Also who doesn't want a nice set of glutes?
Deadlift: You're literally picking something up off the ground. Again, not something you don't want to not be able to do. Deadlifts work all the muscles worked in the squat with more of an emphasis on the back muscles, plus traps and rotator cuff mu
Continue Reading
Squat: First of all, you will never not want to be able to get up off the ground. When loaded and done properly, the squat will have positive effects on your quads, glutes, hams, abs, low back, lats, and upper back, as well as increasing stability and proper movement patterns in the knees, ankles and hips. Also who doesn't want a nice set of glutes?
Deadlift: You're literally picking something up off the ground. Again, not something you don't want to not be able to do. Deadlifts work all the muscles worked in the squat with more of an emphasis on the back muscles, plus traps and rotator cuff muscles. Get a good deadlift and reduce chances of random back injuries. 
Bent Row: Many people have given an answer as a pressing movement. Although they do build a nice chest/shoulders, you're never really going to need to do a strict press in every day movements. Not only will the bent row improve your posture, but will also heavily tax your lats, low back, and abs. 
I've chosen these three because they're, in my opinion, the more important of the primal movement patterns to be done correctly. You will 
not
 be able to build a well rounded, show ready physique, but you can become much, much stronger in every day life and while doing the majority of every day tasks.

article:
I was in the Army in Germany for 7 years, then got out and stayed 8 more on my own as a civilian. One day, I’d finished pumping gas and went inside to pay. There was an American woman screaming at the guy behind the counter. Apparently, her gas bill was not an even number and she had to come up with an amount of pfennigs (pennies). She raised her voice and yelled at him “WELL IN AMERICA, WE KEEP A LITTLE BOWEL OF PENNIES ON THE COUNTER TO USE JUST FOR THAT!” I was soooo embarrassed. How ignorant. She was embarrassing herself and me. There were people waiting in line to pay. Finally, she storme
Continue Reading
I was in the Army in Germany for 7 years, then got out and stayed 8 more on my own as a civilian. One day, I’d finished pumping gas and went inside to pay. There was an American woman screaming at the guy behind the counter. Apparently, her gas bill was not an even number and she had to come up with an amount of pfennigs (pennies). She raised her voice and yelled at him “WELL IN AMERICA, WE KEEP A LITTLE BOWEL OF PENNIES ON THE COUNTER TO USE JUST FOR THAT!” I was soooo embarrassed. How ignorant. She was embarrassing herself and me. There were people waiting in line to pay. Finally, she stormed out. I would say she was an early forerunner of Karen.
 
Another time, I was sunbathing at the river in Wuerzburg. Now, I don’t know how it is now, but in the early 1980s, nudity was acceptable when a person was sunbathing…it was just the culture. Well, another pre-Karen, was yelling at two young women who were sun bathing nude…she was screaming at them, calling them hussies and shameless, and how dare they do that right out in public where kids could see and so on. Seriously, she was in the wrong and could have had the Polizei called on her for assaulting them. When you are in a different culture, that culture’s rules are what matters. Don’t be an embarrassing ass.

article:
I’ll share a story from my own childhood.
 
As context, I’ve always been a horndog, from childhood. Reportedly, as a two year old I used to wander away from my parents when we went to the mall to go chat up beautiful adult women, and only the really beautiful ones.
 
My dad used to constantly play a game with me where he’d pick two women, or female characters or whatever, and ask me who was hotter. Princess Leia vs. Xena, Rogue vs. Jean Grey, kind of stuff. Given the choice, I would always pick Jasmine, from Aladdin, or my mom, who really is quite pretty. My dad asked me to pick between Jasmine and

I’ll share a story from my own childhood.
 
As context, I’ve always been a horndog, from childhood. Reportedly, as a two year old I used to wander away from my parents when we went to the mall to go chat up beautiful adult women, and only the really beautiful ones.
 
My dad used to constantly play a game with me where he’d pick two women, or female characters or whatever, and ask me who was hotter. Princess Leia vs. Xena, Rogue vs. Jean Grey, kind of stuff. Given the choice, I would always pick Jasmine, from Aladdin, or my mom, who really is quite pretty. My dad asked me to pick between Jasmine and my mom once, and after a long period of time I sullenly responded, “Jasmine. And that hurts my feelings.”
 
Relevant part: So I was like four or five, and my dad asked me who was prettier, Storm or Rogue (from the X-Men), and I quickly responded “Oh, Storm is too dark to be pretty.”
So my parents stopped the car and called a member of our congregation, let’s call her Dominique, who is black and is a model, and said, “Hey Dominique, we got a problem. Can we come over?”
 
So I was punished for my childhood racist aesthetics by having to fawn over this ebony goddess while my parents chatted and hung out with her.
 
I have a thing for black girls to this day.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
My mother.
 
Our family is American. My mother was an alumna of Barnard/Colombia, read voraciously, was deeply and broadly knowledgeable about history, literature, politics, mythology, was an equestrian, spoke three languages, and was a teacher. Not ignorant, with one exception.
 
My father was a chemist, a 100% scientist, amateur astronomer, computer geek, total nerd.
 
One day the conversation turned to overpopulation, one of her political pet peeves. Dad said something about it being a problem because insufficient resources would lead to great suffering. Ma replied that if people did not slow down t
Continue Reading
My mother.
 
Our family is American. My mother was an alumna of Barnard/Colombia, read voraciously, was deeply and broadly knowledgeable about history, literature, politics, mythology, was an equestrian, spoke three languages, and was a teacher. Not ignorant, with one exception.
 
My father was a chemist, a 100% scientist, amateur astronomer, computer geek, total nerd.
 
One day the conversation turned to overpopulation, one of her political pet peeves. Dad said something about it being a problem because insufficient resources would lead to great suffering. Ma replied that if people did not slow down their birth rates, so many babies would accumulate that it would make the Earth so heavy it would crash into the sun.
 
Dad and I laughed; good one, Ma.
 
But she was serious. After a stunned pause, we tried explaining that babies are comprised of materials already on Earth, so a new baby was a rearrangement of existing material, not new mass. We tried every argument we could think of, but her mind was made up. It was astonishing that she could be married to a scientist for 43 years and not understand basic physics, nor that her political beliefs did not overrule scientific laws.
 
People don't believe it when I tell this story, but it's true.

title: How to workout
article:
Start small!
 
Begin by doing just 5 pushups a day. If you can’t do pushups, do a plank for 10–30 seconds, depending on your starting strength.
 
Then, when you feel unchallenged by this, do 5 pushups/10 -30 sec plank and 5 squat jumps or maybe 10 pushups/30–60 sec plank.
 
Then, start incorporating other exercises in small increments and/or increase the repetitions of your current exercises.
 
Start holding weights while you do squats and lunges. Learn how to do more dynamic plank exercises.
 
Do this over many months and keeping working towards heavier weights or more reps (don’t overdo the reps though - t
Continue Reading
Start small!
 
Begin by doing just 5 pushups a day. If you can’t do pushups, do a plank for 10–30 seconds, depending on your starting strength.
 
Then, when you feel unchallenged by this, do 5 pushups/10 -30 sec plank and 5 squat jumps or maybe 10 pushups/30–60 sec plank.
 
Then, start incorporating other exercises in small increments and/or increase the repetitions of your current exercises.
 
Start holding weights while you do squats and lunges. Learn how to do more dynamic plank exercises.
 
Do this over many months and keeping working towards heavier weights or more reps (don’t overdo the reps though - that can lead to repetitive strain injuries).
 
If you feel tired one day, just do 5 pushups or a plank or whatever you started at. By giving yourself an opportunity to ease into it on your tired days, you may surprise yourself by pushing a little farther just because you feel warmed up and motivated by your resolve. Give yourself opportunities to succeed and exceed your own expectations!
 
That’s how you can exercise every day, without fail. Keep building out and switching up your workouts and, even if you are injured, you will have something you can do every single day, even if only for a minute or two with your own body weight.

article:

. Lifting weights is also helpful in improving your core strength, increasing your upper body strength, thus improving the amount of power you can generate with your arms. Naturally, of course, working your lower body can increase the power and speed that your legs will generate.

There are tons of 
benefits to running
, especial
Continue Reading

How Real Runners Train on Treadmills
If you're trying to be a runner it is.
Even then going to the gym is helpful. Some marathon runners improve their times by training on the treadmill (thus in the gym)
[1]
. Lifting weights is also helpful in improving your core strength, increasing your upper body strength, thus improving the amount of power you can generate with your arms. Naturally, of course, working your lower body can increase the power and speed that your legs will generate.
 
Lest I forget to mention, it's not good to do ANY intense activity day in and out. Rest days are essential.
 
There are tons of 
benefits to running
, especially high to moderate intensity  running. There are also tons of 
benefits to resistance training
.
 
Resistance training can take far less time to get the same benefits as running.
 
Let me lay this out there. Fitness isn't a binary process. There isn't a single best method to get you optimal benefits. Running (or some other form of moderate to high intensity cardio) AND hitting the gym is the best under all circumstances.  The proportions of how you do them and what how you particularly approach each activity depends on your goals.

How Real Runners Train on Treadmills

This sort of training will produce a lean athletic body with terrific mobility and heart and lungs conditioning. It agrees with my standards of fitness.

This was a great feed and prompted my first response on Quora. I believe the question is an over-generalization. Obviously we are all going to have areas of ignorance in our lives based on our experiences and the experiences we have yet to have. To pinpoint America as the most ignorant nation is not fair or accurate. Are there some dumb fucks in America, God yes! But America is also one of the most innovative countries in the world. Because we are taught to be individualistic we are more capable of innovation( opinion). To answer the question though, I will piggyback off some similar responses. I am the most ignorant person I know. I say this because as I grow older and evolve my viewpoints on most things have changed. Most things aren’t black and white but merely black, white and shades of gray. I am capable of seeing why some people would benefit from one set of beliefs where other ideologies are right for different individuals. For me I now understand that I will never be able to completely become shake my ignorance. My beliefs are shaped by my experiences and what I have learned, whether it is right or wrong. There is just not enough time in the day for me to learn about chemical engineering, astronomy, or whose dick is in Kim K’s butt today.

title: How should my weekly gym workout be?
article:
Time to jump right in. I'd up it to 45 fast walk/slow jog 5 times a week plus 3 lifts. Your lifts should focus on high reps (15-20 per set) in a circuit fashion. This means choosing multiple exercises and doing a set from each all in a row, resting, and going through the "circuit" again. Choose five exercises and go through it 3 times. 
 
As the weeks go by, you can add in more times through, or another circuit after it.  There are a few advantages to circuit training. It saves time. You'll burn tons of calories. You'll push your lactate threshold, which will stimulate lots of growth hormone rele
Continue Reading
Time to jump right in. I'd up it to 45 fast walk/slow jog 5 times a week plus 3 lifts. Your lifts should focus on high reps (15-20 per set) in a circuit fashion. This means choosing multiple exercises and doing a set from each all in a row, resting, and going through the "circuit" again. Choose five exercises and go through it 3 times. 
 
As the weeks go by, you can add in more times through, or another circuit after it.  There are a few advantages to circuit training. It saves time. You'll burn tons of calories. You'll push your lactate threshold, which will stimulate lots of growth hormone release. This is esp important for women. They do not have as much testosterone, but actually secrete higher growth hormone than men. Growth hormone will allow you to build a tighter/leaner physique. 
 
Since diet is 80% of any fitness goal, I'd stick to lean protein + veggies 5 times a day. Drink plenty of water in between meals. Have a refeed, carb heavy meal for one of your meals every 4th or 5th day. This will keep your fat burning hormones charged. And remember, it's not about finding time, but making time. The president trains 45 mins a day 6 times a week, and he's the busiest man alive. So you have some time, so make it a priority if its important.

Healthy Veggies for a Perfect Sandwich:
 
-Spinach or Kale: Packed with iron, vitamins, and antioxidants for a nutritious boost.
 
-Avocado: Provides healthy fats and a creamy texture, making your sandwich rich and satisfying.
 
-Cucumber: Adds a refreshing crunch and hydration to the mix.
 
-Bell Peppers: Offer a sweet and vitamin-rich punch, perfect for a flavorful addition.

Seasonal Veggies (Varies by Season and Location):-

-Summer: Grilled zucchini or eggplant offers a smoky flavor, ideal for warm weather.
 
-Fall: Roasted butternut squash or pumpkin provides a sweet, nutty element to enjoy.
 
-Winter: Caramelized onions or sautéed mushrooms add warmth and depth to the sandwich.
 
Optional Add-Ons:
 
-A dollop of curd (yogurt) or Greek yogurt for a tangy creaminess, a favorite addition for many, including me!
 
-A sprinkle of seeds like chia or sunflower for added crunch and nutrients.
 
This combination of healthy veggies, seasonal produce, and creamy curd makes for a nutrient-dense, flavorful, and satisfying sandwich tailored to any season! 🥗✨
 
Hope It Helps....

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
Relative ignorance or absolute ignorance? If relative, then it is impossible to say, since the coefficient of ignorance varies with time; consequently, I might have judged a very ignorant person as the most ignorant person ever once upon a time in America, but I may have misapplied the coefficient of ignorance by virtue of the prior/previous coefficient remaining “static” in my mind for many decades. I can not obviate this conundrum because the question is worded such “you have 
ever
 met” and at minimum presupposes the judger as constant of mind which is both contradictory and paradoxically tru

Relative ignorance or absolute ignorance? If relative, then it is impossible to say, since the coefficient of ignorance varies with time; consequently, I might have judged a very ignorant person as the most ignorant person ever once upon a time in America, but I may have misapplied the coefficient of ignorance by virtue of the prior/previous coefficient remaining “static” in my mind for many decades. I can not obviate this conundrum because the question is worded such “you have 
ever
 met” and at minimum presupposes the judger as constant of mind which is both contradictory and paradoxically true.
 
I suppose if I went around with the 
a priori 
intention of i) meeting people and ii) judging the absolute or relative ignorance of everyone I met, then iii) entered the data into Stata all the while with no biases 
whatsoever
 then I would have a meaningful answer. This too I fear would give rise to a scenario that is neither real nor possible. as to presuppose I could judge without bias would render my own ignorance equal to zero and my relative ignorance would become entirely irrational to the point I would never have possessed of the ability to judge in the first instance, since I would know everything and be God and the singularity and so on.

title: How workout exercises?
article:
In old school body building routines they used basic movements, nothing fancy. Reg Park's 5x5 routine was literally just back squat, deadlift, and bench press and variations of the theme.
 
It's a myth that people get strong and gain muscle by doing lots of exercises. You need to force your muscles to grow: lift big, heavy weights, in basic movements, and get a nice pump.
 
If you're just starting out, then doing close push-ups and weighted push-ups might help you gain a little muscle, but eventually you'll have to do heavy movements like presses, deadlifts, and squats.. 
 
If you are just starting out
Continue Reading
In old school body building routines they used basic movements, nothing fancy. Reg Park's 5x5 routine was literally just back squat, deadlift, and bench press and variations of the theme.
 
It's a myth that people get strong and gain muscle by doing lots of exercises. You need to force your muscles to grow: lift big, heavy weights, in basic movements, and get a nice pump.
 
If you're just starting out, then doing close push-ups and weighted push-ups might help you gain a little muscle, but eventually you'll have to do heavy movements like presses, deadlifts, and squats.. 
 
If you are just starting out, I suggest you stick to 2-3 compound exercises per workout. rotate between the basics: squat (back or front), deadlift, cleans (if you can do them), a press (overhead, bench, dips), rows. Do pull-ups and some kind of ab work like hanging leg raises or vacuums ever day.
 
Doing few exercises and working really hard on them will give you far better results than doing 3 exercises per muscle group
 
It is possible to overwork a muscle group, but over training is over-worried-about. I work out my back, grip, and legs every single day. Your body will adapt to whatever you throw at it as long as you sleep, and eat well. 
 
Good luck!
 
Nate

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
Ignorance is relative, subjective, and tilts towards intolerance based on personal disposition.
 
I know more than my brother does about building a backyard deck; I have done it, he hasn’t. I also know about replacing a vehicle’s radiator, having done so, while my wife is ignorant of this know-how. That I manage my own stock portfolio puts me at a different knowledge advantage than a dear old friend of mine who makes a livelihood skillfully dissecting turkeys for packaging, a skill I lack.

Continue Reading
Ignorance is relative, subjective, and tilts towards intolerance based on personal disposition.
 
I know more than my brother does about building a backyard deck; I have done it, he hasn’t. I also know about replacing a vehicle’s radiator, having done so, while my wife is ignorant of this know-how. That I manage my own stock portfolio puts me at a different knowledge advantage than a dear old friend of mine who makes a livelihood skillfully dissecting turkeys for packaging, a skill I lack.
 
These people in my life can easily point out a thing or two at which I’m hopelessly inept, making me perhaps the most ignorant person at whatever their particular level of aptitude. But they are tolerant enough to not condemn me for falling short of their quantity of knowledge. I, too, am tolerant of their so-called ineptitude. And I resolve to be always tolerant of everyone in and outside of this great country, well aware that our America, one of the most livable places in our world, is home to some of the most able humans, each of whom may know or are adept at something that lifts them above being denigrated as knowing nothing.
 
Pointing out the most ignorant person among us? How full of self, unenlightened. How condescending. How dare you.

article:

I ordered some food at a Del Taco. The total came up to random amount, and I offered some bills and seven cents so I’d get a quarter back instead of pennies. “You can’t do that!” Okay, I understand that you can’t count change, but the machine does it for you.
 
I work emergency medicine. At this one place the treatment areas are big open rooms and the patients are lined up against the walls. They can see everything that’s going on if the curtains are open. They’re coding someone in the corner. Chest compressions (CPR), a team at work trying to save someone who is dying. Serious stuff. A man on the opposite wall, guarding his nose from an apparent injury, says “I wish they were paying that much attention to me”. I assumed that someone punched him for being an idiot. In this business you don’t want to be the first one to be seen. (And in this business the idiocy is constant.)
 
A woman is acting up. She’s surrounded by staff getting ready to put her down. “I’m a street pharmacist, I take care of my babies!” I replied “if you’re a pharmacist then you know what Haldol is” and I gave it to her in her IV. Haldol is an antipsychotic med that knocks you out. You’ll wake up, having pissed yourself, with a new attitude.
 
I could go on and on.

The three best exercises in my opinion that would give the most complete workout would also be the easiest to do without a gym membership. You could do two them right after reading this answer right where you are the following:
Push-ups:
 Muscles targeted are your pectorals and triceps. You can change the difficulty while performing them either on your knees or with widening or bring in your hand positioning to hit more effectively your chest if it’s a wider stance or triceps if it’s a closer stance.
Pull-ups:
 Muscles targeted are your back and biceps. You’d have to buy a pull up bar but those run relatively cheap ranging from $15–30 from most local stores. Again many different grips to choose from to workout more effectively your biceps or back. If unable to do one you could use a chair to get too the top of the pull up position and try to lower your weight as slowly as possible with your legs spotting you. Eventually you’ll be able to do one on your own!
Bodyweight Squats:
 Muscles targeted are your legs. Pre-dominately your quads. Performed to parallel or deeper will give a angle of benefits fro overall leg development and for the more advanced you could perform one leg squats or hold weights in each hand while performing them.

In a Bar, I had an opportunity to have a conversation with a girl in her early 20’s. I found her particularly attractive who said was training to be a massage therapists.
 
When asked where I’m from, I asked her to take a guess. She said “Europe”. Surprisingly!!!! I was taken aback. No way in the world, I would look like an European.
 
I said to give her another try. Then, came “Africa”, which is also impossible.
 
I gave a clue “ASIA”.
 
But she was like… What ssss ASIA.
 
I said “Continent”.
 
She responded, are you from “THE CONTINENT” ?.
 
I just couldn’t explain further, what a continent is [ Didn’t want to explain the geographical way ]. So, I just said “India” and she was pissed off, and abruptly discontinued the conversation and turned back.
 
OMG! I should have been ideally pissed off. However, I assume I did push bit further into taking wild guesses it seems, that might have missed me an opportunity. GOSH!!! I didn’t intend to. I was just casual, at least, I thought so…
 
I still couldn’t believe and was recollecting the incident 
“Whether she really not know what a continent is? Or She just didn’t know Asia is a continent”. 
Either way, I guess its pretty much ignorant. But cute ignorance if you ask me.

I was on the London Underground (the tube) and this American couple were making disparaging remarks about England, so loudly that everyone heard. They were embarrassing everyone. Something had to be done.
 
As they had got onto the subject of vile rodents scurrying round the underground, I saw my chance. I interrupted them and explained that there was only one type of vicious rodent on the underground - it was a large breed of rat. (
I could tell people in the carriage were listening)
. It did have large teeth and did carry disease, however it was very rare and all station staff would warn passengers if it ever showed up
 (people in the carriage were not sure where I was going with this)
. So, I could reassure her that there were no such rodents generally around and any sightings, and they would hear an announcement. The rodents were called “The Gap”. They look worried. 
Everyone else relaxed.
 
Unfortunately I had to get off at the next stop, so I never knew what happened.
 
(For those who don’t know London, the phrase “Mind the Gap” is announced at all tube stations where the platform is curved and so there can be a gap between the train and the platform. Occasionally they say “Mind the gap between the train and the platform”)

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
It’s not someone I met IRL, but someone I had been having a fairly long conversation with online one year in July, maybe 20 years ago when the possibility of having a chat with someone distant was fresh and new. She was in Michigan, as I recall, and I’m in South Africa.
 
At the end of one comment, she said, “But hey, how’s life treating you? What’s your weather like today?”
 
“It’s been a very cold day, and they say it will be below freezing tonight,” I said.
 
I’m used to people from the Global North assuming that everywhere in Africa is always sultry and tropical and sunny, so I wasn’t surprised tha
Continue Reading
It’s not someone I met IRL, but someone I had been having a fairly long conversation with online one year in July, maybe 20 years ago when the possibility of having a chat with someone distant was fresh and new. She was in Michigan, as I recall, and I’m in South Africa.
 
At the end of one comment, she said, “But hey, how’s life treating you? What’s your weather like today?”
 
“It’s been a very cold day, and they say it will be below freezing tonight,” I said.
 
I’m used to people from the Global North assuming that everywhere in Africa is always sultry and tropical and sunny, so I wasn’t surprised that she was taken aback. I responded:
 
“Well, winter in Johannesburg can be very cold. We’re at a high altitude here, that’s why the area is called the Highveld - sometimes, we’ve even had snow, although that is really unusual.”
 
What shocked me was her reaction:
 
“OMG! It’s winter now in South Africa? I didn’t know that!”
 
She did not know that South Africa is in the southern hemisphere and therefore has the opposite seasons to the northern hemisphere. Yet she was a fairly well-educated person, to judge from our discussion. That was the first time I ever wondered about the failure of US schools to teach geographic basics.

I don't think this counts as one an ignorant “American” necessarily, but it really bothered me so… Today I saw a woman who had just finished shopping. Trying to find the shortest possible route to her car she, with much difficulty, squeezed through tightly packed cars with her cart. She scraped a couple cars in the process, but continued to walk; Didn't change route so that she wouldn't affect any other cars, she just kept walking. She arrived at her car, the one adjacent to the one I was sitting in and unloaded her purchases. She continues to take the, now empty cart, and pushes it forward. I think, “Good, at least she's gonna put it back where she got it from”, but no. She puts it in front of her car, despite the place to put carts is literally five steps away. She sits back in her car and sits there for five minutes, browsing on her phone. I could not believe that she wouldn't have the common decency to put the cart back where she got it. Seriously, all she had to take was five steps and she could've saved someone's car from getting scratched. Sometimes it's the small things that can prove what type of person someone is. (I was gonna put the cart away myself, but someone had already done it by the time I got out of the car)

It was July 2003. Pisa, Italy.
 
I was standing no more than 80-100 meters away from the Leaning Tower of Pisa and enjoying the view when a blonde American man in his 30s, wearing sunglasses and a fishing hat approached me and tapped my shoulder.
 
-Excuse me - said the American man - do you know where I can find the Leaning Tower?
 
I turned my head in his direction, raised my eyebrows in disbelief and said:
 
-Please, follow me.
 
I walked a few meters to our right and he followed me. I pointed to the Leaning Tower and said:
 
-See that white building over there? That’s a tower. See how it’s making an angle with the ground? That means it’s leaning. And we’re in Pisa. It’s safe to say that’s the Leaning Tower of Pisa.
 
The man stared at the building and remained silent for a few seconds. He then turned his head at me and the following dialogue ensued:
 
-Are you sure? That’s a pretty ugly tower and I was told it was beautiful.
 
-Yes, I’m sure. It’s pretty obvious actually.
 
-Whoa. Well, that’s disappointing. Thank you! Good bye!
 
-Good bye.
 
He turned his back on me and went his way. To this day, almost 14 years later I haven’t forgotten the day I met that man, the most ignorant American I’ve ever met.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
I’ve read a few previous answers, and I guess that all of us, not just Americans, are “ignorant” to some degree when we find ourselves in a different culture. I am not offended by ignorance as much as I am by the rudeness and belligerence of some ignorant people. That is not confined to Americans on tour!
 
I recall the two very rude female tourists (who did, alas, happen to have American accents) who were giving the desk clerk of a tiny “pensione” in Seville a hard (and loud!) time because they had a list of complaints which he really couldn’t understand, and he had gone to find someone who migh
Continue Reading
I’ve read a few previous answers, and I guess that all of us, not just Americans, are “ignorant” to some degree when we find ourselves in a different culture. I am not offended by ignorance as much as I am by the rudeness and belligerence of some ignorant people. That is not confined to Americans on tour!
 
I recall the two very rude female tourists (who did, alas, happen to have American accents) who were giving the desk clerk of a tiny “pensione” in Seville a hard (and loud!) time because they had a list of complaints which he really couldn’t understand, and he had gone to find someone who might know English better than he. “Well!” one of them exclaimed to me contemptuously as I passed the desk. “You’d think they would at least be able to understand English!”
 
The really strange thing is that it was a delightful little pensione, very “authentic”; when, twenty years later, we found ourselves back in Seville, we recalled it with such fondness that we actually went out of our way to try and find it. We, as Aussies, could understand the English of these women, but not — in this location — their surprise and frustration at encountering someone who couldn’t. Their arrogance to, and intolerance of, the host was inexcusable.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
The most ignorant? Well, when I travelled in Florida with my family, we often ate in restaurants (because why not? We were there to take a much needed family vacation). Being from Israel, we naturally spoke in Hebrew amongst ourselves (and it probably did not help that my English, like my Hebrew, is often peppered with German words and terms when used verbally). I cannot even count the number of waitresses who told us that they speak fluent Spanish if case we prefer.
 
Now, personally, I did not mind, it was clear that the waitresses were simply trying to be friendly and helpful to customers, and
Continue Reading
The most ignorant? Well, when I travelled in Florida with my family, we often ate in restaurants (because why not? We were there to take a much needed family vacation). Being from Israel, we naturally spoke in Hebrew amongst ourselves (and it probably did not help that my English, like my Hebrew, is often peppered with German words and terms when used verbally). I cannot even count the number of waitresses who told us that they speak fluent Spanish if case we prefer.
 
Now, personally, I did not mind, it was clear that the waitresses were simply trying to be friendly and helpful to customers, and besides, I do speak fluent Spanish as well, and I saw it as an invitation to practice it (and it came handy that one time in Orlando where I met a vendor from Venezuela who really spoke only Spanish). But I kept thinking, and still think to this day: If you are as fluent in Spanish as you claim, can’t you recognize that the language we are speaking is not even remotely similar to Spanish?
 
EDIT: Exceedingly stupid comments trying to argue with me about my own experience or proficiency in English, or just comments trying to push baseless speculations are going to be deleted. I really have neither the time nor patience for this.

There was a guy I called Crazy Joe, once I gave him a ride cuz he was always broke and didn’t have a car, and like always he just wanted to argue without listening, and I was explaining to him that I believe in socialism/communism because we should all help each other, and he kept insisting that capitalism was best because nobody had any motivation to do anything without profit… I was getting annoyed, and finally pulled the car over and told him he owed me $45 for taxi service. He shut up and turned bright red. Of course he didn’t have any money…. in the past I’d helped him move and other stuff for free. I guess that was the last time I ever talked to him.
 
The other one that always bothered me was this nice Israeli lady who ran this nice little gyro shop that I’d eat at. One day for whatever reason we started talking about all the issues over there, and I was arguing that Palestinians have at least some reason to be upset about how they’ve been treated. Think what you want about Israel, but you can’t deny that Palestinians have had a rough time… and she just exploded, “They are animals. Every fucking one of them… they should be shot like dogs.” I was like, oh ok, so this is what racism looks like, and I never went back.

For me it an an ignorant couple.
 
I am from Indonesia but was on holidays in USA (I have been to USA many times and always enjoy it). We were at a BBQ at a friend of my husband who is from England when I was talking to the couple.
 
She. Where are you from.
 
Me. Bali, in Indonesia
 
She. Oh lovely, I love Indian food.
 
Me. Yes, so do I.
 
She. Well of course, you are Indian.
 
Me. No I’m from Indonesia, not India.
 
She. But it is the same place.
 
Me. Ummmmm, no India is a different country, and in a different continent .(I know still sort of part of Asian continent strictly)
 
She. I think you will find that Indonesia is just your way of saying India.
 
Now her husband turn.
 
He. Well, actually Indonesia is the formal way of saying India. In your country you have formal and informal names for places. Sort of why you call Calcutta, Mumbai now.
 
Now my husband (from England) stepped in and said.
 
Husband. But Mumbai is the new name for Bombay. Calcutta is now Kolkata isn’t it? Anyway, they are different countries a few thousand kilometres away from each other.
 
She. Now listen, we were educated in college here in America, so I think we would know more about it than you, don’t you.

How often can you go to the gym? What type of training have you done before? What is your current physical condition? What type of exercise do you enjoy (so that you will stick with it)? All of those questions need to be answered before an accurate answer can be given. However, as a general approach:
 
A three day full body routine would be a great place for anyone new to it, or any experienced gym goers looking for a change. Focus on compound movements for your legs, back, shoulders, chest and hinge movements:
 
So one day could be leg press, pull-ups, dumbbell overhead press, bench press and strai
Continue Reading
How often can you go to the gym? What type of training have you done before? What is your current physical condition? What type of exercise do you enjoy (so that you will stick with it)? All of those questions need to be answered before an accurate answer can be given. However, as a general approach:
 
A three day full body routine would be a great place for anyone new to it, or any experienced gym goers looking for a change. Focus on compound movements for your legs, back, shoulders, chest and hinge movements:
 
So one day could be leg press, pull-ups, dumbbell overhead press, bench press and straight leg deadlifts - another could be squats, dumbbell rows, dips, dumbbell incline bench press, good mornings.
 
Exercise choice is up to you, but concentrate on those five areas and compound movements as they recruit the most muscle fibres. Use free weights, not machines, because machines will not give you nearly enough stress on the muscle to make significant changes. Bodyweight moves could be used instead if you are not comfortable using weights to begin wuth.
 
Cardio will be important too. Best bet is high intensity interval training (HIIT), which could be done on days you are not in the gym.
 
Hope that helps.

article:

As Australians travelling in the US we were often asked questions like “Do you have a democracy in Australia?” and “What language do you speak down there in Australia?”
(As an aside, on another trip my father was in Hawaii and was asked if he got there from Australia by car.)

Continue Reading
Perhaps this isn’t quite ‘ignorant’ but it was naive in the extreme.
 
As Australians travelling in the US we were often asked questions like “Do you have a democracy in Australia?” and “What language do you speak down there in Australia?”
(As an aside, on another trip my father was in Hawaii and was asked if he got there from Australia by car.) 
On this occasion I was buying some gifts from the Chicago Symphony Orchestra gift shop for a musician friend. In those days it was just a counter attached to a regular office, not a separate shop. The 20 something woman behind the counter served me and said that she liked my accent. 
“I like yours too” I replied.
Quizzical look.
“I like your accent” I explained.
“I have an accent?”
“Well yes, we all have the accent that we grew up with.”
The penny dropped with a clang. At this point the more sophisticated office staff (as you would expect in an orchestra office, that seemed to be the majority of the staff) started to take notice.
She proceeded to go around the office to the amazement of her colleagues saying “I have an accent! I have an accent!” 
I suspect with each slowly shaking head and apologetic look I got, her remaining professional credibility slipped slowly away.

article:

One evening we were chatting outside the restaurant where all exchange students had a nice welcome dinner. I was in a group of three friends, I am from Nepal, one friend was from Italy and the other one was Portuguese with a Venezuelan mother.
 
The American started chatting with us, and I didn’t say anything because I just found him irritating but was listening to the conversation that 
Continue Reading
Maybe not the most ignorant, but definitely the most annoying American I’ve met.
 
He was an exchange student in Poland. Naturally he got lots of attention here because I think many Europeans find Americans amusing. One evening we were chatting outside the restaurant where all exchange students had a nice welcome dinner. I was in a group of three friends, I am from Nepal, one friend was from Italy and the other one was Portuguese with a Venezuelan mother.
 
The American started chatting with us, and I didn’t say anything because I just found him irritating but was listening to the conversation that unfolded. In a while came the topic of Venezuela, which my Portuguese friend is actually quite proud to be associated with. The American guy said something like, “Venezuela? Come on, nobody cares about Venezuela. What’s the GDP of Venezuela?” and made snide remarks on how Venezuela was basically a backwater country.
 
I found him even more annoying after then. I really do not understand why he got so much attention.
 
Most Americans I’ve met abroad (in Europe) have been incredibly boastful of their country and just loud and annoying. I will have to go to the US one day to meet some down-to-earth Americans I guess.

At the falls the bus dropped us off and went to bus parking. As soon as we got in the compound, asshole noticed that his camera only had one picture and he left his extra film in the bus. No film for sale inside the falls either at that time.
 
He noticed my camera
Continue Reading
Back in the day of film in cameras we were in Jamaica. We took a tour bus to Dunns River Falls.
 
On the bus was the the bus best example of “Ugly Amtherican” I have ever seen. Loud and calling down every country. He was even fat and was wearing ugly shorts. Telling us all that we better do as Uncle Sam says if we know what is good for us.
 
At the falls the bus dropped us off and went to bus parking. As soon as we got in the compound, asshole noticed that his camera only had one picture and he left his extra film in the bus. No film for sale inside the falls either at that time.
 
He noticed my camera strap had several film canisters on it. It also has red maple leafs on it. Hecasked if I had fresh rolls of film. Truthfully I said yes.
 
He demanded, not asked, that I give him a roll of film.
 
“Nope” I said. To make the story shorter, he whined, demanded, pleaded and threatened for film.
 
“Nope, I do not help assholes. Get some from Uncle Sam.”
 
This exchange was witnessed by several others from the bus. No one, even other Americans gave him film.
 
While at the falls, about half the bus came up to me and thanked me for taking a stand. Some said they too refused to loan him film because of my example.

I was born and raised in America and I have to say, I’ve had unique experiences with ignorant people.
I used to get bullied by a bunch of guys, and one of them mocked me because I had a hyper moment in front of him (because of my ADHD, and I later found out he had ADHD too… wtf.), and thentwo of them would ask me when they saw me on my phone, “Are you paying Mario Kart?”/”Are you on your iPod?”.
Then as I was working at my seasonal job, someone tried to return something that was from a different store entirely. Another moment I had while working there was someone must’ve stole stuff and a customer was trying to hand them in.
When I was in my health class in 10th grade, we were all standing by the door. Well, a few of my classmates thought that would be an appropriate time to talk about how they do drugs and what drugs they do. While we were in the drug unit, talking about how bad drugs are for you.
On my 18th birthday, these popular guys (jocks) were asking me questions, such as “Are you going to go gambling?” “Are you going to start smoking?” then this question really stuck out to me, “Are you going to go to a strip joint?” Even that guys friend picked up that I obviously felt uncomfortable at that question.

title: Can I do a light workout every day?
article:
Rule of thumb for any trainee.
Don’t try to train 4 days a week unless you are fully adapted to training 3 days a week.
Don’t train 5 days a week unless you are fully adapted to training 4 days a week.
Etc.
Don’t train more than you need to progress.
Your progress will eventually slow down or halt. You will need to add more training at this point. This is hard if everything is already dialled to 11.
If you go straight from none or light training to too much you will get injured or burned out.
For 4–5 years I used to work with a guy who was rather overweight and unfit. Once or twice a year he would de
Continue Reading
Rule of thumb for any trainee.
Don’t try to train 4 days a week unless you are fully adapted to training 3 days a week.
Don’t train 5 days a week unless you are fully adapted to training 4 days a week.
Etc.
Don’t train more than you need to progress.
Your progress will eventually slow down or halt. You will need to add more training at this point. This is hard if everything is already dialled to 11.
If you go straight from none or light training to too much you will get injured or burned out.
For 4–5 years I used to work with a guy who was rather overweight and unfit. Once or twice a year he would decide to get fit and come to me with his training and diet plan. It was invariably extreme with a diet of oatmeal and protein shakes and smoothies, training 6–7 days a week with weights, bootcamp calisthenics, bike riding and running.
 
Every time I would advise him to reconsider. Eat normally, just a little less than usual, train three times a week, start by getting stronger, walk a bit daily. He would nod thoughtfully and go back to his navy seal hell week business.
 
He never ever stuck to his plan longer than two weeks and he is still just as unfit as he ever was, only more overweight. Don’t be like him.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
The girl in question is a sweet person, but she was very, very misinformed. Just to be clear, we are both Americans, so this wasn’t something that happened abroad. My mother’s family is Lebanese, and that’s not a secret or anything, and I’m Christian, and don’t hide that either.
 
One day, as we were chatting, she pointed at the little cross I was wearing, and said, “Um, hmm, I’ve been meaning to ask- Why do you wear that?”
 
“Because I want to? I don’t understand what you’re asking.”
 
“Like… Why do you wear a cross if that’s not your religion?”
 
“…I 
am
 Christian. ”
 
“But… I thought you were Arabic?”
 
This 
Continue Reading
The girl in question is a sweet person, but she was very, very misinformed. Just to be clear, we are both Americans, so this wasn’t something that happened abroad. My mother’s family is Lebanese, and that’s not a secret or anything, and I’m Christian, and don’t hide that either.
 
One day, as we were chatting, she pointed at the little cross I was wearing, and said, “Um, hmm, I’ve been meaning to ask- Why do you wear that?”
 
“Because I want to? I don’t understand what you’re asking.”
 
“Like… Why do you wear a cross if that’s not your religion?”
 
“…I 
am
 Christian. ”
 
“But… I thought you were Arabic?”
 
This conversation went on for a long, long, painfully awkward long time, before I realized…
 
She thought Islam and Arabic were the same word. 
I had to explain how a Muslim person’s religion is Islam, just like how a Christian person’s religion is Christianity, and a Jewish person’s religion is Judaism. Then, I had to explain quite a lot of other stuff. It was like her brain was a dictionary and one section’s definitions had all been shifted down a line.
 
Thankfully, though, she was very polite about it, and didn’t insist on something wrong being right. We’re still good friends today.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
It was the CEO of a company I worked for some years back. He was the rude side of ignorant At a sales kick-off in Vegas, I passed him in the corridor at the hotel and bid him “Good Morning”. He just ignored me.
 
He came over to the UK a year or two later to speak at a big company conference my boss and I had organised at a lovely, unique venue in Central London. It was my job when he arrived to escort him to the conference theatre. I was nervous, this was the big boss.
 
As we walked up a very grand set of stairs I asked him what he thought of the venue. His gruff response was “I don’t know, I just
Continue Reading
It was the CEO of a company I worked for some years back. He was the rude side of ignorant At a sales kick-off in Vegas, I passed him in the corridor at the hotel and bid him “Good Morning”. He just ignored me.
 
He came over to the UK a year or two later to speak at a big company conference my boss and I had organised at a lovely, unique venue in Central London. It was my job when he arrived to escort him to the conference theatre. I was nervous, this was the big boss.
 
As we walked up a very grand set of stairs I asked him what he thought of the venue. His gruff response was “I don’t know, I just got here”. I pushed him further saying “look at the ceiling, isn’t it beautiful?” Completely cut me dead. He was very clinical, he hadn’t even said hello when we were introduced.
 
Heard similar stories from colleagues. He didn’t have an ounce of spatial awareness. He’s still the CEO many years later, but when you look at Glassdoor he’s got a negative approval rating. You don’t have to be nice to run an organisation.
 
Thankfully I’ve had the pleasure of working for some very personable CEOs at other companies that have been engaging and appreciative of their employees.
 
[Edited to correct a bit of grammar]

article:

This is São Paulo, where I live. A city with 12.5 million inhabitants that resembles a combination of New York and Chicago. The largest business pole of South America.

Where do you hide when the indians attack?

Do you know Coca-Cola? What about ice-cream?

There have been so many it is difficult to elect the most ignorant of them. Here are some pearls of ignorance I had to put up with:
This is São Paulo, where I live. A city with 12.5 million inhabitants that resembles a combination of New York and Chicago. The largest business pole of South America.
 
Since his arrival Mr. Ignorance has showered me with abundant stupid questions.
 
—
Where do you hide when the indians attack?
 
—
Do you know Coca-Cola? What about ice-cream?
 
—
Are there monkeys and snakes around here?
 
—
How come I can’t find American frozen food ? 
(Dude, this is Brazil, not U.S. We do not import American frozen food. We have plenty of our own)
 
—
Do you guys have malls?
 (No, sir. I do not know what you are talking about. Unless you mean those 50 huge shopping centers that are spread around the city and where you have your lunch every single day!)
 
—
All this reddishness is so annoying 
(Travelling some dirt roads in a recently opened corn field)
 
—
This hotel does not provide dental floss. I should have known I’d have to carry complete toiletry!
 
—
Ugh! Are you eating fried grass? (
His reaction when he saw a plate of kale)
 
—
Brazilians take too many showers.

article:
Yes. I am a poor person. I’m 66 years old and live with my mom so I live in a nice house.
 
I don’t own a car. I have no savings. I don’t have any furniture that is worth moving from here. I spend all my social security before the end of the month.
 
As a matter-of-fact, my mom and I together are poor folks. She has a small savings account for emergencies but she runs short on expenses about $100 a mont
Continue Reading
Yes. I am a poor person. I’m 66 years old and live with my mom so I live in a nice house.
 
I don’t own a car. I have no savings. I don’t have any furniture that is worth moving from here. I spend all my social security before the end of the month.
 
As a matter-of-fact, my mom and I together are poor folks. She has a small savings account for emergencies but she runs short on expenses about $100 a month so I try to offset some expenses.
 
We don’t have a flat screen tv and we don’t ever go out to eat. We rarely eat fast food. Grocery shopping is really difficult deciding what I’m willing to spend money on.
 
Whenever we need something out of the ordinary I look and look for the cheapest place to get it. I go to thrift stores for clothes pretty often.
 
Whenever something breaks I watch you tube to try and fix it myself but I’m not very strong so it often breaks again right away. A lot of my repairs only work if you stand on one foot with your left hand raised up high while you hold onto a doorknob, then insert a bent hanger. Lol, just kidding.
 
We don’t have a lot but we don’t miss much either. I’ve never had much money and when my mom was working she gave all hers to us kids.
 
When I moved in, her house was in a shambles. It was so neglected that the carpet was threadbare, there was tarp paper on the walls of one bathroom and there were rooms that the curtains were never opened for sunshine.

Additional Tips:
Variations

Form

Incorporate Cardio

This combination will give you a well-rounded workout that builds strength, stability, and endurance.

My family is investing a lot of money (for us, it is) on renovating our very old home which my dad constructed more than 16 years ago. He didn't had enough money then to construct a bathroom or a kitchen. We never stayed there because it was very far from the city (much like in a jungle with a population to land ratio of 1 or 2 per sq km). People near my locality have a praxis of open defecation. I persuaded my Mother and my elder brother that it was unhealthy and that we should get the bathroom constructed.
 
We were addled whether to keep paying the ever rising rent(s) for a house in the city or invest a huge amount in our own home and save the money for rest of the time. We dared for this and are using my father's money in reconditioning our old home (this money is my deceased father's monetary compensation as he used to work as a watchman in defence service).
 
Now to answer your question, I'm a poor kid here on Quora that uses his time to gain as much knowledge as he can after working hard in the hot sun as a Labourer for constructing his own home to save Rs.300.
( That image is mine making dua (prayer) for myself after a hard working day ; haha). Thanks for reading and thanks to cheap Internet.

Anyone who wants to vote has been able to vote for the last 200 years.” All you had to do to make that statement was to ignore th
Continue Reading
I’m involved with a volunteer organization that is trying to reduce partisan polarization in the US. In the summer of 2023, I attended their national conference and there were several meetings discussing voting security. All panels for sessions are evenly divided between Red and Blue participants.
 
At one of these sessions, Republican efforts to suppress voting were mentioned. A young man on the Red side of the panel literally waved his hand and said, “This is the US. Anyone who wants to vote has been able to vote for the last 200 years.” All you had to do to make that statement was to ignore the fact that women and Black people, who made up the majority of people in the US, had NOT been able to vote for much of US history.
 
To make it even worse, only a few minutes earlier an older Republican on the panel had described his trips to the South to register Black voters in the early 1960s. He had described how Black people were afraid to be seen even speaking to him during that time because their houses could be burned down.
 
Unfortunately, the audience wasn’t allowed to speak up during this session. I should have ignored that and stood up to point out the obvious fallacy the young man had uttered.

Continue Reading
Monday- Chest and biceps
 
Tuesday- Back
 
Wednesday- Abs, sides and cardio (non-weight/functional training)
 
Thursday- Legs and forearms
 
Friday- Shoulders and triceps
 
This is what my most usual weekly workout routine looks like. I carry this out for two weeks, then switch to another routine for two weeks, and then do two weeks of this one again and this cycle continues. I sometimes may switch between Friday and Saturday, keeping one of those as rest days. Some thumb rules I keep in mind are:-
 
1. No more than two days of weight training on a continual basis, to give the muscles enough time to grow.
 
2. Never mixing weight training with cardio. I either do them at separate times of the day, or just do my cardio on Wednesdays and one of the rest days.
 
3. I mostly isolate the bigger muscle groups, i.e, back and legs. Working out these parts involves a large array of exercises, all of which I prefer carrying out, targeting every part, and avoid mixing these with another body part.
 
4. Getting eight hours of sleep daily, regardless of anything.
 
5. None of the above will work if you eat like a hog. Follow a clean diet, with 2–3 cheat meals in a week.
 
Hope this helps!

They didn’t speak a word of Italian, and the family that operates the trattoria didn’t speak English, as this place is generally only frequented by locals. The Americans asked the server if he spoke American. He indicated he didn’t, so the American woman asked again, in a louder voice, the same question. The server shook his head no, indicating he didn’t understand. So the American woman asks again, this time almost

An American tourist in Palermo, where I live. English is my native language. Anyway, I was in a local trattoria near my home. A group of American tourists came in and were seated. They didn’t speak a word of Italian, and the family that operates the trattoria didn’t speak English, as this place is generally only frequented by locals. The Americans asked the server if he spoke American. He indicated he didn’t, so the American woman asked again, in a louder voice, the same question. The server shook his head no, indicating he didn’t understand. So the American woman asks again, this time almost screaming and very irritated. At that point, I decided I’d help the server out, as I was a friend of the family. So I asked the American woman if I could translate for her. I told her what was on the menu for that day, and she and her group ordered, ate, and got up to leave. The woman came over to the table where I was seated, and said: ‘Thank you for helping us’. She then asked me, ‘How long have you been studying English?’ I told her for a long time, (remember, I’m from the UK). Then she patted me on the arm and said: ‘Well, keep up the good work; if you keep studying, you’ll be fluent in no time at all.”

article:

He laid eyes on me, a proud Korean-American, and immediately conjured up images of a divided nation, a ruthless communist regime, and a people suffering under oppressive rule. His well-intentioned, albeit woefully misguided, concern was both amusing and disheartening.
 
This common misconception highlights the immense 
Continue Reading
A Tale of Two Koreas
 
I've encountered a myriad of fascinating individuals throughout my life, but none quite as perplexing as the man at the gas station. I stood there, a simple transaction morphing into an unexpected cultural clash, chuckling at the sheer absurdity of the situation.
 
He laid eyes on me, a proud Korean-American, and immediately conjured up images of a divided nation, a ruthless communist regime, and a people suffering under oppressive rule. His well-intentioned, albeit woefully misguided, concern was both amusing and disheartening.
 
This common misconception highlights the immense power of media and the alarming ease with which harmful stereotypes can take root. While it's understandable to be curious about diverse cultures, it's paramount that we approach them with open minds and a genuine willingness to learn.
 
In the end, I left the gas station with a few extra snacks and a humorous anecdote etched in my memory. It serves as a stark reminder that even in this age of unprecedented information, ignorance can still persist. But perhaps, with a little more understanding and empathy, we can bridge the divide between cultures and cultivate a more compassionate world.

Not sure I can answer because it did not happen to me but to my father.
 
I am French, and so is my father.
 
Now my father is retired, but in 1984 he was an urban planner. He went to Mission Viejo (California) for a professional travel, to learn how this new city was designed (it was designed and built during the 1970s and early 1980s following an innovative urban planning scheme).
 
During the travel, my father visited some brand new houses, the American guide showing to the group of visitors the wonderful home devices and appliances that made the happiness of American people.
 
Once, with pride showing the object next to him, the guide said “here, in the USA, we have microwave ovens”, as if it was a performance or an honour. This guide simply did not know that, in Europe, we also had microwaves in our homes.
 
Guess what, we also have vacuum cleaners, and even electricity and water! I’m kidding, but the guide was not, he seriously thought his country so much ahead of all others…
 
I remember this anecdote very well because, to ignorance, this guy added arrogance. That said, every country has a lot of stupid, ignorant and arrogant people, USA does not detain the exclusivity.

The recommended frequency of exercise varies depending on factors such as age, fitness level, health status, and exercise goals. However, general guidelines suggest that adults should aim for at least 150 minutes of moderate-intensity aerobic exercise or 75 minutes of vigorous-intensity aerobic exercise per week, along with muscle-strengthening activities on two or more days per week.
 
For example:
Moderate-intensity aerobic exercise includes activities like brisk walking, cycling at a moderate pace, or water aerobics.
Vigorous-intensity aerobic exercise includes activities like running, swimming laps, or cycling at a fast pace.
Muscle-strengthening activities can include weightlifting, bodyweight exercises, or exercises that use resistance bands.
It's also beneficial to incorporate flexibility and balance exercises into your routine, especially for older adults, to improve overall mobility and reduce the risk of falls.
 
It's important to consult with a healthcare professional before starting any new exercise program, especially if you have any underlying health conditions or concerns. They can provide personalized recommendations based on your individual needs and circumstances.

The manager, a man, and the sales lady, were both in their 50’s, or so.
 
I was wanting to ship to an address in NEW MEXICO, from COLORADO. The two states are literally next door to each other.
 
When I explained that New Mexico was part of the US and just south of Colorado, the manager said he was from back East, so how should he know?
 
I told him he was a freaking US Citizen, he should know. The sales lady then asked if my friend spoke English. 🤦🏼‍♀️ 
 
I told them to forget the sale, I wanted my money back. I then left.
 
This was a chain clothing store. I sent a letter to the main office, but never heard back from anyone.

Push-ups are one of the most popular exercises and it is a workout that can be done at any time, anyplace, and by anyone. Push-ups exercise is very useful for weight loss as it pushes your body away from the ground and exerts energy which in turn burns calories.

My husband and I once lived next to a very sweet girl (early 20s), who unfortunately, had very little exposure to other countries or cultures.
 
She once asked my husband: “So, what church do you go to?”
 
Hubby: “I’m Muslim.”
 
Neighbor: “You’re Mormon?”
 
Hubby: “No, I’m Muslim.”
 
Neighbor: “What does that mean?”
 
Hubby: “I believe in Islam.”
 
Neighbor: “What does that mean?”
 
Hubby: “It’s a religion. I’ll explain it to you later.”
 
Apparently, this young woman was not aware of the Islamic religion or of Muslims. You’d think that most Americans would have heard of Muslims at this point, but apparently, she had missed the memo.
 
Edit: Followup Conversation.
 
Many people have asked how the followup conversation went. When he tried to explain Islam to her, she was quite surprised to learn that there were other religions besides Christianity. She basically thought that religion and Christianity were synonymous.
 
We also explained Buddhism, Hinduism, and a few others. She had heard of Judaism, but she had thought that that was a branch of Christianity, like Catholicism. She had no idea that different people in the world believed different religions.

title: How often should I workout for best results?
article:
To see results from your exercise routine, it is generally recommended to exercise at least three to four times per week. This frequency allows for sufficient stimulus to the muscles and cardiovascular system while still providing adequate rest and recovery. However, the optimal exercise frequency can vary depending on your goals, fitness level, and the type of exercises you're doing. Here are some general guidelines:
Cardiovascular exercise: Aim for at least 150 minutes of moderate-intensity aerobic activity or 75 minutes of vigorous-intensity aerobic activity per week. This can be spread acro
Continue Reading
To see results from your exercise routine, it is generally recommended to exercise at least three to four times per week. This frequency allows for sufficient stimulus to the muscles and cardiovascular system while still providing adequate rest and recovery. However, the optimal exercise frequency can vary depending on your goals, fitness level, and the type of exercises you're doing. Here are some general guidelines:
Cardiovascular exercise: Aim for at least 150 minutes of moderate-intensity aerobic activity or 75 minutes of vigorous-intensity aerobic activity per week. This can be spread across multiple days, such as 30 minutes of cardio on five days a week or 50 minutes on three days a week.
Strength training: Incorporate strength training exercises at least two to three times per week. Allow a day of rest between sessions to give your muscles time to recover and grow. Focus on targeting all major muscle groups with exercises like squats, lunges, push-ups, and rows.
Flexibility and mobility exercises: Include stretching and mobility exercises at least two to three times per week, or even daily if possible. This helps improve flexibility, range of motion, and prevents injury.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:

I have had quite a few Americans ask me why my country is so cold, mention things such as “Serbian rubies” and inquiry me about Vladimir Putin.

Please, note that I have many American friends who are super-educated and that each country has a lot of dumb and ignorant people. We just didn’t know much about them before the internet.

There was a road near my work that intersected with the road I was looking for, so after work I took that until I reached it. But having reached it, I didn’t know whether to turn right or left.
 
I figured if I could find the street addresses of two properties on the road, simple arithmetic would answer the question. Unfortunately, where I was was a series of strip malls that d

Some years back, when Minnesota still had emissions testing, I needed to visit the emissions testing facility. I had no idea where it was, save for the road it was on and the street address. (This was also pre-google maps.)
 
There was a road near my work that intersected with the road I was looking for, so after work I took that until I reached it. But having reached it, I didn’t know whether to turn right or left.
 
I figured if I could find the street addresses of two properties on the road, simple arithmetic would answer the question. Unfortunately, where I was was a series of strip malls that didn’t post their street addresses.
 
So I walked into a video tape rental shop (I told you this was some years ago). There was a young man behind the counter, and a younger kid holding a skateboard standing in front talking to him.
 
I asked the clerk what the address of the store was. He didn’t know, and asked me why I wanted to know. I explained my situation and said that I just needed to know whether to head north or south.
 
At which point the kid with the skateboard spoke up, pointing out the storefront window directly at the setting sun, and said “I think that’s south.”

I worked out at home for almost 2 years with no equipments or trainer. My routine was strict and I followed up consistently. I used to wake up at 5 in the morning and have an intense workout consisting of unlimited pushups, pullups, squats, planks, running, cycling etc. Workouts were short and intense mostly over in 45 mins, also because I didn’t have any other equipments haha. I followed a high protein diet daily and boy the results were freaking awesome and satisfying. Now coming today I’ve joined a gym (an expensive one) having 5–6 trainers ,air-conditioned,with boom boom music,ultra high end equipments but the thing is I’m not getting results. You ask why? The thing is I’m not consistent right now. I go for 2 days then skip for 1. So even if you have all the amenities and money, the thing with fitness has always been about consistency. Working out in the morning or evening doesn’t matter. Eating before or after workout doesn’t matter. What matters is working out. Working out DAILY (with sufficient rest in between). So stick to a routine which you are comfortable with. A single workout plan/routine will not work for everyone. But stick to it. Be repetitive. Be CONSISTENT.

I don't think that if somebody is unaware of the Declaration of Independence or of how many states are in America that would necessarily make them ignorant.
 
Knowledge is only useful if its applied knowledge, and neither of those things would really affect somebody's daily life.
 
If someone is planning a trip interstate, as long as they have the ability to read a map or program a GPS they'll be fine.
 
What did bother me when visiting the US was how often the country way referred to as “the world”. I met a man who informed me that he had travelled the world when he had never actually left the country. And it was a common theme with people who had travelled interstate to mention that they had gone halfway across the world.
 
It was weird.
 
A lot of Americans seem to have very little knowledge of countries and events outside of their own borders, as well as the affect their country has on other countries as the self declared world police.
 
That said, I didn't meet a single person in the US I didn't get along with. Everyone was friendly, courteous and genuinely interested in where we had come from, even though they had a lot of weird misconceptions about Australia.

Well, I don’t think this man was unintelligent, just unaware of current events. This was quite a while ago, I was taking a road trip from Michigan to California meandering throughout the country. I got lost somewhere in Texas, really not sure exactly where even, driving down what could best be described as a “dusty trail”, so far off the freeway, when I spied a store. I drove up to the store and got out to get something to drink and some snacks and directions back to the freeway. There were two older gentlemen sitting on the porch and one of them says, “Ain’t that there one of them Japs?”. The other one turned and looked at me and replies, “Yep, he is one of them Japs”. Then asks me what I’m doing there. I told him I was lost and needed directions and some snacks. And he asks, “Are you here peacefully, then?” I answered in the affirmative and he said, “Welcome to the best country in the world, son”, then got up and shook my hand. “Didn’t know they started allowing y’all back in the country.” Wow! The best part of it all, he took his hat off, placed it on his chest and apologized for his nation having killed so many of my people. Well, ignorant sure doesn’t mean “bad person”.
