Of course, and I am one of them. Ya see...
 
I am full time grad student and am not employed at this time (although, I do work 16 hours per week while in school as part of my MSW program but DON'T GET PAID FOR IT). My husband is legally blind and receives monthly disability payments.
 
All together, I would say we (a family of three) live off of about $22,000 a year and that includes my student loans and my husband's modest Minister of Music salary.
 
To get by, we applied for and receive monthly food stamps, Medicaid and WIC benefits. I love to see the expressions on my classmates faces when I talk about my being “poor,” and thus, am actually living all of the things we “study” and read about in our coursework (most of my classmates are White and come from middle-class to upper-middle class homes and backgrounds).
 
That said, my family doesn't own a car and rely on public transportation and Uber to get around. However, my family has the essentials: a roof, food, and clothing (although it's a struggle sometimes to even provide those things); our basic needs are met; but that's about it.
 
So, yeah, I am a poor Quoran and proud:) I hope that answers your question:)

title: Is a morning gym workout better than an evening gym workout?
article:
Studies show that exercising later in the day is much more beneficial than working out in the morning, as your bodily functions are at their best at this time so you’ll have more energy and more strength for an optimal workout. However, many find it harder to exercise after a long day at work.
 
“You’ll likely have more energy to exercise in the second half of the day, compared to the first thing in the morning.”
Your body temperature is highest in the evening. Muscles and joints are up to 20% more flexible this time compared to in the morning, which makes it easier and less of a strain to exercis
Continue Reading
Studies show that exercising later in the day is much more beneficial than working out in the morning, as your bodily functions are at their best at this time so you’ll have more energy and more strength for an optimal workout. However, many find it harder to exercise after a long day at work.
 
“You’ll likely have more energy to exercise in the second half of the day, compared to the first thing in the morning.”
Your body temperature is highest in the evening. Muscles and joints are up to 20% more flexible this time compared to in the morning, which makes it easier and less of a strain to exercise. Chances of injuries during exercise is also lower than morning workouts.
You’ll likely have more energy to exercise in the second half of the day, compared to the first thing in the morning. Not only that, your metabolism and lung functions are also working best in the late afternoon/evening, so you would have more strength and endurance to last through your cardio workout session.
Exercising in the evening gives you an outlet of stress release from the day’s work. You’ll also have a clearer mind to work out as it would be your final task for the day before hitting the sack.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
Ok, it’s cheap, safe and easy to jump on the bandwagon of America-bashing, but since such question already exists and a lot of people have already shared their experiences, I’ll share mine too.
 
Once I had to meet an American guy at the Pulkovo airport just to escort him to his hotel in the city. He appeared to be some kind of mid-level manager at some sound equipment producing company, and he had to conduct business negotiations with their Russian partners. My job was only to take him from point A to point B, but I decided it would be nice to tell him a bit about the history of the area and the
Continue Reading
Ok, it’s cheap, safe and easy to jump on the bandwagon of America-bashing, but since such question already exists and a lot of people have already shared their experiences, I’ll share mine too.
 
Once I had to meet an American guy at the Pulkovo airport just to escort him to his hotel in the city. He appeared to be some kind of mid-level manager at some sound equipment producing company, and he had to conduct business negotiations with their Russian partners. My job was only to take him from point A to point B, but I decided it would be nice to tell him a bit about the history of the area and the city. I pointed him to the Pulkovo Heights and said:
 
“This is where the frontline passed during the Siege of Leningrad”
 
Him: “Which siege?”
 
For a moment I thought the word “siege” was strange to him and elaborated:
 
“I mean, during the war”
 
Him: “Which war?”
 
I: “The World War”
 
Him: “Wait, the First or the Second War?”
 
I: “During the Second World War”
 
Him: “And who did you fight against?”
 
I: “The Germans”
 
Him: “Wow, I never knew they got here!”
 
Take note, this was not some teenage hillbilly, but a guy in his late 40’s working at a well-paid job in New York.

title: Is running every day better than going to the gym every day?
article:
I’m fairly certain it’s not possible.
 
I ran exclusively and competitively for a good number of years. I am 5′6′’ and, at my ‘peak’ shape, I weighed about 105–110 lbs.
 
Running fitness is very different from any conceivable general fitness. If you run for long enough consistently, then you will end up losing weight. Today, I weigh anywhere from 145–155 lbs. I’m not insanely fit but I’m also not nearly as thin as I was when I was running 80–110-mile weeks.
 
If you are looking at general fitness, it’s probably best to keep the running below 30 miles a week and leave room to incorporate other exercises
Continue Reading
I’m fairly certain it’s not possible.
 
I ran exclusively and competitively for a good number of years. I am 5′6′’ and, at my ‘peak’ shape, I weighed about 105–110 lbs.
 
Running fitness is very different from any conceivable general fitness. If you run for long enough consistently, then you will end up losing weight. Today, I weigh anywhere from 145–155 lbs. I’m not insanely fit but I’m also not nearly as thin as I was when I was running 80–110-mile weeks.
 
If you are looking at general fitness, it’s probably best to keep the running below 30 miles a week and leave room to incorporate other exercises.
That’s Mo Farah in the middle. He’s a double Olympic winner, consecutively. What I mean by that is he’s won the 5,000 meter and the 10,000 meter at the Olympic games, two Olympic games in a row.
 
He’s 5′9′’ and he weighs about 130 lbs. It’s fair to say that he’s exclusively a runner.
 
While you probably won’t get down to that weight, that’s the kind of fitness trajectory you will be on. If that’s what you want, then great.
 
Otherwise, running won’t make you ripped. Unless you’re a genetic freak like Alan Webb, I suppose.
But he’s the exception and not the rule.

I did a part-time tour guide stint about seven years ago, taking English-speaking tourists around the Akropolis. I did pretty well, people responded well to me and asked me lots of questions and complimented my English. Some couldn’t believe I was Greek.
 
One fine morning I had a group of almost entirelly American folks plus some Canadian kids with a teacher or guardian. All in all a really nice and pleasant group, polite and well-mannered.
 
So we set off, plenty of talking and explaining on my part.
 
Halfway through while talking about the restoration work, this middle-aged gentleman with a rather drawling accent I still can’t quite place suddenly asks: “So where do you folks worship Zeus if all your temples are wrecked?”
 
I 
wish
 I was kidding.
 
Fortunately the gent’s wife sparred me from being flusteted by jabbing him with her elbow and shushing him then firing a rather more sensible question about the restoration process at me.
 
The Canadian kids gave me a nice tip at the end and treated me to a soda while complimenting my English and knowledge.
 
I managed not to laugh until my break. It made my senior/supervisor 
groan.
 It was pretty breath-taking.

article:

Are you trying to get in shape, build muscle, gain a lot of strength, etc. In terms of answering this question I will just talk about general fitness. First let’s start with the pros. You will be hitting all muscle parts on a daily and being 100% honest that’s the only pro I see I’m sure there are a lot more but in my view I just see a lot of cons. First of all how is your body going to 
Continue Reading
there are thousands of people who can answer this better then me but I will try to answer this with the best of my abilities with a short simple answer.
 
first of all it depends on the goal you are trying reach. Are you trying to get in shape, build muscle, gain a lot of strength, etc. In terms of answering this question I will just talk about general fitness. First let’s start with the pros. You will be hitting all muscle parts on a daily and being 100% honest that’s the only pro I see I’m sure there are a lot more but in my view I just see a lot of cons. First of all how is your body going to recover training every body part every single day the only way you can do that is if your not training hard enough and your muscles aren’t being used as much as they can which will result in not a lot of progress. Second of all you won’t necessarily be able to focus on specific muscle groups like for example a push, pull, legs split offers training chest, triceps, and shoulders for a push day. Back and biceps for pull day. And of course legs for legs. It allows your body to recover while training other body parts you can do this split 3 days a week or 6 with a rest on Sunday.

I drive a truck over the road. Everything I do involves two 30 lb dumbbells, one 50 lb dumbbell and a bench. I do one and sometimes two circuits every 3 days of upper body. So my upper body day looks like this: 30 means the 30’s. 50 means the 50/
Flyes. 30.
Flat dumbbell presses. 30
Alternating dumbbell side laterals. 30.
Seated presses.30.
Upright rows. 30.
Bent laterals. 30.
2 arm dumbbell rows. 30.
Tricep French presses. 50.
Dumbbell pullovers. 50.
1 arm dumbbell rows. After this I take a 2 minute rest. Then I do.
1 arm bench. 50. Rest 1 minute.
1 arm seated press. 50.
The next day I do legs. Again, a non stop circuit.
Lying leg curls with a dumbbell between my feet. 30.
Squats for 60 to 100 reps. 50.
Straight leg deadlifts for 30 reps. 30. 3 minute rest.
Hack squat with feet on board. 30 reps. 30. 2 minute rest.
Lunges. One leg at a time for 30 reps. 30.
I leg calf raises. Bodyweight first set. 30lbs second set.
Day 3 I run a 5k in either 23:30 or 24:30. I alternate times each run.
 
My home gym costed me less that $100. I bought the 30’s and the 50 for 50 cents a pound on Craigslist. I also paid $40 for a Marcy bench. I am able to do 18 exercises.

So I guess I'm pretty poor compared to most other people on this site. But living in a country where loads of people barely manage to getOne good meal a day or a roof over their heads I shouldn't be complaining or calling myself poor. Although I have to say .."urban poverty " is a different thing altogether..it can be more frustrating in some ways -technically you aren't poor but in so many ways you are. Too poor to be well off ;too well off to be poor .

(This story is not embellished by even one word)
 
It was the middle of summer and I had just finished a large cabling job in the ceiling of an industrial building. I was parched so I pulled into a McDonalds drive thru and the following conversation occurred:
 
Worker:
 
Hello. welcome to McDonalds may I take your order?
 
Me:
 
Yes. I would like a large Coke.
 
Worker:
 
Would you like anything to drink with that?
 
Me:
 
Ma’am, I ordered a drink…..a large Coke.
 
Worker:
 
I know you did sir, would you like anything to drink with that?
 
Me:
 
Ma’am, would you please read my order back to me?
 
Worker:
 
Sure, you ordered a large Coke. …… Would you like anything to drink with that?
 
Me:
 
Ok, now you are just irritating me….I won’t answer such a question.
 
Worker:
 
Sir, for the last time….would you like anything to drink with your Coke?
 
Me:
 
Ma’am…..I am at a loss here. Is there a manager I can speak with?
 
The speaker went silent and in about 15 seconds the worker came storming out of the McDonalds and threw her apron in the air. She jumped in her car and sped off. I guess I was the straw that broke the camel’s back.

title: Are there any poor people on Quora, as Internet access is very cheap nowadays?
article:
I'm not rich by monetary standards. I was born and raised in Quiapo, Manila, mind you where we live is not the best part of the city. My mother is a “mananahi” or what you call dressmaker in the west. My father when he was still alive was a carpenter, mason or what they call a manual laborer. They use to be farmers, but they did not own the land that they tilled. We did not own a house in Manila nor did we own a TV set ’til I was 8 years old. My sister is a domestic helper in Singapore.

I'm not rich by monetary standards. I was born and raised in Quiapo, Manila, mind you where we live is not the best part of the city. My mother is a “mananahi” or what you call dressmaker in the west. My father when he was still alive was a carpenter, mason or what they call a manual laborer. They use to be farmers, but they did not own the land that they tilled. We did not own a house in Manila nor did we own a TV set ’til I was 8 years old. My sister is a domestic helper in Singapore.
 
I got lucky, I was able to get a chance to be with people who are smart and was nice enough to share what they know in spite of my economic strata.
 
I live, work and study in the US now. But I am far from being rich. My mother is still in the Philippines, along with my nephews. I have Internet, it's not free, I pay for it from the salary I get. I use it for classes as well.
 
I'm not even sure why I am answering a question like this one because it appears more like a troll question than a sincere one.
 
Yes there are poor people in Quora. I am one of them. I go into Quora whenever it's my break. Why are we here? I guess we just want to know more and share the things we know.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
My partner teaches Cultural Diversity to college freshmen. Over the last 10 years she’s run into African American students who’d never even heard of American slavery. Other students in the same class assured her that Africans were happy to be transported (for free!) to the greatest country in the world, so they could work happily alongside all their friends. It wasn’t slavery, it was a lifestyle upgrade!
 
Most of her students have never heard of the Japanese American internment camps of WWII, about 1/3 thought American Indians are extinct (some thought they were invented only for the movies) and
Continue Reading
My partner teaches Cultural Diversity to college freshmen. Over the last 10 years she’s run into African American students who’d never even heard of American slavery. Other students in the same class assured her that Africans were happy to be transported (for free!) to the greatest country in the world, so they could work happily alongside all their friends. It wasn’t slavery, it was a lifestyle upgrade!
 
Most of her students have never heard of the Japanese American internment camps of WWII, about 1/3 thought American Indians are extinct (some thought they were invented only for the movies) and nearly all of them KNOW for a fact that Arabs and Muslims mean the same thing - the two words can be used interchangeably.
 
Let’s see. There were those who just assume that Civil War and Civil Rights are the same thing, and that slaves could escape their cruel southern masters by hopping a bus (they’d have to sit in the back of course) before joining MLK to protest - right after Rosa Parks was shot. (No, really)
 
My favorite might be the slaves who escaped from England. Longing to see the Statue of Liberty they steamed into San Francisco Bay, after visiting Hawaii.

“ Wow that is way cool. how you guys g

Many years ago, my father took me on a once in a lifetime trip on Concord from London to New York, and then on to Orlando where The British Airways Concord landed simultaneously with Air France Concorde for the official opening if Disney's Epcot Centre.
 
We were staying in the Disney hotel and in the evening sat at the bar with a beer recapping an amazing day. The bar girl was very beautiful and she heard us talking with Brit accents…
 
“ Where ya'll from?”
 
“ Uh …..England”
 
“ That near New York?”
 
“ No. not New England. Old England. You know the Queen and all that”
 
“ Wow that is way cool. how you guys got here?
 
Remember that the Concords landing attracted 40,000 people and was televised nationally..
 
“ We came on Concord”
 
“ What's that?”
 
Slightly taken aback… “ Er it' s a plane that is supersonic. It flies twice the speed of sound”
 
Long pregnant silence while she looked straight into my eyes thinking I was taking the piss, then with a lovely smile and a little flick of her bar cloth at me,
 
“ Ooooo you. Get outta here.”
 
She turned out to be very bright on many topics and blissfully ignorant on others. I”ll never forget her.

long pause there…

“wow, you don't look anything like them”
 
“what do you mean?”
 
“you know, like French and German look alike coz they're close to each other…”

“uh, yeah. so you speak any Italian?”
 
“oh no, my grandparents moved here a long time ago and they only speak to me in English. how about you?”
 
“my ancestors built the California railroad in the early 1820’s, i don't know a single person outside of this country.”
 
that last line was a joke, by the way. heard it from some guy who was being verbally abused by a “proud 3rd generation Italian” taking about this country's immigration problems.

“will it be effective?”

Continue Reading
Let me tell you the fact in a simple way without using any complex fitness terms.
The true work is done on an elevated heart rate. If your heart rate is not elevated in any physical activity, that actually means you're not working out.
 
Now, coming to your question 
“will it be effective?”
 depends on the number of exercises and no. Of sets you do at a time.
 
Lets suppose you're training back throughout the day. If you're doing one set of deadlift at a time, then sorry my friend, the work required to build muscle is not happening. However, over the period of time you'll notice some changes in your body.
 
In other case, if you do two or more exercises at the same time. Then your heart rate will elevate and then work happens.
 
The conclusion is, you can workout once at a time or throughout the day. Just you've to make sure that your heart rate is elevated. And another, splitting yiur workouts throughout the day is time consuming.
 
There's no wrong in experimenting. Think, Take action, Experiment and share your knowledge to others ❤️
 
Upvote if you get some value from this.
 
Disclaimer:
 
To join our community, click here -> 
The Muscly Advisor

As the “outsiders” we were immediately quizzed and as we still retain some semblance of an Aussie accent despite our 37 years in America. The usual “
Your not from around here
” - yes we are we live in….up the freeway…
 
Anyhow it went further downhill than normal, because a group stated, 
well you seem like foreigners to me
. Stating that we are Americans but yes, we were not born here (by the way we are about as White as you can be - the 23andme genetics test exclaim it).
 
Then we were told well 
as you are foreigners then you must be Muslims
. This was getting bad.
 
Not willing to play the game I said I was not but I was raised by Hindus (I grew up in a Hindu dominated country). That was a befuddling answer, so then they asked if “
are you a terrorist
?”
 
Bottom line even though I looked like them the mere presence of an accent rendered me into the foreign terrorist threat. Just awful, and sad and aggravating.
 
My wife made me stay to be polite but it was very hard. Not at all comfortable.

title: What is a good weekly workout?
article:
I would highly recommend you start with a beginner lifting routine where you perform full body weight training 3 times a week and rest every other day. You should also perform some type of steady state cardio for 20 min on your rest days 2 to 3 times a week. 
 
Alternatively, you can also try a upper body and lower body split and repeat this one time so you lift 4 times a week with 2 to 3 sessions of 20 min steady state cardio as well. 
 
You can start by doing body weight exercises for building your strength but you should invest in some type of resistance bands or weights for the long term.

I would highly recommend you start with a beginner lifting routine where you perform full body weight training 3 times a week and rest every other day. You should also perform some type of steady state cardio for 20 min on your rest days 2 to 3 times a week. 
 
Alternatively, you can also try a upper body and lower body split and repeat this one time so you lift 4 times a week with 2 to 3 sessions of 20 min steady state cardio as well. 
 
You can start by doing body weight exercises for building your strength but you should invest in some type of resistance bands or weights for the long term. 
 
For cardio you can jog or walk outside. 
 
If you need detailed information for your training routine, you can check it out here:
 
For at home free workouts, you can check it out here:
Quick Fat Loss Workouts at Home or Anywhere
 
In terms of eating, you need to figure out your calories and macros based upon your fitness goals and use a tracker to track your food intake. If you need detailed macro tutorial, you can check it out here:
 
You can eat anything you desire as long as you are within your macro goals to reach your fitness goals. Good luck :-)

Oh My! This is such a sad list of answers. The answers are sad. The length of the list is sad. Here’s a couple more:
 
1). Riding in a car on a road that paralleled a Florida beach, we were driving in and out of patches of fog. The girl in the front seat seemed to be uneasy about the fog and exclaimed that she wished “It would go away”. … a few moments of silent agreement, then the driver spoke: “Hey Susie, did you know that fog is just a cloud that’s developed on the ground?” [I thought it was a joke question] …a few more moments of silence, then: “Nuh uh! …Clouds are millions and millions of miles away!”
 
2) At a diner, I was exchanging small-talk with a young lady who suddenly blurted that she quit her job that afternoon. Of course, thinking there was a backstory to the statement, I asked why. Her answer:
 
“Well, I was thinking… I have bills and I’m working. If I quit working, I’m still going to have bills; so what’s the point?”
 
The reason I didn’t try to reason this out with her wasn’t because I was flabbergasted (I was), but rather because of the obvious pride she exhibited for this stroke of glorious insight. She was a nurse! …True Story!

Some anecdotes of sheer ignorance displayed by Americans that I’ve seen myself or have heard from friends. It seems that it mostly has to do with ignorance of the rest of the world and with current affairs.
An American exchange student to the UK asked, ‘can you get into Germany now? I thought there was a big wall around the country.’
A friend, Italian, moved to Columbus, Ohio, and was welcomed by a resident who claimed that the city was ‘founded by Christopher Columbus himself’.
The same friend was told by an economics PhD student that universal healthcare doesn’t work because ‘everywhere that has it is going bankrupt’.
A man who said that he was from New Jersey was greatly offended when my partner told him that she didn’t know exactly where that was. But when she told him that she was from Finland, he asked her whether if that was ‘a country in Asia’.
An American woman who just visited London told me that the city ‘is not really British anymore because there’s literally no white people anywhere’.
A man in Nevada asked me how tall I was. I answered in meters. He didn’t have a clue what I was talking about and proceeded to ask if I’m stupid or not.

I met a Nazi. He was a friend of a friend. We had a BBQ at my friend's place and this guy shows up. The gathering contained many different cultures including my very good friend who is Jewish. Anyway, for some reason we started talking about religions, etc. All of a sudden he started telling us how he loves Hitler and he wished, Hitler killed ALL of the Jewish people. At first I thought that he was joking. But after a few seconds I realized that he was dead serious. My Jewish friend is the sweetest person ever. The guy knew her religion, but he didn't know her at all though. I looked at her and she had tears in her eyes. She didn't say anything, but I couldn't just sit there without saying anything especially that this subject is very sensitive to me because I am from Poland. I asked him to stop and told him that's very inappropriate to say things like this in front of my friend. He didn't care; he went on and on some more about his hatred for my friend's religion. Then all of a sudden I became so angry that I told him: “Now I see what you are and I don't feel sorry for you and what happened to you”. The guy was in a wheelchair because he had a bike accident a few years back. After saying that I was embarrassed of myself for going to his level. But seeing how he hurt my friend built up this enormous anger. I guess we were both ignorant, but n...

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
In September 2011, I was on holiday in Athens with my family and on the 9th of September we went on a bus tour to the Corinth Canal. Also on the bus were a bunch of Americans who were loud and obnoxious all day long. We stayed out of their way so. It wasn’t too bad in the end. However, when we got back to Athens, we were informed by the tour guide that the Twin Towers had been attacked, which of course took the shine off the day.
 
After all the flights were cancelled the Americans were re-directed to our hotel things got a little bit chaotic to say the very least. But, you would think wouldn’t y
Continue Reading
In September 2011, I was on holiday in Athens with my family and on the 9th of September we went on a bus tour to the Corinth Canal. Also on the bus were a bunch of Americans who were loud and obnoxious all day long. We stayed out of their way so. It wasn’t too bad in the end. However, when we got back to Athens, we were informed by the tour guide that the Twin Towers had been attacked, which of course took the shine off the day.
 
After all the flights were cancelled the Americans were re-directed to our hotel things got a little bit chaotic to say the very least. But, you would think wouldn’t you that these stranded Americans who had just faced one of the biggest tragedies in their recent history would have behaved with grace and dignity? But no, they invaded the hotel and descended on the roof bar that first night and proceeded to get completely shit faced. Then, one of them, a bloke of about 25, stood in the middle of the room and at the top of his voice shouts ‘HEY HONEY, WHERE THE FUCK IN THE WORLD ARE WE?!’ Ignorant, arrogant, and lucky to get out of the room with his face intact. I would have died of embarrassment if he’d been my husband.

title: Are there any poor people on Quora, as Internet access is very cheap nowadays?
article:
I’m poor. I have $7 between my checking and saving accounts and about $50 in my wallet that will go to keeping my phone on for another month next week. I would have around $250 extra money in my pocket tomorrow, but the arrangement that it depends on hit an unexpected screeching halt that’s keeping me from going back home tomorrow as per the original plan.
 
My most valuable possessions are probably my 3 year old Lenovo laptop and the PS4 that my uncle had given me for Christmas last year. Other than that the main things I own are just my clothes, my cards (MTG mainly), and a few games and books.
 
Continue Reading
I’m poor. I have $7 between my checking and saving accounts and about $50 in my wallet that will go to keeping my phone on for another month next week. I would have around $250 extra money in my pocket tomorrow, but the arrangement that it depends on hit an unexpected screeching halt that’s keeping me from going back home tomorrow as per the original plan.
 
My most valuable possessions are probably my 3 year old Lenovo laptop and the PS4 that my uncle had given me for Christmas last year. Other than that the main things I own are just my clothes, my cards (MTG mainly), and a few games and books.
 
I’ve been living with my family this whole time (excluding being at Job Corps and a one year dorm stay while I was in college), but I’m not trying to rely on them anymore than necessary especially with them being pretty much done with me at this point.
 
Right now, I’m working on getting set up with AmeriCorps so I can go home for a brief rest before starting with them. I can’t wait to get started. It’ll be nice to finally be in another state and earning a steady bit of pay so I won’t have to worry about how I’m going to pay for everything as much.

title: Is it bad to do full body workouts every day?
article:
I think you should avoid full body everyday in general.
 
however it depends on your experience volume and how your program is set up as well.
 
if its a body weight program that does not use the same exercises everyday and the volume is not too high and you don’t go to failure then I would say it could work.
 
if your a beginner I would tell you to just work out three days a week and not more. too much training is counter productive because your body needs rest.
 
however I been watching a lot of prison style work out videos and it seems that you can get results and get away with it if you workout everyd

I think you should avoid full body everyday in general.
 
however it depends on your experience volume and how your program is set up as well.
 
if its a body weight program that does not use the same exercises everyday and the volume is not too high and you don’t go to failure then I would say it could work.
 
if your a beginner I would tell you to just work out three days a week and not more. too much training is counter productive because your body needs rest.
 
however I been watching a lot of prison style work out videos and it seems that you can get results and get away with it if you workout everyday but I don’t think its a good idea in general .
 
the way I train is inspired from this so I split body weight exercises and punching bag exercises one day and next day some form of cardio , runnning biking or swimming or whatever I have the opportunity to do. I also shadow box everyday when I train.
 
weekends off to rest and its hard to workout everyday so I don’t feel bad if I miss a day .
 
when I train with weights I always just train three days a week . at least 24 hours between rest and I do 5x5 programs and only use barbells.

Who was the most ignorant person you have ever met in America?
 
Like someone who doesn’t know what year the Declaration of Independence was signed or how many states there are making up America.
The two most ignorant American persons I have met were two ladies visiting Kiruna in Sweden. They were there to see the midnight sun.
 
Comes midnight, and the ladies asked where this midnight sun was. I was a bit perplexed, but pointed at the sun, still up but low over the horizon. “It’s over there.”
 
“But that’s the regular sun.”
 
“What did you expect” I said amused, “a second sun that only comes up at midnight?”
 
“Yes!” they said.
 
When I realised they were not joking, I took a deep breath and explained that the thing with the midnight sun is that the sun never drops below the horizon, it’s 24 hours of daylight. So it’s still up at midnight.
 
And they just wouldn’t grasp it! They couldn’t get it even when I used a tennis ball to demonstrate. Eventually I just gave up.
 
All other Americans that I have met, including in the US, have mostly been intelligent and friendly, but nobody came even close to these two ladies in sheer ignorance.

I am British and live in the UK; my only real experience of America itself has been New England - Massachusetts, New Hampshire and Maine - where I have friends that I visit from time to time. I was delighted to find that most of the people in that region did not conform to the stereotypical view the rest of the world holds about Americans being uneducated and insular. Sadly, however, the same cannot be said of many Americans from other parts of the USA and I saw most examples of this when I worked at a major UK airport. For example: an American (from Texas) I encountered during the course of my work asked me where to find his baggage. I asked where he had arrived from and he replied “Maleyga, Spain”. Ignoring his mispronunciation of Málaga, I asked him if he’d been there on vacation and it emerged that, in fact, he had been working there for some 2½ years. I asked him if, perhaps, he hadn’t noticed that the local people called it “Málaga rather than “Maleyga” - his reply: “Sure, but that’s ‘cos they’re like all Mexicans, too lazy to learn proper English ….” I was unable to resist a face-palm, and I walked off, leaving him to find his own luggage.

title: Is a full body workout two or three times a week as effective as a split routine working out 5 or 6 days a week? How do I get the best results possible with the least time invested?
article:
I’m echoing some other points here, but for beginning lifters in the first year or two of their fitness journey, a full body workout three times a week is a solid program, assuming that you can stick with it. During those first couple of years, you’ll learn a variety of exercises that you can add or swap in for different muscle groups periodically.
 
After your beginning stage, if you’re interested in developing a well-rounded physique, I don’t think that either full body workouts or the once-per-week “bro” split are optimal. I’m not saying that you can’t get results from these types of programs,
Continue Reading
I’m echoing some other points here, but for beginning lifters in the first year or two of their fitness journey, a full body workout three times a week is a solid program, assuming that you can stick with it. During those first couple of years, you’ll learn a variety of exercises that you can add or swap in for different muscle groups periodically.
 
After your beginning stage, if you’re interested in developing a well-rounded physique, I don’t think that either full body workouts or the once-per-week “bro” split are optimal. I’m not saying that you can’t get results from these types of programs, it’s just that, given your desire to get “the best results possible,” you’ll get more from an upper/lower or push/pull/legs split. The reason for this is that you need too much volume/sets to perform your entire workout in one session with a high level of energy, but you’ll need to hit each muscle group more than once per week if you want to continue steady gains in strength and size. You can use your exercise knowledge to choose movements that give you the most “bang for your buck” or help you focus on body parts for added/quicker development.

This one I was told by my father and dates back to the ‘60s.
 
He was a researcher on high power cables at a major Italian manufacturer, actually one of the technological leaders, especially in the field of submarine cables (none of the leaders was American at the time).
 
During a business trip in the USA in the mid ‘60s he engaged in some small talk with a group of American businessmen, I can’t remember if it was at his hotel or at an airport. Hearing that he was Italian and working in the field of electric power they made some questions and were surprised to hear that electricity was available at almost all homes in the country, and in all western Europe, including small mountain villages and little islands. One commented that it must have been such big change in his (my father’s) life when the Americans brought electricity “after the war” (meaning WW2). It was hard for my father to convince them that Italy pioneered hydro power in Europe in the late 19th century and that the first thermal powerhouse in Europe (the fourth in the world) went in operation in his hometown. He still remembers how skeptically they took his words.

She seemed surprised and told me that there are no slaves in Georgia and that the suggestion was probably just communism. That turned the conversation to the USSR/Russia. I made the mistake of mentioning the CCCP and she had trouble grasping why a country would come up with two different names. She

It’s a close race with many contenders. One that comes to mind is a woman that I met on a ferry crossing the English Channel. She was telling me about the beautiful old buildings in her home town, Savannah, Georgia. I made a passing remark about them being a product of the once booming slave trade. She seemed surprised and told me that there are no slaves in Georgia and that the suggestion was probably just communism. That turned the conversation to the USSR/Russia. I made the mistake of mentioning the CCCP and she had trouble grasping why a country would come up with two different names. She also told me that America had stopped the Russians from buying Cuba because they weren’t allowed to come that close to the USA. I pointed out that they were less than 100 miles from Alaska, which Russia sold to America. She was shocked. 
so was I, but for different reasons. She was actually quite bright and engaging and I had trouble reconciling that with her ignorance. She knew much more about European art than she did about her own country’s history and geography. She has since told me that she is still mortified by how little she knew then.

Sometimes I cannot even afford food, have to eat from gurudwaras or One roti worth 5rs and have to spend whole day on it. My colleagues try to show mercy on me, in a humiliating way, Hurts a lot.
 Talk about Internet being cheap.
 
All my struggle is for that one day when I will make my parents proud of me, and proving the world wrong, Showing that someone can be that successful after being thrown from home. That One Day!
 
So yes, I am poor, very very poor.

About 1990 I was in the US for tourism for some months.
 
I was staying in youth (backpacker) hostels so meeting a lot of other foreigners. I had a car and knew my way around Fullerton, Orange County, which us foreigners just considered a bit of LA close to Disneyland that had a hostel.
 
So one day I was with an English guy from the hostel and went to a chain burger place I liked. Americans being the friendly lot they are, at least in this area, would often start chatting to us. This time it was a local girl about university age. In fact we were walking distance from UCLA. She became intrigued with our accents. Part of the conversation went like this:
 
She: Where are you guys from?
 
Me: Australia.
 
He: I’m from England.
 
… just a couple of other long forgotten other questions …
 
She: You both speak English so well! What language do you speak at home?
 
Aussies who travel are kind of used to this. But asking somebody you’ve just been told is from England what their home language is?!
 
Me: Australia is a former British colony and England is where the name of the English language comes from.
 
She: Oh yeah… giggles…

I just stood there with my mouth agape, my mind unable to come to terms with what emotion I should display. It was a mixture of wanting to laugh and cry at the same time, wanting to be angry and wanting to say “you are kidding right” at the same time.

i have to agree with Dan Hunter, bread really makes the sandwich. growing up in the ’70s and ’80s in the south (U.S.) eating commercial white bread, i didn’t really understand that, but now i do.
 
i remember the first couple of times traveling to spain and seeing sandwiches everywhere, a thin baguette with just a tiny bit of ham and cheese and thinking what nerve they had calling that a sandwich and charging that kind of price.
 
because i was thinking in the subway/blimpie frame of mind — what you put on the bread is what you’re paying for and the spanish sandwiches looked pretty skimpy on the fillings.
 
it didn’t take me long to realize the bread was a key element of the sandwich, versus being simply a carrier for the filling. it was eye-opening.
 
good bread is really the most essential part of a sandwich, and it depends on the sandwich, as well! for example, sometimes even the lowly loaf of white bread is just the right thing for a certain type of sandwich. just as a hearty slice of rye is perfect for others.
 
my second favorite sandwich ingredient is probably … … … this is tough … … … i’m going to go with ham.

title: How should my weekly gym workout be?
article:
Here are some recommendations for a well-rounded weekly gym workout routine:
2-3 days of strength training, focusing on compound exercises that work multiple muscle groups like squats, deadlifts, bench press, pull-ups, etc. Aim for 3-4 sets of 8-12 reps per exercise.
2-3 days of cardiovascular exercise like running, cycling, rowing, or swimming. Aim for 30-60 minutes per session at a moderate to high intensity.
1-2 days of lower-impact exercise like yoga, Pilates, or light jogging/walking to allow for recovery.
Be sure to allow for 1-2 rest days per week where you do light activity or no exercise

Here are some recommendations for a well-rounded weekly gym workout routine:
2-3 days of strength training, focusing on compound exercises that work multiple muscle groups like squats, deadlifts, bench press, pull-ups, etc. Aim for 3-4 sets of 8-12 reps per exercise.
2-3 days of cardiovascular exercise like running, cycling, rowing, or swimming. Aim for 30-60 minutes per session at a moderate to high intensity.
1-2 days of lower-impact exercise like yoga, Pilates, or light jogging/walking to allow for recovery.
Be sure to allow for 1-2 rest days per week where you do light activity or no exercise at all. This is important for muscle recovery and injury prevention.
Vary the exercises, rep ranges, and intensity from workout to workout to continually challenge your body and avoid plateaus.
Don't forget to properly warm-up before each session and cool down/stretch afterwards.
The specific exercises and time allotments can be adjusted based on your fitness level, goals, and available time. The key is to have a balanced routine that hits all the major muscle groups and incorporates both strength and cardiovascular training.

title: Is a morning gym workout better than an evening gym workout?
article:
A morning workout is useful if one is looking to burn calories. A longer gap between the last meal and the workout, combined with more available oxygen if the workout is in a ventilated area or outdoors all help burn calories. It's also useful in pumping freshly oxygenated blood to the brain, first thing in the morning and in getting the fitness objective ticked on your checklist.
 
An evening workout is useful to build on a somewhat warmed up body and to remove the stress of the day's routine. It takes a different meal time adjustment from the person going for a morning workout. The cool down ph
Continue Reading
A morning workout is useful if one is looking to burn calories. A longer gap between the last meal and the workout, combined with more available oxygen if the workout is in a ventilated area or outdoors all help burn calories. It's also useful in pumping freshly oxygenated blood to the brain, first thing in the morning and in getting the fitness objective ticked on your checklist.
 
An evening workout is useful to build on a somewhat warmed up body and to remove the stress of the day's routine. It takes a different meal time adjustment from the person going for a morning workout. The cool down phase of the workout needs to be longer/slower in an evening workout since the air temperature tends to cool the body faster. (Not applicable if one works out in an air conditioned gym.) This is also useful for those whose routines involve late nights.
 
As an aside, the key to waking early is to eat 2 hours or more before hitting bed. Sleeping on a full stomach tends to restrict proper digestion and affects oxidation (burning) of food. This causes reduced oxygen in the blood and the brain suffers from grogginess by the morning.

This, unfortunately, was more than one but all with the same issue. For several summers I worked in a museum gift shop in a small town in Canada, near the US border. They all assumed it would be snowing and freezing cold in southern Canada- in August! We’re farther south than than mos northern parts of Maine, but okay! Even if you don’ t know a lot about Canada….wouldn’t you at least look up what to wear while there? Our national animal is a beaver, not a polar bear! Even the farthest inhabited areas are still quite warm in summer!

title: Is a full body workout two or three times a week as effective as a split routine working out 5 or 6 days a week? How do I get the best results possible with the least time invested?
article:
Conventional wisdom says beginners should do full body workouts 2–3 days a week and advanced lifters should do splits.
 
My lifting “career” however has gone the other way around. As a teenager I was influenced by bodybuilding magazines and always tried to train like the pros, which meant splits, going to the gym five times a week and training different muscle groups on each day.
 
These days, in my late thirties, I do mostly full body workouts. When you have a family and a job, you don’t have a lot of time to train and the reality is that you will skip workouts. For this reason, I always do full bo
Continue Reading
Conventional wisdom says beginners should do full body workouts 2–3 days a week and advanced lifters should do splits.
 
My lifting “career” however has gone the other way around. As a teenager I was influenced by bodybuilding magazines and always tried to train like the pros, which meant splits, going to the gym five times a week and training different muscle groups on each day.
 
These days, in my late thirties, I do mostly full body workouts. When you have a family and a job, you don’t have a lot of time to train and the reality is that you will skip workouts. For this reason, I always do full body although I try to accentuate certain muscle groups.
 
As an individual, you need to consider that theory isn’t everything. For me, a full body workout gives me so much more satisfaction, as I get a feeling of all around tiredness and I feel like I’ve done something good for the whole body. When I do get sore it feels so much more natural. Having only sore arms for example feels kind of weird. I prefer an overall feeling of slight soreness.
 
My advice is to just do what feels right to you and keeps you motivated.

My advice is to just do what feels right to you and keeps you motivated.

“Excuse me, do you have any Asprin”
 
The reply:
 
“Oh My God, You’re an African American Englishman!”

I guess it’s kinda sweet that she was trying to be sensitive or politically correct but it is totally ignorant.

title: How long will it take to get big if doing full body workouts every day with heavy weights?
article:
I like where your head is at.
 
After my son was born, I switched to a full body 3x/ week routine down from a 5 day bro split.
 
This way if I was exhausted because my son decided he didn’t want me sleeping, I could still hit each muscle twice a week.
 
For the natty guy, frequency and volume are going to be your best friends. But don’t go crazy, you still need to recover. 
Research shows
 2-3x a week is sufficient assuming you are working hard in the gym.
 
If you’re going to go with a full body routine, leave a rest day between each workout.
 
Your schedule might look something like this:
 
Monday: 
Workout 1
 
Tuesday:
 Rest
 
Wednesday:
 Workout 2
 
Thursday: 
Rest
 
Friday:
 Workout 3
 
Saturday and Sunday: 
Rest
 
You could add another workout on Sunday but then you’d have a weird rotating schedule and always be askin’ “Is today a workout day?”
 
If your schedule has you working out on back-to-back days you’d have to get fancy with exercise selection on the first of the back-to-back days so you’d be ready to go the following day.
 
For example, I wouldn’t give you a ton of cable flyes on the first day then have you do a heavy bench on the second. Your chest would be toast and you’d lift like shit.
 
In that instance I’d go with a Full Body/Upper/Lower. Again, it comes down to whatever motivates you and your schedule. Neither option is better than the other.
 
With these, your schedule might look something like this:
 
Monday:
 Full Body
 
Tuesday: 
Rest
 
Wednesday:
 Rest
 
Thursday:
 Lower
 
Friday: 
Upper <–Biceps on Friday. Always go into the weekend with an arm pump.
 
Saturday and Sunday:
 Rest
 
So with that being said, here’s a template you can use.
 
For more daily workout tips, follow me on 
Instagram
.

I have a friend who is always bashing the idea of capitalism, complaining that the rich are too rich, and how they are always stealing from us poor people.
 
We were heading to a wedding, I realized I forgot to pack my dress shoes. I told him I had to stop and buy some. He asked where, and I saw a sign for Walmart, so that’s where I turned.

I’m not sure this answer’s your question, but I love telling this story.
 
I have a friend who is always bashing the idea of capitalism, complaining that the rich are too rich, and how they are always stealing from us poor people.
 
We were heading to a wedding, I realized I forgot to pack my dress shoes. I told him I had to stop and buy some. He asked where, and I saw a sign for Walmart, so that’s where I turned.
 
He through a hissy fit. He had never set foot in a Walmart on principle. He ordered me not to buy anything from Walmart. He told me they were evil. He told me they sold goods made by children being paid in pennies. He told me they were only interested in profit.
 
I looked at him and said, “Are you serious? Tell me one store that’s not interested in making a profit.”
 
He followed me in, grudgingly. Then he looked around. He saw the same things he bought at other stores, but at better prices. He was impressed with the selection, He ended up buying a few things he needed, because the prices were so good.
 
I guess that’s what happens when you go into a store that’s only in it for the money.

Cause I just thought I could and should of been doing 5–6 workouts a week. The mind pump guys shared this also and said they started making a lot of progress themselves when they did 3 full

I recently followed the Mind pump guys on YouTube. Very smart longtime personal trainers and simalar experience as me in my career. I was doing bro split workouts forever and often fighting plateaus for my own progress. Yet I was often doing 2–3 full body workouts for my clients cause it fit best with their schedules and they were having great success with that. Why didn't I apply that to my own program???? Cause I just thought I could and should of been doing 5–6 workouts a week. The mind pump guys shared this also and said they started making a lot of progress themselves when they did 3 full body workouts a week. By hitting each muscle 3 times a week but giving your body more rest overall allows more muscle growth. Also I used to waste a lot of time working on isolation exercises and wasn't doing much the second half of the workouts anyways I still do a little mobility, stretching and walking on off days. I have made a lot of progress and the effort throughout the week is much less. It's crazy! With that being said it's still good to switch it up. I'll do an upper/lower or push/pull/legs split time to time.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
When I was in 4th grade I got into an argument with another kid over whether or not One Thousand and Ten Hundred were in fact the same number. I said they were, they said they were not. A 6th grade girl was nearby so I asked her so she could set this guy straight. She looked at me and said “they’re not the same number”. I was too flabbergast to respond with anything other than indignation. Still burns me up.
 
Later in 8th grade in Science class there was a top-down diagram of a car traveling forward (to the right) and arrows pointing out the window at 10, 11, 12, 1, and 2 o’clock. The teacher as
Continue Reading
When I was in 4th grade I got into an argument with another kid over whether or not One Thousand and Ten Hundred were in fact the same number. I said they were, they said they were not. A 6th grade girl was nearby so I asked her so she could set this guy straight. She looked at me and said “they’re not the same number”. I was too flabbergast to respond with anything other than indignation. Still burns me up.
 
Later in 8th grade in Science class there was a top-down diagram of a car traveling forward (to the right) and arrows pointing out the window at 10, 11, 12, 1, and 2 o’clock. The teacher asked “if you threw a ball out the window of the car which path would it take” by show of hands. A couple kids raised their hands for 10, more at 11, a couple at 12 and just me at 1. I got laughed at and tried to explain that it would really be more like 12:30 and that the momentum of the car would still be influencing the ball’s trajectory once released. The teacher flat out told me I was wrong and to put hand down and shut up. :(
 
Is it any wonder that we Americans are so ignorant compared to other countries :’(

title: Is a full body workout two or three times a week as effective as a split routine working out 5 or 6 days a week? How do I get the best results possible with the least time invested?
article:
I encourage a 4-day upper/lower split as a better option personally but if you really want to do a 5-day routine instead of 4 that has a 2x a week frequency per muscle group then you just move one upper/lower split to a push-pull-legs approach.
 
It’s pretty simple to execute but harder for most to adhere to, which is why I usually don’t bother. You can get enough volume with a 4-day upper/lower split, you’re just distributing 2 days into 3 shorter days.

 - Upper

- Upper Push

- Upper Pull
Or whatever variation of that you prefer.

I encourage a 4-day upper/lower split as a better option personally but if you really want to do a 5-day routine instead of 4 that has a 2x a week frequency per muscle group then you just move one upper/lower split to a push-pull-legs approach.
 
It’s pretty simple to execute but harder for most to adhere to, which is why I usually don’t bother. You can get enough volume with a 4-day upper/lower split, you’re just distributing 2 days into 3 shorter days.

Tues
 - Upper
Wed 
- Lower
Thur 
- Upper Push
Fri 
- Upper Pull
Or whatever variation of that you prefer.
 
Some people find this psychologically comforting or something, I assume because it aligns with their work week and they love going to the gym after work every day or before work every day consistently. I don’t know … I do know almost every time a client of mine insists on doing this within 3–6 months they invariably fall back to upper/lower 4x a week instead.
 
There isn’t much of an advantage in lifting 5x a week over 4x a week in my view, so save yourself one trip a week or do some cardio is usually what I tell people.

During the southern summer / northern winter, midnight in Brisbane occurs when it is is 9am in New York and 6am in LA. Brisbane is 15–18 hours ahead. In the late 1990s I was living in Australia and used to play a lot of backgammon on yahoo, which also included functionality to chat to your opponents in text.
 
I was shocked to find the number of American players who did not understand time zones. During the southern summer / northern winter, midnight in Brisbane occurs when it is is 9am in New York and 6am in LA. Brisbane is 15–18 hours ahead. So if I am playing an American at night, the game probably started after midnight for me and would be dragging into the early hours of the morning.
 
This fact often came up in conversation when I’d have to refuse a request for a rematch, y’know, cos it’s 3am or something, so I’d explain that where I was it was early morning in the following day and had to go. The reaction I got was often either astonishment or disbelief.
 
I’d ask something to the effect of “Are you not aware of the existence of time zones and the fact that it is not the same time everywhere in the world at once?” To this I would get the inevitable response “Of course I know about time zones, but they only make a difference of a few hours.”

‘Could I have half a pound of potato wedges please.’

‘About eight ounces. Doesn’t have to be exact. An ounce or two either way is fine.’
 
More problems understanding what I want. Then I realize. Their weighing/pricing machine displays

Sadly, this isn’t just one unique and ‘special’ individual. It is a common occurrence - try it yourself and see.
 
So, there I was, at the local supermarket (this applies in pretty much any supermarket). I’m feeling peckish and decide to treat myself to some comfort food. I go to the hot food counter and ask
 
‘Could I have half a pound of potato wedges please.’
 
This bamboozles the person behind the counter. I helpfully say
 
‘About eight ounces. Doesn’t have to be exact. An ounce or two either way is fine.’
 
More problems understanding what I want. Then I realize. Their weighing/pricing machine displays the weight in pounds and a decimal fraction of a pound.
 
The server didn’t know what half a pound translated to as a decimal.
 
To be cruel, you could try asking for 12 ounces. To be sadistic, ask for 11 ounces.
 
I should add that I live in Redmond/Bellevue, WA. Home of Microsoft and many other high tech companies, close to the home of Amazon and other high tech companies, close to Google’s third largest office, and so on. High tech galore, but not so much when ordering potato wedges.

About ten years ago I was in a bar and struck up a conversation with a 20-something girl next to me. I forget exactly how it came up but I said “Well, we all have to die sometime.” She looked at me incredulously and said “No we don’t.”
 
She didn’t know that everyone dies.
 
She said something along the lines of if you get sick or something happens to you yes you can die but that it doesn’t happen to everyone. After coming to grips with her ignorance (by just saying “yes we do” to her “no we don’t” a few times) I countered with “Then why is the oldest person alive like 120 or something?” Her defense to that argument boiled down to no one born before 1900 had managed to avoid all the calamities that can cause death, but that didn’t mean that we were destined to die.
 
I’m guessing this was a parenting fail, like when she was first exposed to death and got scared her parents mollified her by saying not everyone dies. And it’s not like there’s a unit in Social Studies called “You’re gonna die.” Still though, for an adult not to understand that essential truth blows my mind every time I think about it.

I’m an American, and I get pretty peeved by the utter stupidity of some of our inhabitants.
 
Let’s roll the tape, shall we?
 
1) Someone asked me where Sweden was located on the world map.
 
2) Some people like to generalize all white people as being the same: snobby, former slave-owners, uncaring. This especially applies to people with deep anti-white sentiments.
 
3) I was on AirBerlin once on a flight inbound to New York City, and when lunch came, an American mom with her family said out loud, “OH LOOK, BLUEBERRY PIE,” when it clearly was a plum pie. Imbecile.
 
4) A lot of people in my AP US History class do not know all 50 states and their locations.
 
5) 75% of my friend’s AP World History Class does not know what Brexit is.
 
The list goes on and on.
 
I don’t blame for some Americans for being completely oblivious when it comes to new experiences or what goes on in the world today— we’re bred to be ignorant. I’m sure that if my family had deep roots in the United States (my family immigrated from Poland in 1995), and if I wasn’t an inquisitive person, I’d be pretty ignorant, too.

I am from Panama, but lived for years in the US. Over the years I lived in the us (10+) I have both made some great friends, and met some ignorant people.
 
Apart from the traditional questions (“Is Panama in Africa?”, “Does the Panama Canal have anything to do with Panama?”, “Do you have [cars/TV/internet/etc] in Panama?”, etc.), the one that took the cake was a lady back in the 90’s attending at Nordstrom. She heard me and my roommate (an Ecuadorian) talking in Spanish…
 
“Where are you from?”she asked
 
“Panama” I replied.
 
“Oh, Panama… Is it true that everyone lives in a palm tree down there?” she said
 
“Sure. Of course it is true” I answered sarcastically, while giving my roommate a WTF look.
 
“But, HOW do you get up there” she continued…
 
I looked at her now totally perplexed and answered the first thing that popped into my mind…
 
“ELEVATORS!” I said
 
By the way, for those of you who cannot picture Panama City (the one in Central America, not the one in Florida), here is a picture of the city I was born and raised in:
As you can see, we do not exactly live atop palm trees…
 
:-)

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
It's a toss up between the numerous Americans who don't realise Australian is an English-speaking country and a girl I met on a tour many years ago who didn't realise America was significantly older than Australia in terms of colonisation.
 
It was 1993, and we were in Europe and I was marvelling at the architecture and the idea that people had been walking cobbled streets for a millennium or more. I said to her in terms of buildings and architecture that Aus was a baby in comparison, being just over 200 years old (First Fleet was 1788) so we didn't have that same sense of history in terms of anc
Continue Reading
It's a toss up between the numerous Americans who don't realise Australian is an English-speaking country and a girl I met on a tour many years ago who didn't realise America was significantly older than Australia in terms of colonisation.
 
It was 1993, and we were in Europe and I was marvelling at the architecture and the idea that people had been walking cobbled streets for a millennium or more. I said to her in terms of buildings and architecture that Aus was a baby in comparison, being just over 200 years old (First Fleet was 1788) so we didn't have that same sense of history in terms of ancient roads, buildings and artifacts. She replied the US was the same, only dating to 1776.
 
We were 22 and I had never studied American history, so I tentatively mentioned Columbus and the Spanish, and then said, “And weren't you a British colony before that (meaning 1776)?”Her response? “Oh, were we?” I asked her if she celebrated Independence Day. And she did. I have no idea what she thought she was celebrating on July 4th…
 
I found it odd that she didn't know such a basic piece of her country's history.

title: Which 3 exercises would give me the most complete workout?

Since no weight lifting routine can cover the whole body in just 3 exercises, its much easier to look at some body weight movements that will range the gamut.
 
The first one is skipping rope. This involves both your upper and lower body, getting the ankles and knees going along with the shoulders and wrists too. There is also a cardio and balance element that is excellent as well.
 
The second would be crunches while prone. Raising your arms from straight over your head while flexing at the knees involves all of the extremities while also getting in some core work too.
 
The last one would have to be toe touches if you are able. Again, the feet and legs have to form a solid base, the back and core are involved while the arms and shoulders reach their full potential limit.
 
You will get a solid workout in less than 20 minutes time.
 
Get even more great FREE weight loss advice at http://getslimandsexy.com

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
While visiting the states I came across the usual group of people who were unsure of where various European countries were. But there are probably a lot of Europeans who couldn't place American states - so ok, no big deal.
 
But my strangest experience went like this:
 
Me: So what sort of relationship do you guys have with Canada?
 
Other: Fine. Why do you ask?
 
Me: Well, it's a different country.
 
Other: No, it's not.
 
Me: (Taken aback). Well it's on the American continent, but it's a different country.
 
Other: No, it's part of the USA.
 
Me: (Not knowing what to say). Ummmm. I don't mean Alaska. I mean Canada.
 
Continue Reading
While visiting the states I came across the usual group of people who were unsure of where various European countries were. But there are probably a lot of Europeans who couldn't place American states - so ok, no big deal.
 
But my strangest experience went like this:
 
Me: So what sort of relationship do you guys have with Canada?
 
Other: Fine. Why do you ask?
 
Me: Well, it's a different country.
 
Other: No, it's not.
 
Me: (Taken aback). Well it's on the American continent, but it's a different country.
 
Other: No, it's part of the USA.
 
Me: (Not knowing what to say). Ummmm. I don't mean Alaska. I mean Canada.
 
Other: Just a minute, I'll ask my friends.
 
To my utter amazement his friends backed him up!
 
I still don't know if they were seriously confused or they were pulling my leg.
 
I would like to mentione that during all the conversation everyone was polite friendly and agreeable - indeed this was my impression of most Americans I met.
 
In fairness I should also mention that I have had conversations about the UK while living in Spain which are almost as bizarre.

One that sticks in my mind was a woman who was coming to the UK (I was an immigration officer at Heathrow airport, in the early 90s) as the dependent wife of a man who was with the US forces.
 
However, as the stamp, conditions and length of stay granted depended on what exactly their role was (army officer, civilian staff, contractor etc) I had to ask some more questions to establish what he did in the UK.
 
She seemed to not know anything about his job etc, so after several questions, and getting more and more exasperated, I asked ‘Well, does he work for NATO?” to which she replied, inevitably, ‘what’s NATO?”.
 
Maybe that doesn’t sound so stupid in comparison to other remarks, but bear in mind that she was coming to the UK for a number of years, and her entry was entirely dependent on her husband, yet she didn’t have a clue what he did, where he worked, or even who he worked for.
 
I think in the end he was waiting for her downstairs, and it got sorted. He should have provided her a letter which said “I am very stupid and don’t know anything, All the details you will need are written below”.

I don’t understand not being able to identify a green cabbage on sight, but working at a grocery store in a checkout line and not knowing a cabbage when you see one is pretty bad.
 
Another woman who worked in my office at the time asked me if England was part of Germany. She wanted to know because she had to m

I can’t say either of these people qualify as the most ignorant person in America, but sometimes a person will ask me a question that shocks me.
 
Once a woman checked me out at a grocery store and she asked me what vegetable I had so she could find the code. It was an ordinary green cabbage. I don’t understand not being able to identify a green cabbage on sight, but working at a grocery store in a checkout line and not knowing a cabbage when you see one is pretty bad.
 
Another woman who worked in my office at the time asked me if England was part of Germany. She wanted to know because she had to make an international call for one of the engineers and she already knew the country code for Germany.
 
Questions like this make me long for the conversation of someone who just doesn’t know what year the Declaration of Independence was signed.
 
My husband cheerfully answers questions like this without hesitation, but I hesitate because it confuses me that people have the jobs they have and don’t know these things. I think they can’t possibly be asking me the question I heard. But yes, they are.

Vertical climbing.
Excellent for cardio
Low-impact (much needed for me after years of abusing my knees playing basketball on asphalt — a wonder that I don't have a torn ACL)
Hits up nearly all of the major muscle groups, in both the lower and upper body
Can stay at home to do it, and vertical climber machines are fairly easy to transport, depending on the brand and type you get
The vertical climber I have is a MaxiClimber XL-2000. Hands-down the best investment I've made for my physical health, and extremely thankful for getting it pre-COVID, since I have zero plans for paying for a gym membership again.

So we shook and you know what happened? He gave me tip and nobody saw that. It was 30 dollars and it was really big to me. That was a nice impression that I had with American.

I have a friend from California. Not the ignorant type at all, honestly. But she does not know a thing about Canada. Nothing. When I asked her to name the provinces of Canada, she came up with Ontario, Quebec, Montreal, Saskatoon, and something like Watasatchewan. I also was having a discussion with her about universities, and when discussing the possibility of me attending the University of Victoria, she asked where it was located. Logically it’s in Victoria. But she had no clue. So I led her on. Told her it was in the middle of the Northwest Territories. Accessibly only by ice road. And she believed me. She said it was sad how isolated it must be for people who attended it. She only started doubting when I told her there were polar bear races there.
 
She’s also a serious football fan, but had never heard of the Canadian Football League or the Grey Cup, one of the oldest pro sports trophies in North America. The existence of football in Canada shocked her, but she also thought Canadians didn’t watch the Super Bowl. She’s a great friend, but the ignorance about Canada always makes me laugh.

I didn't meet ignorant Americans, I must admit. In the US, I met, say, rather stubborn people with their minds made up about something they never experienced themselves, having only read about it in books, and who would be relentless in holding on their particular opinion. But that is not contingent upon nationality - one can meet people like this everywhere. Surprisingly, these people were either academics or educated people, and never “blue collars” - well, that thing they call "Ivory Tower” is called so for a reason. I am Russian from Russia, born and raised, and when they asked me about Russia and I would answer they would be trying to prove me wrong because they had read some obscure book on the topic or watched the news regularly.
 
Also, well-traveled Americans maybe somewhat more likely to make biased assumptions, since they have been to other countries they tend to think they are knowledgeable about the world. For example, a person who was an avid traveler and who also visited Russia asked me at a reception if I knew what a watermelon was when I reached for a fruit salad plate.

Dear 
Smh

I am a big proponent of the sport of Powerlifting three times a week. If you do it right, you gain terrific strength, build plenty of muscle, lose body fat, correct your posture, build some powerful legs, strengthen your core, build slabs of muscle on your back, shoulders and gain an industrial-vise Grip strength. Do you like that?
 
If so, look for a plan of action, three times a week training (not working out) with the barbell squats in one day, a couple of days later with the deadlifts and after a couple of days of rest training with overhead pressing, then repeat endlessly!. You can also mix it up with more cardio conditioning another day when not lifting weights (active recovery).
 
Your work ethics, nutritional and recovery ability will produce the results.
 
Thank you

Medical Doctor, a Strength Training coach and common-sense specialist
 before doing anything you may read in some of my answers.

title: How should my weekly gym workout be?
article:
No. If you are going to the gym “always”, you're surely wasting your time, fooling around or working out with a less than optimal intensity which would lead to no results at all.
 
Exercises, and more precisely strength exercise, must be intense. You really have to push your limits to force your body to adapt and get stronger.
 
If you workout with this level of intensity, you MUST let your body rest and recover from the beating. You must eat and sleep properly to let the body “heal” and get stronger. At least, you must let it rest for a whole day before attempting to punish it again.
 
Your body is li
Continue Reading
No. If you are going to the gym “always”, you're surely wasting your time, fooling around or working out with a less than optimal intensity which would lead to no results at all.
 
Exercises, and more precisely strength exercise, must be intense. You really have to push your limits to force your body to adapt and get stronger.
 
If you workout with this level of intensity, you MUST let your body rest and recover from the beating. You must eat and sleep properly to let the body “heal” and get stronger. At least, you must let it rest for a whole day before attempting to punish it again.
 
Your body is like a plant that needs a certain amount of water and time to grow. Watering it twice a day won't make it grow faster.
 
If you're spending more than an hour a day working out, you're not doing it right. Focus on compound exercises (the most basic ones, those who work many muscles at once). Three exercises, four at most. One push + one pull + one leg exercise. And when performing each exercise, you must crush it. Work all the way to muscle failure. You can be done in 30 minutes.

 leave Romania in the mid-1990s, so okay, I decided the question wasn't so absurd and explained that he had left after the fall of Communism in that country. She whispered to me, wide-eyed, “Romania isn’t a Communist country?”
 
I’ve never had the courage to ask her what she thinks about East Germany or Czechoslovakia.
Edited to add: My mother and I are visiting this family. From today,
 
My mother: The United Kingdom is made up of Wales, England, Scotland, and Northern Island.
 
Relative: Just Northern Ireland, not Southern Ireland?
 
…
 
My mother: So you see here, inscribed on the side of a pound coin, is something in Welsh, the language of Wales.
 
Relative: Wales has a language?!
I will just say that you don’t have to be competent at geography to have a kind heart. :)

His English was acquired primarily in New Zealand, and he still has a trace of that accent. Besides being fluent in English, he’s conversational in French and German.

The following happened to a Korean friend of mine, Mr. M., a very witty, erudite fellow who has lived in multiple countries and has been a professor of (European) history in the US for some time. His English was acquired primarily in New Zealand, and he still has a trace of that accent. Besides being fluent in English, he’s conversational in French and German.
 
About twenty years ago, Mr. M was spending some time in Seoul with his parents, because he had just finished his Army service and was waiting for a new visa to return to California to complete his doctorate. His parents were fairly lenient about letting him while away the days in various cafes, where he’d content himself reading Nietzsche or Sartre (in English).
 
Anyhow, one day Mr. M. was sitting in an Arby’s in Seoul, reading, when a classically Midwestern, Ugly American couple approached him. In a loud, braying voice, the man asked him,
 
“Excuse me, do you speak Oriental?”
 
Whereupon my friend, without missing a beat, gazed up at the rube and replied, in his silkiest, most Oxonian tone, “No. Do you speak Caucasian?”

article:

This sort of training is especially recommended to people after joint surgeries to maintain and/or rebuilt their muscles. For instance, people after knee surgeries are exercising their quadriceps muscles by simple contractions of the said muscle. Their knees are fully extended and they perform and/or hold contractions.

Continue Reading
The answer is yes you can.
 
Isometric training is how. You contract muscles but don’t move your joints.
 
This sort of training is especially recommended to people after joint surgeries to maintain and/or rebuilt their muscles. For instance, people after knee surgeries are exercising their quadriceps muscles by simple contractions of the said muscle. Their knees are fully extended and they perform and/or hold contractions.
 
It’s not perfect as they need to exercise in that way much longer compared with someone who would do a couple of squads but it’s nonetheless effective in maintaining and rebuilding musculature.
 
Also, the progression is rather limited. Training your muscles in this way will shape them and make them generally stronger, but training isn’t all about strength and endurance. It’s also about function, coordination and multi-joint activation. Isometric exercise won’t make you much more functional per se.
 
However since you asked only about getting muscles the answer is yes it is possible to get toned and strong muscles without any resistance training.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
It really has nothing to do with knowledge… ignorance is a mindset. I live in ‘America,’ and I’ve met my share of ignorant people, but the first person I’ve met who totally fit the bill was when I was in Canada, of all places, in Waterton National Park.
 
Back in the 1970s, our family vacationed in the Glacier/Waterton area. I was photographing a particularly friendly chipmunk when a man approached. “Amazing, isn’t it?”
 
“Yep,” I replied, scanning the near-overwhelming beauty of the mountains that surrounded us, “it sure is beautiful.”
 
“Not that. It’s amazing that all this was created only 7,542 (I’

It really has nothing to do with knowledge… ignorance is a mindset. I live in ‘America,’ and I’ve met my share of ignorant people, but the first person I’ve met who totally fit the bill was when I was in Canada, of all places, in Waterton National Park.
 
Back in the 1970s, our family vacationed in the Glacier/Waterton area. I was photographing a particularly friendly chipmunk when a man approached. “Amazing, isn’t it?”
 
“Yep,” I replied, scanning the near-overwhelming beauty of the mountains that surrounded us, “it sure is beautiful.”
 
“Not that. It’s amazing that all this was created only 7,542 (I’m guessing here; don't recall the exact date) years ago, by God’s hand.”
 
I was stunned. How on Earth could anyone believe such drivel in an age of so much information? I asked him then, “If that’s so, where did the dinosaurs come from?”
 
“They weren’t dinosaurs, they were dragons that God decided couldn’t go on the Ark.”
 
Here’s an otherwise intelligent person who was convinced by others to swallow this bit of silliness.
 
The encounter has stayed with me since then.
