I was getting ready for a road trip and stopped into a grocery store to stock up on snacks and beverages for the road. While I’m waiting in line I hear the checkout clerk talking loudly with the person ahead of me. I heard something like, “I can’t believe you went all the way to Australia, that’s just ridiculous!” It was clear she (the checkout girl) knew the guy (visited Australia sometime recently) and was laying into him for some reason.
 
I’m running through possible reasons that she’d have such a big problem with Australia. Maybe she had a bad experience involving an Aussie, the guy made a trans-Pacific trip for silly reasons, maybe she just doesn’t like spiders and snakes… the list goes on.
 
When I get to the front I ask in the friendliest possible manner, “So, what’s the problem with Australia?”
 
Her reply: “[scoff] I mean, I’m already from America.”
 
I was just kind of stunned and completed the transaction with a mask of disbelief on my face. She literally thought that there was no point to travelling since America was the pinnacle of perfection. Blew. My. Mind.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
Wow, Jeremy, are you reading my mind? This morning I was just having a dialogue in my head regarding education (or lack of), and willful ignorance. My father was born in 1920 and my mother in 1923 in a very poor area of the Appalachlan mountains. Neither one completed elementary school, but each knew the number of states and the year the Declaration of Independence was signed. They both could read and write, do basic math, and acquired an incredible amount of knowledge during the 83 plus years each spent on the planet. Formal education is a wonderful asset, both for an individual and society.

Wow, Jeremy, are you reading my mind? This morning I was just having a dialogue in my head regarding education (or lack of), and willful ignorance. My father was born in 1920 and my mother in 1923 in a very poor area of the Appalachlan mountains. Neither one completed elementary school, but each knew the number of states and the year the Declaration of Independence was signed. They both could read and write, do basic math, and acquired an incredible amount of knowledge during the 83 plus years each spent on the planet. Formal education is a wonderful asset, both for an individual and society. But if a person has a desire to learn, he or she will. And if a person, doesn’t want to learn, well I don’t know if ignorance is bliss, but I fear it may be rampant currently, based on some of the Jay Leno skits and You-tube on-campus videos I’ve seen. I’ve met PhDs and MD’s who struggle with most of us consider “common” knowlege, and I’ve met people who didn’t complete high school who built and ran businesses that generated over a million dollars profit annually on a consistent basis.

He showed up one night, and was on edge about something. I proceeded to call him out on his agitation.

“9/11 was completely faked, the world trade centers never existed.”
 
A
 few kids in the background started to laugh
 
I proceeded to attempt a debate in which he quickly pushed me down. He apologized but not before giving me a lecture on how the world trade centers were holograms placed in our memories to give the NSA an excuse to spy on us.
 
We argued with him for a while, but eventually we stopped talking about the subject. Probably for the best.
 
I suppose his problem was more stupidity than ignorance, but his aggressive behavior was inexcusable.

title: How should my weekly gym workout be?
article:
Diet plays a huge role. In terms of body composition, body fat vs. lean mass, the lion's share of results come from the kitchen.  Don't undersell yourself there, or all the physical work you do with exercise will amount to little more than frustration. 
 
Think of it like home renovations. If you tear apart your house and then rebuild it with the same old materials, you're going to have the same place you did before -- perhaps a little more beat up for the effort. If you want a newer, sharper looking house with better structure, you need to use new, high quality materials. 
 
The renovation is your

Diet plays a huge role. In terms of body composition, body fat vs. lean mass, the lion's share of results come from the kitchen.  Don't undersell yourself there, or all the physical work you do with exercise will amount to little more than frustration. 
 
Think of it like home renovations. If you tear apart your house and then rebuild it with the same old materials, you're going to have the same place you did before -- perhaps a little more beat up for the effort. If you want a newer, sharper looking house with better structure, you need to use new, high quality materials. 
 
The renovation is your exercise, the materials are your food. No sense in beating yourself up without rebuilding properly. 
 
As for the exercise itself: when my clients are pressed for time (and many of them are), but want to lose weight but stay fit, I have them do HIIT -- high intensity interval training. Usually making use of circuits of body weight exercises or using weights. Strength training causes your body to maintain muscle while burning fat, leading to a leaner, more toned physique.

title: How often should I workout for best results?
article:
A great deal depends on your current state of fitness, and what it is you’re trying to accomplish.
 
Pro athletes, Olympic competitors… May spend 4–6 hours in training per day. However, these are elite athletes and all training is done under the watchful eyes of professional coaches and trainers.
 
For the average person who’s in fair-decent shape, most authorities recommend a minimum of 1.5 hours of aerobic exercise per week. That ain’t much…Several half-hour workouts weekly.
 
Much better, if you have the time, is a 45-minute to 0ne hour aerobic workout daily. That’s 10 minutes of warm up, 10 minutes
Continue Reading
A great deal depends on your current state of fitness, and what it is you’re trying to accomplish.
 
Pro athletes, Olympic competitors… May spend 4–6 hours in training per day. However, these are elite athletes and all training is done under the watchful eyes of professional coaches and trainers.
 
For the average person who’s in fair-decent shape, most authorities recommend a minimum of 1.5 hours of aerobic exercise per week. That ain’t much…Several half-hour workouts weekly.
 
Much better, if you have the time, is a 45-minute to 0ne hour aerobic workout daily. That’s 10 minutes of warm up, 10 minutes of cool down, and 35–40 minutes of work with your heart-rate in the “aerobic training” zone.
 
If you’re doing calisthenic/bodyweight training, then a good, full-body workout that takes about an hour 4–5 times a week is decent.
 
If you’re doing weight training, then a full-body workout 3 times a week should take you 1.5 hours or so….. And if you’re more advanced and doing “split” routines, then your 5-times a week (usually) workout should take around an hour.

C

 was very pregnant. I got to know them somewhat well.

was ready to settle down and take care of the child, but 
C 
was not ready to be a parent. He wanted to drink and party while she stayed home. Luckily, she later left him and I imagine she made the right choice for the child. I was thinking one day, 
God, why did they keep it? 
I started a conversation with them about the pregnancy and how they were doing and eventually 
C 
started really talking, and this is what slipped out of his mouth:
 
“I just really wish I hadn't relied on pot seeds as contraception.”
 
“….…What?” I asked incredulously.
 
“Yeah,” he continued, “I heard smoking the seeds made you infertile so we just did that. But here we are!”
 
They kissed and my jaw all but dropped. I have absolutely nothing against teen parents or cannabis, but are you fucking kidding me?
 
This
 is why good sex ed matters.

title: Are there any poor people on Quora, as Internet access is very cheap nowadays?
article:
I am an American, so even being “poor” by American standards seems quite rich to those in middle Asia.

I am an American, so even being “poor” by American standards seems quite rich to those in middle Asia.
 
So scratch the pissing contest.
 
I work for the world's largest corporation (by revenue), Walmart. My monthly take home pay is around $900/mo.
 
Rent, for starters, is $495/mo. This is for a cheap one bedroom apartment in a particularly bad part of town, where there is significant amounts of crime. I always carry a knife with me day or night because of the ever-present risk of criminal assault to myself. Utilities are a bit more, at $150/mo for light usage. Groceries run about $150/mo for a lot of high-calorie, low-nutrition crap that sucks and can easily make you fat while failing to properly provide nutrients. My mobile costs $63/mo for service ($45) + monthly financing ($17) for the mobile itself.
 
Now, this would seem to eat all my pay, but I live with my parents to pay only half of the stated utilities and rent.
 
If I lived on my own… I might not be able to afford it due to the variability of my pay. It is often less (up to $300 less per month.)

As others say, you don’t need many.
 
There are 4 basic movements:
Lower body push
 (squat)
I do mostly low bar squats, but you can squat high bar if you prefer. I also do paused (2 count) squats as a lighter variant. Front squat, overhead squat, leg press, split squat, lunge are all usable variants as well.
Lower body pull
 (deadlift)
I do conventional deadlifts. I also do snatch-grip deadlift as a lighter variant and rack pull as a heavier one. You can also do Romanian DL, clean or snatch grip high pull or Olympic lift (clean,snatch) variants.
Upper body push
 (press)
I do mostly close grip bench press, with or without a pause. You can also do overhead press, push press, incline BP, dips or pushups for variation.
Upper body pull
 (row)
I do mostly weighted parallel-grip chinups, but there are many types of row (barbell or dumbbell) and pullup that can be used.
You should do one of each per workout although you can alternate lower body push and pull (squats and deadlifts) if you prefer. You don’t need more than two variants at most for each movement.

Whilst the desire to be muscular comes and goes, my ultimate goal is to be close to skinny (and toned if I can) and flexible.
 
I am relatively skinny, I really have poor stamina, and considering I have cerebral palsy, my flexibility is better than it has ever been.
 
(Since 15 I been going to the gym. Since 26 I’ve been jogging/running, and that’s the time when I started disliking the gym and use it purely for flexibility training - if at all.)

article:

If one focuses too much on gym and weight training, there is risk of losing stamina and cardio strength.
 
Hence, an ideal mix of cardio exercises like

Your question immediately rings a bell as I have faced this same question during my own quest for fitness. If one focuses too much on running, the body may start looking ultra thin and one may suffer from injuries like knee problems and back problems. If one focuses too much on gym and weight training, there is risk of losing stamina and cardio strength.
 
Hence, an ideal mix of cardio exercises like running and moderate weight training is the best solution. In my view, unless you are training for a marathon, you can maintain stamina by running 22-25KM a week over three running sessions and doing other exercises on the remaining days. I would suggest the following weekly routine:
 
Sunday - long run - 12 km at steady pace withing 75-80minutes.
 
Monday - rest
 
Tuesday - weights training at gym - cover biceps and back muscles
 
Wednesday - short run - 5km - at your best speed.
 
Thursday - weights training at gym - legs and triceps
 
Friday - Medium run -7km - run at medium n brisk pace alternately
 
Saturday - weights training at gym - shoulders and chest
 
I have followed similar schedule for many years. The point to remember is that when your are mixing cardio and weights in the above manner, keep both of them moderate. We have seen bulky and muscul...

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
My story is not about ignorance, but a lack of common sense. Years ago I was working for an American company, in Malaysia. In January of one year, a whole bunch of us got to go to San Francisco for the company’s annual sales pep talk :-D. We all stayed at a really nice hotel, and one evening, after all the rah-rah for the day was over, we all decided to have a drink before heading back to the hotel. As I was the designated driver I didn’t want anything to drink, so just asked for a glass of warm water. Soon enough, everyone else got their drinks, but I didn’t get mine. Instead the waitress (wh
Continue Reading
My story is not about ignorance, but a lack of common sense. Years ago I was working for an American company, in Malaysia. In January of one year, a whole bunch of us got to go to San Francisco for the company’s annual sales pep talk :-D. We all stayed at a really nice hotel, and one evening, after all the rah-rah for the day was over, we all decided to have a drink before heading back to the hotel. As I was the designated driver I didn’t want anything to drink, so just asked for a glass of warm water. Soon enough, everyone else got their drinks, but I didn’t get mine. Instead the waitress (who was really very sweet) came over and said, very apologetically, “I’m sorry Ma’am, we have HOT water, and we have COLD water, but we don’t have any WARM water”.
 
We all looked at each other, not sure if she was serious… then realised that, yes, she was serious! So I said, “Can you take a glass, half fill it with HOT water, then top it up with COLD water?” And she says “Oh WOW, that is so clever!!.. and, Yes, I got my glass of warm water.
 
It was a real face-palm moment!

title: Which 3 exercises would give me the most complete workout?
article:

2.barbell shoulder shrugs(reversed)

I'll give you some interesting ones just to spice things up. Always remember that the key is mind-muscle connection.
 
Notice that I included no isolations. They are useful but only as an accessory to your compounds.
 
Focus on the muscle you're trying to work when youre executing these workouts:
 
1.Hexbar deadlifts.
Hard to find in most gyms but an absolute gift if you get your hands on it. Lift as your would in a conventional deadlift but finish each rep with a squeeze of your traps till you feel the burn.
 
2.barbell shoulder shrugs(reversed)
This is a tricky 1 but intense on your traps and back delts. Do slow and controlled movements. This is not recommended for beginners as you can hurt yourself if you do not have adequate control.
 
3. Farmers walk
If you cant find these specialised bars you can use the hex deadlift bar. These is a full body compound workout but it hits your traps like a goddamn nuke. Remember to brace your core as you walk and look up. Footwear is important as well. You should not be wearing track shoes.
 
Happy lifting!

article:

Pros:

You have time to recover. You know even when you do arms exercise sometimes you get little bit of leg soreness! A
Continue Reading
Well I think it really depends on your goals and body. Firstly, you can’t train every day, you should give your body a rest to maximize your performance and recover. So you can train full body, but do it 3–4 times a week that would be enough. Here’s what I think:
 
Pros:
Doing 3–4 days is enough so you don’t have to make time everyday to work out. I mean if you do 3 days for legs, 3 days for arms then you will need to workout almost everyday and for many people it’s not very convenient.
You have time to recover. You know even when you do arms exercise sometimes you get little bit of leg soreness! As it is not always possible to isolate everything. So if you are working out every day on a different area you might have still feel too sore to do your best.
Cons:
If you want to see change on your shoulders or arms as soon as possible then this isn’t the best choice. As the results will come slowly.
It usually takes longer so if you are very busy it would be hard to commit to it. It might be more suitable for you to do 20 minutes every day on specific areas.

Man,  I don’t think I can narrow it down to one.  But, I will give you a story of a person who fell in the lowest category of ignorant, that of the moron.  This is about 15 years ago, and I took my then 5 yr old lad to the service station down the road.  I felt like getting him some candy; he’d been a good boy that day (LOL).  I decided that since I was there, I’d also pick up a gallon of milk, and a candy bar for myself.  So, I placed the two items of candy, and the milk on the counter.  Yes, just those three items.  The young woman, an adult, scanned them, and informed me of the total.  $14.83.  After 15 years I’m guessing on the cents, but it was around that.  I looked and said that it can’t be correct, as the milk was around $2.50, and the candies combined were roughly $1.50.  Simple math.  Her response?  “Well, that’s what the computer says it costs.”  I stared into those lovely vacant eyes, turned, and walked out with my boy.  I still shudder just a bit when I think about that event.  At the time, I was certain that Armageddon was seriously imminent.

title: What are the dirtiest songs you've ever heard?
article:
Nowadays, many songs are explicit… played in a variety of contexts without a whisper of protest. Do CD’s even have to display an Adult Content warning anymore?
 
But in the 1970’s, when I was a teen, explicit language was very much an exception in the pop music I knew. The success of a record was very much, at that time, long before the “wild wild west” of the Internet, connected to the AM and FM radio airplay it got, and strict FCC censorship laws applied to song lyrics at that time. Most sexual (and illicit drug or government protest) references had to be cloaked in metaphor… intimated in one w
Continue Reading
Nowadays, many songs are explicit… played in a variety of contexts without a whisper of protest. Do CD’s even have to display an Adult Content warning anymore?
 
But in the 1970’s, when I was a teen, explicit language was very much an exception in the pop music I knew. The success of a record was very much, at that time, long before the “wild wild west” of the Internet, connected to the AM and FM radio airplay it got, and strict FCC censorship laws applied to song lyrics at that time. Most sexual (and illicit drug or government protest) references had to be cloaked in metaphor… intimated in one way of another, not explicitly stated. Another trick at that time was to have the lead singer mutter and garble any words that might be objectionable.
 
So you can imagine how startled I was, attending a party in 1980, to hear the DJ suddenly put THIS record on. It was the dirtiest song lyric I had ever heard up until that time.
 
But it was— and still is— an incredible sounding record, and I remember going out to purchase that album the day after the party.

The only gadget I own is a Wiko feature phone priced at $12 (I bought it second-hand at $5) To cut the long story short, I survive on $1 each day and I’m in Quora. Am I fit to be called poor?
 
I have seen some answers where certain individuals claim to be poor whereas they have laptops and cameras! You should be in jail for not using those devices wisely. Give me a laptop today and look out for my next answer in 5 weeks!

At a Burger King near downtown Houston, TX, the guy at the counter tried to patronize and bully me with a barrage of intentionally annoying questions that ended with a "So, what's your name?”
 
Keeping calm, I said that it was Rama.
 
He: "Never heard of it. So, is that like Obama?...Osam
Continue Reading
There are frequent occasions on which I have received an "Is that near Delhi?" to my response that "I am from a city in India called Chennai" to a possibly insincere query and infrequent ones where I have been confronted with the otherwise standard "Do you speak Hindu?" stuff, but these didn’t go far enough as this:
 
At a Burger King near downtown Houston, TX, the guy at the counter tried to patronize and bully me with a barrage of intentionally annoying questions that ended with a "So, what's your name?”
 
Keeping calm, I said that it was Rama.
 
He: "Never heard of it. So, is that like Obama?...Osama?"
 
I could sense the xenophobia couched under the attempt at deliberate dumbness that rendered the “deliberate” adjective unconvincing.
 
My blood was on the quick way to boiling point during which I simultaneously thought of explaining through Arthur C. Clarke and complaining to the store manager, but then decided not to do anything owing to my perception of life perhaps being hard on the guy.
 
I just hurled back, "Very much like Osama."

Back when the election was in full swing, I was in line at a restaurant and two older women behind me were mourning and moaning the fact that there was not a decent candidate to vote for. They didn't like Trump because of all of antics, and they hated Hillary for being Hillary. They had no idea who to vote for. I was in the same dilemma, but I had already made up my mind to vote Libertarian. I was just about to turn around and suggest that they do the same when one of the ladies stated that she "just wished Sarah Palin would run." 
"Oh, yes!" Said the second woman, "I just love her, and she would make such a great President."
I spun around and just stared at both of them in utter shock. So much so, that they both took note and stepped away from me clutching their purses. 
After a moment, I was able to regain my composure and turn back around, but the whole time I was thinking: "What the hell?" If there was one thing that could possibly have made the last election worse, it was Sarah Palin. Could you imagine her being in the race too? Oh my GOD!!!

(At this point I was sure she was joking but no)
 
“Scotland and England are in the same country…the UK”
 
“US”
 
“What?”
 
“It's called the US? For United States.”
 
“Scotland isn't in the United States. Neither is England”
 
“Umm I never said they were”
 
“…ok. Well…what are you doing later?”
 
“Sleeping. Why what do you do at night time?”
 
We had this conversation at 11am. It still gives me a headache to recall to this day

I haven’t met Trump yet but when I do he will be.
 
I can however give you details of the most ignorant family to visit the United States (in the late 1979s). They visited a motel whilst driving through Florida. The son chatted with a nice local lady in the bar and totally failed to realise that she was amorously interested in him, his parents were astounded when he returned to the family room as they had not expected to see him till the next morning. The parents went on to visit friends in Washington DC. One of the days their hosts got called out for a work emergency and left them to their own devices. They went out for a walk of about three miles and found a street market, they had a marvellous time shopping and talking with the locals. When they told their hosts about it they blanched “whites don’t go in that part of town and the police only go in in large groups!”. It was my family, my ignorance of American mores cost me a holiday romance, my parents ignorance saved them from hostility in the hood because they were friendly and not afraid.

Three years ago I sat next to a lady on a flight from Paris to Abidjan; she’s got to be much more ignorant than the most ignorant person in America.
 
Here’s what happened. An hour after we took off, she slightly lifted her head looking straight, then said out loud: “why the hell did he stop?”. I didn’t pay much attention to her, just shrugged and got back to whatever I was doing at the moment. A couple of minutes later she turned to me and said again:”why the hell did he stop? We were already late when we took off!!”. She seemed very irritated. I asked her: “who are you talking about?”. she answered: “that damn pilot! he keeps stopping the plane!”. I couldn’t believe my ears. I was expecting her to say: “gotcha!” and burst into laughter. It never happened. I didn’t really know what to say so I told her:”uhmm…I don’t think the pilot stopped the plane…”. She rolled her eyes and said:”Of course He did!! can’t you tell we’re at a standstill?”. I gave her a looooooong stare and just said: “don’t you worry sweety, planes are always late anyway…”.

Whilst driving a taxi in the UK I had an awful American chap who was insistent on paying for his taxi in American dollars and would not believe that dollars were not legal tender.
 
His taxi cost £10, short trip, without tip, so I explained with much patience that to accept the dollars I would have to charge him the additional costs involved to take them to the bank the next day; an hour of my time, parking up, and the fuel involved. The £10 taxi then became $50. He still refused to pay so had to be convinced with the threat of dumping him back at his starting point or involving the police.
 
He still couldn’t understand why I wouldn’t accept dollars in the UK.
 
To redress Karma some years later the day after Trump was elected I picked up an American couple who immediately apologised for being American. They explained they were embarrassed democrats ashamed by the actions of Mr Trump: I halved their taxi fare and wished them well.
 
I have chatted to some lovely North Americans but in my experience they usually turn out to be Canadians.

A couple of weeks ago, I was at a party with my grandmother, who is well into her eighties. We struck up a conversation with a woman who was maybe 35. Let's call her Jane. Somehow the topic of school integration came. My grandma was talking about what it was like to be a black teacher in a predominantly white school in the 1960s. She told us that on the day Martin Luther King, Jr was assassinated, some of her white coworkers were celebrating.
 
Jane says, “oh my gosh! You were alive when Martin Luther King was?! He is such a hero of mine! I can't believe you were alive at the same time! It is such an honor to meet you!”
 
She then excitedly shook my grandma’s hand. As if she were some sort of celebrity! Because she was born before 1968? And it just got worse…
 
Jane: “Oh my gosh I just can't believe the other teachers would be happy that he was killed! How could anyone want him dead?! I just can't believe that! I mean everybody loved him!”
 
I don't know that I've ever seen someone express so much ignorance in such a short period of time.

title: How long will it take to get big if doing full body workouts every day with heavy weights?
article:

How unfit you are now
How intense and efficient you train
If you’re 32 stones and workout for 10 minutes everyday, you’ll likely make a lot more progress than you think. When you’re 130 kilos of pure muscle, a 10 minutes workout probably isn’t the best option for you. Losing fat can be quick, but building muscle will be very slow.
 
If you’re very fat at the start of your transformation, you’ll likely make progress really quickly, as like I said before, losing fat is very easy physically. Mentally, it’s a different battle.
 
If you’re not fat at all, chances are that yo

It really depends on two things.
How unfit you are now
How intense and efficient you train
If you’re 32 stones and workout for 10 minutes everyday, you’ll likely make a lot more progress than you think. When you’re 130 kilos of pure muscle, a 10 minutes workout probably isn’t the best option for you. Losing fat can be quick, but building muscle will be very slow.
 
If you’re very fat at the start of your transformation, you’ll likely make progress really quickly, as like I said before, losing fat is very easy physically. Mentally, it’s a different battle.
 
If you’re not fat at all, chances are that you’re already ripped, you just need muscle to show it off, so simple gym work will really help you grow a better physique.
 
If you’re a little fat and have a little muscle, you could just focus on fat loss for a bit, and then build your muscle up later. There are many ways of going about this, but it all depends on how you started, and how much you want the change.
 
If you really want the change, you’ll work harder to get it quicker.

This is an experience from my Belgian mother. After WWII she married my American father and went to visit my father’s family in Mobile Alabama in 1949.
 
My mother was born and grew up in a city, Belgium’s second largest. Urban, international, a huge gigantic harbor with ships and people coming from everywhere. Anyway, my father’s Alabama family asked her while visiting if she’d gotten used to wearing (leather/normal) shoes since getting married.
 
My mother was flabbergasted and also somewhat insulted that her new American family thought that she’d never worn shoes in her life or if so only wooden shoes. Which, no normal person in her city would have been caught dead in. The wooden shoes in Europe thing is such a tourist joke, but apparently my Alabama family bought into it and thought that folks in Europe all wore wooden shoes in everyday life.
 
What made it even funnier were their (no doubt true) stories about going barefoot to school back in the Great Depression years before WWII. Of which they were sort of proud in a way.

I was in the park after a parade and saw some mounted police officers in a cool formation. I decided to snap a picture and took a step back to get them all into the shot. Some women were walking on the path and one of them walked into me and then let out an exasperated sigh. Now, I had been standing in that spot for at least a good five seconds, enough time for her to go around me. But she bumped into me and kept walking. "I'll watch where I'm standing next time." I said sarcastically, "I guess you will." she said equally sarcastically. "I don't get an 'excuse me'?" I asked. "You bumped into me!" she snapped. We went back and forth a bit as she kept walking, going past the officers on horseback whose photo I had just snapped. She said something to one of the cops and he said "Yeah, right, right." in mock agreement. When she was out of earshot, one of the cops said to me, "Hey, man, let me take YOUR picture." Surprised, I gave him my phone and he took two shots of me with their horses. Even the law was on my side that day and moment!

I was travelling in California with my Husband, his sister, and her then-boyfriend. They are all from Australia (G’day mate.)
 
One evening as we were sitting at the hotel bar, we noticed quite the influx of US Marines in dress uniform, and their dates in formal gowns.

The conversation went something like this:
 
Marine:
 “I’ve spent some time in Australia, we trained there with [AU’s version of the Marines]”
 
Us: 
“That’s great, how did you like it?”
 
Marine:
 “It’s the best third world country I’ve ever visited!”
 
We all just looked at each other while the guy kept chatting away about his time in our ‘Third World Country’ - we didn’t bother to correct him.
 
We still have a chuckle when we think back to this story, either the guy didn’t fully understand the definition of the term - or the Northern Territory left a poor impression on him!

article:

As a beginner avoiding an injury by learning how to lift or set up the equipment is the first step.
 
A good way to start is to get instruction on selectorized or plate loaded equipment. Once you have a little experience and have built some strength then if you are interested progress to free weights. The machines are safer to use than free weights as long as they are set up properly.

If you will be lifting free weights or even using plate loaded or selectorized equipment you should have an introductory session from a competent trainer showing you how to use the equipment safely. As a beginner avoiding an injury by learning how to lift or set up the equipment is the first step.
 
A good way to start is to get instruction on selectorized or plate loaded equipment. Once you have a little experience and have built some strength then if you are interested progress to free weights. The machines are safer to use than free weights as long as they are set up properly.
 
Don’t be too enthusiastic and overdo at first. Work the volume and intensity up as you become accustomed to working out. Many with good intentions about increasing their fitness have awakened the day after their first workout or week and don’t return to their gym because of muscle soreness. Gyms rely on selling memberships to those who show up a few times and quit. If everyone that had a membership used it, most gyms couldn’t handle the capacity.

So...

One of the top contenders was a very senior employee of a large Pharmaceutical Co based in Research Triangle Park. He was to manners what what Adolph Hitler was to inclusivity. Many years ago I was required to ‘show him around Europe’ as if we were visiting a theme park in an alien land (which I suppose, to him, it was) and he managed to insult and alienate just about every Chief Executive of our subsidiary companies en route. He didn’t have any real idea of where we were and genuinely believed that The Netherlands was a ‘made up country’ and Portugal was ‘a part of Spain’. He simply couldn’t grasp that US law didn’t apply in France or Germany - after all, ‘we beat them in WW2’ and regarded the European currencies as ‘monkey money’.
 
I do owe him a single slice of gratitude. I was young and he taught me a valuable lesson From that time onwards, I never, ever trusted US, or US based executives again. How on earth he achieved his level of seniority remains a total mystery - but the company did eventually fail spectacularly!

title: Is a full body workout two or three times a week as effective as a split routine working out 5 or 6 days a week? How do I get the best results possible with the least time invested?
article:
Effectiveness is relative to your goal.
 
For a beginner, a full body routine 2–3 times a week is sufficient. They have little training experience, need to practice the same exercises more frequently and don’t need a huge training volume.
 
An experience bodybuilder would need 5–6 training sessions per week, split in to different muscle groups. The reason for splitting the muscle groups up is that is allows each group to be targeted with more volume.
 
An inexperienced trainee might only need 8–10 sets targeting their legs to stimulate muscle growth, due to lack of training experience.
 
The bodybuilder m
Continue Reading
Effectiveness is relative to your goal.
 
For a beginner, a full body routine 2–3 times a week is sufficient. They have little training experience, need to practice the same exercises more frequently and don’t need a huge training volume.
 
An experience bodybuilder would need 5–6 training sessions per week, split in to different muscle groups. The reason for splitting the muscle groups up is that is allows each group to be targeted with more volume.
 
An inexperienced trainee might only need 8–10 sets targeting their legs to stimulate muscle growth, due to lack of training experience.
 
The bodybuilder might need 30–40+ sets for their legs, to stimulate any muscle growth and will also need longer to recovery. Therefore, one sessions per week with huge volume is sufficient.
 
The only benefit of a beginner training 5–6 times per week would be to increase energy expenditure for a fat loss goal. However, this can be managed via diet or additional lower-intensity exercise (such as walking).
 
I hope that helps.

Short answer: 
It depends…
 
To gain muscle, you need a couple of things:
regular stimulus to adapt
fuel to make adaptation
So I wont go on about the second point- to keep that simple, aim for 14x your body weight(lb) or 31x body weight(kg) in calories, and add as necessary.
 
But for working out- 2 factors come into play
 
Consistency
 and 
Energy.
 
To choose a time (because neither in inherently “better”)- 
 
When do you have the most energy?
When can you workout consistently?
 
If you aren’t a morning person; or can’t workout without eating- the early morning isn’t going to work for you.
 
Conversely, if there’s no way in heck you have the time or energy to workout after work, that time probably won’t work.
In the afternoon, you are more likely to have fuel in your system
In the morning you are possibly able to carve out/ schedule a regular time.
Summary:
An ‘okay’ plan, 90% of the time, works better than the ‘perfect’ plan 50% of the time. 
With everything- It depends, what works for you?

Wow, could I eat a lot of food.
 I bet I was guzzling 3000 calories a day easily - and of course none of it was processed food - there wasn’t a lot of that in those days.
 
Whenever I stayed over at a youth hostel I would store my bike and walk into the door for registration. Many of them, in those days, provided dinner as part of

In my crazy wilder days touring around Europe in the early 70s, I was pedalling a bicycle all over and I had a 40 pound backpack strapped on it. I went over the Black Forest mountains, etc. So, I’d sure say that was a workout that lasted the whole day. So what happened? 
Wow, could I eat a lot of food.
 I bet I was guzzling 3000 calories a day easily - and of course none of it was processed food - there wasn’t a lot of that in those days.
 
Whenever I stayed over at a youth hostel I would store my bike and walk into the door for registration. Many of them, in those days, provided dinner as part of the package and they had big bowls of food for all to jump into….sort of like a big dining room table. Now you have to imagine this little girl who weighed about 105 pounds and was only 5′3″……….I’d eat a ton of food and I mean a ton! and then after everyone else was finished I’d clean up all the various bowls of food. People would ask how the heck I could eat so much because they had never seen the bike when it arrived!!!

I grew up with a mother who worked 2 to 3 Jobs at a time just to keep food in our bellies and a roof over our heads so yes we grew up pretty poor (and I still am, living paycheck to paycheck) and I still had the greatest childhood a kid could ever ask for. We lived all summer long in a camp site to we didn't have to pay rent during the summers and I would not change one little thing about that. I will go to my grave with memories of a childhood spent with love and adventures and if we had been a well to do family, I wouldn't have those memories. We couldnt afford to own a house or 5 cars or even 1 car that didn't have holes in the floorboards where slush from the roads would fly into during the winter months but the love and attention from my family are the only memories that will even matter when I am laying on my death bed. The memories of a loving and wonderful life will be what I think about during my last moments. The rich and the poor will end up in the same size hole or same size urn when it's all said and done

In terms of diet you just need to make sure that you are eating more calories than you currently are eating. Add one balanced meal to your current diet or one weight gainer shake then monitor your weight. If after 2 weeks you are not gaining any weight, then you should add another shake or meal. You want to continue to do so until you reach the desired weight or you like the way you look.
 
Hopefully this helps and good luck!

Most of these answers involve the dumbest people in America, and typically revolve around a lack of geographical knowledge. Here’s mine though:
 
So, it wasn’t in America, but it did involve (fellow) Americans.
 
I was in Spain. I was staying with a nice couple I had met during my travels. The three of us went to Penedes, where they produce Cava, to visit wine country. We were on the tour for about an hour. The gal doing the tour was really nice and did an exceptional job. I learned along the way that she spoke 5 languages! At one point toward the end of the tour, she mispronounced some English word, and a couple Americans in the group laughed at her, then pronounced it correctly in a super condescending way. WTF?! I wish she would have finished the tour in Spanish at that point to remind everyone they are in HER country.
 
Maybe not the most ignorant thing ever, but it’s not the first time that I’ve seen Americans give a non-native speaker a hard time, like they’re supposed to be fluent at birth. Pisses me off.

I work as a Sales Engineer for a very big technology company and meet a lot of people from around the country because if this. I have clients in pretty much all of the states west of Mississippi and co-workers from literally every state.
 
Before I get to this, let me give you a brief background about myself and my friends. All of us are College educated. We are all either engineers, doctors, interior-designers, project managers, pharmacists and other professions, even in upper level management positions. Some of us were born in the US and some of us pretty much immigrated to the US around or after high school.
 
This is a typical ‘'Ignorant American’ that I meet on a common basis. Not just me but pretty much every one of my Indian and S.Asian friends, including my wife. The question or rather statement that is made is, “Wow, you speak really good English! Did you learn English in school?”
 
We pretty much just smile it off. This is something that happens even today. I don't think it's going to change anytime soon!

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
A number of years ago I travelled from the UK to Huntsville, Alabama for some specialist IT training and at one of the breaks, I found myself exchanging pleasantries with another one of the course attendees, a Computer Science graduate from Alabama.
 
"Where are you from?" he asked, picking up on my accent.
 
"England," I replied. He was thoughtful.
 
"What language do they speak there?"
 
"Er, English."
 
Another pause.
 
"Can you use dollars and cents there?"
 
"No, we have our own currency: pounds and pence".
 
We went back to our course - he enlightened, me confused.
 
Now I'm not for a moment suggesting this is typ
Continue Reading
A number of years ago I travelled from the UK to Huntsville, Alabama for some specialist IT training and at one of the breaks, I found myself exchanging pleasantries with another one of the course attendees, a Computer Science graduate from Alabama.
 
"Where are you from?" he asked, picking up on my accent.
 
"England," I replied. He was thoughtful.
 
"What language do they speak there?"
 
"Er, English."
 
Another pause.
 
"Can you use dollars and cents there?"
 
"No, we have our own currency: pounds and pence".
 
We went back to our course - he enlightened, me confused.
 
Now I'm not for a moment suggesting this is typical of Americans and we have our share of insular Brits but my impression is that this insularity is more prevalent in the US. Perhaps our relative country sizes determine whether the population is inward or outward looking.
 
Edit: in fairness, in the UK we get exposed to a lot more American culture (via TV, films, music, etc) than those in the US get exposed to UK culture.

title: What is a good at home workout routine for intermediate beginners?
article:
Here is a good workout plan for beginners:
Start with Cardio: Begin with 20-30 minutes of cardiovascular exercise, such as jogging, cycling, or swimming, three to four times a week. This will help improve your endurance, burn calories, and get your heart rate up.
Incorporate Strength Training: Add strength training exercises two to three times a week. Start with basic bodyweight exercises like squats, lunges, push-ups, and planks. Gradually increase the number of sets and reps over time.
Alternate Between Muscle Groups: Alternate between working different muscle groups on different days to allow 
Continue Reading
Here is a good workout plan for beginners:
Start with Cardio: Begin with 20-30 minutes of cardiovascular exercise, such as jogging, cycling, or swimming, three to four times a week. This will help improve your endurance, burn calories, and get your heart rate up.
Incorporate Strength Training: Add strength training exercises two to three times a week. Start with basic bodyweight exercises like squats, lunges, push-ups, and planks. Gradually increase the number of sets and reps over time.
Alternate Between Muscle Groups: Alternate between working different muscle groups on different days to allow for recovery time. For example, do cardio on Monday and Wednesday, and strength training on Tuesday and Thursday. Rest on Friday and Saturday, and do active recovery like stretching or yoga on Sunday.
Remember to listen to your body and adjust your workout plan as needed. Additionally, incorporating healthy eating habits and getting enough rest and recovery time will help support your fitness goals and overall well-being.

I will say that they were some of the nicest people I’d met though :-).

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
There was this particular girl who stands out among all the Americans that I have had a chance to interact with.
 
In the autumn of 2011, I had gone to visit some family friends in Baton Rouge, Louisiana. They had a teenage daughter and we both got along really well. Instead of staying inside, well shielded from the brutal sun, we decided to go for a walk to the nearby pond. On the way, we met her school friend. We started conversing a little. 
Please note that we had no trouble in deciphering our accents. 
when she asks me,
 
“Where are you from?”
 
“India”
 
She replies with a smirk plastered on her face;

There was this particular girl who stands out among all the Americans that I have had a chance to interact with.
 
In the autumn of 2011, I had gone to visit some family friends in Baton Rouge, Louisiana. They had a teenage daughter and we both got along really well. Instead of staying inside, well shielded from the brutal sun, we decided to go for a walk to the nearby pond. On the way, we met her school friend. We started conversing a little. 
Please note that we had no trouble in deciphering our accents. 
when she asks me,
 
“Where are you from?”
 
“India”
 
She replies with a smirk plastered on her face;
 
“Indiana?”
 
“No No, India, the country India in Asia.”
 
She says, with a gleaming smile on her face as if she is lending me a helping hand;
 
“Asia? Oh don't be silly! Indiana is in the United States of America.”
 
She was pleased with herself for correcting an imbecile like me while I just stood in the corner, trying way too hard to not throw a freaking World Atlas on her satisfied face.

One of my classmates. Let's call him Jack (not his real name).
 
First, he thinks that babies are made by brain signals that a couple has once they are married. “I don't know how it knows,” he says. “but your brain somehow knows when you get married and sends signals to start production of a baby.”
 
Then, we have health class. “No, babies are still made from brain signals,” he insists.
 
He also believes that Texas is bigger than Alaska. Even though my friends and I knew it was wrong, we asked the teacher. Right in front of him.
 
And he still says, “Texas is bigger than Alaska!”
 
He thought Virginia was a city, until our whole class teamed up against him.
 
Then, after a week or so of persuading, we finally got “Jack” to believe Virginia is a state.
 
“Fine,” he grudgingly admitted. “Virginia is a state, not a city.”
 
Everybody was shouting “YES!” inside.
 
He also once thought I stole his phone and deleted all his apps, when in reality his dad had done it…but that's a story for another time.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
This didn’t happen to me, and it didn’t happen in the US, but it does fit in well with the “ignorant American” theme.
 
I’m South African, my dad was in high school in the 70’s, and one of the families at his school hosted an American girl as an exchange student for the year. Now in South Africa the school year runs from January to December, meaning that our long holiday coincides with Christmas and the southern hemisphere summer. This family arrived at the airport in Durban to pick the girl up, and saw her dressed in thick winter clothes. After greeting her, they asked if she wanted to go to the
Continue Reading
This didn’t happen to me, and it didn’t happen in the US, but it does fit in well with the “ignorant American” theme.
 
I’m South African, my dad was in high school in the 70’s, and one of the families at his school hosted an American girl as an exchange student for the year. Now in South Africa the school year runs from January to December, meaning that our long holiday coincides with Christmas and the southern hemisphere summer. This family arrived at the airport in Durban to pick the girl up, and saw her dressed in thick winter clothes. After greeting her, they asked if she wanted to go to the bathroom and change into some cooler clothes for the drive back home. She looked around all confused and said, “But I don’t understand! It’s summer in America!”
 
It must be said though that America definitely doesn’t have the monopoly on ignorant people. Our own president believed that Africa was the biggest continent in the world and wasn’t crossed by any rivers. He also doesn’t seem to be able to do basic maths…

title: What is a good weekly workout?
article:
What you're doing is a great start!
 
It sounds like time efficiency is important to you and you like body weight exercises. Given those two assumptions, I suggest:
Continuing the 100 push-ups. If you can do all in one set then you need to challenge yourself with weight or elevating your feet.
Swapping out the sit-ups for more effective core exercises. Sit-ups don't activate the entire core and can lead people to “cheat” by using momentum. They also can lead to strain on your back. I would do planks instead. They take up less time and you can focus on good form and slow breaths to work your core ni
Continue Reading
What you're doing is a great start!
 
It sounds like time efficiency is important to you and you like body weight exercises. Given those two assumptions, I suggest:
Continuing the 100 push-ups. If you can do all in one set then you need to challenge yourself with weight or elevating your feet.
Swapping out the sit-ups for more effective core exercises. Sit-ups don't activate the entire core and can lead people to “cheat” by using momentum. They also can lead to strain on your back. I would do planks instead. They take up less time and you can focus on good form and slow breaths to work your core nicely. Add side planks to mix it up. For more of a challenge, add a safe but unstable platform like 
Core Flytes
.
Adding exercises to incorporate other muscle groups. You have chest, triceps, and core but not back, biceps, shoulders and legs. Air squats are great body weight exercises that will work you legs / glutes. Add some pull-up sets in and you're covering post of the major muscle groups.
Hope this helps!

Workout routine should be divided by different muscle groups to different days and a exercise should not be repeated for 2 days. So, keeping this in mind you should make your routine like I have done-
 
Monday- legs - thigh curls, squats , lunge , calf raise, legs burnout continued with calf jumps.
 
Tuesday- shoulder and forearm - overhead press, standing fly, front raise, shrugs, forearm inner wrist curl, forearm reverse curl, frontal raise.
 
Wednesday- chest - pushups, barbell deadlift, dumbell incline bench press, dip, fly, cable crossovers, plate press.
 
Thursday- bicep and forearm- dumbell curl, reverse curl, hammer curl, barbell curl, forearm hold
 
Friday- back- Superman, row, standing uplift, high row, side uplift, pullups, Superman static hold.
 
Saturday- triceps - dip, elastic stretch down, seated dip, skull crusher, tricep pushups, tricep kickback and kickback hold.
 
Note: proper stretch warmup of 5 to 10 minutes should be done before and maximum time for doing exercise is 1 hour.

I would need a medical history first to decide and then do a fitness test to finally determine. A generally healthy person would start with a walk to warm up and then stretch to your comfort level. If no other weights or equipment do any physical movements that are safe example running on the spot lifting knees to waist clapping hands overhead as you do jumping jacks like we used to do years ago and rarely do now not raising the heart rate or PE (perceived exertion) above a 5 to start and no higher than a 7 if in fair to good condition always communicate with your DR. or a Personal Trainer with a good reference from those you trust. PE= 1 sitting -10 very tired let your body be your guide. So if you can a few half sit-ups - depending on your strength and on toes or on your knee pushups. The best is to go online and see what fits your fitness level or contact a professional Trainer. Best overall is Buy a concept 2 rower and a few lightweights that's all you need and a bit of professional training. Bob Martin

No - this has been researched in the Center for Economic Disparity on Social Media (CEDSM), located in Seattle. There was a poor person on here in 2013, but his focus was on asking only “If I only have peanut butter and need a house and meal, what should I do?” Over and over again. He was provided with 2098 math proofs, 134 chemical compositions of peanut butter, an offer for one Quora users house for free if he could explain how to get out of it (sorry, insider Quora thing), in addition to several engineering diagrams, a suggestion to live in a cave and eat peanut butter, 13 people who told him to be happy for his tax/bill/job-free life, and a promise from a New Hampshire Congressman to provide white bread, jelly, and mansions for all poor Americans. The poor guy either died of hypothermia or starvation before reading through the maths derivations -
 
As a side note, there is an interesting proof of multiple levels of infinity in the answer thread, but I forget it's relevance to peanut butter and housing.

Once I attended an international conference for young chemists. Participants included mostly Ph.D. and Masters’/undegraduate students and, that year, a small delegation (2 students) from the USA was attending.
 
We’re talking 100% attendees studying Chemistry at a University.
 
During one of the social breaks (I believe after dinner or so), I was chatting with a girl from the Netherlands. One of the American students (very friendly, by the way) approaches us and asks where we are from. After her answer, he replies:
 
“The Netherlands? Wow, where is that? Is it close to Japan?”
 
We (me and the Dutch girl) both gave each other the biggest “WTF” stares and just burst laughing.
 
PS: to his credit, I think it might be that the American student in question never heard of “The Netherlands” but would have avoided embarassing himself if she had said “Holland”. Yet, given the girl’s phenotype (blonde, blue eyes, very northern European complexion) to assume proximity to Japan was somewhat… ludicrous.

So a couple or so years back when I was 31 and single, I met a middle-aged lady in YMCA. I think she was probably 47–48 and also had 2 daughters. She used to teach TRX there. I moved to US from India for higher education and career and had been living and working in the US for past 7 years. I also did not have any idea of dating culture (I still don't) and family/marriage of Americans. And as you can imagine as a 31 year old never married and no children I'd myriad options on that front for me. So this YMCA lady seemed nice and one day asked for my phone number and I gladly gave that to her. After about a month or so I started getting texts and voice messages from her. So I asked her what's the matter and she says to me that she is trying to set me up with some 39 year old single (and divorced) mom of 1. And I was banging my head against the wall. Coming from India I'd never heard of second marriage and divorce (and that too at 31 years age). I thought she was the most ignorant person I met in America.

Continue Reading
I agree, push, pull and squat combination provide you with a solid full body workout BUT what if you aren’t a gym member or don’t have excess to weights or a pull up bar, what will you do?
 
While push, pull, squat variations are perhaps THE exercises to go to, others, often neglected ones, might give you just as good as a workout.
 
Two exercises that come to mind that BOTH work FULL body, especially your core and balance are:
staggered get up (while holding a weight - even a household weight such as a jug of water- over your head)
roll up (if you have weights you can add chest press, pull over or overhead squat hold when rolling back up into a standing position)
Both exercises will work your legs, glutes, core and upper body strength. These are a bit different from the standard exercises but IF YOU ONLY engage in basic exercises you are missing out!
 
Change things up. You might be surprised just how challenging these are for you, especially the first one!

We are barely able to pay our rent and our utilities are extremely late. However, reading all of your answers and comments made me realize how ignorant I was being. We may not have money right now, but at least we have a decent house, food in the cabinets, vehicles, jobs, and education. Reading all the responses to this question made me completely reevaluate my frame of thinking and my attitude I have had over the last few months and how ignorant I have been. So thank you my fellow Quorans for making me realize how much of an asshole I have been, and for how much I have been taking for granted the things that I do have. Every story I have read has been so inspiring and seeing how everyone has such positive attitudes saying that they know their situation is going to get better is amazing. Because I have been so negative lately and have been feeling so discouraged lately.

title: Can I do a mixed workout every day in the gym?
article:

First 3–4 weeks:
 
It doesn’t matter - just get to the gym!
 Establishing the routine and making sure you’re making time is crucial right now. Even if you go for 5 minutes, just get there. Do what you like. Play around. Experiment. Have fun!
Second 2–3 weeks:
 
Determine your goal.
 Your program design will depend on what you want to achieve. If you want to run a 5k, your program will look different than if you wanted to increase your bench press. Do research, talk with fitness professionals, and figure out a plan. Remember that you can change it

Hey there! I’d say there are 3 main parts to my answer:
First 3–4 weeks:
 
It doesn’t matter - just get to the gym!
 Establishing the routine and making sure you’re making time is crucial right now. Even if you go for 5 minutes, just get there. Do what you like. Play around. Experiment. Have fun!
Second 2–3 weeks:
 
Determine your goal.
 Your program design will depend on what you want to achieve. If you want to run a 5k, your program will look different than if you wanted to increase your bench press. Do research, talk with fitness professionals, and figure out a plan. Remember that you can change it in the future, but you need a plan to start!
Next 2–4 months: 
Work the plan.
 Resist the temptation to change plans after 2 weeks if you don’t see progress. You need time to see if the plan is working or not - which is usually 
at least 4 weeks
. Keep working through the hard spots, plan for difficulties, and above all, DON’T GIVE UP. You can do it!
I hope this helps - best of luck!
 
Genevieve

Location: Lugano, a beautiful lakeside city in the Italian speaking part of Switzerland.
 
My wife and I sat down at a table outside a restaurant. We were given menus, these were trilingual, in Italian, German and French, the three main languages of Switzerland. We chose and ordered in German, which we spoke better than the other two.
 
As we were waiting for our food to arrive, we noticed that a family group at the next table, who were already there when we had arrived, were still looking at their menus. They were talking to each other in English, with US accents.
 
Then one of them said “I think there is more than one language on this menu, look it says tomato twice here” (only twice because it is Pomodoro in Italian, Tomate in French and German).
 
Perhaps not ignorant, just “green”, not used to handling different languages and not pre-prepared with a list of menu words. But they could have asked (politely) if the waiter spoke English; or noticed we were speaking in English and asked us.

Years ago, my fraternity sent a contingent to a conference in Nashville. We decided to check out Fort Knox on the drive home to Montreal.
 
We took the tour and were hanging out and started a conversation with a major serving there. He asked us what school we went to and where we were from. We said McGill in Montreal, Canada. He then remarked that the USA had a city named Montreal as well and it had a good baseball team called the Expos. We started to titter and giggle and the major asked what was so funny, we told him that that Montreal was our Montreal and we couldn’t believe he didn’t know that. He started to insist there were two Montreals, when our chapter president, a kid from Boston with a southie accent laid into him about how embarrassed he was as an American at the level of ignorance shown by an american officer, especially a field grade officer. Ignorance about the USA’s neighbour and closest ally.
 
The major’s facial expression was priceless. A goldfish out of water came to mind.

title: What is a good at home workout routine for intermediate beginners?
article:
Well, calisthenics which involves bodyweight exercises without the use of special equipment may help. That is to say, doing variations of push-ups, sit-ups, leg raises and squats will do.
 
Weightlifting, if you have free weights, can also be great for beginners. With a barbell that has a reasonable weight to give you a challenging kind of resistance, or a pair of dumbbells that aren’t too light for you to lift, you could do many exercises. Well, calisthenics which involves bodyweight exercises without the use of special equipment may help. That is to say, doing variations of push-ups, sit-ups, leg raises and squats will do.
 
Weightlifting, if you have free weights, can also be great for beginners. With a barbell that has a reasonable weight to give you a challenging kind of resistance, or a pair of dumbbells that aren’t too light for you to lift, you could do many exercises. Some examples are the alternating bicep curls, barbell curls, dumbbell or barbell rows and overhead, or ground chest press. You can also do weighted squats and sit-ups using either or both.
 
Plan your workout routine by deciding whether you’re going to go for a full-body workout or split system routine. Don’t work on specific muscle groups for several days to avoid injuries. Try to count your repetitions and sets. For the basics, you may want to do 8 to 10 repetitions of any of the exercises mentioned, per set. Also, you could start with 3 to 4 sets.

all the answers i’ve read were from india and nepal. i live in florida, USA.
 
i am not poor now. i have reversed my life. in 2003 my ex-husband started us on a downward spiral of spending and mortgaging. when i left in 2007, i had a few thousand dollars in the bank, no car, no job, no place to live. in 2008, i was working free-lance, teaching, doing anything i could to pay the rent on a subsidized apartment. i juggled credit cards. i made less than the poverty level.
 
i was lucky. i have a BA, an MBA, 30+ years work experience and i was struggling. i found a series of temp jobs, 2008 to 2011. i juggled bills and amassed a huge amount of debt on credit cards. i had no medical or car insurance. then i got a full-time job, then another. from 2011 to now i have been blessed with work that pays decent and that i enjoy.
 
so, not poor now, but i was. it has changed my view of the word, made me more compassionate. if i had a struggle with all my advantages, how do other people get ahead?

title: Is a morning gym workout better than an evening gym workout?
article:
It’s better to work out when you have optimal energy and nutrition for working out.
 
Example - my buddy just recently hit a 300 pound paused bench press for the first time. He did it during our normally scheduled 3PM gym time…after a full day of eating.
 
A week later we were at the gym at 10AM, with only a small breakfast for energy - he couldn’t hit the 300 pounds again when doing touch and go (much easier than pausing at the bottom).
 
He wasn’t any weaker per se, he just hadn’t had enough to eat.
 
So for optimal strength gain you want to work out when you have enough energy to get through your progr
Continue Reading
It’s better to work out when you have optimal energy and nutrition for working out.
 
Example - my buddy just recently hit a 300 pound paused bench press for the first time. He did it during our normally scheduled 3PM gym time…after a full day of eating.
 
A week later we were at the gym at 10AM, with only a small breakfast for energy - he couldn’t hit the 300 pounds again when doing touch and go (much easier than pausing at the bottom).
 
He wasn’t any weaker per se, he just hadn’t had enough to eat.
 
So for optimal strength gain you want to work out when you have enough energy to get through your program, while also having enough food to lift as much weight as your potential allows for (within the parameters of your program, obviously)
 
There is no magical bodily function which necessitates this to be morning or night, it is a function of your own energy levels and what resources your body has access to.
 
Follow me on Instagram for more content and help at 
Joe.Lifts.Bro

title: What are the pros and cons of training full-body every day?
article:
The pros are - you can train your entire body in one session. Even while doing only three sessions in a week, you hit each muscle thrice. So the frequency is on the higher side and we know that higher frequency leads to more gains. It is beneficial for people who cannot come to the gym often. This type of training is also beneficial for someone whose main goal is to build strength. The cons are- it takes a lot of time to complete the session. Also training this longer leads to central nervous system fatigue, which affects the intensity of training and intensity is one of the major contributors
Continue Reading
The pros are - you can train your entire body in one session. Even while doing only three sessions in a week, you hit each muscle thrice. So the frequency is on the higher side and we know that higher frequency leads to more gains. It is beneficial for people who cannot come to the gym often. This type of training is also beneficial for someone whose main goal is to build strength. The cons are- it takes a lot of time to complete the session. Also training this longer leads to central nervous system fatigue, which affects the intensity of training and intensity is one of the major contributors to hypertrophy. Also training muscle groups like triceps with the same intensity after doing bench press is difficult because intensity is compromised due to the onset of peripheral fatigue at this point. So, my advice to you- follow full body workouts only in cases you want to build foundational strength as in beginners. A full body workout for an intermediate is inferior in terms of hypertrophy.

Because of my accent (although I swear SHE was the one with the accent!) she asked me where

Not ignorant in the rude sense, but I met someone who was seriously ignorant of the world that exists outside of Los Angeles.
 
I was in Anaheim California for a tech trade show, and waiting for a bus to go into the city where things would certainly be more interesting. The bus driver got *off* the bus and sat on a bench, and told me I might as well sit with her while she ate her … whatever it was - a little green fruit thing with a lot of seeds. She offered me one, but I sided on safety and said no thanks.
 
Because of my accent (although I swear SHE was the one with the accent!) she asked me where I was from.
 
I told her “Canada” and she looked at me with a look of pity. “La Canada? Uh, East LA…” I corrected her “No, the country, Ontario, Canada. Up North.” and she again looked at me and said “Ontario, northern Cali? Is that wine country?”
 
Friendly. But very weird. She seemed genuinely blown away that there was a country of the same proportions of the USA “hiding” up there.

Unfortunately there are many but one was VERY eventful…
 
One time I was on holiday and met this very… how should I say… stupid American man. He was discussing Europe’s geography with his wife and I can tell you he definitely hasn’t got a geography degree. I distinctly remember him saying that when they visit London, the first thing they should do is go and see the Eiffel Tower. Let me just say that the Eiffel Tower is in fact in Paris which is around 300 miles away. I’m pretty sure that they went onto proceed to look up directions and how long it takes to get there etc. That was funny. The man said that google must be wrong because it did in fact say that the Eiffel Tower was in Paris 300 miles away. He then concluded that London must be huge and Paris was a district of London with the English Channel being the River Thames. Best story to tell though honestly although if I were him I would be extremely embarrassed and either a) get a brain WITH brain cells or b) go to specsavers.

title: Can I do a mixed workout every day in the gym?
article:
My number one recommendation:
 
1- Spend more time a standing up
 
Depending on what your job is, most people tend to spend a lot more time sitting down than is recommended. Not only does it promote a sedentary routine, it is also terrible for your posture as the muscles required for healthy core are not as active, therefore will atrophy at a faster than ideal rate. If you can stand up for a greater portion of your day compared to sitting (whilst keeping focus on a good posture as much as possible) it will set you up for a much more active lifestyle without having to completely change your routine. 
Continue Reading

1- Spend more time a standing up
 
Depending on what your job is, most people tend to spend a lot more time sitting down than is recommended. Not only does it promote a sedentary routine, it is also terrible for your posture as the muscles required for healthy core are not as active, therefore will atrophy at a faster than ideal rate. If you can stand up for a greater portion of your day compared to sitting (whilst keeping focus on a good posture as much as possible) it will set you up for a much more active lifestyle without having to completely change your routine. Things like changing to a stand-up desk, parking further away to add a couple of minutes for a quick walk in between errands, anything you can think of to get you off your butt throughout the day will help to transform your life easily. On top of this, burpees are a fantastic way to start the day, it activates most of the major muscle groups and doesn’t require any special equipment

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
Ignorance, in my understanding, is to be defined with reference to a topic or area of knowledge.
 
For example a mechanical engineer may be ignorant of human anatomy. Thus it is not possible to identify “the most ignorant” person.
 
That said, let me recount couple of incidents. I was teaching Engineering Drawing to freshman
engineering students. I asked one student “what is one-half of two and a half?” He pulled out his calculator, fiddled with it some, then did something with pencil and paper and then gave his answer: “One-and-a-half”!
 
Again, another time, another student in Engineering Drawing cla
Continue Reading
Ignorance, in my understanding, is to be defined with reference to a topic or area of knowledge.
 
For example a mechanical engineer may be ignorant of human anatomy. Thus it is not possible to identify “the most ignorant” person.
 
That said, let me recount couple of incidents. I was teaching Engineering Drawing to freshman
engineering students. I asked one student “what is one-half of two and a half?” He pulled out his calculator, fiddled with it some, then did something with pencil and paper and then gave his answer: “One-and-a-half”!
 
Again, another time, another student in Engineering Drawing class. As I go round and check their work, I saw this student had drawn a line at an angle to a horizontal line, whereas he was supposed to draw a perpendicular. I pointed it out and told him “the line is not perpendicular.” He replied: “It looks straight to me!”
 
For me, these are examples of extreme ignorance of basic math and geometry considering these are engineering majors!

It is convenient like going to a Mexican restaurant and there are chips and salsa on the table to hold one over until the food arrives. This is mentioned because my favorites take a lot of time to prepare. My absolute favorite is a ham and Swiss. On white bread with heavy mayo, one very thin slice of onion spread out to add flavor, lettuce and tomato. If we have leftover steak, I buy chipotle peppers in adobo sauce, and take a spoon of adobo sauce and add it to mayonnaise until it has a good flavor but not too spicy. The sandwich is chipotle mayo, thin cut steak, and sharp cheddar cheese. Growing up, mom made tuna and mayo. Her friends put pickle relish in tuna which I found to be as disgusting as candied yams. Later in life, I make tuna with hard boiled eggs, mayo and a little mustard…like deviled egg tuna salad. Finally, which comes only once a year…turkey and mayo on homemade white bread.

title: Is a morning gym workout better than an evening gym workout?
article:
There are advantages and disadvantages to both morning and evening gym workouts. In general, there is no definitive evidence that one is universally "better" than the other. It largely comes down to individual preference and lifestyle factors.
 
Some potential benefits of a morning workout include:
- Increased fat burning potential, as the body tends to have lower insulin levels in the morning.
- Less interference from daily stressors and distractions compared to later in the day.
- Can help energize you for the day ahead.
 
Potential benefits of an evening workout include: 
- Muscles are typically 
Continue Reading
There are advantages and disadvantages to both morning and evening gym workouts. In general, there is no definitive evidence that one is universally "better" than the other. It largely comes down to individual preference and lifestyle factors.
 
Some potential benefits of a morning workout include:
- Increased fat burning potential, as the body tends to have lower insulin levels in the morning.
- Less interference from daily stressors and distractions compared to later in the day.
- Can help energize you for the day ahead.
 
Potential benefits of an evening workout include: 
- Muscles are typically warmer and more flexible in the evening.
- Hormone levels, including testosterone, may be higher later in the day.
- Can help relieve stress and unwind after a busy day.
 
Ultimately, the best time to work out is the time that you are most consistent and able to stick to your routine. The key is finding what works best for your individual schedule, preferences, and fitness goals.

Our teacher gave us a practice quiz online with 5 basic questions :
 
What is the longest river? (I answered Amazon)
 
True or false : Is the Earth around 8000 mi in diameter? (I answered true)
 
True or false : Is Iceland the biggest island? (I answered false)
 
What country does this outline make? (I answered Italy)

I easily got all 5 correct. I asked my friend to see how much he got correct. He said he only got 2 correct. Apparently, the only questions he got right were the last one and the first one. I replied :
 
Me : Dude, haven’t you seen Iceland before? Greenland is right next to it and it is way bigger.
 
Him : I don’t know. I haven’t looked at a map since a long time ago.
 
I also wanted to add that I was watching a movie with him once. I told him the average movie is 2 hours. He said it was more like 1 hour and his example was the Jurassic World movie. Jurassic World is slightly more than 2 hours.

title: Which 3 exercises would give me the most complete workout?
article:
To get the most 'complete workout, you should be building muscle and burning fat. Therefore my top three (I'm throwing in a fourth, bonus round!): 
Pushups
 (targets pectorals, deltoids, triceps, serratus anterior and abdominals)
Squats or jump squats
 (targets legs, butt and back...also targets arms if you hold weights in both hands. If you do squat jumps then you get your heart rate up, which burns fat)
Burpees
 (targets full body AND increases heart rate to encourage fat burn)
BONUS:
 
Planks/Plank Walks
 (targets full body: arms, shoulders, abs, back, glutes, legs)
How many of each move you do will d

To get the most 'complete workout, you should be building muscle and burning fat. Therefore my top three (I'm throwing in a fourth, bonus round!): 
Pushups
 (targets pectorals, deltoids, triceps, serratus anterior and abdominals)
Squats or jump squats
 (targets legs, butt and back...also targets arms if you hold weights in both hands. If you do squat jumps then you get your heart rate up, which burns fat)
Burpees
 (targets full body AND increases heart rate to encourage fat burn)
BONUS:
 
Planks/Plank Walks
 (targets full body: arms, shoulders, abs, back, glutes, legs)
How many of each move you do will depend on your level of fitness. If you are a beginner-intermediate then I would begin doing each move for 30 - 60 seconds. I would start with at least 3 rounds of these moves and work your way up. 
 
Don't try to crank through these moves, poor form can lead to injury. Make sure you are consciously activating your muscles while doing each move and make sure to breathe!

Depends on what you call “poor”. I’m not living in a hut and compared to some of the better posters I have a rain-tight roof over my head (at least for now), some kind of heating and easy access to electricity. in my country though I am still considered at the very lowest economical end because I’m living “in the minus”. That means my salary may be enough to pay for rent and fixed cost, but I struggle paying for food and if anything else comes up (like the costs of my education, something breaking, or just having to replace anything else than the content of the fridge and some TP) I have to go into debt and pay that off slowly, which is hard, because I do not earn enough to save a single cent a month.
 
So I am “poor” for the living standard in my country but compared to other countries I am “rich” because I have stuff they could never afford. Also the fact that they can’t really fall back on anything while, if shit ever goes down for me, Germany at least has a social system.

He was colossally thick, but interestingly, didn’t have any kind of obsession with guns.
