He was always bullying people, and failed all his exams.
 
Dead by 44.
 
I once phoned him up years later to see how he was doing.
 
I said ‘Have you ever thought about Jesus Christ?’
 
To which, in his dulcet, delicate way, he replied: ‘What are you? A f**king Jew?’.
 
I had to stifle the chuckles at this barbaric man’s chronic ignorance.
 
He didn’t think his way to the top. He beat everyone up. He was Obelix to my Asterix.
 
No one really remembers him as being overly pleasant or wise, although he could be riotously funny, which was his only saving grace.

Q: What are the best exercises that I should be doing weekly?
 ·
 
Cardio exercises would be best if your goal is stamina and cardiovascular health. Dr. Kenneth Cooper, who spent his career studying cardio exercise and its effects, developed a point system to measure the cardio effects of different exercises at various durations and intensity levels. He recommends a minimum of 35 points per week for men, 27 points per week for women, exercising at least 4 days a week and at most 6. (He specifically recommends taking at least one day off each week.)
 
His point system tells you for each type of exercise the number of points earned for various times and distances, as shown in this table: 
https://www.cooperaerobics.com/Downloads/About/Aerobics-Points-System.aspx
 
The table starts with Walking/Running, but scroll down through the document to see the points for cycling, for swimming, and other cardio exercises, including some sports. My own favorite is 
Nordic walking
.

But I guarantee you, he is of far better caliber, and a far better and “wiser” person than the President of the United States.
 
“Ignorance” is a relative term- the native peoples of the Amazon are ignorant of most things you consider essential- cell phones, computers, email etc. But far worse than ignorance is the arrogance of the educated.

The entire class was in hysterics.
Olivia out!
 
*Edit* // Something else recently happened. Today — in science — a boy raised his hand and blatantly stated that “The USA is a state, like New York is…” .
 
The world we live in…

I was working a machine learning gig a few years ago in downtown SF.
 
I was having lunch one day with the project manager and one of the staff engineers.
 
The night before, the president of Iran made a speech, in NYC at Columbia if I remember correctly (Astounding that they would normalize a Holocaust denier).
 
The manager remarked to me, “I think the president of Iran is correct; the holocaust did not actually happen.” I was taken aback, and responded, “I am pretty sure it happened, my father was a holocaust survivor.” This shook him, and he said, “Well maybe, but not as many people were killed as claimed.” I politely explained that they were lying to him. I can’t remember what happened then other than the staff guy explaining to me later that this guy’s thinking is typical of certain people back in his home country.
 
The next day my contract was terminated.
Not a fun story, but seems to be a popular one.

I wrote a check and noticed that I was writing the date December 7th. I said “Oh, it's Pearl Harbor Day.” “Oh, that's right, it is.” said the person behind me in line.

I cannot choose a *most* ignorant person from among the endless examples throughout my life. One who I remember often, though, was a grocery clerk. She was young, but I think it's safe to assume she was out of high school.
 
I wrote a check and noticed that I was writing the date December 7th. I said “Oh, it's Pearl Harbor Day.” “Oh, that's right, it is.” said the person behind me in line.
 
The clerk looked flustered. “I…I don't know what that is.”
 
Okay, I told myself, everyone hasn't been in the Navy like I have, or lived in Hawaii, both reasons to know the event very well. But is it normal not to know what Pearl Harbor Day is? I can get not knowing *when* it is, as it continues to recede into the past…but not to know *what* it is?
 
This was after 9–11, but not too long after if I was still writing checks, and Pearl Harbor was brought up a lot in the media as being the last attack on US soil before it. So…? Am I expecting too much of “kids these days”?

Continue Reading
Continuous integration (CI) is a DevOps practice designed to avoid the problems that come from integrating changes late in the development process, such as merge conflicts and build errors, bugs, or even the ultimate realization that your software doesn’t actually do what your users need. With CI, you commit, build, and test everyone’s code changes as you go.
 
Integrating frequently throughout a project allows you to minimize conflicts, check how everyone’s changes interact, and address any bugs before they become deeply entrenched in the code and relied on by other functionalities.
 
A CI server (or build server) plays a key role in implementing and managing CI/CD pipelines. It serves as the glue that holds all stages of the pipeline together, applying your business logic to coordinate automated tasks while also collating and publishing feedback.
This article
 offers more details about what a CI server does and how it can help you get the most out of CI/CD.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:

This happened about a week ago.
 
First, some background: I am a first year Physics student at a Swiss university, and I just happened to have met my ex-classmate in a train. After a brief chitchat, he eventually asks me:
 
“So, what’re ya studying?”
 
“I think I’ve told you before”, I replied; “its sciency stuff.”
 
“Math?” (if this doesn’t already ring any bells), he asks.
 
“No, but we rely on it heavily”, I reply. “You’re ‘pretty close’ ”.
 
After a few seconds of hesitation, he asks:
 
“Trigonometry?”
 
Now what the ****, seriously. A first year university student, who has previously been in an ‘advanced’ physics class for a few years, while also studying calculus is unable to differentiate between a branch of a subject and the subject itself.
 
Damn, I felt alone on that train. And damn, was I tempted to reply: “Nope, arithmetic.”

article:

I was quite confused and asked, “What language do you think we speak in Australia?” She looked confused, “Don’t you speak French?” Not that I’ve ever noticed.
 
It seemed to be a widespread belief though, because visiting a classmate who was doing a school exchange in another state, we attended her school f

When I was visiting the US, trying to buy clothing I asked the sales assistant to please help me with the sizing as the US size numbering system is different from what I was used to. “Where are you from?” she asked. “Australia,” I replied. “Oh my!” she said. “You speak remarkably good English.”
 
I was quite confused and asked, “What language do you think we speak in Australia?” She looked confused, “Don’t you speak French?” Not that I’ve ever noticed.
 
It seemed to be a widespread belief though, because visiting a classmate who was doing a school exchange in another state, we attended her school for the day. In her French class, one of her American classmates turned to me and said, “This should be really easy for you.”
 
Again I was confused, thinking, “How does he know I studied French at my high school?” I asked why he said that. “Don’t you speak French in Australia?” he replied. “Not unless we studied it in school or emigrated from France,” I told him.

I do not consider myself poor, but some people I have the misfortune to know think they have the right to tell me how I would have lots of money if I….
 
These people go to Tim Hortons three times a day, owe money on their cars, home, credit cards, and bank loans. I live in an apartment building with many tenants on welfare, and new Canadians. I spend more money each month on insulin and special food for my two cats that were dumped when others had enough of them then my husband and I spend on our own food. I rescue other abandoned animals, help rehabilitate and rehome them, I bake for my neighbours, I teach English to those who need help, and I never buy fast food and coffees at outside places. I still wear a pair of jeans that I have owned for 23 years and keep patching, I have no problem wearing others castoffs, yet I consider myself incredibly rich in love from animals and humans.
 
Money may be nice, but sharing what you have is much nicer in my opinion.

During the tour, the tour guy pointed out what is today a bar/restaurant but was originally built under the instruction of Napoleon Bonaparte and meant to be his private residence. One time I was on a date with a guy in the US Air Force; this was our first time meeting so I felt it would be a good idea to go on a walking tour of the French Quarter in New Orleans (the town I was living in at the time).
 
During the tour, the tour guy pointed out what is today a bar/restaurant but was originally built under the instruction of Napoleon Bonaparte and meant to be his private residence. This is now called the “Napoleon House” the tour guide said. I was mortified when my date yelled out “Napoleon who?” And no, he was not being sarcastic. As the tour continued & we were walking I asked my date, “Don’t you know who Napoleon Bonaparte is? Didn’t you never hear of the French Revolution?” He scoffed and said “The only Napoleon I know of is Napoleon Dynamite.” Seriously. That was his response and again he was not being sarcastic.
 
Needless to say, after the tour ended, so did the date—and I have never regretted NOT going on date #2 with that guy.

Have you looked at some of the questions that get asked by my “fellow countrymen” on Quora?
 
But moving on…
 
When I was in the Navy (circa 1967–1971) I heard two bubbas discussing the national anthem. One of them said something like, “It were writ by Stephen H. Foster, during the Civil war!”. As both these guys outranked me by at least three stripes and a couple of dozen hashmarks between them, I said nothing. I was a fly on the wall.
 
The other guy said: “Yer dumber ’n sh*t! Everybody knows what the Star Spangled Banner was writ by Francis Scott Key!”.
 
I was dumbfounded. He actually had gotten it right! I was almost a little proud of him.
 
Then he went on: “…And it weren’t in no Civil War, ya dumbsh*t! He wrote during the war of 1812!”
 
I was doubly dumbfounded! He was already two for two! This guy was on a roll!
 
Then he capped it off to really put the other guy in his place:
 
“…
When the Yankees was attackin’ the Alamo!
”.
 
True story.

This happened many years ago, but it is what came to mind when I read this question…
 
I was teaching class, and we were discussing the U.S. invasion of Iraq. Students were discussing their various thoughts on the situation.
 
One student stated, very loudly, “You know what really bothers me? All those people who are shouting and holding up signs…why aren't they speaking English?”
 
I explained that it is unreasonable to expect people in a foreign country to protest in another country's language. She didn't understand what I meant, and the class was trying to explain to her that Arabic is the language of the people who were protesting.
 
After a while, I stopped everyone and asked her where she thought “those people" lived. She said, “I don't know…near Arizona?”
 
That is when I realized that she thought the the Middle East was next to the American Midwest! I showed her where it is on the map, and she said, “Oh! Things make so much more sense, now!”

title: How should my weekly gym workout be?
article:
The best thing for you to do in terms of exercise is to get a couple of kettle bells, they look like a cannon ball with a handle. There are TONS of workouts online for kettle bell training that uses full body movements like kettle bell swings, squats, thrusters, anything and everything. Not only is this an awesome workout but it will burn more calories for you too. 
 
In terms of diet, if your only issue is cravings then you're in good shape. If you are craving salt a lot then you are quite possibly dehydrated. Try to drink at least 3 litres of water daily. When you are craving a snack, try and g
Continue Reading
The best thing for you to do in terms of exercise is to get a couple of kettle bells, they look like a cannon ball with a handle. There are TONS of workouts online for kettle bell training that uses full body movements like kettle bell swings, squats, thrusters, anything and everything. Not only is this an awesome workout but it will burn more calories for you too. 
 
In terms of diet, if your only issue is cravings then you're in good shape. If you are craving salt a lot then you are quite possibly dehydrated. Try to drink at least 3 litres of water daily. When you are craving a snack, try and go for something that is more protein than a carb. My favourite healthy snack is carrots and hummus, they help me out a ton. Protein shakes help a ton as well because they keep you satiated and feeling full between meals.
 
Let me know if you have any other questions but you'll do great, 30 mins per day is more than enough time to sculpt that physique!
 
-Mike

title: What is a good weekly workout?
article:
Assuming that you have proper range of motion and basic working knowledge of exercising, breathing, and good nutrition.
 
Saturday and Wednesday: 5 -10 min cardio(work up a sweat)
 
2–3 dynamic stretches
 
A set or three of warm up sets before each exercise(e.g. warm up set of 135 lbs for 10–12 reps, then working set of 225 lbs for 8–10 reps)
 
Working Compound Sets:
 
3 sets of 8–10 reps of squats, 4 sets of 8–10 reps on the bench press, 2 sets of 8–10 reps of dead-lifts
 
Super Set:
 
Dumbbell Arnold Press 3 sets of 10–12 and Pulls or Lat pull down 3 sets of 10–12

Super Set:
 
Dumbbell Arnold Press 3 sets of 10–12 and Pulls or Lat pull down 3 sets of 10–12
 
Static L-Sit 3 sets of 10–30 second holds and Oblique workout 3 sets of 10–15
 
Bicep curls 2 sets of 10–12 and Skull Crushers 2 sets of 10–12
 
5–10 min cardio
 
Stretch(pick three yoga stretches work on getting better at them)
 
Approximately 1.5 to 2 hour routine
 
Any further questions please ask. Will be happy to go into specifics.
 
Hope it helps. Good luck!

I thought it was much larger than that.”
 
I was enjoying a day at the National Park in Hana, Maui with some friends and was just returning from a nice swim at one of the seven pools. Walking back down the path a lady is passing me with her partner and asks me if the pools are very far away. I tell her no they are right up ahead. She says to her partner they had better be since its already taking hours to get to them. Then she says why in the hell did they have to put them so far from her hotel!

Mayonnaise
: Some people may not like it. However I do love it not only because it tastes good, but it can also help moisten the sandwich. From my experience, if you don’t spread mayo on your sandwich, it can be very dry for you to swallow your sandwich.
Caramelised Onion
: It adds an amazing sweetness to your sandwich. Sweat your onions (I prefer red onions personally) with some oil, and then add your balsamic vinegar & sugar, let the it reduce until you end up with a soft caramelised onions.
Bacon
: Just because it’s good haha.
Gherkin

Smoke
: When I’m in the mood for it, I like to grill my sandwich. The smokiness from the grill just adds another layer of flavour. I said this because I believe the term “Flavour” is the quality of something that can trigger your 5 senses (taste, smell, hear, sight, feel/touch).

“Your English is very good. It's much better than our tour guide here in China!”
 
I just said “thanks” and proceeded to give myself a (facepalm). She said it with such a smile as if she was so proud of me I really couldn't say anything else.

Well I never actually met this person , but here goes.
 
I was nineteen years old and working at a BPO center where we handled requests from customers in the US.
 
The department I worked in handled orders for agents that worked in phone stores across several states.
 
On this particular day, we were having a backlog of orders because of an issue with the shipment center adjusting to daylight saving time.
 
An irate agent called in, angry about his several orders which were delayed. Like the dutiful customer service agent that I was, I kept calm and tried to explain the issues we were experiencing.
 
He demanded to speak to a supervisor because what I was saying made no sense to him.
 
Since the customer is always right **rolls eyes**, I granted his request.
 
A few minutes later my supervisor gets off the call with the most incredulous look on her face.
 
This man…who was at least thirty years old…had never heard of daylight saving!

I have thought of leaving my country for safety issues but my main concern is my age, 52, a little old to start again in another country. I use Quora mostly to practice my English and to learn interesting things, specially a way to win dollars because any amount is like gold here.

The best workout routine for beginner
The basic thing to do for initial days is to Maintain a healthy diet and avoid fried and fatty foods.
Do full body workout instead of split body workout.
Don't get attracted by marketing of supplements like multivitamin, fish oils, pre-workout etc. These all things are marketing strategies to attract people. You doesn't need any of them ,these things are for professional bodybuilder.
You only need a good protein source it may be whey protein or you can eat any protein rich food at home like paneer, curd ,soaked chickpea etc.
Drink enough water and Maintain hydration.
For beginner Don't do heavy workout, only 2 repeatation per muscle is enough for you.
Do stretching and mobility exercises.
Before workout warmup is very very important. Do warmup of joints.
Rest is as important as workout. So after a full body workout rest for atleast one day.
Finally overall your diet and rest determines your muscle gain.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
I used to live in the U.S., and so I’ve met a lot of ignorant Americans; some would ask whether people in Finland live in igloos, whether we have polar bears wandering on the streets, and so on. But that’s “normal”.
 
The most ignorant American I ever met, or the one that best comes to mind, was an elderly lady next to whom I sat on a flight from Albuquerque to Boston. This lady was friendly enough, and asked me what I did for a living. I had already moved back to Finland by that time, and I was studying at the University of Helsinki while employed as a research assistant at the local Accelerator
Continue Reading
I used to live in the U.S., and so I’ve met a lot of ignorant Americans; some would ask whether people in Finland live in igloos, whether we have polar bears wandering on the streets, and so on. But that’s “normal”.
 
The most ignorant American I ever met, or the one that best comes to mind, was an elderly lady next to whom I sat on a flight from Albuquerque to Boston. This lady was friendly enough, and asked me what I did for a living. I had already moved back to Finland by that time, and I was studying at the University of Helsinki while employed as a research assistant at the local Accelerator Laboratory. I explained this to her, confident that everybody at least knew what particle accelerators are.
 
She looked at me, slightly puzzled. Then, she asked: “Accelerator… sort of like airplanes? They accelerate, right?”
 
I can proudly say that I didn’t laugh at this sweet old lady, but I’m afraid we didn’t talk much for the rest of the flight.

title: What is a good workout routine at home?
article:
Working out from home is a great way to elevate your overall fitness. Here are just some things that you can do:
Bodyweight Circuit: 
Squats, lunges, push-ups, burpees. 30 seconds per exercise, minimal rest, repeat 2-3 times.
HIIT (High-Intensity Interval Training): 
Intense exercises (e.g., jumping jacks) with short rest. Aim for 20-30 minutes.
Yoga: 
Boost flexibility and mental well-being. Various levels available online.
Strength Training: 
Use resistance bands or household items. Focus on squats, deadlifts, and bench presses.
Cardio Workouts: 
Running in place, jumping rope, or dancing. Aim for 150

While I assumed he meant questions about World War 2 and the Nazis, it was actually a bit more rudimentary than that.

- “No, there’s an ocean in the way.”
“Do they have cars in Germany?”
 
- “Yes. Have you heard of BMW o

In 1999 I was an American high school exchange student living in a small town in Germany.
 
One of my friends in the town had been a German exchange student in Louisiana the previous year and while he loved the experience and the people, he admitted that he did have to repeatedly answer profoundly basic questions about where he was from and what it was like. While I assumed he meant questions about World War 2 and the Nazis, it was actually a bit more rudimentary than that.
“Can you drive to Germany?”
 
- “No, there’s an ocean in the way.”
“Do they have cars in Germany?”
 
- “Yes. Have you heard of BMW or Mercedes or Porche?”
 
“Yeah.”
“Those are German cars. They are made in Germany.”
“Do you have houses in Germany?”
 
- “No, we all live in trees. My sister and I each have a tree and my parents have a bigger tree of their own.”
 
“Wow, that’s so cool.”
Obviously that last answer isn’t true, but it was readily believed and accepted.

title: What is the best workout routine to follow?
article:
If you want to work out five days per week and are working on both strength and cardiovascular fitness, try three days of strength training, two days of cardio, and two days of active rest. If you want to work out four days a week, think about your goals: If you want to add muscle, cut a cardio day.
 
Keep the fuss to a minimum and stick with the basics.
 
Lunges. Challenging your balance is an essential part of a well-rounded exercise routine.

Unfortunately, I’ve only been to the US once, to visit family.
 
I was a child at the time, the second youngest of five. We were all excited as it was our first trip abroad and a big event when you’ve got five kids (age range from 7 to 16) My poor parents manage to stagger off our flight from Glasgow and we get through passport control. My father hands over our family passport (still allowed at that time) which clearly stated that we were UK citizens. The lovely lady in passport control then had the following conversation with my dad:
 
Lady: “Are you from Ireland?” (I can only guess it was the accent)
 
Dad: “No, we’re Scottish.”
 
Lady: “You’re Scottish. Oh my! Your children speak such good English!”
 
Dad: “Er… thanks. It’s actually the language we speak in Scotland.”
 
I still wonder how someone could work in passport control, regularly process planeloads of Scottish people and not know that everyone in Scotland speaks English.

title: What is the best workout for me?
article:
Personally I enjoy fully body rack sessions, biking, and running.
 
Rack session to failure: Squats, Bench press, Deadlifts, Rack pulls, and Shoulder press. I do this on the smith so I can remain at the same rack. This is great for my lazy days, and when the gym is packed.
 
Biking: Stationary bike or bmx. BMX, you pretty much have to stand and actually put in the work to get over different terrain, unlike the typical bike which has gears to adjust. The stationary bike, I like, I can get my 10–24 miles in without the wear tear of terrain.
 
Running: I like for hiit. I tend to run in intervals. 5 minute

Personally I enjoy fully body rack sessions, biking, and running.
 
Rack session to failure: Squats, Bench press, Deadlifts, Rack pulls, and Shoulder press. I do this on the smith so I can remain at the same rack. This is great for my lazy days, and when the gym is packed.
 
Biking: Stationary bike or bmx. BMX, you pretty much have to stand and actually put in the work to get over different terrain, unlike the typical bike which has gears to adjust. The stationary bike, I like, I can get my 10–24 miles in without the wear tear of terrain.
 
Running: I like for hiit. I tend to run in intervals. 5 minutes straight running, 3 minutes walking, 3minutes running, 5 mins walking, 10 running, 1 walking, 4min run, etc. On the treadmill it’s different, there’s not a lot of impact on my feet and legs from terrain. This way I can protect my feet, and legs from micro trauma and lowers the risk of re-injury. I do this for about 30–60mins.

In 1988, while in New York State I was on the train from Poughkeepsie to NYC. I was 17 years old (soon to be 18). I encountered a young man in his 20’s who told me he was a waste engineer normally working in Washington, DC but traveling at the time. When I told him I was from Portland, Oregon which is a “city”, he seriously remarked this…
 
“I thought you all lived in grass huts and smoke weed all day.”
 
Grass huts, no. The rain prevents such habitats and never could be a reality. Portland is a city. We live in houses and apartments like everyone else. Weed however… well let me tell you all now that even in 1983, weed in Oregon was so much better than weed anywhere else that those who knew better… refused to partake in other states. But “all day”? Nah. I tried NY weed once. It was brown and weird, tasted like crap and didn’t work.
 
Now we go to “the weed store” just like going to the grocery store, and it’s not weird at all.

Assuming you mean financially poor, I would qualify. My social security, and only income, is below the U.S. poverty line for a family of three. That includes my wife and one of her grandsons who lives with us. If we lived in the U.S. I imagine it would be stressful. Here in Mexico, we are fine.
 
We live in a small (38 sq. meter/400+ sq. ft) house. My wife owns it, so we don’t pay rent. If we did, it would be the equivalent of less than $150 per month. We are in an area with good public transportation, so we don’t need/have a car. We pay what would be about $550 USD per *year* for health insurance via the government health system. Unlike most financially poor people, we have savings that amount to about $4,000 USD. Barring a real emergency, it is untouchable.
 
Twenty five years ago, I had a low six figure income. All things considered, my life now involves less stuff and less stress. I have no complaints… and I don’t feel poor.

black!”

They replied, “Oh, no, if you’re from Africa, you must be black!”

With the caveat that people from East Tennessee love to make fun of their hillbilly roots and this was a story told by a former politician, here goes. Lamar Alexander was speaking at a sports hall of Fame ceremony I attended in his home town of Maryville TN. He had had been the governor and US. senator of the state of Tennessee, as well as a US Cabinet member, so highly regarded.
 
A little more background, highway 321 winds just north of the Smoky Mountains from Lenoir City to Pigeon Forge, the home of Dollywood. It is named the Lamar Alexander Parkway.
 
The distinguished Mr. Alexander recounted that one morning driving down Highway 321 he stopped at a gas station for a cup of coffee. As he had no cash on him he presented his debit card to the young lady at the register. She examined the card with growing confusion, finally giving up and looking at him. “Was you named after this road"?
 
That was one entertaining night.

title: Is it bad to do full body workouts every day?
article:
Bad, no.
 
But not ideal.
 
The problem is the muscles need time to rest.
 
So if you want to do full body workouts every day, that is fine. But it’s not the optimal way toward muscle and strength growth.
 
Two better options:
Full body workouts three days a week with at least a day in between workouts, or
Some type of split routine, where the different muscles are never taxed two days in a row
The point is for muscles to get 48+ hours of rest in between being beaten up in the exercise routines.
 
If you like full body workouts, but you don’t want to have days you don’t exercise, there are other options for the
Continue Reading
Bad, no.
 
But not ideal.
 
The problem is the muscles need time to rest.
 
So if you want to do full body workouts every day, that is fine. But it’s not the optimal way toward muscle and strength growth.
 
Two better options:
Full body workouts three days a week with at least a day in between workouts, or
Some type of split routine, where the different muscles are never taxed two days in a row
The point is for muscles to get 48+ hours of rest in between being beaten up in the exercise routines.
 
If you like full body workouts, but you don’t want to have days you don’t exercise, there are other options for the “rest” days. You can use them for cardio. Stretching. Yoga. Long walks.
 
You certainly can, and probably should, exercise every single day. It’s good for the body. Great for the soul! But if you’re going to put your body through all that stress, you should definitely seek the path to the best results.

My ignorant Americans weren't actually in the States but I love this story.
 
July 4; Verona, Italy. Met a couple from Massachusetts. He was a teacher (!) and she was an administrator.
 
I wished them a happy Independence Day and he went off about how disappointed they are by the lack of celebrations (in Italy) for July 4.
 
I'm Canadian, so I bit my tongue and politely told them that I'd been with a group of Americans on July 1 and they'd made a big deal out of wishing me a happy Canada Day and they'd even bought me a specialty dessert in Siena to celebrate.
 
He looked at me like I was crazy, shrugged, and said he had no idea when that was.
 
So, you expect another country, on another continent, to celebrate YOUR independence day but you can't even be polite enough to pretend to care about your next door neighbours independence day.
 
I just smiled politely to his face and have laughed at his ignorance for years.

The evening before that assignment was due, a black woman walked in with her daughter looking for materials on Joan of Arc. As diplomatically as I could, I explained that all the materials on Joan of Arc were checked out, and recommended she pick someone else. The mother asked who, and I suggested St. Thomas Aquinas. When the woman a

I was working as a reference librarian in College Station, TX years ago. We would cooperate with the schools in providing materials for student assignments. This particular assignment was to write about a Medieval personage, with Joan of Arc being the most popular.
 
The evening before that assignment was due, a black woman walked in with her daughter looking for materials on Joan of Arc. As diplomatically as I could, I explained that all the materials on Joan of Arc were checked out, and recommended she pick someone else. The mother asked who, and I suggested St. Thomas Aquinas. When the woman asked who he was, I explained that he was the greatest of the Catholic philosophers and theologians. Well, this woman looked at me like I had told her she stunk. She told me, “My daughter ain’t doin’ no paper on no Catholic!”. Then she said to her daughter, “c’mon honey, let’s go get you some books on Joan of Arc,” and stormed out.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
In Germany at university, in the early 1990s, we had a guy who became a German citizen. His parents were from Turkey (Türkiye), but he was born in Germany, spoke perfect German, and – if I may say so – didn’t look “Turkish”. If you didn’t know his background you would think he is German.
 
When somebody in Germany becomes a citizen, that person is considered basically 100% or very close to 100% German. You are part of “the team”.
 
Or so we thought. Along came another guy, an American student, Peter (name changed), who insisted that not matter what he will always consider him Turkish, and he will al
Continue Reading
In Germany at university, in the early 1990s, we had a guy who became a German citizen. His parents were from Turkey (Türkiye), but he was born in Germany, spoke perfect German, and – if I may say so – didn’t look “Turkish”. If you didn’t know his background you would think he is German.
 
When somebody in Germany becomes a citizen, that person is considered basically 100% or very close to 100% German. You are part of “the team”.
 
Or so we thought. Along came another guy, an American student, Peter (name changed), who insisted that not matter what he will always consider him Turkish, and he will always be a Turk for him. Peter even went out of his way to say this to his face. Something along the lines: you are not and never will be German because you are Turkish and for me you will always be a Turk.
 
When we tried to talk to Peter, he insisted on being right and got very agitated. There was no way to change his mind.

Where I worked in the mid-90s, we internally posted a job opening for an account liaison for Central and South America. A lady from the purchasing department applied.
 
When we interviewed her, my co-worker asked, “Are you fluent in Spanish?”
 
She said, “No, I don't speak Spanish. I don't see why it would be a requirement for the job.”
 
My co-worker nicely let her know that fluency in Spanish is a primary requirement listed in the job description.
 
She asked, “why?”
 
I replied, “Because you'll be working with clients in Nicaragua, Costa Rica, and Colombia.”
 
She looked at me puzzled. “I thought this job was working with customers in Central and South America?”
 
My co-worker caught on and asked her? “What do you think is in these parts of America?”
 
“Everyone knows,” she began, “Michigan is in North America, Missouri is in Central America, and Alabama is in South America. And they all speak English.”

I was interested in the culture of the country and its history. I also tried to learn a few phrases in the language of the country. I will confess that my French and German were far better than my Vietnamese, Korean, and Tagalog. While at a military dinner at Ft. Leavenwort

I was saddened to read these responses concerning American ignorance of other countries and cultures. As I traveled around the world during my military service, one of the first things I did, even before arriving, was to get out a map to see where I was going to be (I did have a pretty good handle on basic world geography). I was interested in the culture of the country and its history. I also tried to learn a few phrases in the language of the country. I will confess that my French and German were far better than my Vietnamese, Korean, and Tagalog. While at a military dinner at Ft. Leavenworth KS, my wife and I were seated across from an Afghanistan officer. When the main course was served, he asked what it was, and it was either chicken or veal cordon bleu. As I said that, I commented, “You’re Muslim, aren’t you?” He replied, “Yes” I reached out to the host with the problem, and the officer got a T-bone steak replacement.

title: How often should I workout for best results?
article:
The American Heart Association recommends that adults engage in at least 150 minutes of moderate-intensity aerobic activity or 75 minutes of vigorous-intensity aerobic activity per week, spread out over at least three days per week, for optimal fitness results. Strength training exercises should also be done at least two days per week.
 
However, the optimal number of days per week for exercise can vary depending on individual factors such as fitness level, goals, and schedule. It's important to listen to your body and consult with a healthcare professional or certified fitness trainer to create

The American Heart Association recommends that adults engage in at least 150 minutes of moderate-intensity aerobic activity or 75 minutes of vigorous-intensity aerobic activity per week, spread out over at least three days per week, for optimal fitness results. Strength training exercises should also be done at least two days per week.
 
However, the optimal number of days per week for exercise can vary depending on individual factors such as fitness level, goals, and schedule. It's important to listen to your body and consult with a healthcare professional or certified fitness trainer to create a personalized exercise plan that works best for you.
 
There are many great fitness apps, wearable technology, and gym equipment available to help you achieve your fitness goals. You can research and compare options to find what works best for you and fits your budget and lifestyle.

Marsha Blackburn. At the time she was a state senator and she came into the radio station I worked at for an interview. She had a man with her who was a little older than her and I don’t recall his name or his role. Throughout the interview, during commercial breaks this man would tell her that what she just said was wrong, and in one case told her that the legislation she was advocating for would do exactly the opposite of what she just said it would do. She looked at me and rolled her eyes as if to say she thought the man was being ridiculous by correcting her. Her entire attitude was that it didn’t matter what the legislation did and that this was just an opportunity for her to get her name out there. I was a die hard Republican at the time and told another one of our hosts that we’d be better off losing that seat to the Democrats. Absolutely the dumbest politician I’ve ever met, and I’ve met a lot from both parties.

what? What? Hold on.
 
he repeated the plate.
 
what the fuck is that? I can’t write that fast. November? That is on the licence plate? What’s all the other words?

it took him about 20 minutes to get her to write down a 7 character license plate.
 
man I felt bad for him having to work with morons like that.

Start with bodyweight exercises like squats – the OG booty lifters! Spice it up with push-ups for those biceps and triceps to sparkle. Grab a chair for dips – it's like a mini arm party!
 
Don't forget the core – planks are your secret weapon for a strong, sassy midsection. Jumping jacks add a touch of cardio fun, keeping the heart pumping. Want to level up? Grab a couple of water bottles for makeshift weights – hydration and strength, double win!
 
Now, consistency is the name of the game. Aim for 3-4 times a week, but listen to your body – it's your BFF in this journey. As you get stronger, sprinkle in more challenges. Maybe try balancing on one leg while brushing your teeth – multitasking at its finest!
 
Lastly, enjoy the process, my strong friend. Your living room is now your strength sanctuary, and those muscles will be singing your praises. Let the at-home strength extravaganza begin – you've got this!

I have to admit that I’ve had a few laughs at the expense of Americans, mainly because some of them seem to be incredibly ignorant of the world outside of the USA and hold the belief that almost everything that they do culturally is what the rest of the world also does. I’ve lost count of the number of times I’ve been in a chat room and had someone from the US ask, “So what are you guys doing for the 4th of July?”
 
But the biggest clanger I’ve ever heard an American come out with was in 2009, when, on the eve of the US presidential election, Stevie Wonder told his audience, “Don’t forget to vote for Barak Obama tomorrow.”
 
I know the bloke is blind, but surely he knew what country he was in and surely he didn’t believe that the people of Perth, Western Australia, had the legal right to vote in US elections!
 
I hope some one has a story to top this one because I’m sure there could be a book in it - a big book!

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
I was walking across the Millennium Bridge in London a few years ago. Two American ladies, both quite old, asked me to take a photo of them with St Paul’s Cathedral in the background. I did so happily. One of them then told me that she thought it was “good that they had modelled that building on our US Capitol”. I stifled laughter and told her that the dome of St Paul’s Cathedral was around 150–200 years older than the dome of the US Capitol. I wasn’t sure of the exact dates myself. (Both buildings are older than their domes.) The lady actually laughed at me and said “Oh please!” 🤣 “Ma’am,” I 
Continue Reading
I was walking across the Millennium Bridge in London a few years ago. Two American ladies, both quite old, asked me to take a photo of them with St Paul’s Cathedral in the background. I did so happily. One of them then told me that she thought it was “good that they had modelled that building on our US Capitol”. I stifled laughter and told her that the dome of St Paul’s Cathedral was around 150–200 years older than the dome of the US Capitol. I wasn’t sure of the exact dates myself. (Both buildings are older than their domes.) The lady actually laughed at me and said “Oh please!” 🤣 “Ma’am,” I said, “I think the US Capitol dome is really quite new. I mean, in Europe it would barely be regarded as historic.” I offered to look the dates up on my phone for her, but she stormed off with her friend, calling me a moron. It was difficult to work out why she had left her country! Those dates were 1710 and 1866, by the way.

Well you have to prioritise them accordingly depending upon what your body demands.
 
When you look at your naked body in the mirror, what do you see? Unless you are some sort of genetic muscle mutant, your body will fall into one of the three typical body shapes.

 Lean and long, with difficulty building muscle

 Big, high body fat, often pear-shaped, with a high tendency to store body fat

 Muscular and well-built, with a high metabolism and responsive muscle cells
If you're
 
Ectomorph 
gym should be your priority. You should consume high protein diet.
Mesomorphs 
should preferably go for both cardio and strength.
Endomorphs 
on the other hand should give their priority to cardio i.e. running ,etc. You should prefer high fat medium protein and very low carbs diet (the keto) .
Eat healthy keep working hard.
 
Jai hind

title: What is the best workout for me?
article:
I define best by how well it addresses my immediate goals, which alter over the year. I typically define by training cycles about 1 year out and then have several 3–4 month blocks that are dedicated to specific outcomes, but also flow well with each other.
 
For example, while I’m a powerlifter, I’m dropping down a weight class so I’m focused on hypertrophy. I find I do better with this style of training when I’m cutting weight, compared to a strength cycle. It’s a lot of sets in the 8–12 range depending on the movement, with just a few heavy singles mixed in to preserve top-end strength.

I define best by how well it addresses my immediate goals, which alter over the year. I typically define by training cycles about 1 year out and then have several 3–4 month blocks that are dedicated to specific outcomes, but also flow well with each other.
 
For example, while I’m a powerlifter, I’m dropping down a weight class so I’m focused on hypertrophy. I find I do better with this style of training when I’m cutting weight, compared to a strength cycle. It’s a lot of sets in the 8–12 range depending on the movement, with just a few heavy singles mixed in to preserve top-end strength.
 
Once my weight is where I want it I’ll return to powerlifting training, which is mostly done in the 3–5 range for core lifts and slightly higher for assistance lifts.
 
In my experience, the biggest mistake people make is not identifying their goals clearly enough, whichever makes it hard to choose the right program.

article:

It turned out that not only had he never heard of the US Civil War, he didn't know about slavery. I did my best to explain the issues to him, but felt like maybe I did him a disservice by exposing him to this painful history of which he was blissfully unaware. I have asked myself ever since “how did educating him about these things improve his life?”
 
It certainly seemed like he was not happy to learn he was

I recently worked closely with a young man (late 20s), of African ancestry, who was genuinely confused about why the Confederate flag was so controversial and offensive to African Americans. It turned out that not only had he never heard of the US Civil War, he didn't know about slavery. I did my best to explain the issues to him, but felt like maybe I did him a disservice by exposing him to this painful history of which he was blissfully unaware. I have asked myself ever since “how did educating him about these things improve his life?”
 
It certainly seemed like he was not happy to learn he was ignorant of these matters.
 
Footnote: another young man of African ancestry overheard the conversation and stated that the Confederate flag represented all people black and white who fought for the South. I didnt have the energy to even deal with this statement.
 
Let me tell you, Kentucky is a very unique place.

In Thailand a few years ago, a lovely young man from South Africa gave me a ride on the back of his motorbike. I asked where he was from in South Africa.
 
“Johannesburg,” he replied.
 
I said something generic like, “Oh cool.”
 
He was surprised. “You've heard of it?!”
 
I was a bit offended. “Why wouldn't I have?!”
 
To be honest, my knowledge of South Africa was and still is severely limited. If he had said any city other than Johannesburg or Cape Town, I would have stared at him blankly and asked how far said city was from Johannesburg or Cape Town, my only two reference points.
 
But I was offended that he had 
assumed
 I wouldn't know. I seemed worldly and sophisticated … 
didn't I?
 
Then he said, “It's just I met another American the other day and when I told him I was from South Africa, he asked where it was in Africa.”
 
“Uh huh…”
 
“I told him it was in the north. He believed me.”

I mean just because I have brown skin and do not have slit eyes, does not mean I am not Asian. Nepal is in ASIA. Go to Google maps. Asia is the largest continent and it has various races. Asia is not only consist of yellow race and small, slit eyes. From Middle-East to South-East, everyone is Asian. India itself has so many races from the people who have small, slit eyes to big, brown eyes, from pale skin to rich brown skin. And same goes to my country. We have diversity. Asian consists of many races. So please open up your eyes and mind, ‘Mericans.

title: What is a good workout routine at home?
article:
Any good workout routine should have a proper structure to avoid any injuries and to see progress.
 
So, before diving into workouts, ensure your body is ready with a brief warm-up, followed by cardio and other workouts and end it with a cool-down workout.
 
Here’s a sample workout routine you could follow:
 
Warm-Up (5 minutes):
Jumping Jacks
Arm Circle
Leg Swings
March in Place
Cardio (15 minutes):
Jumping Jacks
High Knees
Lunges
Squats
Core workouts (10 minutes):
Plank
Russian Twists
Mountain Climbers
Leg Raises
Cool Down (10 minutes):
Seated Forward Bend
Child's Pose
Cobra Stretch
Quad Stretch
Consult with a healthcar

I’ve never met this American in-person, nor do I know who he is. But, I was going through ‘Americans were asked to place European countries on the map’ pictures. Obviously, there was a ton of mistakes and laugh from my side, but that was nothing compared to one particular picture.
 
This brainiac placed a total of 5 countries correctly - the United Kingdom, Ireland, Spain, France and Germany. Among other things, he placed Denmark in Sweden, Poland in Bulgaria, Italy in Portugal (!), Cyprus on Crete, Iceland in Northern Ireland and along with poorly drawn snowmen and snowflakes, he placed Switzerland in Hungary. If this didn’t amaze you, wait until you hear that he placed Russia in Asia and Africa (only European borders were shown so I’m assuming he saw a big chunk of land and thought it was Russia).
 
I realize he is American and all, but you gotta be completely uneducated to do something like this.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
I don’t know if a meta-answer is permissible, but every time I encounter an answer to this question it strikes me that bring surprised by ignorance is itself a bit ignorant Ignorance, after all, is the default state. No matter how obvious a fact may seem to be, you aren’t born knowing it. History and geography are simply not emphasized in American schools; but more than that, the message isn’t conveyed that grown up human beings should know about such things. Under the circumstances, it’s hardly a wonder if an American kid can’t find France on a map. If anything is worthy of surprise or, more

I don’t know if a meta-answer is permissible, but every time I encounter an answer to this question it strikes me that bring surprised by ignorance is itself a bit ignorant Ignorance, after all, is the default state. No matter how obvious a fact may seem to be, you aren’t born knowing it. History and geography are simply not emphasized in American schools; but more than that, the message isn’t conveyed that grown up human beings should know about such things. Under the circumstances, it’s hardly a wonder if an American kid can’t find France on a map. If anything is worthy of surprise or, more to the point, of concern, it ought to be that our institutions do such a rotten job of informing people or making them want to inform themselves. Of course it isn’t just the schools that fail. I reserve a large portion of my scorn for the Society for the Promotion of Public Ignorance that is American journalism.

It depends on your goals, do you want to be an athlete, powerlifter, weightlifter(Olympic), Bodybuilder, a Model, a Strongman(the sport), a Strong guy?
 
It all depends on your goals.
 
Starting Strength is a good foundational program for guys trying to get strong and don’t care about aesthetics. Someone who had never trained before but wanted to be a Strongman, or a Strong guy might like this program.
 
5/3/1 or the Juggernaut Method are great for people who want to be powerlifters.
 
Catalyst Athletics has tons of programs for Olympic Weightlifters.
 
Bodybuilding is the most tricky but I have heard good things about Arnold’s Blueprint to Mass and Jim Stopanni’s programs. For modeling you could do the same with maybe less volume for legs.
 
For an athlete there are tons of sport-specific programs out there, and Athlean-X is pretty great for losing body fat while staying athletic.

article:
Not too long ago my high school’s biology class decided to take a little trip to the Oregon Coast for a field study on marine biology. While my friend and I were taking pH and salinity samples of some tide pools a man with a camera I’m going to call him Joe.
 
Joe: 
So do you know when I can see a killer whale?
 
Me:
 Uhh…..
 
I give him the “one moment finger” trying to remember some of the info my biology teacher said about whales in the area.
 
Joe: 
Do you even speak English?
 
I stand there dumbfounded for a moment. He then proceeds to tap my friend next to me and ask her if I spoke English.
 
Friend: 
Uhhh……
 
J

So where are you from?

Dakota.
 
As I walk away I hear him mumble something along the lines of “I never knew there was a city in China called Dakota.”

title: What is a good at home workout routine for intermediate beginners?
article:
Oh yeah.
 
Full body routines are GREAT when I don't have much time. If you focus on compound movements (large movements that involve a lot of body parts) you can get a fabulous workout in not a lot of time. 
 
Here's a cheat sheet on how to structure a full body workout for best results. Choose 1-2 exercises from each section and do 2-4 sets of 8-12 reps with challenging weight.
Push Motion:
 Pushup, Bench Press, Chest Fly, Dips
Pull Motion:
 Deadlift, Bent Over Row, Pull Up, Lat Pulldown, Seated Row
Leg Motion:
 Squat, Leg Press, Lunges, Hip Thrusts
Press Motion:
 Barbell Overhead Press, Dumbbell Overhead
Continue Reading

There was a woman I worked with for years that, though she had graduated high school, she must not have learned much. On a fairly regular basis she would ask questions or make statements that would stop your brain for a moment. We worked together in the same office for more than 10 years and knew a fair amount about each other's lives (birth of a child, new car, vacation, death of a family member, etc.) Very often she would ask about some topic in the news an, at best would have some knowledge but it would be mixed up. (For example, she thought it was terrible when they tore down the Berlin Wall - it had stood for more than a thousand years and it could be seen from space.)
 
One day we had the following conversation:
 
Her: You're Jewish right?
 
Me: Yes
 
Her: so you have had one of those circumcisions?
 
Me: Yes
 
Her: How often do you have to get that done?
 
Me: Every time I get a haircut.

My Junior year in college, a couple of my friends convinced me to go to NYC with them. I hate cities, but I was the kind of person at the age of 20 that with enough begging I'll hand you my wallet.
 
Turned out to be an ok trip. Met a couple people from Ireland and Scotland. My ancestors are from there, so I was excited to interact with people who grew up in my grandparents home land.
 
I digress. We went to an Irish bar. I was sitting next to this lady who apparently lived really close to the place. Something like piano man came on and we both started singing to it. Really fun. We bonded a bit so small talk ensued.
 
I can't recall how the topic came up, but when we talked about the tragedy of 9/11 she explained that apparently most people from NYC had no idea it happened for months. She went on blissfully for roughly 4 months before realizing the event even happened.
 
How… just… how.

title: What is your favorite sandwich ingredient?
article:
Ham croissant sandwich with latte

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
Is this ignorance? Or… I don’t even know.
 
I got a call, a telephone poll. The operator had a soft but unmistakeable accent. I’d guess Galveston. After the questions about (if I recall correctly) how pleased I was with my recycling service, she read from her script, “Now I have some demographic questions about you and your household, if you don’t mind. What is your profession?”
 
“I’m a computer programmer.”
 
“And what is the ethnic background of your family?”
 
“We’re Asian.”
 
She gives that chuckle you make when you figure something out. “That explains it.” Her accent was much stronger when she was spea

Is this ignorance? Or… I don’t even know.
 
I got a call, a telephone poll. The operator had a soft but unmistakeable accent. I’d guess Galveston. After the questions about (if I recall correctly) how pleased I was with my recycling service, she read from her script, “Now I have some demographic questions about you and your household, if you don’t mind. What is your profession?”
 
“I’m a computer programmer.”
 
“And what is the ethnic background of your family?”
 
“We’re Asian.”
 
She gives that chuckle you make when you figure something out. “That explains it.” Her accent was much stronger when she was speaking for herself and not reading from the script.
 
“Explains what?”
 
She answered, in the sweetest, most guileless tone, “Computers are so difficult and you Asians are always so smart.”
 
Simultaneously, the nicest and the most racist thing anyone has ever said to me.

This is an interesting topic indeed. From most people's perspective I would probably be classified as “poor”:
 
• I don't have a car (I can't drive anyway, because I’m visually impaired)
 
• I don't have a TV (I don't like it, to me it's a waste of time and money)
 
• I don't have a big place (it's easier for me to get around and I don't have to clean as much)
 
• I don't have many clothes/shoes (I move around a lot, so a small wardrobe has its perks)
 
My lifestyle is quite minimalistic and I don't need much stuff to be happy. Even if I had won the lottery, I would still keep the same stuff as I have now unless it breaks. But even then I wouldn't have a problem to buy used items.
 
Money is only a tool to pay the bills and buy whatever is needed to live more or less comfortably. With a lower cost of living I can actually afford a few girly things or gadgets now and then.

During quarantine, I did pull ups every day for 30 days. These are some pros and cons that I observed:
 
Pros:
Your muscles will become more defined. 
Maybe it’s also got something to do with my diet, but I became leaner and my back and arm muscles were more clearly visible.
Pull ups become easier. 
It sounds obvious, but what I mean is your body starts to find the most efficient way to manipulate the muscles to perform a pull up, allowing you to increase your reps
Cons:
Your blisters might hurt
. 
A bit.
 This is especially true if you’re not used to having blisters around where the fingers connect to the palm. Just have to suck it up, they’ll disappear soon.
You’re not doing enough in the workout. Only one side of your upper body is being worked with this one exercise. What about your chest and legs? Incorporate pushups, squats and lunges for a more comprehensive workout.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
The worst personal experience I had was actually in the UK.
 
Just after the 9/11 disaster I was in Birmingham for a broadcasting trade show. Our UK distributer had also some other technical people over from the US. When the show was finished we decided to take a cab to the airport together to limit costs.
 
Aside the first available taxi stood a guy looking a bit like this:
My American partner’s reaction was: “I’m not getting in his taxi, I don’t trust it. You know what happened in New York.”
 
I was a bit flabbergasted and told him: “But he is not an Arab. He’s a Sikh, from India. These people have no
Continue Reading
The worst personal experience I had was actually in the UK.
 
Just after the 9/11 disaster I was in Birmingham for a broadcasting trade show. Our UK distributer had also some other technical people over from the US. When the show was finished we decided to take a cab to the airport together to limit costs.
 
Aside the first available taxi stood a guy looking a bit like this:
My American partner’s reaction was: “I’m not getting in his taxi, I don’t trust it. You know what happened in New York.”
 
I was a bit flabbergasted and told him: “But he is not an Arab. He’s a Sikh, from India. These people have nothing to do with that attack.”
 
But he could not accept that: “He’s wearing one of those turbans and he has a beard. How do you know that he’s not a terrorist?”
 
At a certain point I had to give up and accept that we would take another taxi. There was still a plane to catch.

title: How often should I workout for best results?
article:
As often as you can. If you are a beginner than start 3 times a week, nonconsecutive days, with full body workouts. Later on, as you progress you can switch to any split or template that fits with your lifestyle. You can stay at three times a week full body, or four times with upper/lower, upper/lower body split, or even six times with push/pull/legs done twice ina week by alternating the muscle groups worked. Find a porgram online, there are many good free ones, that has as many days as your scedule allows, from three to six and go for it. But be realistic, if you’re not sure you can consiste

As often as you can. If you are a beginner than start 3 times a week, nonconsecutive days, with full body workouts. Later on, as you progress you can switch to any split or template that fits with your lifestyle. You can stay at three times a week full body, or four times with upper/lower, upper/lower body split, or even six times with push/pull/legs done twice ina week by alternating the muscle groups worked. Find a porgram online, there are many good free ones, that has as many days as your scedule allows, from three to six and go for it. But be realistic, if you’re not sure you can consistently do a certain number of days for at least a few months from now, then choose less days. But basically, with three to four you can’t go wrong. Just make sure you train all your muscle groups at least twice a week, with at least one rest day between them, and you will be fine. Hope this helps.

This was around the time when Lil Jon was still relevant. About a year beforehand he had released “Let’s go.” It was high school, so there was a LOT of ignorance going around, but this one… this one sticks out a bit.
 
There we were… home room. The morning announcements come on. Nobody’s paying TOO much attention because it’s the morning news. All of a sudden, Crazy Train plays over the intro to one of the segments. That’s when X (we’ll call him X) pipes in, loud enough for everyone to hear, “I can’t believe Ozzy ripped off Lil Jon!” Silence… Aside from the tv and the announcements, the room was silent. All faces, teacher’s included, were facing X. Some mouths were agape, jaws set in a silent position that screams bewilderment until someone says “What!?”
 
Okay, maybe this wasn’t THE most ignorant person I’ve met here in the States, but it was definitely a moment worth mentioning.

My wife and I were there with an English couple we were friends with when we all met this blonde valley 
girl.
 
It
 seemed we could not shake her off while she talked without end. She was especially glomed on to our friends’ wife Bea, who was from a small town SE of London, the only break was for her to refill her glass.
 
So finally we sit for dinner, and wouldn't you know it she took the seat in the middle of us. Out of her continual chatter came the question to Bea, “I just love your accent, where is it from? “; to which I said without even picking my head up, “Atlanta! “.
 
Without hesitation she said, “Oh! I’ve always wanted to go there! Can you tell me where to go? “ That was the only time I saw Bea shoot liquid from her nose trying so hard hold in her laughing.

This was right after I got out of school and got my new job in the state of Mississippi. I was excited with the money I was making. Since my childhood in India, I always had plans to visit some of the best tourist spots in the US. One of the places I wanted to visit was the Niagara Falls!!!! I remember reading about it in middle school in India and had dreamed about visiting it some day.
 
So after about a few months into the job, I planned a trip to Niagara Falls. My colleague who’s also an Engineer asked me what I was doing for the weekend. I couldn't control my excitement and told him that I'm going to visit the Niagara Falls. And his response was "What's Niagara Falls?” I couldn't believe someone in the US would not know about it! Turns out he's quite ignorant and has never been out of Mississippi in his entire life. I still find it incredulous. I mean Niagara Falls!!!!!!

title: How often should I workout for best results?
article:
You'll continue to exert the same amount of energy, your smartwatch will tell you you're burning the same calories, but the weight will stop dropping off. If you do the same workout repeatedly, your body adapts and you get fewer gains every time you do that routine.

title: What happens if you workout every day?
article:
Anything in excess is bad but exceptions exists too.
Personally having trained for 7 days a week for few months did not help with muscle recovery. I was so obsessed that I stopped caring for results and blindly lifted heavy weights daily . Although I had read about overtraining and it's cons but I continued. I was missing the peace of mind and felt weakness because of aggressive training. Maybe because my body was not able to adapt considering I have a desk job.
 
I started taking a day off and later found the ideal split with 2 days off in a week gave some serious results. I feel more strength an
Continue Reading
Anything in excess is bad but exceptions exists too.
Personally having trained for 7 days a week for few months did not help with muscle recovery. I was so obsessed that I stopped caring for results and blindly lifted heavy weights daily . Although I had read about overtraining and it's cons but I continued. I was missing the peace of mind and felt weakness because of aggressive training. Maybe because my body was not able to adapt considering I have a desk job.
 
I started taking a day off and later found the ideal split with 2 days off in a week gave some serious results. I feel more strength and hungrier to lift than before.
 
So if I were to recommend then 4–5 days per week is healthy and good. Few pointers:
Choosing rest days is important too. I always prefer a day off after legs day.
Try avoiding rest for 2 days consecutively. It depends on your workout intensity too.

I don’t like indulging the dumb American stereotype (and you do 
not
 have to look long or hard to find thick people where I’m from) but…
 
When I had recently arrived in the country and was buying a car, I took a test drive. While talking to the sales guy in the car, he asked me where I was from. Knowing that saying “Britain” sometimes confuses people here, and not really being in the mood for a long explanation of the difference between country and nation and why part of the island of Ireland isn’t part of the country of Ireland, etc., I said “England”.
 
“Oh, your English is really good!”
 
I think I almost crashed the car.
 
After a couple of minutes I established that, yes, he really did think we spoke another language, although he didn’t know what it might be. I assured him that we actually speak English and, in fact, that was how the language had got its name.

I walked into my new office space on my second day at work.
 
I felt happy.
 
Our friendly office receptionist walked in to ask if I needed anything.
 
“I’m fine, thank you.” I smiled at her.
 
“So you are from India right? Which part of India?”
 
“That’s right, from Ahmedabad.” I shuffle around. Adjusting books, and frames while telling her more about my beautiful city.
 
“So did you go to school in Ahmedabad?”
 
“Yep.”
 
“How did you go to school? Did you ride elephants?”
 
I stopped dead in my tracks and looked back to see if she was joking.
 
She wasn’t. Her sincere face had an invisible question mark.
 
“No, I went in a school bus.”
 
“Really?” Her face had a look of genuine surprise.
 
I sighed and tried to give her a better insight into India, just so that she knows India is VERY different from what she was thinking.
 
It was a long day.

Maybe not the most ignorant American but fun to mention.
 
On my first visit to Switzerland, 28 years ago, my flight arrived early morning in Zurich and I was travelling to Neuchatel so I was waiting for the train at Zurich train station. I decided to sit down to read near some shops. At that time of day, they were just opening. A fellow passenger I recognized from my flight that morning approaches the deli near where I sat and asked for some Swiss cheese. The server replied, in very good English but with a slight accent, “they're all Swiss cheese, which one?” wave gesturing at the impressive cheese display.
 
“I want Swiss cheese”, followed by “which one” was repeated a number of times with increasing frustration until finally the server grabbed a few slices of what I assume were Emmental, wrapped it assertively and handed it to the customer.
 
Welcome to Switzerland!

Student: So, what language do you speak at home, Sir?

John: Well then!
 
Student: ??
 
John: Like, we speak English in England! You know, it’s where the word comes from!!
 
Student: Really?? Wow!! I never knew that…

When I was 15, I went to Pennsylvania for an exchange program (I’m from Santiago, Chile).
 
At their school, I introduced myself and spoke a little bit of my country, since they had never heard of it, and said it was also located in America (the continent) just like theirs; when a student says “what? in which state? I’m assuming Florida or New Mexico”. 
I stated that we were a country, not part of the United States, and he continues to say “Oh, so you’re talking of America as of Mexico, USA and Canada… why?” 
I spent like 5 minutes trying to make him understand that America was a continent, being South America part of it. He said he was totally unaware of that.
 
The introduction went on, and I asked the class if they had questions. All questions were like “do you hunt for food?” “what clothes do you wear?” “do you live in tents?”. They thought we were nomadic tribes…

The most ignorant by far was a woman that I knew online. She lived in Oklahoma, was barely scraping by, was sick but had no healthcare so wasn’t seeing a doctor, and was literally on the verge of homelessness. She was also a die-hard trumper because (and I do quote — I’ll never forget what she said), “Trump is rich and he’s going to change the laws so I can get rich too.” She also honestly thought that once she got rich too she’d be welcome in the “inner circles” of the rich. She talked about who she’d hang out with.
 
She was educated and had previously had a good job, but she was one of those “temporarily embarrassed millionaires.” She could not admit to herself or to anyone else that she was destitute.
 
John Steinbeck, “Socialism never took root in America because the poor see themselves not as an exploited proletariat but as temporarily embarrassed millionaires."

article:
Back when I was working in a multinational US company, one of their managers went to Italy. He was in the team coordinating the Y2K worldwide project. His name and family name were both Italians, so, during a conversation, I asked him where he was born.” Actually in the USA” was his reply, “but my parents were born in Italy, in Abruzzo”. Then he went on explaining to me (an Italian) that Abruzzo is a region of Sicily. (Which it’s not)
 
For those of you who are not familiar with Italy (the majority, I'd assume) it is like saying that Alaska is part of California. I tried to change his view on the

Back when I was working in a multinational US company, one of their managers went to Italy. He was in the team coordinating the Y2K worldwide project. His name and family name were both Italians, so, during a conversation, I asked him where he was born.” Actually in the USA” was his reply, “but my parents were born in Italy, in Abruzzo”. Then he went on explaining to me (an Italian) that Abruzzo is a region of Sicily. (Which it’s not)
 
For those of you who are not familiar with Italy (the majority, I'd assume) it is like saying that Alaska is part of California. I tried to change his view on the subject, but nope, he would rather believe what his dad and mom told him. Good son.
 
And, of course, I don't think it was his duty to know that, but maybe to have some doubts and check…
 
And, as others have already said, this case doesn't mean all US people are the same.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
When I was 18 I got my first car and a couple buddies and I drove down to Florida from Quebec for March break partying.
 
So we’re at the beach one day and I started chatting up a really cute girl who had a Southern drawl that mesmerized me. After a few minutes this hillbilly looking dude walked up to us giving me the stink eye. The cutie said “This is my husband Harold.” Oh.
 
We all talked for a bit and I learned they were from Tennessee. When Harold heard I was from Canada he wanted to know about the snow and ice houses we had ‘up there’. “What are they called?” he asked. I said “You mean igloos?

When I was 18 I got my first car and a couple buddies and I drove down to Florida from Quebec for March break partying.
 
So we’re at the beach one day and I started chatting up a really cute girl who had a Southern drawl that mesmerized me. After a few minutes this hillbilly looking dude walked up to us giving me the stink eye. The cutie said “This is my husband Harold.” Oh.
 
We all talked for a bit and I learned they were from Tennessee. When Harold heard I was from Canada he wanted to know about the snow and ice houses we had ‘up there’. “What are they called?” he asked. I said “You mean igloos?” He said no, it’s something else. I said that they were called igloos but he kept insisting there was another word for them. I remember saying that I did not live in one but a few of my neighbors did. The conversation never did get any smarter and I never forgot it.

article:

Essentially not.
 
It is recommended not at all to grind through whole week. our body needs as much rest as it needs workout. 5 times a week is the standard regimen most of the bodybuilders and workout enthusiasts tend to suggest.
 
And it completely depends upon your goal. You want to get fit and look just an ordinary guy in the house, three times a week is more than enough. If your ambitions are lot bigger than just being fit , you've to put in more hard work , and more hard work requires more time.
I've been experimenting with my Workout regimen for the past 2 years trying out and inducting new workout recipes. From working out seven days a week to skipping workout downright whole week I've tried out everything to make my body adapted for changing workout cycle.
Three times a week would be enough and rest can be made up for by introducing a good diet plan.

title: What is a good weekly workout?
article:
These days many people are facing health issues. The busy schedule and stress have forced many to grow extra weight. As a result, they are relying more on medication to improve their health. A full-body workout
 
is one of the most effective ways to reduce body fat. It is an efficient way to target every major muscle group. To achieve your best physique, a proper strength training program is essential. Whether you’re looking to transform your body or just kick your training up a notch, it’s important to add training volume in the form of reps, sets, and weight) to stimulate new muscle growth as 
Continue Reading
These days many people are facing health issues. The busy schedule and stress have forced many to grow extra weight. As a result, they are relying more on medication to improve their health. A full-body workout
 
is one of the most effective ways to reduce body fat. It is an efficient way to target every major muscle group. To achieve your best physique, a proper strength training program is essential. Whether you’re looking to transform your body or just kick your training up a notch, it’s important to add training volume in the form of reps, sets, and weight) to stimulate new muscle growth as you progress. You may follow this following workout plan
Day 1: Chest + (Light) Triceps.
Day 2: Back + (Light) Biceps.
Day 3: Core + Forearms + Calves + Cardio.
Day 4: Shoulders + (Heavy) Triceps.
Day 5: Legs + (Heavy) Biceps.
Day 6: Rest (Light core workout as an option)

This is a heck of a loaded question but someone comes to mind immediately.
 
So, I never met her, and I wasn’t there for this but it was on national TV for all to see. While waiting for a show to start (I think it was an episode of the OC - sorry!) I stayed on the channel and watched the tail end of Anna Nicole Smith’s reality TV show.
 
During the last segment they were heading to the airport to fly into LAX and someone mentioned how they were happy to be heading back to Cali. Anna’s response was “Wait… Isn’t LA different than California…?” Anna is an ADULT who presumably went to grade school, and she had been in the show business for years and probably flew, and drove into Los Angeles 100’s of times… And she still didn’t understand the difference between the city of Los Angeles and the state of California.
 
Yeah, that one takes the cake for me.
 
RIP Anna

work out basically depends on ones body structure and goals.
 
If one wants to loose weight than they tend to do more of weight loss exercise and on other hand if one wants to gain muscle than one will tend to do weight training.
 
i workout 6 days week and take one day off for recovery. stating the week with workout of back on Monday, chest on Tuesday, legs on Wednesday (legs and back not together just to give some recovery time for lower back). Biceps and triceps on Thursday Shoulder and traps on Friday and finally cardio on Saturday (some cardio is also important so that muscles don’t gets stiffer)(can skip cardio if not want to participate in competitions). I do abs workout on Wednesday and Saturday. I see that i give all muscle group enough time to recover.
 
I am planning to change this routine after 4 months so my body don’t get used to the routine.
