title: Is it bad to do full body workouts every day?
article:
It depends on what your purpose is. If your want to strengthen your nervous system then you can workout the whole body everyday. You just have to make sure you do not more than 5 reps on a moderately difficult exercise and don’t exert your muscles too much and keep them fresh. By the way this won’t help you add more muscles though you could still get strong like Bruce Lee.
 
And if you want to get more ripped or add muscles you have to go all in and breakdown your muscles. But you can’t do work out on whole body everyday as your muscles would need lots of rest. If you do workout everyday you are 
Continue Reading
It depends on what your purpose is. If your want to strengthen your nervous system then you can workout the whole body everyday. You just have to make sure you do not more than 5 reps on a moderately difficult exercise and don’t exert your muscles too much and keep them fresh. By the way this won’t help you add more muscles though you could still get strong like Bruce Lee.
 
And if you want to get more ripped or add muscles you have to go all in and breakdown your muscles. But you can’t do work out on whole body everyday as your muscles would need lots of rest. If you do workout everyday you are likely to fatigue and put excess pressure on the muscles and cause injury. This is also one of the reason why workout geeks have a separate leg day, back day, chest day so by the time the particular muscle part has to be worked upon next time it has got enough rest.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
My mum’s hairdresser. My parents were living in D.C., I was visiting from The Netherlands. He asked me where I was from - so I told him, “The Netherlands”. The conversation that followed was so uninformed about geography and history that I can’t even recall correctly what the line of conversation was, but it involved questions about whether the country Amsterdam was near The Netherlands, what it was like to live in a “former Soviet Union block country”, what it’s like to “have your own language” (after he heard me speak Dutch to my mother), whether Paris is in Germany, and it got worse after t
Continue Reading
My mum’s hairdresser. My parents were living in D.C., I was visiting from The Netherlands. He asked me where I was from - so I told him, “The Netherlands”. The conversation that followed was so uninformed about geography and history that I can’t even recall correctly what the line of conversation was, but it involved questions about whether the country Amsterdam was near The Netherlands, what it was like to live in a “former Soviet Union block country”, what it’s like to “have your own language” (after he heard me speak Dutch to my mother), whether Paris is in Germany, and it got worse after that.
 
He was a nice guy and I couldn’t blame him for not caring about the details of European countries, but it did teach me that the US itself is two very different countries, and in some cases it only takes a 10 mile drive from Bethesda to Virginia to understand this.

title: Is running every day better than going to the gym every day?
article:
Thanks for reaching out. I don't view running as better than going to the gym for strength training, which is what i think you're implying with the question.
 
Running is my preferred cardio (rowing is 2nd) to supplement weight training for physical fitness. It has been very helpful with with building endurance. And yes, I got addicted to the adrenaline/endorphine release from sprint intervals.
 
It's also my form of meditation, there's something about the rhythmic breathing pattern that allows me to process my thoughts on 5k, occasionally longer, leisure runs. Others prefer yoga for this.
 
So with re
Continue Reading
Thanks for reaching out. I don't view running as better than going to the gym for strength training, which is what i think you're implying with the question.
 
Running is my preferred cardio (rowing is 2nd) to supplement weight training for physical fitness. It has been very helpful with with building endurance. And yes, I got addicted to the adrenaline/endorphine release from sprint intervals.
 
It's also my form of meditation, there's something about the rhythmic breathing pattern that allows me to process my thoughts on 5k, occasionally longer, leisure runs. Others prefer yoga for this.
 
So with regards to your question, I completely agree with 
Darren Beattie
. There's a variety of exercises that can be done at the gym. Be it resistance strength/circuit/body weight training. A good fitness regimen should include both cardio & strength training.

title: How long will it take to get big if doing full body workouts every day with heavy weights?
article:
Generally, muscle growth is a simple 3 step process. 1) hit the muscle with stress (exercise), 2) eat some protein and recover (rest) and 3) be persistent (repeat).
 
The most important element you need to make this formula work is resistance. Without resistance there is no stimulation, and without stimulation there is no muscle development.
 
The push up creates the resistance that stimulates the muscle growth of the chest, triceps and shoulder. The resistance force them to contract hard to push back up.
 
In order for muscle to grow, it has to push beyond a certain limit for a long time. You need to 
Continue Reading
Generally, muscle growth is a simple 3 step process. 1) hit the muscle with stress (exercise), 2) eat some protein and recover (rest) and 3) be persistent (repeat).
 
The most important element you need to make this formula work is resistance. Without resistance there is no stimulation, and without stimulation there is no muscle development.
 
The push up creates the resistance that stimulates the muscle growth of the chest, triceps and shoulder. The resistance force them to contract hard to push back up.
 
In order for muscle to grow, it has to push beyond a certain limit for a long time. You need to stress the muscles harder consistently.
 
To keep on growing the muscles of your chest and build strength, you will need to switch to a more advanced variation of push-ups and add weight or increase reps to add extra resistance to your current method.

article:

But, the body needs to recovery time as well to repair the stress and strain done on the muscles and joints. The recovery part along with diet is what actually makes you stronger. 
 
I would suggest 4 days of intense work, a day or two of active rest where you do some light workouts or cardio and one day of complete rest. This will keep your body and mind fresh and ready to tackle the next day's w

Full body workouts are brilliant for the body. Nothing makes the body stronger than full body exercises. Having done both isolation exercises and full body, a huge thumbs up for your choice of exercise. 
 
But, the body needs to recovery time as well to repair the stress and strain done on the muscles and joints. The recovery part along with diet is what actually makes you stronger. 
 
I would suggest 4 days of intense work, a day or two of active rest where you do some light workouts or cardio and one day of complete rest. This will keep your body and mind fresh and ready to tackle the next day's workout. 
 
You can find a lot of routines online which can suit you. The most important part though is, 
LISTEN TO YOUR BODY
 . Within a short span of time, you'll know when to take it light and when to go full steam ahead. 
 
Have a great path to fitness.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
My Scottish friends, a married couple, moved over from the UK to USA. One day they were talking to a waiter at a restaurant.
 
The waiter asked them eventually: “How long have you lived in USA?”
 
They answered: “Three months.”
 
The waiter: “Wow! Your English is really good!”
 
Yet I must say I met ignorant people in every country of the world I ever visited. And most likely I can be found completely ignorant by someone coming from a different culture and different reality. E.g. I can drive on snow without any problem, but I had to learn at the age of almost 50 how to prepare the house for a hurricane.
 
Th
Continue Reading
My Scottish friends, a married couple, moved over from the UK to USA. One day they were talking to a waiter at a restaurant.
 
The waiter asked them eventually: “How long have you lived in USA?”
 
They answered: “Three months.”
 
The waiter: “Wow! Your English is really good!”
 
Yet I must say I met ignorant people in every country of the world I ever visited. And most likely I can be found completely ignorant by someone coming from a different culture and different reality. E.g. I can drive on snow without any problem, but I had to learn at the age of almost 50 how to prepare the house for a hurricane.
 
Therefore, I suggest that we judge the situations (because they are funny, or pathetic, or whatever they seem to be), but not the people. Because if we were born the other person and brought up in the same way, we would be equally ignorant.

If not 
the 
most ignorant, one of the finalists is a former co-worker who was the type of Miami Cuban exile who opposed sending Elian Gonzalez back to Cuba. She said she always voted Republican “because they’re tougher on Castro.”
 
At the time, Bill Clinton was president. I pointed out to her that so far, Fidel Castro had outlasted Dwight D. Eisenhower, John F. Kennedy, Lyndon Johnson, Richard Nixon, Gerald Ford, Jimmy Carter, Ronald Reagan, and George H.W. Bush. And as we know, he went on to outlast Clinton, George W. Bush, and (almost) Barack Obama. That was six Republican presidents and five Democrats. So the Republicans hadn’t overthrown him any more than had the Democrats.
 
I made no impression on her. If she’s still alive today, she probably voted in the Florida primary for Marco Rubio, and definitely in the general election for Donald Trump.

title: Are there any poor people on Quora, as Internet access is very cheap nowadays?
article:
I have never been on a “vacation.”

title: What happens if you workout every day?
article:
Depends what you’re doing…. Intensity and duration, and how you structure your workouts.
 
You MIGHT have positive results as Geoffrey indicates.
 
Or, you might very rapidly get into a state of overtraining.
 
The standard, for many, many years is at least 24 hours rest for each muscle group worked. Of course, this means “worked” in the context of a hard lifting session. If you go in and knock out a couple of sets of say….Squats at much less weight than you usually use…..Then you might get away with that for a long time.
 
But most non-superhuman folk need rest for each muscle group. That’s why many seri
Continue Reading
Depends what you’re doing…. Intensity and duration, and how you structure your workouts.
 
You MIGHT have positive results as Geoffrey indicates.
 
Or, you might very rapidly get into a state of overtraining.
 
The standard, for many, many years is at least 24 hours rest for each muscle group worked. Of course, this means “worked” in the context of a hard lifting session. If you go in and knock out a couple of sets of say….Squats at much less weight than you usually use…..Then you might get away with that for a long time.
 
But most non-superhuman folk need rest for each muscle group. That’s why many serious lifters do “split” routines…. Half the body for one session, half for another. Sufficient rest in between.
 
For old guys like me…. I find that at least 48 hours is more appropriate. I do two full-body sessions per week with good results.

This answer can go FOREVER. In fact, people have written whole books on the subject. One such book is 'SPARK' by John J Ratey. This book discusses the benefits of exercising on the mind not just the body.
 
Let me give you my own explanation. We are all animals on this earth. What do animals do? Animals hunt/forage, eat, sleep, and procreate. That's basically it. That is what our bodies and minds are designed to do. In the past we would have to chase down animals, walk miles for water, and forage for berrys all day. In our modern world, we don't need to hunt or forage for anything. We have to walk 10 steps to the fridge to get a slab of meat. In our modern world, we die of totally different reasons than we did 100 years ago. We are dying primarily by the product of inactivity. We don't move as much as we should.
 
This is a good enough reason for me.

article:

However, programming a full-body workout of that intensity is harder to do especially if you're a beginner. The volume you do should be the same just spread out the 6 weeks. With higher frequency training you lower the intensity of your workouts. Especially on back to back days like in the image I have shown. It's also important not to train every ser to failure when doing this. Your body recovery if doing it right goes up too as you get something called the repeated bout effect. This repeate
Continue Reading
You can get the best strength and size gains doing full body twice a week and the research shows this. However, programming a full-body workout of that intensity is harder to do especially if you're a beginner. The volume you do should be the same just spread out the 6 weeks. With higher frequency training you lower the intensity of your workouts. Especially on back to back days like in the image I have shown. It's also important not to train every ser to failure when doing this. Your body recovery if doing it right goes up too as you get something called the repeated bout effect. This repeated stimulus leads to less muscle damage over time. Certain athletes do this too. This however is not necessary if you're a beginner and if you can't train 6x a week then training a muscle 2–3x a week is more than enough as long as you get the required total volume.

title: What is your favorite sandwich ingredient?
article:
The Argentine sandwich, known as "sandwich de milanesa," is a beloved staple in Argentine cuisine, adored for its simplicity and deliciousness.
The sandwich de milanesa typically features a breaded and fried beef or chicken fillet, known as milanesa, which is similar to the Italian cotoletta. The meat is usually pounded thin, coated in egg and breadcrumbs, and then fried until golden and crispy.
 
The key components of a sandwich de milanesa are the milanesa itself, bread (often a crusty roll or baguette), and various toppings. Common additions include lettuce, tomato, avocado, and mayonnaise. Som

The Argentine sandwich, known as "sandwich de milanesa," is a beloved staple in Argentine cuisine, adored for its simplicity and deliciousness.
The sandwich de milanesa typically features a breaded and fried beef or chicken fillet, known as milanesa, which is similar to the Italian cotoletta. The meat is usually pounded thin, coated in egg and breadcrumbs, and then fried until golden and crispy.
 
The key components of a sandwich de milanesa are the milanesa itself, bread (often a crusty roll or baguette), and various toppings. Common additions include lettuce, tomato, avocado, and mayonnaise. Some people also like to add cheese or a squeeze of lime for extra flavor.
 
This sandwich is more than just food; it represents 
comfort and home for many Argentines
. It's commonly found in eateries known as "cafés" or sandwich shops throughout the country.

title: How to workout
article:
You can make your workout time more effective by squeezing in AS MUCH WORK AS YOU CAN into the time you have.
 
Most people mistakenly assume that the amount of time they spend at the gym/working is directly proportional to their results.
 
Nothing can be further from the truth.
 
You can spend 2 hours in the gym, but if you take long breaks between sets, spend time swiping up and down your social media accounts, or just yapping with your buddies, you’re probably not working hard enough.
Similarly, if you only have 30 minutes in the gym, but you cram 20 sets of intense lifting into that time, you’ll lea

You can make your workout time more effective by squeezing in AS MUCH WORK AS YOU CAN into the time you have.
 
Most people mistakenly assume that the amount of time they spend at the gym/working is directly proportional to their results.
 
Nothing can be further from the truth.
 
You can spend 2 hours in the gym, but if you take long breaks between sets, spend time swiping up and down your social media accounts, or just yapping with your buddies, you’re probably not working hard enough.
Similarly, if you only have 30 minutes in the gym, but you cram 20 sets of intense lifting into that time, you’ll leave a pool of sweat on the gym floor and create an awesome stimulus for results.
 
I’ve seen this question asked many times, so I’ve written an article to explain.
 
How Much Time Should You Spend In The Gym? (HINT: Wrong Question!)
Good luck.

title: Is it bad to do full body workouts every day?
article:
Yes. Absolutely. There is 
no
 question in this matter. You can 
absolutely
 work the same muscles everyday. If you couldn't, manual labourers would simply keel over. This notion of over-resting is one of those modern 'fitness' myths born in North America that needs to die.
 
So long as you're getting sufficient sleep and nutrition, taking care of your general mobility work, and not over-straining when you train, you can train the same muscle groups every day. 
 
If you're straining to your max, deadlifting until your nose bleeds, or grinding out savage reps on  squats... then no, training every day wou
Continue Reading
Yes. Absolutely. There is 
no
 question in this matter. You can 
absolutely
 work the same muscles everyday. If you couldn't, manual labourers would simply keel over. This notion of over-resting is one of those modern 'fitness' myths born in North America that needs to die.
 
So long as you're getting sufficient sleep and nutrition, taking care of your general mobility work, and not over-straining when you train, you can train the same muscle groups every day. 
 
If you're straining to your max, deadlifting until your nose bleeds, or grinding out savage reps on  squats... then no, training every day would be begging for an injury. But if you're training with the same mentality toward intensity that Olympic weightlifters have -- which focuses on how clean the technique is, and acceleration of the bar -- daily training can pack quite a punch.

“I’m not joki

As a sixteen-year-old, I worked at a chain bookstore in a mall.
 
One day I was working the information desk by myself when a couple, dressed in biker gear, strode up to my counter.
 
“We need you to settle something for us,” the lady informed me.
 
“Uh, okay,” I said, hoping it was something I could quickly and easily find in a book. This was the late 90s, before the era of smart phones and Google searches.
 
“How many states are there? I say 52. He says 47.”
 
After a moment of stunned disbelief during which I am certain my jaw dropped wide open, I delicately tried to ask if they were serious.
 
“I’m not joking around! Just tell us!” the man snapped.
 
“There are 50 states,” I said.
 
The women turned to the man. “See? I told you, she doesn’t know anything.”
 
And they stormed away, presumably to continue their argument elsewhere.

Got some big gains in this 28-day challenge. That is why, If you are just a beginner, it is advisable not to stick to a routine but build it as you get stronger and stronger day by day. You will not lose motivation.

article:

I don’t know what it means to be poor because I don't know what it’s like to be rich.
 
I am constantly in fear of being homeless. I don’t know how I will pay rent this coming month but I try to have faith.
 
I am a single mother with young children and no income.
 
I am a victim of lifelong abuse and torture.

I want to die every single day. My children need me but I can’t provide for them. It’s the m

Am I poor? I don’t know.
 
I don’t know what it means to be poor because I don't know what it’s like to be rich.
 
I am constantly in fear of being homeless. I don’t know how I will pay rent this coming month but I try to have faith.
 
I am a single mother with young children and no income.
 
I am a victim of lifelong abuse and torture.
 
I escaped a cult and am ostracized from family.
 
I want to die every single day. My children need me but I can’t provide for them. It’s the most painful experience.
 
I suffer from depression, anxiety and constant panic.
 
Money doesn't buy happiness, but when you’re struggling to support your young children, the lack of money can surely buy lifelong death.

Like, you could do a push/pull split, meaning that one day you do excercises that you push away from you to perform, and the next day you do exercises that you pull towards you to perform. Examples of pushing exercises could be bench press, shoulder/military press, or tricep push downs. Then for pulling you could do pull downs, rows, bicep curls and whatnot. You’d want to have a day where you trained legs, too. Or if you 
Continue Reading
It depends on what you’re doing, and what you’re looking for. If you want to get big, don’t do full body workouts. Split your workout into muscle groups or types of movement. Like, you could do a push/pull split, meaning that one day you do excercises that you push away from you to perform, and the next day you do exercises that you pull towards you to perform. Examples of pushing exercises could be bench press, shoulder/military press, or tricep push downs. Then for pulling you could do pull downs, rows, bicep curls and whatnot. You’d want to have a day where you trained legs, too. Or if you split it into muscle groups, which is what I do, you would do chest one day, another day do back, another day do shoulders, another day do arms. If you’re dead set on doing full body workouts, keep it to three days a week so your body can recover properly.

Hi there. It's nice to see you curious about fitness.
 
To begin, I will explain simple stuff that will surely help you.
 
First of all, learn basic bodyweight exercises like pushups, pull ups, squats and leg raises. Always do a bit of warm up, like running and jumping on the spot for a few mins to feel ready. Then start the workout.
 
The next thing is to stretch. You should stretch for a few mins daily. This will improve you muscles' abilities. You will feel stronger and flexible.
 
The last thing is to eat healthy. Just avoid junk food. Eat fruits and vegetables when possible, otherwise home cooking is healthy too. Don't complicate with home cooking, that might irritate you. Eat every nutrient in required amount, especially protein. This helps to recover quickly.
 
Hope this helps! Sleep well, eat well and have a fitter tomorrow!

Royal Marines (In the depths of deepest Africa)
Do your balls hang low? Can you swing them to and fro?
Of these the second is probably the dirtiest.

article:

This question assumes wrongly that the internet is for the rich or well off or middle class.
 
We did a case study sometime ago in Africa. We interview a couple who after much thought bought a phone instead of a goat with their savings.
 
The goat would have given them prestige and a store of wealth. The phone would allow the man to check prices of coffee and see if it was a good time to sell. He would save money by not having to travel to the Market.
 
The internet provides options for the poor to be informed and learn. Share ideas and contribute. It alleviates their suffering and in a small way connects them to a better lifestyle and hope for a better future.
 
While some use the internet for vanity and ego with likes and followers as the currency of popularity, the poor use it to squeeze out a life that's just a little bit better.

In the declaration it is spelled ‘the united States of America’ in the constitution ‘the United States of America’. In the former clearly a denomination as ‘united’ was not capitalized, in the later they took the effort to make sure the founders convey the intent of making ‘United States’ the name of the country being created in the CONTINENT of America. Given the attention to detail the founders p

I have met many in the United States that believe the US of A is America.
 
If that is not ignorant, what is?!
 
The name comes from the declaration of independence and later repeated in the Constitution. In the declaration it is spelled ‘the united States of America’ in the constitution ‘the United States of America’. In the former clearly a denomination as ‘united’ was not capitalized, in the later they took the effort to make sure the founders convey the intent of making ‘United States’ the name of the country being created in the CONTINENT of America. Given the attention to detail the founders put on the creation of this nation and its form of governance, one would think that if they intended to make the name of this nation the same as that of the continent, they would have said something, somehow, somewhere. They did no such thing.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:

Crossing the parking lot of the Madonna Inn in California, I passed a lady in her 30s, staring at a German sports car. She was circling it with a look of puzzlement and borderline bewilderment. As I passed her she said “Excuse me sir? Could you tell me what kind of car this is?”. I knew exactly what make and model of car it was. It was an Audi TT and I told her. She seemed somewhat annoyed that I knew this for some reason and she fired back quite quickly with “How do you know that?”.
 
“Because it says so right here on the rear” I replied, pointing to the clearly visible “Audi TT” emblazoned on the car. Maybe she overlooked it due to a neurological condition or perhaps she was illiterate.
 
She then asked “Are you Australian?”.
 
No harm in that except I've a rather strong Irish accent. “No, I'm irish” I answered.
 
“Is that near Sweden?”.

I worked for a while in the summer of 1972 at a German-sponsored archeological dig in northern Greece. The crew basically took over a whole small Greek village. One of our fellows was from Florida. His wealthy mother had apparently given him $10K in travellers cheques (a LOT of money in those days for a traveller) and told him to get lost for the summer. He had a number of health issues including epilepsy. Every night he got himself filthy drunk and would eventually have to be helped back to his tent. Pretty sure he lost his medication every night with vomiting. For sure he lost his false teeth one night! He would have seizures during the day as we worked under the hot sun, but would refuse medical care. I don’t know if he had a death wish, but we were all scared to be around him in case he died while in our company. That was pretty ignorant.

(1) I started a job. A new co-worker said, “You have an accent, where are your from?” “I recently moved here from New England,” I said. “Oh, did you have your car shipped over to this country?”
 
(2) I was at McDonald’s getting a cup of coffee at the drive through. When I got up to the window to pay, the McDonald’s employee told me the electricity had gone out and while she was able to open the register, the machine would not tell her how much change to give me. I figured out what I was owed and told her the amount when I handed her a five dollar bill. She didn’t believe me. I put the arithmetic down on a piece of paper and handed it to her ($5.00 - $2.25 = $2.75). She refused to believe it and told me she had to talk to the manager. I asked her to please hurry because I was on my way to work. She returned and sheepishly gave me my $2.75.

article:

I agree with majority of the answers already given to this question. When we workout, we are actually doing mass damage to our body. Especially if you are working out the right way meaning intensity and form wise.
 
With that being said, you should be resting after a good full body workout. Growth happens from tearing things down and allowing them to rebuild back up. If you go back the day after and tear everything down again before it’s had a chance to heal and build up, what results will come out of this? No to much.
 
Active recovery is always good. Breaking a light sweat while getting the body to move promotes blood flow. Blood contains the minerals and nutrients needed to heal.
 
As others have mentioned, yoga, power walking, stretching, foam rolling, light biking, playing football or Frisbee with your kids if you have any, etc.

title: Can I do a light workout every day?
article:
If your workout is very light then definitely yes. But remember all muscles of your body needs time to repair. REST IS AN IMPORTANT PART OF BODY BUILDING. If you are not giving your muscle fibers time to repair after a workout do not expect good results.
 
I recommend moderate workout of particular muscle groups a day with adequate rest.
 
For example
 
Monday - Shoulders & Upper Back
 
Tuesday - Chest & Lower Back
 
Wednesday - Cardio & upper Abs
 
Thursday - Arms & Lats
 
Friday - Lower Body
 
Saturday - Cardio & lower Abs
 
Sunday - rest

If your workout is very light then definitely yes. But remember all muscles of your body needs time to repair. REST IS AN IMPORTANT PART OF BODY BUILDING. If you are not giving your muscle fibers time to repair after a workout do not expect good results.
 
I recommend moderate workout of particular muscle groups a day with adequate rest.
 
For example
 
Monday - Shoulders & Upper Back
 
Tuesday - Chest & Lower Back
 
Wednesday - Cardio & upper Abs
 
Thursday - Arms & Lats
 
Friday - Lower Body
 
Saturday - Cardio & lower Abs
 
Sunday - rest
 
So in this routine, the next time u work on your shoulders you have already given enough time for it to recover.
 
Note - larger muscle groups like shoulder, chest, quads etc needs minimum 5–6 days to recover.
 
Smaller muscle groups like abs takes 2 days max to recover.

When I was really little I was fascinated by maps. As a result, I could find any building or road in the city I live in, the next city over, every county highway in the county and the eastern half of the county directly west of my own. This gets interesting when I try giving people directions if they aren't adept in the geography department.
 
Me: “Take 181 to Pioneer out to Wasaukee and take a left. Then turn left on the freeway by Woddman’s. Get off on Capitol and Turn right. Head out to 162 and…”
 
Them: “Where's 181?”
 
Me: “On second thought, use your GPS.”

I’m in a gym now I got to do a bunch of stuffs and I’m fit” which doesn’t justifies the actual purpose of gym. Hence I would like to conclude by saying that a person can be extremely fit by working out at home provided that your determination is unsahakable.

Interestingly enough, “Cesare” stopped attacking me after we discussed the source of his name and the fact that I seemed to be the only one who knew where it came from. i was just dumbfounded that people managed to get into college in the United States and even graduate without passing some World History.
 
I love history, but the Borgias were definitely covered in my required Western Civil...

I had known, and become friends with, my 74 year old, ex middle school teacher, now American health insurance agent for about two years. We spoke often as friends and she made no bones about her disgust of American ignorance.
 
I'm Scottish and in none of the many conversations we had, did she ask one question about Scotland or the UK until the day she blew me out of the water by asking, “What language do you speak in Scotland?”
 
I'm pretty sure a certain part of my anatomy puckered up as the words left her lips. I looked at her with a mixture of disbelief, anger and despair before I was able to answer, “Swahili.” The friendship was doomed when she then, with enormous confidence and no sign of irony or sarcasm replied, “I think that's more of a middle eastern language!!”
 
Absolutely stunning and by no means an isolated incident.

First of all, Internet is not “very cheap”. It's over $50 a month.
 
Poor depends how you define it. Poor people often live in bad neighborhoods. But many live in nicer neighborhoods and forego extra things to get by. If you're basing “poor” on being below the poverty level, that's almost impossible to achieve these days. Poverty level is where you make a low enough amount of money to qualify for aid. However, even at mimunim wage it is not possible to work 40 hours and still qualify. These people are living on under $1,000 a month, and that's without bills and rent taken out. These people almost all have cell phones, and most have cars because a car is essential to working. If they have cell phones, they have internet. Poor isn't what you think it is. It's struggling to get by, going into debt, but still having a car and a phone.

According to the U.S. and Indiana state governments, I live several thousand dollars per year below the poverty level for a family of five.
 
You might have a hard time believing that when you look at my life.
 
I know I fit the label. I shrug, and accept the food stamps—every little bit helps—but I don’t make a big deal out of it. I live quite frugally, but life isn’t bad—a house, three healthy kids, two old, ugly, but reliable cars, and no credit card debt—I’m not stupid enough to get myself into that trap. I don’t get cable, I haven’t bothered to replace the flip phone I lost weeks ago, and I almost never go out to eat. My kids get free lunches at school, and the state covers them for health insurance.
 
I don’t care about the label much. My needs—and even a few of my wants!—are met, and I do my best to be content with it.

title: Can I do a mixed workout every day in the gym?
article:
If you have already hit puberty and below age 24. You are at your physical peak.
 
If you wish to train a 5 day week then high intensity on particular muscle groups, low intensity on the same muscle group the next. Mid intensity for the rest of the muscle groups until it's turn for high intensive workout.
 
This will allow time for recovery and muscle gain. Also your glycogen stores in both your muscles and liver can recover.
 
Alternate days can be one session high intensity next one mid/low intensity depending how hard you train before and how well your body recovers.
 
Intensity of workout should incre
Continue Reading
If you have already hit puberty and below age 24. You are at your physical peak.
 
If you wish to train a 5 day week then high intensity on particular muscle groups, low intensity on the same muscle group the next. Mid intensity for the rest of the muscle groups until it's turn for high intensive workout.
 
This will allow time for recovery and muscle gain. Also your glycogen stores in both your muscles and liver can recover.
 
Alternate days can be one session high intensity next one mid/low intensity depending how hard you train before and how well your body recovers.
 
Intensity of workout should increase slowly to prevent burnout. Check you resting heartrate daily. If it is still high after a night's rest then you have overtrained.
 
Over time, your resting heartbeat will be lower, indicating adaption and fitness.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
It happened many years ago, in Spain, with an exchange student still in his teens.
I had never realized before to which extent some folks from a relatively new country lack historical perspective, as compared to what we are used to in Europe.
 
I will always remember two unconnected questions in particular, from the same person:
The guy once asked me, in the middle of a conversation about Jesus and Palestine, whether the Romans did use rifles. Yes, like you read it. I am not sure what he thought the Romans were actually and where to locate them on a timeline.

It happened many years ago, in Spain, with an exchange student still in his teens.
I had never realized before to which extent some folks from a relatively new country lack historical perspective, as compared to what we are used to in Europe.
 
I will always remember two unconnected questions in particular, from the same person:
The guy once asked me, in the middle of a conversation about Jesus and Palestine, whether the Romans did use rifles. Yes, like you read it. I am not sure what he thought the Romans were actually and where to locate them on a timeline.
A few days later, while visiting a museum of baroque wooden sculptures from the 18th century, he went to touch one of those religious sculptures (which you obviously shouldn’t) and claimed these felt like there were made of… plastic!! I remained speechless, obviously.

title: Is it bad to do full body workouts every day?
article:
Some
 people (not everyone!) get a 
very
 good response to training frequency. Basically meaning that doing muscle groups more times a week can give them fantastic results. You should at least try it and see what happens.
 
I think the potential drawback to full body every day is if your body isn't used to the frequency, and you're sore all over all the time. Working out then might be a bit too painful, you might not squeeze out much juice, you might not want to go to the gym.
 
But for intermediate training and above (i.e. when you don't get super sore and you won't hurt yourself doing a high-frequenc
Continue Reading
Some
 people (not everyone!) get a 
very
 good response to training frequency. Basically meaning that doing muscle groups more times a week can give them fantastic results. You should at least try it and see what happens.
 
I think the potential drawback to full body every day is if your body isn't used to the frequency, and you're sore all over all the time. Working out then might be a bit too painful, you might not squeeze out much juice, you might not want to go to the gym.
 
But for intermediate training and above (i.e. when you don't get super sore and you won't hurt yourself doing a high-frequency program), you can experiment with increasing frequency per muscle group and seeing if you're one of the higher responders. I think this school of thought is becoming more popular in contrast to many bro-split programs.

title: What is a good weekly workout?
article:
A hour a day is a great!  Variety is good to keep yourself from getting bored.  Cardio four times a week is great.  You can include dance in that category.  Strength training is usually done alternating days.  However, if you want to have a routine of 30 minutes cardio/ 30 minutes strength every day, that is fine too,  as long as you work different muscle groups each day or use light weights.  Yoga can fit in anywhere.  Some types can count as cardio.  Others are more strength and flexibility intensive.
 
Exercise aids weight loss, but can't really substitute for healthy eating.  The body is very
Continue Reading
A hour a day is a great!  Variety is good to keep yourself from getting bored.  Cardio four times a week is great.  You can include dance in that category.  Strength training is usually done alternating days.  However, if you want to have a routine of 30 minutes cardio/ 30 minutes strength every day, that is fine too,  as long as you work different muscle groups each day or use light weights.  Yoga can fit in anywhere.  Some types can count as cardio.  Others are more strength and flexibility intensive.
 
Exercise aids weight loss, but can't really substitute for healthy eating.  The body is very caloric efficient and you will be horrified about how much exercise is needed to burn off something as minor as a muffin.  Be mindful of what you are eating and exercise portion control for things you know you shouldn't be eating.

title: Are there any poor people on Quora, as Internet access is very cheap nowadays?
article:
Are there any poor people on Quora, as Internet access is very cheap nowadays?
 
“Cheap” is relative. So is “poor.” Many of the world’s people cannot afford internet access. Many afford internet access by sacrificing something else. Many Quora users may access the internet from computers at public libraries or similar places where access is free or very cheap. Such access is generally limited by time segments such as fifteen minutes, or one hour, per day.
 
From my reading of answers, I get the impression that some Quora users may even access the internet from prison and others may be homeless. So y
Continue Reading
Are there any poor people on Quora, as Internet access is very cheap nowadays?
 
“Cheap” is relative. So is “poor.” Many of the world’s people cannot afford internet access. Many afford internet access by sacrificing something else. Many Quora users may access the internet from computers at public libraries or similar places where access is free or very cheap. Such access is generally limited by time segments such as fifteen minutes, or one hour, per day.
 
From my reading of answers, I get the impression that some Quora users may even access the internet from prison and others may be homeless. So yes, there are poor people on Quora, and some of them may be too poor to provide a roof over their own heads.
 
I suggest you don’t insult these people by suggesting that internet access is cheap. It is anything but cheap.

Frankly, in residency at a charity hospital in Louisiana it was not unusual (2–3%) to meet patients who couldn’t read or write. These individuals would sign the surgical consent form with an X with multiple witnesses. Coming from the North East I found this stunning.
 
When interviewing for the position I was asked “You do understand the type of patients we treat here, don’t you?”
 
I responded “I expect you are a tertiary referral center much like the University of Maryland school of medicine”.
 
The interviewer said “We treat a lot of ignorant ****** people here.”
 
My North Eastern response was “I understand you have a lot of uneducated ***** patients here”.
 
We both knew what we were saying, smiling at each other. Unfortunately he was more correct than I.
 
Fortunately things 25 years later are different.

I once interviewed someone who couldn’t explain his own job. As in, the very highly paid job that he had been doing for over a year.
 
I explained his job to him.
 
Then I asked him what I’d just told him.
 
He still couldn’t explain the job.
 
So he didn’t get the job.
 
Another time, I talked to a guy who’d spent a year as an exchange student in Paris.
 
I said, “Oh, Paris, that must have been great.”
 
“It’s OK, I guess.”
 
“Well, what did you do while you were there? Anything interesting?”
 
“No, nothing special.”
 
Nothing special. In Paris. For a year.
 
Not food. Not romance. Not a good book. Not something seen through a window or out walking. Nothing.
 
I told him I’d give him five minutes to make something up. Anything.
 
He couldn’t or wouldn’t.
 
So he didn’t get the job either.

What do you really want out of your workouts?
 
I see this is keyed under bodybuilding, but getting started from scratch, building strength, building muscle size and building muscle endurance each take slightly different approaches.
 
What resources do you have?
 
Many towns have a halfway decent rec center or a “Y” and might have a franchise gym, but you don’t have to venture far into a rural area for all that to disappear. Can you get dumbbells, kettlebells or a used weight set? Bench and rack? Are you handy enough to build your own? Or would you rather go with resistance bands or bodyweight-only exercise?
 
Chloe has good advice for getting in the habit of healthy physical activity. Start with one or two things and add on as each becomes a habit. You’re more likely to stick with it long enough to get results.

On holiday in Ecuador in the late 90s with my then-girlfriend, we went on a 7 day boat tour of the Galapagos Islands. And on that boat was a young American woman who believed that, as a result of semi-regular viewings of the Discovery Channel on cable TV, she knew pretty much everything there was to know about the natural world. Basically the same as an advanced degree, the Discovery Channel was in her mind.
 
She also believed, it turned out, that all fish were the same species and, rather like different breeds of dog, could all breed with each other. A shark-halibut hybrid fish was just as poss
Continue Reading
On holiday in Ecuador in the late 90s with my then-girlfriend, we went on a 7 day boat tour of the Galapagos Islands. And on that boat was a young American woman who believed that, as a result of semi-regular viewings of the Discovery Channel on cable TV, she knew pretty much everything there was to know about the natural world. Basically the same as an advanced degree, the Discovery Channel was in her mind.
 
She also believed, it turned out, that all fish were the same species and, rather like different breeds of dog, could all breed with each other. A shark-halibut hybrid fish was just as possible in her opinion as an Alsatian-Spaniel cross.
 
She got really upset when I tried to explain that different kinds of fish were genetically distinct species and came from surprisingly different branches of the tree of life.

title: What is a good workout routine at home?
article:
If you need an inexpensive but highly effective method, learn to skip rope, standing on a firm but soft mat. The soft surface is important, because without it, you’ll hurt your knees. Buy a durable, flexible skipping rope. Ask for a recommendation from a serious sporting goods store or a coach. Skipping rope for 30–45 minutes requires determination, but it exercises almost all your muscles, and it is an excellent cardio-vascular workout. However, if you do it six days a week, you’ll become highly fit sooner than you expect. Don’t worry if you take a while to get the co-ordination right and bui
Continue Reading
If you need an inexpensive but highly effective method, learn to skip rope, standing on a firm but soft mat. The soft surface is important, because without it, you’ll hurt your knees. Buy a durable, flexible skipping rope. Ask for a recommendation from a serious sporting goods store or a coach. Skipping rope for 30–45 minutes requires determination, but it exercises almost all your muscles, and it is an excellent cardio-vascular workout. However, if you do it six days a week, you’ll become highly fit sooner than you expect. Don’t worry if you take a while to get the co-ordination right and build to 30 minutes; that’s normal. When you achieve it, you’ll find the skipping goes into autopilot, and you’ll like that sensation. Remember to hydrate before, during, and after, as efficient skipping will require it. Best wishes.

Years ago when I was buying my house, I ran into the most perfect example ever of why people view federal employees in general and VA minions in particular with such scorn and disrespect. My loan officer went to the VA with my green sheet (loan guarantee form given to discharged veterans) and came back with a denial. He had come up against a pencil neck who would not be told under any circumstances that May came before September. On September 7th of 1980 the rules had changed, but as I had enlisted in May of the same year the changes didn't apply (as a disabled vet they didn't apply anyway, but that was beside the point). This genius had even gone so far as to scribble in pen on my DD-214 copy that I had enlisted after September 7th just below the typed May 16th enlistment date. I went to the VA myself to no avail (at least not at first), and after arguing with that same person for nearly an hour and refusing to leave I was threatened with removal and/or arrest. I was working at the time as a security supervisor...

Cashier: Where are you from?
Me: Oh, I’m from Malaysia.
Cashier: So you’re Malay? (I also get this one a lot)
Me: No, I’m Chinese.
Cashier: But you speak English.
Me: Yeah, I’m from an English-speaking family.
Cashier: But you’re from Malaysia…
Me: So where are you from?
Cashier: My parents are Vietnamese but…
Me: No, I mean you, personally, where were you born?
Cashier: Oh, I’m from California.
 
Despite being an English-speaking Vietnamese American she still couldn’t wrap her head around the idea of English-speaking Asians coming from anywhere else.

My grandfather's wife once told me “I don't believe in dinosaurs, you know?”. I was so shocked this otherwise very fine lady, who could crack jokes and make my granddad laugh all the time although he was so hard of hearing he was almost deaf, would say something like this. So I tried to let it pass, pretending I didn't care. She went on “yeah, they're not even in the Bible!”
 
I hadn't realized until then what bigotry and unchallenged creationist lobbying could do. I mean, what do these people think? That paleontologists just make these up or something? That they somehow have the time and skills to devise elaborate hoaxes on such a vast scale?
 
Occam's razor would advocate in favor of dinos being legit, I should think. I mean someone even found actual dinosaur feathers preserved in amber, for crying out loud!

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
So: ignorant, but not stupid, just lacking experience:

So: ignorant, but not stupid, just lacking experience:
 
1982. I am alone, with a hire car, exploring parts of the Ouachitas in Arkansas ( I am an ecologist) Stay in a neat motel in Mena. Waitress service for breakfast. Same waitress each day, very polite and friendly, takes my order.
 
After a couple of days, makes conversation
 
“ you not from around here?”
 
Me; “no”
 
She: “ from New York?”
 
I should add that as a Brit with what others have described as a BBC accent, this attribution came as a bit of a surprise. US friends roll about at the thought that I might be from NY.
 
But this speaks to limited experience rather than bad education. I guess Mena does not have that many out of state visitors. And being mistaken for a dam Yankee did not mean any lack of courtesy and friendly service.

title: Can I do a mixed workout every day in the gym?
article:
It entirely depends on what you're trying to accomplish.
 
Are you trying to lose weight, or are you trying to build muscle ? Both at the same time is going to be extremely difficult if you only go to the gym once per week.
 
Other answers say high weight, low reps for once a week, but not only is this geared more towards a mass build than a weight loss/tone, but also can be unnecessarily dangerous to the joints of you're only doing it once a week.
 
I would recommend a treadmill or eliptical set before lifting. Then high reps with low weight when you lift, or a warm-up set on every specific exercise b
Continue Reading
It entirely depends on what you're trying to accomplish.
 
Are you trying to lose weight, or are you trying to build muscle ? Both at the same time is going to be extremely difficult if you only go to the gym once per week.
 
Other answers say high weight, low reps for once a week, but not only is this geared more towards a mass build than a weight loss/tone, but also can be unnecessarily dangerous to the joints of you're only doing it once a week.
 
I would recommend a treadmill or eliptical set before lifting. Then high reps with low weight when you lift, or a warm-up set on every specific exercise before you do your actual sets, followed with descending weight sets.
 
And remember that diet is key — if you don't keep a proper diet, the gym will not help you with anything you're trying to accomplish.

title: What is your favorite sandwich ingredient?
article:
My favourite sandwich ingredient is mature cheddar cheese.
 
None of these ultra processed sliced cheeses. Nor a mild or rubbery cheese. But a good honest mature cheddar - offering firmness and tanginess. Personal favourite cheddar cheeses are from the UK’s West Country - matured for at least 18 months.
 
As for the bread, my preference is home baked. I have a baking machine to speed up this process. A crusty, well risen white loaf is a vehicle for the flavoursome cheese. Or it a loaf of a wholemeal or white mix - offering flavour and texture.
 
The spread must be butter and the entire sandwich seasone

My favourite sandwich ingredient is mature cheddar cheese.
 
None of these ultra processed sliced cheeses. Nor a mild or rubbery cheese. But a good honest mature cheddar - offering firmness and tanginess. Personal favourite cheddar cheeses are from the UK’s West Country - matured for at least 18 months.
 
As for the bread, my preference is home baked. I have a baking machine to speed up this process. A crusty, well risen white loaf is a vehicle for the flavoursome cheese. Or it a loaf of a wholemeal or white mix - offering flavour and texture.
 
The spread must be butter and the entire sandwich seasoned with black pepper fresh from the mill.
 
Non-guilty pleasure: a parmesan cheese sandwich. Not grated parmesan, but thick calorific slides of Parmigiano.
 
Writing this Quora answer has left me famished.

title: Can I do a light workout every day?
article:
So technically yes but with a major caveat.
 
Here is the thing, what you’re talking about isn’t “working out”. In order to strengthen muscles, we need to WORK OUT hard enough to cause microscopic tears in the muscle. Then, with adequate nutrition and rest, the fibers repair themselves and we end up stronger. You can’t do this three times a day.
 
If you’re messing around with light weights 3 times a day, you’re not adequately stressing the muscle to cause these microscopic tears.
 
A better plan is increase the intensity of the workout to the point that you’ve exhausted the muscles. Then get good slee
Continue Reading
So technically yes but with a major caveat.
 
Here is the thing, what you’re talking about isn’t “working out”. In order to strengthen muscles, we need to WORK OUT hard enough to cause microscopic tears in the muscle. Then, with adequate nutrition and rest, the fibers repair themselves and we end up stronger. You can’t do this three times a day.
 
If you’re messing around with light weights 3 times a day, you’re not adequately stressing the muscle to cause these microscopic tears.
 
A better plan is increase the intensity of the workout to the point that you’ve exhausted the muscles. Then get good sleep, good nutrition and let your muscles get strong. So either heavier weights, more reps, slower movement to keep your muscles stressed for a longer amount of time. Pick all of these if you want.

title: Is running every day better than going to the gym every day?
article:
Running 30 minutes a day on average equates to 3–4 miles assuming you are doing long distance running and any high intensity training. If you are new to running, it’s going to be difficult reaching a solid distance, but it gets easier by the day. You are likely to burn around 500 calories during your actual run, but your raised metabolism will carry on for the next 24 hours, so you are going to lose a fair amount of calories doing it. If you don’t eat the calories to make up for that lost, expect to lose weight overtime. Also, your fast twitch muscle fibers will gradually convert to slow twitc
Continue Reading
Running 30 minutes a day on average equates to 3–4 miles assuming you are doing long distance running and any high intensity training. If you are new to running, it’s going to be difficult reaching a solid distance, but it gets easier by the day. You are likely to burn around 500 calories during your actual run, but your raised metabolism will carry on for the next 24 hours, so you are going to lose a fair amount of calories doing it. If you don’t eat the calories to make up for that lost, expect to lose weight overtime. Also, your fast twitch muscle fibers will gradually convert to slow twitch as you gain long distance efficiency. Because if this, you can expect your legs to decrease in size and power, but covering that 3–4 miles will soon become 5 miles in a span of 30 minutes if you are consistent.

The authorities usually quietly remove the trouble makers. People without river front property get upset if the beavers are killed openly. Travel the world and learn amazing stuff. I don’t know what happened to the Canadian beavers. It took a week or so before the road was reopened.

title: Is it bad to do full body workouts every day?
article:
Muscles and your nervous system need to recover from the exercise stress. You don't grow from exercising. You grow from proper rest after properly performed exercises.
 
Fitness beginners require more rest between exercises than people who are at an intermediate to advanced level.
 
Body types also vary. Some respond and grow more quickly than others.
 
If you do full body workouts every day you won't gain as much lean muscle mass as you would if you did it two, three, or four times per week. And you'll be at a greater risk for injuries, which can stop exercises for days, weeks or months of recovery.
 
I 
Continue Reading
Muscles and your nervous system need to recover from the exercise stress. You don't grow from exercising. You grow from proper rest after properly performed exercises.
 
Fitness beginners require more rest between exercises than people who are at an intermediate to advanced level.
 
Body types also vary. Some respond and grow more quickly than others.
 
If you do full body workouts every day you won't gain as much lean muscle mass as you would if you did it two, three, or four times per week. And you'll be at a greater risk for injuries, which can stop exercises for days, weeks or months of recovery.
 
I understand the addiction and I love to exercise upper and lower body everyday. I just vary which areas I work and keep the total volume (time under tension/sets and reps) lower each day.

I met a woman who believes that “scientists” put a chip in her brain to track her and read her thoughts. She could not define “scientist.” When I told her that I am a scientist, she became fearful and stopped talking to me (thankfully). She is the most ignorant (and loony) American that I know of.
 
A close runner-up is a guy I know who believes that we did not land men on the moon. He believes a lot of other wacky conspiracy theories. He reads a lot to try to be informed, but he reads things written by nut-jobs. He believes that he can build a perpetual motion machine to generate power by using rare-earth magnets arranged in a special pattern. His actual level of understanding of science is very, very, low, but he thinks of himself as knowledgeable. I think that is the worst form of ignorance.

I once worked with a person who used the saying, “Don’t confuse me with facts, my mind’s made up.” Although said in jest, I believe this epitomizes the character of any person who would qualify for the ‘Most Ignorant Person” award. Along with this mindset, which I believe is termed “cognitive dissonance”, are those individuals unwilling to at least listen to an opposing point of view and really consider it. Give it a little thought without just thinking what response is necessary to refute this information. When I think of it I’ve learned less from those who share my perspective but a plethora of information from those who have a different point of view. This is one of the major issues of today’s society, WE AREN’T WILLING TO LISTEN! Give the other person a chance, you just might learn something.

Fair ‘nuff. I initially thought she was thinking way off, but it wasn’t as bad as I thought.

A middle aged tourist once walked up to me and worriedly asked if I knew what my shirt read.
 
I'm a millennial Finn, about 26 at that point in time. I grew up reading fan translated manga on pirate sites. I'd played Runescape, WoW, and LoL for almost 2 decades, and had bought a “crit happens” t-shirt from an anime con the previous year. I'd known about the ‘ignorant american’ stereotype, but didn't yet completely believe that such ignorance could be found in a nominally developed nation. Yet here this man was, in a tourist city in the Finnish Lapland, questioning someone who by almost every international metric would likely know what the shirt said.
 
I couldn't help just laughing and telling him that I likely know the meaning of the text better than he does, after which he left in a huff. 😁

I took English and linguistics classes and in one of them, I was talking about American Sign Language (ASL) and how similar it was from the French Sign Language since it is largely based on it and the two are quite intelligible.

I studied abroad in a well-known Northern American university two years ago. I had the whole experience, as a foreign student, and lived on campus, met people with different background. I took English and linguistics classes and in one of them, I was talking about American Sign Language (ASL) and how similar it was from the French Sign Language since it is largely based on it and the two are quite intelligible.
 
I had to explain to this American young woman, about my age, that there is indeed numerous sign languages in the world, as there is spoken languages. She just couldn't believe there was more than one language — and that it was not ‘gesturing’. Also, did not believe me when I said they developed naturally. I have no idea if I made her change her mind but I made my point nonetheless.

I was once visiting the United States from England, and of course received all of the comments of, “Wow, your accent is so adorable!”, and the like, but one in particular really stood out.
 
We (me and my family), were eating breakfast in a hotel, when the waitress came up to us and popped ‘the question’.
 
“Wow! I love your accent, where are you guys from!?”
 
Big smile. Eyes wide.
 
Of course, we all smiled and I replied that we were from England.
 
Her face took on more of a curious/confused expression as she asked the following:
 
“Hmmm, London…. 
(Eyes open wide with sudden clarity) 
Do they speak FRENCH there?!”
 
God bless America.
 
(There was also the lady I saw ask her husband (?) in Universal studios whether the clouds were real, or if it was just a big screen.)

“Ignorant” in the UK can mean a lack of knowledge or rudeness, so if you mean the second definition, we’ve just returned from the Mississippi Delta, visiting a few towns and cities along the river starting in Memphis and finishing in New Orleans. The fabled Southern charm was almost universal, most people were friendly, garrulous and interested, we had a great time. The one exception was a young lady in the gift shop at Graceland (Graceland was a highlight, I didn’t want to go but I’m glad I did) who was VERY rude when I stood at the counter to pay for some ice creams. She looked very confused when I countered with EXTREME politeness in return, finishing with “thank you SO much, I hope the rest of your day is as pleasant as you are”. I could see my wife out of the corner of my eye laughing.

I started training with weights about 30 months ago. I'd never trained with weights like this before. Today I am a certified personal trainer and have done my first powerlifting meet. It doesn't take long to fall in love with weights once you discover what your body can do for you.

Depends on what your goals are. If you want to be a typical gym goer, your gains would be typical gym gains (not very much). If you want to go the extra mile and train intelligently people would be amazed at what you can do and ask you how you got there. 
 
I started training with weights about 30 months ago. I'd never trained with weights like this before. Today I am a certified personal trainer and have done my first powerlifting meet. It doesn't take long to fall in love with weights once you discover what your body can do for you. 
 
If I were you I'd go for a beginners routine like Starting strength or Stronglifts 5x5 and see what it does for you in 2-3 months. You'd start noticing gains in 2-3 weeks like never before. Make sure you eat right though, you can't out-train a bad diet.

I turned on the Sirius radio comedy channel yeasterday and someone was equating socialism with communism. They were saying that socialists like Bernie Sanders would take away all your rights and freedoms. You wouldn't be able to leave the country because they would build walls. The irony was palpable.
 
I desperately wanted to tell them that all developed countries including the USA are socialist to a degree. The USA provides food for the needy, basic education, transportation facilities, water, sewers, fire protection and policing, plus emergency medical, but many civilized countries go further and provide full medical care, and even education beyond grade school. These things do not require one to give up any basic freedoms. The only question is whether the benefits exceed the cost.

I was on a business visit to Muskegon in 2015 Feb, where I meet this guy! I was shopping at the Lakers mall. I was looking for a wifi extender at the Radio shack. They were closing and everything was on sale to clear stock..
 
So this guy walks up to me because I was the only dusky out of town guy with black hair in the shop and starts enquiring as to where I am from and what was the purpose of my visit and so on!!
 
I told him that I was from India and was there on business! This is when the shocker came. He says “ India, oh i have herd so much about it.. I know it's an exotic place.. where is it really!? Is it in like Pakistan???”
 
Needless to say, I sat with him for 2 more hours to teach geography, maps and some basics on Indo Pak relations so he doesn't do this mistake again!!

title: Is a full body workout two or three times a week as effective as a split routine working out 5 or 6 days a week? How do I get the best results possible with the least time invested?
article:
You go the the gym less
Training full body correctly means you probably end up building slightly more muscle than a split.
Training full body correctly means you’re less likely to end up with imbalances
Training the squat, bench, press and deadlift multiple times a week means you can more technical practise of the lift.
Better technique = Less injury.
Better technique = You can lift more weight quicker = faster gains. Also learning good technique early means you don’t have to unlearn bad technique later down the line!
To be totally honest if you don’t train full body as a beginner you’re just not be
Continue Reading
You go the the gym less
Training full body correctly means you probably end up building slightly more muscle than a split.
Training full body correctly means you’re less likely to end up with imbalances
Training the squat, bench, press and deadlift multiple times a week means you can more technical practise of the lift.
Better technique = Less injury.
Better technique = You can lift more weight quicker = faster gains. Also learning good technique early means you don’t have to unlearn bad technique later down the line!
To be totally honest if you don’t train full body as a beginner you’re just not being anywhere near as efficient as you can be for getting gains. It gets different when you get to being intermediate but if we’re being totally real then 97% of gym goers are beginners.

Build exercise into what you are doing.
 
Walk or bike to school. If it's too far, then get off the bus a kilometer or two before your school, and walk or jog the rest of the way. Do the same going home.
 
Take the stairs, don't use the elevators
 
When someone needs something from another room, jump up and get it for them. 
 
Practice doing isotonic and isometric exercises while you study
Isotonic Vs. Isometric Contraction
 
Walk faster, so you can walk a longer distance. If you only have 30 minutes to walk or jog, going faster will allow more movement and more exercise.
 
Sign up for a sport. Take swimming lessons, learn to salsa or hip hop dance,  join a bowling league, play one on one with your buddy at the local courts. Do these activities instead of screen time.

I was giving a workshop to a group of volunteer service workers, and talking about the issues that people with disabilities face in times of disaster.
 
During our lunch break, one of the attendees came up to me and said that they disagreed on the basis that that “you people” (meaning people with disabilities) were covered by the ADA.
 
I disagreed, and cited the Civil Rights Act as a piece of legislature that did not “fix” racial issues.
 
The woman countered that I was wrong, stating that disability issues were not the same as racial issues. The only issues they faced, had to do with accessibility
 
I pointed out that people with disabilities experience many of the same social issues as other minority groups, including access, representation, among others.
 
This seemed to bother her quite a bit, and as a consequence, when the workshop resumed, she began to derisively snort in response to many of the things I said.
 
At the end of the day, I confronted her and asked her ...

She was passed a handful of coins . .

Many many years ago, on a family holiday to Orlando, in Florida, we were staying in an International Drive hotel.
 
Towards the end of our first week, my wife decided to make use of the hotel's laundry room. Just like any other laundrette, it made use of coin slots. Coin slots for detergent, for softener etc etc.
 
During this visit to the laundrette, a fellow Brit seemed to be having trouble operating the various dispensers. She asked "Is there something wrong with these machines?". My wife offered to help, as she does, and suggested that she try the dispensers.
 
She was passed a handful of coins . . . every one of them a British coin!
 
When she pointed out that the dispensers required U.S. Quarters, the woman responded by asking:
 
"Oh! Does it have to be American money?".

title: What is your favorite sandwich ingredient?
article:
First, ham is my go-to ingredient. Its rich flavor and moderate saltiness make every bite full of satisfaction. At the same time, the texture of ham is also very good. It is chewy but not too hard, which fits perfectly into the sandwich.
Next is Swiss cheese. Its milky flavor and smooth taste form a wonderful contrast when combined with ham. Swiss cheese becomes more fragrant after heating, especially in toasted sandwiches, and the stringy effect of cheese is mouth-watering.
Finally, I like to add fresh vegetables to the sandwich, especially lettuce and tomatoes. The crispness of lettuce and the
Continue Reading
First, ham is my go-to ingredient. Its rich flavor and moderate saltiness make every bite full of satisfaction. At the same time, the texture of ham is also very good. It is chewy but not too hard, which fits perfectly into the sandwich.
Next is Swiss cheese. Its milky flavor and smooth taste form a wonderful contrast when combined with ham. Swiss cheese becomes more fragrant after heating, especially in toasted sandwiches, and the stringy effect of cheese is mouth-watering.
Finally, I like to add fresh vegetables to the sandwich, especially lettuce and tomatoes. The crispness of lettuce and the juiciness of tomatoes add a fresh taste to the whole sandwich, making the taste more layered. These vegetables also make the sandwich look more tempting and improve the nutritional value.

When I was the anchorman for the weekly news magazine program European Journal, (produced by Germany’s international broadcaster Deutsche Welle) a chief producer was hired from LA. His MO was, if the US doesn’t touch or influence our reports they wouldn’t get on the air. At the second staff meeting I asked him a number of questions: where is Serajevo (he’d never heard of it), what is the capital of Germany (he said Berlin … at the time it was Bonn), name the allied countries in wwii (he told us the US single handedly won wwii). He had to make a one day lay over in Vancouver, the first time he had been to Canada. He was in disbelief that the city had skyscrapers. How did this ignorant jerk get the job? We found out he lied on his CV. I led a staff rebellion and he was neutralized.

I admitted my ignorance and my embarrassment, and told him that I needed to educate myself about all the people of the world and the struggles

Me! The most embarrassing and culturally ignorant thing I ever said was when my coworker Khalil was going to go on a trip to Lebanon for five weeks. I wished him well and said "watch out for those Palestinians, I hear they can really be trouble." He told me with a dead pan expression "I am Palestinian." The blood drained from my face as I realized I had heard about Israelis and Palestinians on the news all my life but had no idea who these people were. I admitted my ignorance and my embarrassment, and told him that I needed to educate myself about all the people of the world and the struggles they experience, and that that was an eye-opening moment for me. I decided then to become more culturally aware and quit letting my middle-class white upbringing narrow my view of the world.

title: How often should I workout for best results?
article:
You've probably been told that you shouldn't work out every day. And you know what? That's a good idea.
 
Exercising too much can make you sore, and if you're sore, it's hard to get motivated to exercise again. You might also be worried about overtraining, which is when your body gets used to exercising and doesn't gain the benefits of working out.
 
So what's a good amount of exercise? For most people, 30 minutes is enough to get the job done. But keep in mind that every person is different-some people don't like exercise at all, while others need more than an hour or two to feel their best. So fig
Continue Reading
You've probably been told that you shouldn't work out every day. And you know what? That's a good idea.
 
Exercising too much can make you sore, and if you're sore, it's hard to get motivated to exercise again. You might also be worried about overtraining, which is when your body gets used to exercising and doesn't gain the benefits of working out.
 
So what's a good amount of exercise? For most people, 30 minutes is enough to get the job done. But keep in mind that every person is different-some people don't like exercise at all, while others need more than an hour or two to feel their best. So figuring out exactly how much time and how often works for you is key!
If you like the answer, please upvote the answer :)
 
Follow me for more cool and interesting information.

When I was 14 and living the north of Mexico, an American friend of ours took us for a car ride to a small village in the mountains near our home.
Whilst walking around the village we encountered another American. An evangelical missionary. 
Our friend introduced us as "my British friends". He shook hands with us and conversed with us for perhaps ten minutes, and then he turned to our friend and said "Excuse me, where did you say your friends were from? It's just that I think they can understand what I am saying".
Ha ha.

title: What is a good workout routine at home?
article:
It depends on your health and what your goals are, but here’s one I do sometimes (I do have a gym membership, but I sometimes work out at home because I don’t have time to get to the gym.)
 
I have two sets of dumbbells and use them to do bent rows for the back, shoulder presses for the delts, curls for the biceps, and overhead tricep presses. I do push ups for chest and sometimes do triceps dips on a chair. I also do sit ups and have a medicine ball for core and shoulder work and I’ve got an old exercise bike for cardio.
 
It’s not perfect, but it gets me a good workout when I don’t have time to go
Continue Reading
It depends on your health and what your goals are, but here’s one I do sometimes (I do have a gym membership, but I sometimes work out at home because I don’t have time to get to the gym.)
 
I have two sets of dumbbells and use them to do bent rows for the back, shoulder presses for the delts, curls for the biceps, and overhead tricep presses. I do push ups for chest and sometimes do triceps dips on a chair. I also do sit ups and have a medicine ball for core and shoulder work and I’ve got an old exercise bike for cardio.
 
It’s not perfect, but it gets me a good workout when I don’t have time to go to the gym.
 
I should point out that this workout routine is for general fitness and building a little bit of muscle while (hopefully) losing some weight off the middle.

I was in Jackson, Tennessee with my family back in June 2015 and looking around this “Casey Jones” museum, an old train-driving legend of some description.
 
There was a portly, round-faced man with a borderline incomperehensible accent who sold us our tickets, and we wandered round the very small, empty museum for a time.
 
Seeing as we were the only ones there, and had a “foreign” accent (Australian), he struck up a conversation with my parents.
 
I wasn't 100% listening before I noticed my dad saying we lived in the Middle East. The man was absolutely taken aback, looking angry as anything, and just said “…you're not gonna bomb this place are ya?!?”
 
After explaining that no, we weren't, and that you can't “praise Jesus in class”, we quickly took our leave.

title: Is it bad to do full body workouts every day?
article:
You're going to need to focus on compound movements.
 
Your body has 650 muscles. Some of those are used for smiling or moving your pinky toes. We will ignore those.
 
When you look at the movements your body is capable of that can move a sizeable load you get the following:
Pushing with chest.
Pulling towards chest.
Pulling the body up by the arms.
Pushing something overhead.
Hinging at the hip.
Pushing with the glutes and quads.
Every powerlifter will prescribe the following 3 exercises:
Deadlift
Squat
Bench Press
Those do cover much of our need. However, you need a few more:
Chinup
Pullup
An overhead press
A fe

You're going to need to focus on compound movements.
 
Your body has 650 muscles. Some of those are used for smiling or moving your pinky toes. We will ignore those.
 
When you look at the movements your body is capable of that can move a sizeable load you get the following:
Pushing with chest.
Pulling towards chest.
Pulling the body up by the arms.
Pushing something overhead.
Hinging at the hip.
Pushing with the glutes and quads.
Every powerlifter will prescribe the following 3 exercises:
Deadlift
Squat
Bench Press
Those do cover much of our need. However, you need a few more:
Chinup
Pullup
An overhead press
A few variations of row.
I can't fit 7 exercises into a single workout, so I do 4 every workout, doing variations of the repeated movement.
